definitions.definition: moderately cold; neither warm nor cold: a rather cool evening.
feeling comfortably or moderately cold: I'm perfectly cool, but open the window if you feel hot.
imparting a sensation of moderate coldness or comfortable freedom from heat: a cool breeze.
permitting such a sensation: a cool dress.
not excited; calm; composed; under control: to remain cool in the face of disaster.
not hasty; deliberate: a cool and calculated action.
lacking in interest or enthusiasm: a cool reply to an invitation.
lacking in warmth or cordiality: a cool reception.
calmly audacious or impudent: a cool lie.
aloof or unresponsive; indifferent: He was cool to her passionate advances.
unaffected by emotions; disinterested; dispassionate: She made a cool appraisal of all the issues in the dispute.
(of a number or sum) without exaggeration or qualification: a cool million dollars.
(of colors) with green, blue, or violet predominating.

subdefinitions.definition: great; fine; excellent: a real cool comic.
characterized by great facility; highly skilled or clever: cool maneuvers on the parallel bars.
socially adept: It's not cool to arrive at a party too early.
acceptable; satisfactory; okay: If you want to stay late, that's cool.

definitions.definition: coolly.

subdefinitions.definition: (used to express acceptance): Okay, cool! I'll be there at 10:00.
(used to express approval, admiration, etc.): He got the job? Cool!

definitions.definition: something that is cool; a cool part, place, time, etc.: in the cool of the evening.
coolness.
calmness; composure; poise: an executive noted for maintaining her cool under pressure.
to become cool (sometimes followed by down or off): The soup cooled in five minutes. We cooled off in the mountain stream.
to become less ardent, cordial, etc.; become moderate.
to make cool; impart a sensation of coolness to.
to lessen the ardor or intensity of; allay; calm; moderate: Disappointment cooled his early zealousness.
See entry at cooldown.
to become calmer or more reasonable: Wait until he cools off before you talk to him again.
to calm or settle down; relax: cooling out at the beach.
blow2 (def. 48).
calm down; take it easy.
heel1 (def. 26).

vice-versa.name: What Is The Correct Way To Use "Vice Versa"?
vice-versa.description: Do you know how to use "vice versa" correctly? We've all gotten it wrong ...
vice-versa.transcript:
One time, when I was in debate class I misused the word conception.

I won’t get into all the details.

But, another phrase that used to float around and get misused all the time in the halls of the old H.S. was vice versa. Now, I will have to admit that I misused it sometimes, misspelled it a lot of times.

Turns out, you don’t need a hyphen in between the two words.

The other thing is it comes from two Latin root words: vicis, which means “arrangement, or order” and versus, which actually means “reverse.” So, it literally means “reverse order.”

For instance, if I say something like “my mom loves me and vice versa,” that totally makes sense because my mom has the capability of loving me and I have the capability of loving her.

But, if I say “hey, I love comic book movies and vice versa,” well, that doesn’t make any sense …

Though I would desperately love for them to love me they’re not real.

melancholy.name: The Bizarre Origin Of The Word "Melancholy"
melancholy.description: The meaning of melancholy was never a good thing, but it was way worse in medieval times … kind of like everything else back then when I think about it, actually.
melancholy.transcript:
The meaning of melancholy was never a good thing, but it was way worse in medieval times … kind of like everything else back then when I think about it, actually.

You see, back then the word melancholy (which originated from the Greek word melankholía) referred to too much black bile backed up in someone’s system, something that was said to cause feelings of gloominess and depression.

And, it’s not like things for melancholy got a whole lot better as time went on—it went from being about the body to being more about the mind. By the 14th century, it began to indicate a sort of sad, dejected feeling. Well … at least the black bile was gone?

In 1607, it finally got its own psychological diagnosis—melancholia—which is when someone suffers extreme manic-depression. Melancholy was a verified mental illness … we don’t actually have any black gook in our systems.

Wouldn’t that be such an easy explanation for sadness though?

xx.name: Where Do "XX" And "XXX" Come From?
xx.description: Let’s talk about letters, namely XX. They’ve got more meaning than you might expect.
xx.transcript:
Let’s talk about letters, namely XX.

They’ve got more meaning than you might expect.

Kiss, kiss

No, no.

And let’s not forget the indie pop duo,

(singing) I’ve been crystalized …

(singing) wo ooh, wo ooh, wo ooh …

(laugh)

But, did you know the actual meaning dates all the way back as an abbreviation for sugar?

Powdered sugar to be exact.

You see, old school bakers and people back then wrote out their recipes all by hand.

To indicate sugar they’d write XX, kind of like the LOL in your text.

The more Xs, the finer the crystals.

X is kind of grainy, XX is more refined.

Now XXX puts us in a bit of a bind.

It has a widely known double meaning, and so I really must warn …

XXX is also the name of guilty viewing pleasure,

action film series XXX, starring Vin Diesel.

So good.

So, next time you’re writing shorthand, maybe you’re composing a tweet,

use X instead of sugar that would be sweet.

juxtaposition.name: What Does "Juxtaposition" Actually Mean?
juxtaposition.description: When you place things side-by-side, you automatically start comparing because the differences are highlighted. And, there's a word for that: "juxtaposition."
juxtaposition.transcript:
A grandfather and a grandson: one is young and one is old, of course, but one has black hair and one has white.

When you place things side-by-side, you automatically start comparing because the differences are highlighted. And, there’s a word for that: juxtaposition.

Juxtaposition means “an act or instance of placing different things close together or side by side, especially for comparison or contrast,” and sometimes this happens naturally … or sometimes it’s for dramatic effect.

In fact, juxtaposition is a popular literary tool used by authors. It creates a visual effect without an actual visual. You know, that whole “it was the best of times, it was the worst of times,” kind of thing.

And, sometimes, one person can create this side-by-side contrast all on their own … business in the front, party in the back … now that’s a whole lot of juxtaposition.

xxxx.name: What Does "XXXX" Really Mean?
xxxx.description: Did you just try looking up xxxx on Dictionary.com? Did you get a definition of "confectioner's sugar"?
xxxx.transcript:
Did you just try looking up xxxx on Dictionary.com? Did you get a definition of “confectioner’s sugar”?

Well … I’m pretty sure that isn’t what you were hoping for. But, that’s why I’m here … to give you all those other xxxx definitions you were searching for.

In letters and text messages, xxxx symbolizes a series of kisses, used as an affectionate sign-off or goodbye.

The origin of xxxx to represent kisses is linked to XOXO, indicating “kisses and hugs,” with X standing for kiss and O, hug. This practice is said to date back to the Middle Ages, with X signed to represent the Christian cross, which the signer then apparently sealed with a kiss as a show of sincerity.

And, many Australians know XXXX as a brand of beer brewed in Brisbane by Castlemaine Brewers. In fact, one of their ads may have led to XXXX’s next usage …. a censor for vulgar words or as filler text for unknown characters.

And, finally, of course, it’s the abbreviation for confectioner’s sugar.

lying.name: Why Is "Lying" Spelled With A "Y"
lying.description: Why in the world is "lying" spelled with a "Y"?
lying.transcript:
Why is lying spelled with a Y?

So, lying seems to stem all the way back to the 900s when it started out as the old English term l-y-g-e or l-i-g-e, lyge or lige, (hopefully one of those is right), meaning “to deceive.”

OK, so now we’re getting somewhere because that’s where the Y comes in. But, why the two different spellings?

You see, back in the day scribes changed the I to a Y for readability. I’s are kind of hard to read depending on how sloppy your handwriting is … especially if you’re me. So, voila, two versions of the words were created.

The Y carried over, even though the other form l-i-e kept the I. Plus, the I-E vowel combo is kind of hard to figure out how to say so, maybe, those guys back then kind of had things figured out better.

element.name: How Does The Word "Element" Have 15 Definitions?
element.description: The word element actually has 15 definitions, it has meanings beyond science.
element.transcript:
When we think of element, we typically think of chemistry … the periodic table, the elements that make up water, and air, and salt.

But the word element actually has 15 definitions, it has meanings beyond science.

The weather is an element … and man does it suck being exposed to those elements sometimes … especially on the way to work.

But, what about when you’re in your element? Yup, that’s a thing … it’s your natural habitat or environment, it’s where you feel like you.

Sometimes, elements are singled out and ostracized because they’re different or because their views don’t align with everyone else’s. They become the radical element and that can be bad or good.

How about the elements of grammar or a language … yup words.

The elements of the Earth … and that band Earth, Wind, and Fire … they’re part of the meaning too.

pedantic.name: Is The Word "Pedantic" Good Or Bad?
pedantic.description: Is "pedantic" a good or a bad quality? Well, actually, this word's history may help us figure it out!
pedantic.transcript:
When I was at work the other day, a colleague of mine who has a habit of using SAT-worthy words called a certain client “pedantic” … and I had no idea if he was complimenting this guy or not.

But, it turns out he wasn’t.

It’s weird, because I always thought pedantic was something people were proud of … like if they were good at grammar or remembered a lot of facts … and then they just educated people about it.

And, actually that is where the word came from. In Latin, pedant meant “school teacher.” And, back in the day, school teachers were certainly sticklers for the rules.

But nowadays, rules have relaxed and things, like language, keep changing. So, pedantic isn’t a compliment anymore because it really means these people are close-minded, they’re “overly concerned with minute details or formalisms.” And, when you’re “overly concerned” with the little stuff … it’s hard to see the big beautiful picture.

noun.name: We Asked: How Do You Remember The Definition Of A "Noun"?
noun.description: How do you remember what a noun is? This poet has a unique way of thinking about a noun's meaning ...
noun.transcript:
We know nouns as” classes of people, places, and things.”

They are your school, your teacher, the homework you forgot to bring.

Nouns are also “ideas, qualities, and states of existence, like beauty, brains, and intelligence.”

That was a definition new to me, and, yes, it’s possible to be all three.

Then there are pronouns, which are like nouns, but with another name.

Here’s an example, let me explain.

This is my plant, watch it grow.

It is the pronoun referring to plant, the plant’s alter ego.

So, now here’s a sentence, pick out the nouns, since now you know.

“I‘m so much smarter after watching this video.”

Ha.

hypocrite.name: Why Was "Hypocrite" Originally Used To Describe Actors?
hypocrite.description: Find out why this theater teacher loves to call his students "hypocrites" ... he's a good teacher, we swear!
hypocrite.transcript:
I’m a theater teacher, and I LOVE the term hypocrite because originally it meant play-acting or pretending to be something that you’re not, so it makes sense that I’d like it.

In fact, in ancient times, around the times of the Greeks and Romans, actors were hated so much, that the term hypocrite was used as a derogatory jab to put somebody down, questioning their legitimacy … a lot of times used in the political arena to make fun of someone.

So, I guess in a way things haven’t changed.

Over time, hypocrite became less and less about acting and more and more about someone preaching a virtue but not living according to that virtue.

So, why do I like hypocrite so much? Well, every time I call a student a hypocrite they shoot me the dirtiest look, and they’re foul, until I get an opportunity to explain the origin of the word. And then, for me, it’s a win-win.

adult.name: We Asked: What Does It Mean To Be An "Adult"?
adult.description: Should we be using "adulting" instead of the word "adult" these days?
adult.transcript:
Today I have to go to work, and then I have to go to the DMV. I really hate adulting.

Why do we become an adult at age 18? Or is it 21? Even though at 18 we can vote, and join the military, and see R-rated movies, we still don’t feel ready to be adults. We’re still in school or figuring out our careers, and we need the support of our parents.

So one may legally be an adult, but possess none of the maturity and responsibility that may define them as an adult. I guess that’s why we created the word adulting, which means “to do grown-up things like hold responsibilities, have a nine-to-five, pay a mortgage, pay a rent, pay car payment.”

Man, it’s so hard to be an adult.

aesthetic.name: How Do You Describe Someone's "Aesthetic"?
aesthetic.description: If you like a certain type of interior design, or art form, or particular band, or even a certain color ... that is your aesthetic; it evokes a happy and calming emotion in you because it's what is pleasing to your senses.
aesthetic.transcript:
If you like a certain type of interior design, or art form, or particular band, or even a certain color … that is your aesthetic; it evokes a happy and calming emotion in you because it’s what is pleasing to your senses.

(And by senses, we really just mean sight and sound).

However, your aesthetic doesn’t consider the band members’ actions, or the depth of the lyrics, or the price of the piece of art, or the functionality of the design … you just like how it sounds or looks and that’s it.

All white houses look so peaceful and clean … but that is SO not functional with kids and pets and … life.

And, what about the people we find aesthetically pleasing. It’s basically all about the attraction.

That’s why you keep pursuing those strong, big, dark, handsome guys … even though they always end up being pure trouble.

So, the next time someone asks you about your aesthetics you can confidently say what you like, what is pleasing to your senses.

But, remember, just because you love the sound of the rain while you’re sleeping … doesn’t mean you want to be sleeping in the actual rain.

Aesthetics are great … but don’t forget the actual logistics too.

was.name: Here's A Little Reminder About "Were" Vs. "Was"
was.description: This man had a serious debate over using "were" vs. "was" ... at the pub. Makes sense. Did he figure it out?
was.transcript:
My daughter has her MFA in creative writing,

so whenever we go out together

I’m very self-conscious about what I say

because I don’t want to look like an idiot

in front of her.

So if we’re at the pub, and I want to say, “Uh…

I wonder if I were to have another pint

I’d regret it in the morning?”

As the words are coming out of my mouth

I start to think to myself, “wait a second

is it if I was to have another pint

or if I were to have another pint,”

because I confuse those two all the time:

was versus were.

It turns out there’s an easy way to keep track of it.

If what you’re talking about is something

that you’re daydreaming about,

or if it’s wishful thinking, or something you desire,

then the correct word is were.

“Uh, I wonder if I were to have another pint

I’d regret it in the morning.”

Ok, but what about was?

“I didn’t make it to mass on Sunday

because I was in the pub having a pint.”

The event actually happened.

You were in the pub having a pint.

cohesive.name: What Does "Cohesive" Mean Outside Of Science?
cohesive.description: Sandy and Danny, peanut butter and jelly: these pairs are cohesive because this means being naturally and logically connected.
cohesive.transcript:
You are the milk to my cookies! The peanut butter to my jelly! (Singing) We go together like rama-lama-lama …

Now maybe Sandy and Danny weren’t so cohesive at the beginning of Grease … actually, they were pretty different. But by the end of the movie, they’re unified like a well-oiled machine. Grease lightning.

Sandy and Danny, peanut butter and jelly: these pairs are cohesive because this means being naturally and logically connected.

And, with an origin from the Latin word cohaesus meaning “to stick together,” you know peanut butter and jelly were meant to be.

But, cohesion is everywhere: like a sports team that works really well as a unit, who sticks together and has one another’s backs … and therefore wins a lot of games.

Or, the relationship between flowers and bees. The bees eat the sticky pollen and then transport said pollen to other plants so they can reproduce.

Oh, and if you think that is cool … water is a great natural example of cohesion. Each water molecule forms hydrogen bonds to other molecules. This is how water molecules stick together to become a cohesive liquid … and not just tiny particles like sand.

(singing)

We’ll always be together
Wha oooh, yeah!
We’ll always be together

hear.name: What Is The Difference Between The Words "Hear" And "Listen"?
hear.description: See, everybody says they want to be heard. But, in actuality, they want to be listened to.
hear.transcript:
Do you have somebody in your family that you just love, love, love, love, love with all your heart, but this person just do not listen for nothing?

The physical activity of sound is perceived with their ears, but, they don’t listen.

Like that’s my sister, my sister all day. I can tell whenever I’m talking to her on the phone she’s like on the computer doing this, this, and that, because she’s always like, “Mhm, mhm, mhm.” Then I’m like, “Now, what did I say”? She’s like, “Oh, well, oh, oh, oh, I…I wasn’t paying attention.” Because you heard me, but you wasn’t listening.

Because listening is a more conscious activity than just hearing. Listening, you have to actually pay attention to what the person is saying…not just perceive sound. There’s a difference.

See, everybody says they want to be heard. But, in actuality, they want to be listened to.

listen.name: What Is The Difference Between The Words "Hear" And "Listen"?
listen.description: See, everybody says they want to be heard. But, in actuality, they want to be listened to.
listen.transcript:
Do you have somebody in your family that you just love, love, love, love, love with all your heart, but this person just do not listen for nothing?

The physical activity of sound is perceived with their ears, but, they don’t listen.

Like that’s my sister, my sister all day. I can tell whenever I’m talking to her on the phone she’s like on the computer doing this, this, and that, because she’s always like, “Mhm, mhm, mhm.” Then I’m like, “Now, what did I say”? She’s like, “Oh, well, oh, oh, oh, I…I wasn’t paying attention.” Because you heard me, but you wasn’t listening.

Because listening is a more conscious activity than just hearing. Listening, you have to actually pay attention to what the person is saying…not just perceive sound. There’s a difference.

See, everybody says they want to be heard. But, in actuality, they want to be listened to.

heritage.name: What Is The Difference Between "Heritage" And "Inheritance"?
heritage.description: While inheritance and heritage may seem similar, and the definitions do have some overlap, there is a distinct difference.
heritage.transcript:
When my uncle passed away, I was honored to receive a small inheritance of $1,000. He was an important man in my life, and it meant a lot to me to know that he wanted to pass something along to me. With this inheritance, I wanted to do something to pay tribute to the heritage in our family.

My uncle was an outdoorsman, and our favorite thing to do on Saturday morning was go out early and walk through the woods and go fishing.

My kids are young, and I want to pass down the heritage of loving the outdoors and water onto them.

With the inheritance my uncle left me, I’m building a pond in my backyard to be able to share that heritage, that tradition of fishing that my uncle shared with me.

While inheritance and heritage may seem similar, and the definitions do have some overlap, think of the word inheritance as a tangible amount of value being passed along, usually after death, while the word heritage means “something that is handed down as a tradition,” it is intangible and priceless.

inheritance.name: What Is The Difference Between "Heritage" And "Inheritance"?
inheritance.description: While inheritance and heritage may seem similar, and the definitions do have some overlap, there is a distinct difference.
inheritance.transcript:
When my uncle passed away, I was honored to receive a small inheritance of $1,000. He was an important man in my life, and it meant a lot to me to know that he wanted to pass something along to me. With this inheritance, I wanted to do something to pay tribute to the heritage in our family.

My uncle was an outdoorsman, and our favorite thing to do on Saturday morning was go out early and walk through the woods and go fishing.

My kids are young, and I want to pass down the heritage of loving the outdoors and water onto them.

With the inheritance my uncle left me, I’m building a pond in my backyard to be able to share that heritage, that tradition of fishing that my uncle shared with me.

While inheritance and heritage may seem similar, and the definitions do have some overlap, think of the word inheritance as a tangible amount of value being passed along, usually after death, while the word heritage means “something that is handed down as a tradition,” it is intangible and priceless.

onomatopoeia.name: What Kind Of Words Are Onomatopoeia?
onomatopoeia.description: Few words are as fun to say as onomatopoeia, but what the heck does it mean?
onomatopoeia.transcript:
Onomatopoeia is a literary device  used by authors, like myself, to…

(clang)

Oh sorry, Jolene. Did all my clanging and banging bother you?

Can you please keep it down, Brolene?  Can’t you see I’m trying to film? As I was saying friends,  onomatopoeia is a device used by poets and authors alike, like myself, to imitate the sound…

(snap crack pop)

Oh, can you hear my gum?  I just love the way it snaps, cracks, and pops.

(lip smack)

So, in conclusion, as I wanted to say, onomatopoeia is a word used to imitate the sound of the thing it’s describing, kind of like hoot, which is what this has been, friends.

commission.name: What Does Working On Commission Mean?
commission.description: What does it mean to get paid by commission? This man can explain.
commission.transcript:
I was flipping burgers at a fast food joint. For every hour I worked, I got paid. It made total sense.

I remember college and grad school, as I was looking for jobs in between semesters, I kept seeing a term pop up on applications: by commission.

I didn’t really understand what this term meant.

Growing up, I was a big comic book nerd, and I had heard artists got paid by commission.

Then I started doing more research on the term, and it was usually associated with the sales of a product. For however much the salesperson sold, they would get a percentage of the total sales. Usually six percent. Higher in some cases, lower in others.

The term is rooted in, ”to commit.” So if you’re committed to getting up every day and grinding, putting in the hours, you could make tons of money. And, working by commission might be exactly what you want to do.

note.name: Why Does The Word "Note" Have 31 Definitions?
note.description: "Note" isn't a very noteworthy word at first glance ... but it is one very small word that describes a lot of common things.
note.transcript:
Note isn’t a very noteworthy word at first glance … but it is one very small word that describes a lot of common things.

Originating in the 1300s as “musical note,” it still holds that meaning plus more … many, many more.

Because writing music notes turned into just writing notes in general …

And, then technology required us to remember too many passwords and websites … we started writing notes to ourselves for future reference … because life got complicated.

Oh, right … money, money’s a note, a bank note.

But, what about note‘s presence off the page? It took on meaning in the world of sound too. A music note was something you could write and hear …

And, someone’s voice could also hit notes too.

Plus, for your own safety, it’s pertinent to take note of any and all warning signs …

because note is actually pretty noteworthy after all.

please.name: Why Are We Always Trying To Teach Kids To Say "Please"?
please.description: Is there anything cuter than a kid saying please? But, why is it one of the first things that we teach them to say?
please.transcript:
Please sounds so sweet when it’s coming from your kid.

Please, a word often used for,  “a polite request or question.”

Can I please have another juice? Can I please stay up for one more hour? I really want that toy, pretty please. Is there anything cuter than a kid saying please?

Why is it one of the first things that we teach them to say? Why don’t they ever remember it? Does it even matter? And, why do we let things slide?

Could it be because kids are so demanding, it’s nice to hear something courteous from them? They might not be polite, but they can sound like it. Are we training them to manipulate us gullible adults who are completely at the whim of their cuteness, and now they know it?

Maybe.

null.name: Can "Null" Ever Be A Positive Word?
null.description: Why is "null" such a negative word? Let us explain these definitions a little bit more ...
null.transcript:
Null is a pretty negative word … meaning “without value, effect, consequence, or significance” or “being or amounting to nothing,” it’s hard to believe anybody or anything would want to be considered null.

Unless you are terminating a marriage or contract, null and void is like music to the ears … or you’re trying to disconnect and go off the grid for a while.

Or, you love math and 1s and 0s.

Ok, so null isn’t the most optimistic word we’ve ever heard … but it seems that it’s not all bad either. Aren’t you glad you gave null another chance?

whip.name: How Does "Whip" Have So Many Definitions?
whip.description: "Whip" is one of the most versatile words we have. We bet we'll teach you a few uses for the word that you never knew!
whip.transcript:
The word whip may have originated in the 14th century as an “instrument for flagellating” (uh, yikes), but now, in every realm or instance, you can probably think of a way to use this word. For instance … Yo, come check out Jimmy’s new whip!

The chef ignored the electric mixer and only wanted to use the wire whisk to whip his egg whites into high peaks. It’s so much more satisfying to do it yourself.

The Republican whip was making calls to get support up until the last second before the final vote.

That sense has been around since 1850!

Or after the holidays it’s time to stick to a diet and whip myself back into shape.

And, just because we literally meant you could use it in every situation …  the best pitcher in the league had a WHIP (Walks plus Hits per Inning Pitched) under 1. It may sound complicated but that’s good.

revolution.name: Why Are Only Some Wars Called "Revolutions"?
revolution.description: There's a reason why some wars include the word revolution in their names and why others don't. Is it because revolutions completely overhaul the old way of doing things, they inspire something new in all of us?
revolution.transcript:
There’s a reason why some wars include the word revolution in their names and why others don’t.

It’s because revolution means “an overthrow or complete replacement of an established system.” So, basically, the entire government has to be changed in order for it to be revolutionary.

The Revolutionary War was when the US split from England and when we developed our own government. The French Revolution led to a democratic government for the country. And, the Russian Revolution ended the empire of a Tsar and led to the rise of Marxian socialism under Vladimir Lenin.

Those are revolutionary changes.

And, that also explains why The Civil War didn’t have revolution in the name. The Civil War ended slavery … but it didn’t change how the US government fundamentally worked.

It doesn’t stop at wars and government, either.

Some inventions are truly revolutionary in that they create “a sudden, complete, or marked change in something.”

The wheel changed how we travelled and transported things; it was the first of its kind. And, refrigerators changed how we ate. Printing presses changed how we digested information. Light bulbs changed how we functioned during the evenings and nights.

Revolutions completely overhaul the old way of doing things, they inspire something new in all of us.

And, yes, change can be hard, but maybe that’s why revolutions only come around once in a while … when that change is truly needed.

save.name: How Does "Save" Have So Many Definitions?
save.description: This story about Karen and Karl may just help illustrate that the word "save" can be used in a lot of different ways! In fact, "save" seems to always be here for us when we need it most.
save.transcript:
It was just a normal day for Karen. She is driving along when all of sudden, she sees something sharp in the road! Oh no! She swerves to try and save her tire, but it’s too late. Now Karen has a flat. Poor Karen.

Luckily, Carl saw this, and decided to pull over and help her change her tire. Carl likes to save the day. Thanks Carl!

Karen appreciates the help, but she’s no damsel in distress who needs saving. She is a modern woman … who also wants to save some face, so Karen offers to buy Karl dinner. She sends Karl a save the date.

Karen and Karl go out for Kabobs. They have fun. They laugh. He makes her feel safe, which is kind of like save, but in the present tense. It was that night, over dinner that Karen and Karl fall madly in love and decide to move in together. Thank goodness they have both put away a lot in personal savings!

So you think this story is good so far? Just wait, I have saved the best for last! Karen and Karl then got married and had a whole bunch of babies. Aw, everyone loves a happily ever after!

But wait, what is the moral of this story? That everyone loves Kabobs? No, of course not!

The point of this story is to illustrate that the word save can be used in a lot of different ways! From the heroic act of saving the day and helping someone out, to the mundane act of building up personal savings.

If I were you, I would save this story in your memory so you can be sure to remember all of the different uses of this flexible four letter word.

distraction.name: What Does "Distraction" Actually Mean?
distraction.description: "Distraction" means your attention is drawn away by other things ... and if social media has anything to say about it we're all pretty susceptible to distractions these days.
distraction.transcript:
Distraction is “the art of distracting or being distracted” … great, super helpful. What does distract mean?

Oh, a cat … a really cute cat. Aw, meow.

OK back to it. Distract means …

(ding) Somebody tagged a photo of me … oh, wonder what it looks like.

For real, distract is a word for “drawing away or diverting, as the mind or attention.” 

Got it, so distraction then … got a text!

Ugh, distraction means your attention is drawn away by other things … and if social media has anything to say about it we’re all pretty susceptible to distractions these days.

Oh, my ride is here … on to the next distraction!

hilarious.name: What Is The Difference Between "Hysterical" And "Hilarious"?
hilarious.description: The other day, I heard "hysterical" used as an insult ... how does this funny word also act as an insult, particularly to women?
hilarious.transcript:
I never wanted to believe that my Dad was stealing from his job as a road worker. But when I got home, all the signs were there (get it).

That was funny … like, really, really funny. I’m hilarious … or am I hysterical? They both mean the same thing, right—that I’m comedic gold …

Except the other day, I heard hysterical used as an insult … and I now I’m questioning whether I want to be hysterical after all. How does this funny word also act as an insult … particularly to women?

The origins of hysterical have something to do with it. Hysterical comes from the word hysteria which comes from the Greek hysterikós, meaning “suffering in the womb.”

So, yeah, the ancient Greeks believed that when a woman was being “irrational” it was because her uterus was literally wandering around her body causing trouble. That’s not hilarious.

A number of ailments and attitudes were blamed on hysteria, including anxiety, boldness or outspokenness, sexual desire, and—no joke—the suffragist movement.

And this should, perhaps, give us some pause before we call someone “hysterical.” The word’s origin ties it to the idea that any show of emotion or force from a woman is evidence of her fragility and instability … and women are anything but.

Not to mention there are better options: hilarious options to be exact … and hilarious‘s origins are full of “cheerfulness, gaiety, and merriment.” No gendered insults hiding there! In fact, in ancient Rome Hilaria were a class of holidays, times of pomp and rejoicing.

So, funny people rejoice: we now have a clear descriptor … we’re f’ing hilarious.

hysterical.name: What Is The Difference Between "Hysterical" And "Hilarious"?
hysterical.description: The other day, I heard "hysterical" used as an insult ... how does this funny word also act as an insult, particularly to women?
hysterical.transcript:
I never wanted to believe that my Dad was stealing from his job as a road worker. But when I got home, all the signs were there (get it).

That was funny … like, really, really funny. I’m hilarious … or am I hysterical? They both mean the same thing, right—that I’m comedic gold …
