The origins of hysterical have something to do with it. Hysterical comes from the word hysteria which comes from the Greek hysterikós, meaning “suffering in the womb.”

So, yeah, the ancient Greeks believed that when a woman was being “irrational” it was because her uterus was literally wandering around her body causing trouble. That’s not hilarious.

A number of ailments and attitudes were blamed on hysteria, including anxiety, boldness or outspokenness, sexual desire, and—no joke—the suffragist movement.

And this should, perhaps, give us some pause before we call someone “hysterical.” The word’s origin ties it to the idea that any show of emotion or force from a woman is evidence of her fragility and instability … and women are anything but.

Not to mention there are better options: hilarious options to be exact … and hilarious‘s origins are full of “cheerfulness, gaiety, and merriment.” No gendered insults hiding there! In fact, in ancient Rome Hilaria were a class of holidays, times of pomp and rejoicing.

So, funny people rejoice: we now have a clear descriptor … we’re f’ing hilarious.

grace.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Grace"?
grace.description: Did you know that "grace," "gracias," and "grazie" all descend from the same Latin word, "grātia"? Let us explain!
grace.transcript:
¡Gracias! Grazie!

Oh, wait … we’re on the definition page of grace, aren’t we?

Actually, this is relevant … keep listening … because when a Spanish or Italian speaker says “thanks,” they are invoking one of the meanings behind the word grace.

Grace, gracias, and grazie all descend from the same Latin word, grātia.

For the ancient Romans, grātia had three distinct meanings: (1) a pleasing quality, (2) favor or goodwill, and (3) gratitude or thanks.

And, we find all three of these meanings in modern-day English. The first when we describe someone as having (or not having) grace: “She was as graceful as an elephant on skates.”

The second when we talk about giving or getting grace: “by the grace of God.”

And, the third when we say grace (i.e., “thanks”) at a meal.

So, yes, you ended up on the right definition page … and you learned a little bit about the relationship between three words in three different languages that you didn’t know before. You’re welcome.

share.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Share"?
share.description: Remember when we were kids in the cafeteria and all we shared were Lunchables and the answers to that first period math quiz? Now kids share just about anything just for a “like” on Instagram. So, where did this word come from?
share.transcript:
Remember when we were kids in the cafeteria and all we shared were Lunchables and the answers to that first period math quiz? Now kids share just about anything just for a “like” on Instagram.

But, what happens when you share an article that contains misinformation? Or, when a misrepresented photo of a classmate is spread which then turns into cyberbullying. Or, when political ads and information are backed by dishonest people.

Seems like sharing has gone from innocent to injurious. What happened to the whole “sharing is caring” thing?

Maybe share is just going back to its roots, way back to the 1300s when share meant “cutting, division.” Or, perhaps, further back to its Old English roots when share was scearu and meant “fork of the body; groin” because, these days, an injurious online share can be like a real kick to the balls.

Ouch. Share doesn’t have to be such a hurtful word. Online sharing can be caring. (Like thumbs up sign)

calling.name: What Does The Word "Calling" Actually Mean?
calling.description: It's probably wise to listen to our callings. Sometimes they're loud—like someone calling our name—or sometimes they're much more subtle, like that little voice in our head telling us “this is what we’re meant to do.”
calling.transcript:
It’s probably wise to listen to our callings. Sometimes they’re loud—like someone calling our name—or sometimes they’re much more subtle, like that little voice in our head telling us “this is what we’re meant to do.”

Either way, listening is probably in our best interests.

Yes, calling means literally “calling someone” with your voice or a phone … this version of the word actually stems from an Old English word hildecalla meaning “battle cry.” Wow, that’s a loud calling.

But, there’s another side to calling too. The word shares roots with the Latin word for “glory”—glōria. This is how calling goes beyond the vocal and enters the vocational. And, we’ve actually all been searching for these types of callings for a long, long time: this version of the word originated in the Bible.

So whether your calling is loud (and often times in your mom’s voice) or subtle … listen up, it’s important.

sign.name: Why Does The Word "Sign" Have So Many Meanings?
sign.description: It's confusing because the word "sign" has so many meanings, which is why it can be added to lyrics to symbolize a lot of different things. So, what do some of our favorite singers mean when use the word "sign" in their music?
sign.transcript:
There’s a lot of songs about signs …

“Sign, sign, everywhere a sign” … or how about “I saw the sign and it opened up my eyes” … does anybody know what Ace of Base was talking about? Yes, I’ve just dated myself, but seriously, what sign were they seeing?

It’s confusing because the word sign has so many meanings, which is why it can be added to lyrics to symbolize a lot of different things.

Were these musicians literally talking about a physical object, action, event, or pattern that conveys a meaning?

You know like STOP!

Or DO NOT ENTER!

or a nicer “Hey, you’ve arrived, welcome to White Mountain”?

or “Elephant crossing”?

Maybe it was peace … like the peace sign?

Or, hang ten?

Or, thumbs up?

I know … it was probably more of a metaphorical sign, a token or indication of friendship or camaraderie that you get from just one hug?

But, it could have been a discrete sign, a motion or gesture used to express or convey an idea, command, or decision—like those weird sports signs they signal to each other … nobody knows what those mean right?

Or, was it just a subtle eye roll … we all know what that means.

Maybe a not so subtle ear plugging sign … teenagers are fun.

What about an omen … oh, an omen, for sure.
Whatever the sign actually is (and as you can see it could really be anything), it was there, somebody saw it, and it made an impact. And, that’s really the universal idea that ties all of these sign senses together … even Zodiac signs. They’re real.
OK, signing off. Over and out.

obnoxious.name: "Obnoxious" Used To Have A Very Sinister Meaning
obnoxious.description: Once upon a time, 1578 to be exact, the word "obnoxious" was born.
obnoxious.transcript:
Once upon a time, 1578 to be exact, the word obnoxious was born.

And, it used to have a more sinister meaning.

The original definition of obnoxious meant “exposed or liable to harm, evil, or anything objectionable.”

Nowadays, you may be tempted to call your little brother an “obnoxious brat,” but you probably don’t mean he’s evil or that he should be harmed … like seriously harmed.

Today, the word obnoxious means that all too common feeling of inspiring annoyance … and if you have to choose between annoyance or pure evil … it’s probably better to have to deal with the first one, right?

Ooooh … is that clown scary!

And, that’s the part of the definition that stuck.

Now, obnoxious means “highly objectionable or offensive,” and that is for sure what your little brother is, right?

As well as that guy in the car next to you … who just cut you off because he’s head banging to his screaming music. He’s totally annoying … and his singing, which you can hear because it’s incredibly loud … is truly offensive to your earbuds.

sweet.name: Why Are There So Many Definitions For The Word "Sweet"?
sweet.description: When someone calls you "sweet" ... what do they really mean? Are they complimenting you, insulting you? Help!
sweet.transcript:
“You’re sweet, but I just don’t think this is going to work out.”

Ugh, a cliche break-up line if I ever heard one. And, what does “you’re sweet,” even mean in this context? It’s one of those words that has become so vague, I don’t even know it’s real definition. Is it supposed to make me feel better … because it absolutely does not.

So, because I was just dumped … I have a lot of time on my hands, which means I, of course, looked into that annoying little word sweet to see why it was used to describe me.

Well, sweet used to mean “not salty,” in relation to water, when it originated in the 13th century. Does that mean fresh then? I’m “fresh,” but there’s just no spark? Guessing that’s not the meaning that describes me.

Or, another meaning from the 13th century is “wholesome.” Isn’t wholesome just a code word for boring … that’s a real ego boost.

I also don’t have any lingering taste of honey or sugar. At least, not that I’m aware of …

Hey … sweet can also mean “easily managed” or “done without effort.” So, what, I’m easy now?

Oh wait—in wine terminology, sweet means “not dry.” So not dry means I’m not boring; that I’m fun to be around, and maybe I just have too much personality; I’m like a fine red wine.

Huh. Maybe being sweet isn’t something to be sour about after all …

clean.name: Why Is It So Hard To Keep Things Clean?
clean.description: No matter how many times you clean something, it always gets dirty again. Why?! Well, actually, that unobtainable sense of perfection goes all the way back to this word's origin. Take a look.
clean.transcript:
This house. Is never. Clean.

No matter how many times I dust or mop, there’s a streak here or a dust mite there. It drives me nuts.

But, it’s not just me … clean can actually be far from clean itself.

For starters, people use clean for a wider variety of purposes than one may at first realize. Parents ask their kids to clean their rooms (like, five times a day), causing a lot of pre-pubescent eye-rolling (and time-outs) … and sure, we all know that one. That’s part of what contributes to my rages, right?

But, while researching cleaning products … I found that a lot of criminals can come clean and confess what they did.

And, someone can also be clean if they’ve stopped using drugs or alcohol.

Oh, and if a politician pulls the majority of votes, well, then, they’ve just had a clean sweep.

These definitions of clean really muddied it up, but there does seem to be one underlying theme here: clean is “pure.” This goes way, way back to its Old English roots to the word clæne meaning “free from dirt or filth.”

If something is clean, there’s no issues or impurities getting in the way of its perfect state … and that’s just unobtainable.

But, hey, that doesn’t mean I still can’t try, right? Maybe, this will just help me take it a little less seriously … no more white in this house, ever.

american-dream.name: Is The American Dream Still Attainable?
american-dream.description: Today, the phrase American Dream is often uttered with equal parts longing and eye-rolling. The eye-rollers think the American Dream’s dead. The opposing party begs to differ. Why is there so much debate?
american-dream.transcript:
In 1931, the phrase American Dream was born. Now, keep in mind that date—1931. We’re talking the midst of the Great Depression, arguably the worst time period to be in the country, and some guy is talking about the American Dream?

A dream in which “the fullest stature of [each man and woman] shall be able to attain to the fullest stature of which they are innately capable of”?

That’s optimism if I ever heard it.

See, the man who coined the term, James Truslow Adams, was a historian who was attempting to clearly define what set the United States apart from other countries. This for him was the American Dream, something that the European upper classes couldn’t quite understand because mobility wasn’t something that existed in that culture.

It was a thought that the unheard freedom this country allowed gave room for anyone to get to the top, if only they reached for it.

Today, the phrase American Dream is often uttered with equal parts longing and eye-rolling. The eye-rollers think the American Dream’s dead … or that it was all a farce to begin with.

The opposing party begs to differ. There are a couple of kinks, sure, but the American Dream prevails through the systems in place and the people who have the capacity to use those systems for good.

So, maybe it was never a truly attainable dream or maybe it’s something you have to work hard to achieve. It doesn’t make a difference either way, because dreaming is uplifting and if we keep the American Dream as alive as it was in the darkest of times in 1931 … maybe it’ll help those in the future sleep better.

strip.name: When Did "Strip" Start To Mean Getting Naked?
strip.description: Isn't it interesting when a word can have so many different meanings ... but the one we all think of when we hear the word "strip" is about getting naked. Why is that?
strip.transcript:
Isn’t it interesting when a word can have so many different meanings … but the one we all think of when we hear the word strip is about getting naked … why is that?

Human nature … we guess, but strip actually goes a lot deeper than skin level.

Originating in the 13th century, it did first mean “make bare,” but also to “plunder, despoil.” So, actually it didn’t originate as a word to describe the naked body … it described land being conquered and scourged. Wow, that might be an even less flattering picture than a strip club.

However, later that century, the sense of “to unclothe” was established. And, strip tease wasn’t far behind … it’s been a phrase since 1929.

Let’s get our minds out of the gutter for a minute though … you can also strip a tree, strip sheets from a bed, strip someone of their privileges, strip paint, strip a screw (ugh, isn’t that the worst?!).

And, don’t forget … strip is also a noun. (Yes, all those meanings before were verbs …).

Since the 15th century, strip as a noun has meant “long, narrow, flat piece” and a “narrow piece of cloth.” Even, comic strip has been around since 1920.

That’s not all though … what about airport strip, film strip, nose strip, Sunset strip … or a strip of bacon.

Strip is more savory and complex than we all thought … but even after this well-rounded look at the word, you’ll still automatically think about getting naked whenever you hear it.

No judgment, we will too.

c-est-la-vie.name: How Do You Use "C'est La Vie" In A Sentence?
c-est-la-vie.description: In French, "c'est la vie" means "that's life." And, we English speakers borrowed it into English in the 1880s as an idiom to express acceptance or resignation, much like "oh well." But, how do you use it in a sentence?
c-est-la-vie.transcript:
In French, c’est la vie means “that’s life.” And, we English speakers borrowed it into English in the 1880s as an idiom to express acceptance or resignation, much like oh well.

Because sometimes you need a phrase that makes you feel a little bit better about your situation …

In everyday speech and writing, people usually issue a c’est la vie to shrug off slight disappointments or signal resigned acceptance of some unpleasant affairs or facts. And, we all experience disappointments and rejections …

But, c’est la vie is a way for us to bond together, to pull ourselves out of the depressed funks these everyday mishaps may put us in and say “hey, life sucks … at least right now, and that’s OK.”

Nobody is perfect and this one phrase nicely reminds us of that … this shot is out of focus … isn’t it? Ugh … c’est la vie.

choice.name: Why Is It So Hard To Make A Choice?
choice.description: Ah, so you chose to view this video. But, what other kinds of choices led you here?
choice.transcript:
Ah, so you chose to view this video. But, what other kinds of choices led you here?

Maybe you made a choice to watch this video because you perceived it to be something informational or entertaining.

Well, that’s pretty interesting because the Old French choisir serves as the root of the word choice and it means “to perceive.” This developed into chois—“the action of selecting”—later in the 14th century.

And, maybe you chose to look up the word choice because sometimes many things feel out of our control (like gender, sexuality, race, and even physical aspects like hair) but choice is something that is always ours, right?

And, when we feel out of control, or down-and-out about our situations, looking up words, understanding their definitions, and learning how they affect us is helpful to put things into perspective.

Because your choice to come to Dictionary.com and watch this video was a good one … it’s here to remind you that what we can do with the cards we’re given is a choice that’s always our own. When we feel upset or frustrated with our genetics or environments, we always have the power to spin things in a positive direction even when it seems hard. Bad choices are inevitable, but they teach us how to become and act better.

So keep choosing your actions carefully and keep looking up words that will help you understand what’s happening around you. That will never be a bad choice.

suit.name: How Did "Suit" Become An Insult?
suit.description: You may have heard people refer to (and by refer we mean insult) out-of-touch businessmen as "suits." Which makes sense considering the word’s origin ...
suit.transcript:
You may have heard people refer to (and by refer we mean insult) out-of-touch businessmen as suits. Which makes sense considering the word’s origin, which dates back to the 1300s: “a band of followers, or retinue” and the “set of matching garments” they wore.

“Band of followers”? Harsh. Maybe 14th century suits weren’t too dissimilar from today’s.

But, the word suit isn’t limited to mocking execs. What about all those less insulting, more genuine definitions for the word suit?

You can don a track suit before a quick jog around the neighborhood.

Or, slip on a suit of armor for that upcoming Ren Faire.

In a game of cards, a suit can get you a winning hand, which is what brings us the idiom to follow suit. To play the same suit as another is to follow their example. Yup, that originated in cards.

And a suit, or lawsuit, can be filed in a court. Those suits are way less fun …

Maybe you’re not much of a follower. Maybe you don’t find formalwear, or card games, or Ren Faires suitable. We get it.

Suit yourself.

major.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Major"?
major.description: Major, similar to its latin derivative magnus, means “great in size, extent, or importance.”
major.transcript:
Here in the US, turning 21 is a pretty big deal.

It’s a major life milestone, right up there with graduating and losing your first baby tooth … although, perhaps, with a slightly higher chance of a hangover the next day.

And, why is this such a major milestone? Well, because major, similar to its latin derivative magnus, means “great in size, extent, or importance.”

That might also explain why we call the big leagues of professional sports the majors.

Or, why we call a multimillion dollar studio film a major motion picture.

Speaking of motion pictures: do you remember the classic Damon Wayans comedy, Major Payne. How could you forget? Major is an officer ranking just above Captain, just below Lieutenant Colonel.

Or, how about music? Back when we were younger and our parents forced us to play the piano, we had to practice our C-major scales each day.

That might explain why we aren’t musicians but were instead English majors in college … no surprise there.

No matter which way you spin it, we’ve always been major nerds. Some things never change.

mad.name: How Does The Word "Mad" Have So Many Meanings?
mad.description: The word "mad" really drives me mad. I mean, just think about it. I’m so mad at you, I could say. But what if I said I’m so mad about you. Those are like two opposite things, infuriation and infatuation. How can this one word, "mad," be both?
mad.transcript:
The word mad really drives me … mad. I mean, just think about it. I’m so mad at you, I could say. That means “I’m so angry at you.” But what if I said I’m so mad about you. That means “I’m crazy about you.” Those are like two opposite things, infuriation and infatuation. How can this one word, mad, be both?

So, mad originally meant “demented, crazy, or out of one’s mind.” We can find this sense recorded by the 1300s—and it’s still around today. Stark, raving mad or mad scientist, for instance, are about some seriously loose screws. Or, mad dog. The very earliest evidence for mad, in fact, describes a dog as having rabies. Now, mad dog is something of nickname for a manly man who goes all out—he might even give a mad dog stare, or a threatening, crazed look.

You’ll especially encounter mad as “insane” in British English, whereas mad for “angry” appears more common in American English. But, “angry” mad was around long before the United States. It’s found by the 1400s.

Both are states of extreme agitation. When you’re mad as hell or mad as a hornet, you’ve really gotten carried away.

And, when something really gets carried away, say, like a sax player ripping a solo, it’s really intense. It’s really exciting. It’s really good. That’s how mad becomes slang for “excellent” or “cool” in jazz slang by the 1940s. This mad later, by the 1990s, shifted to a sense of “abundant” or “great in amount,” like a rapper who has mad skills or gets mad respect.

The next time someone tries to push your buttons by saying You mad, bro?, ask them some follow-up questions. Do you mean I’m “crazy”? Or I’m “angry”? I’m “extra”? Or I’m “really awesome”? That’ll drive ‘em mad.

abstinence.name: What Does "Abstinence" Mean For You?
abstinence.description: "Abstinence" is so very often about personal choices. That's why we should also try to abstain from judgment.
abstinence.transcript:
I practice abstinence. Now, for many people, that means they refrain from drinking alcohol. For others, that means not having sex until they are married. But, me? I like a good drink every now and again and, well, you know, but I abstain from red meat.

No, I’m not a vegetarian. I eat chicken. I eat fish. And don’t get me wrong: I love a good bacon cheeseburger. That’s the whole idea of abstinence, though: I’m voluntarily restraining myself from something I enjoy but know is harmful for me.

See, I’m concerned about how much raising cattle contributes to climate change. I’m also concerned about the treatment of pigs on big farms. Plus, too much red meat isn’t good for my heart—or waistline.

So, I hold myself back from eating beef and pork. That’s what abstinence and its verb, abstain, literally mean. They go back to a Latin verb abstinere [ahb-stin-ey-rey], which is “to hold back” or “to keep away.” The ab- part means “away from” and the –tinere, a form of the verb for “hold” or “keep.”

But, that’s me. I’m not trying to be preachy. Abstinence is so very often about personal choices. And, I also try to abstain from judgment.

name.name: Why Are Our Names So Important?
name.description: In the classic Shakespearean play, Romeo and Juliet, Romeo questioned, “What’s in a name?” Good question: Why are names so important to us?
name.transcript:
In the classic Shakespearean play, Romeo and Juliet, Romeo questioned, “What’s in a name?”

Romeo makes a pretty good point, I mean, names feel kind of arbitrary. But, they are one of the only ways we can define ourselves in the world that we live in.

Take my name for instance, Sam. Now, when most people hear Sam they probably assume it’s short for Samuel. In most cases, they’d be right. In mine, they’d be wrong because my last name is Manual. And Samuel Manual. Ewww. No. So, thanks, Mom and Dad for keeping it short.

I was known as Sam Matthew Manual. And my sister was known as Sarah Matthew Manual. But, when we were home, when we were with our Indian community, when we were back in India, we were known as Giju and Gina. And, anytime anyone called me Giju it was an immediate rush of connection to culture and community and love.

Now, every once in a while, I would try and teach an American friend to call me Giju. When they would get it right, it was awesome because it was a connection to this community, this heritage, this far away land, but also family. It was everything. And, it was awesome.

So Romeo, the names that we’re given and the names that we give ourselves are pretty darn important.

triage.name: What Is The Gruesome Origin Of The Word "Triage"?
triage.description: There are lots of words with truly gruesome histories that have evolved over time to have much gentler meanings. Triage, is a great example of one of these words.
triage.transcript:
There are lots of words, Blockbuster, Bulldozer, and deadline, that have truly gruesome histories, but have evolved over time to have much gentler meanings.

Triage is another example. I learned about that word when I was 12 years old watching my favorite show, M*A*S*H. Even at 12 years old, I understood most of the medical words they were using like surgery and sutures and I.V.s and stuff like that.

Anyway, while most of the episodes were pretty humorous, this one definitely was different. It was not going to be a funny episode. There were lots of wounded, and Hotlips Houlihan was in surgery looking for Hawkeye and Klinger, and somebody told her they were out by the buses doing triage. And I was like, triage? What’s that?

There were wounded everywhere, and they’re laying on the ground, and they’re… they’re calling out for their mothers, and at 12 years old, I’m sure my eyes were as big as saucers. And then, there’s Hawkeye.

He and Klinger were out there organizing the wounded by the severity of their wounds, and prioritizing who would get surgery first, and in some cases, who was too far gone for surgery. Life and death decisions. This was the definition of triage.

But, today, the word has become watered down. People use it in all sorts of situations when they’re talking about scheduling items or prioritizing events. I was in a big box store the other day, and a manger walked up to one of his co-workers, and he says, “Hey… there’s a new truck out on the loading dock, can you meet Frank and help him triage it?”

different way. It’s become watered down to mean ANY situation where people need to prioritize a schedule or organize items. The other day I was in one of the Big Box home improvement stores. And this manager walked up to his coworker and says, “A truck just pulled into the loading dock. I want you and Frank to run triage on it.”

I didn’t say anything, but the thought-bubble above my head:
“You keep using that word. I do not think it means what you think it means.”

sultry.name: Why Does The Word "Sultry" Seem Like An Insult?
sultry.description: If someone called me "sultry," it would be an immediate turn-off. There’s just something sort of … gross about that word.
sultry.transcript:
If someone called me sultry, it would be an immediate turn-off. There’s just something sort of … gross about that word.

Sultry means “oppressively hot, close and moist.” Maybe I just don’t do well in humid weather?

In fact, sultry started off as a word that specifically applied to weather, to describe muggy, humid, sweltering conditions. I’ve been through Georgia in the summertime, I know what that feels like.

And sultry can apply to things associated with sweltering heat, too. Like “sultry work in the fields.” Again: not for me.

Of course that all explains why sultry these days also means “characterized by or arousing passion.” This sense of “hot with lust” dates way back to the 1700s. We’ve been hot with lust for centuries. But of course back then the word would have only been used to describe women,  not men, because, well, [shrugs] sexism.

Sultry ultimately derives from the word swelter, which, if you go far enough back, used to mean “faint with heat,” or “to perish with heat.” Again: no thanks.

But that’s not to say sultry doesn’t have its time and place. If you’re going for romance, describing a partner or a situation as sultry can convey passion and desire, which can definitely be a compliment.

perseverance.name: What Is Your Story Of "Perseverance"?
perseverance.description: There are times in life where you have to show a tremendous amount of patience to get the thing that you want. During these times perseverance might be the best word to keep in mind to help you move forward.
perseverance.transcript:
There are times in life where you have to show a tremendous amount of patience to get the thing that you want.

Perseverance was exactly the word that I needed to move forward.

I’ve been a youth mentor now for years in different churches around the country and I have loved it. But, the very first gig I ever got in the field was the one that tested my patience the most.

Growing up, I didn’t really live in a great part of my area. I lived in what we would consider the inner city. We didn’t make that much money. We…uh…were struggling.

I had been working at a summer camp program that had shut down for the year. It was the fall. I was living in a trailer in the woods. It was creepy, and I really just needed community and connection.

Eventually, they were able to transfer me to a school that had a little bit better, um, funding.

And, lo and behold, a church that I had volunteered for years earlier had a position open up. So I applied, and I thought I was a shoo-in. But eight months…of interviews and phone calls and emails and trips, I wasn’t the frontrunner I thought I was.

So, I switched schools as a little girl. I remember walking into the classroom and seeing the word perseverance written on the chalkboard. On the very first day of my time there the teacher defined the word perseverance.

I knew if I wanted to be in the field maybe I should apply to some other places. That’s how I ended up in Greensboro, North Carolina, for the next five years, and I wouldn’t change it for anything in the world.

And, uh, it still means a lot to me, so…thank you to that teacher.

“Steady persistence in a course of action, a purpose, especially in spite of difficulties, obstacles, or discouragement.”

chronological-order.name: Why Is It Important To Tell Stories In Chronological Order?
chronological-order.description: Yes, there is importance to telling stories in "the arrangement of things following one after another in time." Without chronological order there'd be no fairy princesses and no joyful endings...
chronological-order.transcript:
Most of us know the story of Cinderella: Cinderella and the Prince live happily ever after. Until one day, a carriage is turned into a pumpkin by a fairy, and then Cinderella is stuck scrubbing floors for her mean family and occasionally crashing parties and leaving glass slippers laying around. The end. Uh … that took a dark turn!

Cut to a scene of a million babies crying during this bedtime story because … it makes absolutely no sense. Why? What the $*!* happened to this classic fairy tale?

Well, it was told out of chronological order.

Yes, there is importance to telling stories in “the arrangement of things following one after another in time.” Without chronological order there’d be no fairy princesses and no joyful endings … because we’d all be too confused to know whether the story was happy or sad.

So stop confusing people and keep your facts (in time) straight … for the sake of Cinderella.

complacent.name: Is "Complacent" A Negative Or Positive Word?
complacent.description: Nowadays, "complacent" is seen as such a negative word. Which is funny because, originally, it was actually kind of a positive word.
complacent.transcript:
Nowadays, complacent is seen as such a negative word. Which is funny because, originally, it was actually kind of a positive word.

Now, if you go back centuries ago and look at the Latin origins of the word complacent, it’s actually pretty positive. It actually means, ”to take the fancy of” or “to please.” Today, complacent means “to be pleased with oneself or situation.” But here’s the catch: ”Usually without an awareness of a potential danger or defect.”

Think of “The Tortoise and the Hare.” The hare started off really good in the race. He started racing off, got real comfortable with his lead. So he got complacent, thought he could take a nap. That, of course, left him to the potential danger of the tortoise, who kept at it, who wasn’t complacent and ended up beating him. So, I guess you know, don’t be uh, complacent like the rabbit … or the hare?

dossier.name: How Do You Pronounce "Dossier"?
dossier.description: What do you call a bundle of papers? A stack? Pile? Trash? All that work you’ve been putting off? What about "dossier"?
dossier.transcript:
What do you call a bundle of papers? A stack? Pile? Trash? All that work you’ve been putting off?

What about dossier?

When you read the word dossier, it looks like [doss-ee-ur]—like it means more dossy, whatever that is. But, when you hear the word dossier, it sounds like some fancy, French perfume. [Doss–ee–ey.]

Well, dossier is French, but ain’t perfume—and it ain’t all that fancy once you get to know it.

Borrowed into English by the late 1800s, a dossier is “a collection or file of documents on the same subject, especially a complete file containing information about a person or topic.” That is, “a bundle of related papers.”

Today, we often see dossier in criminal contexts. For instance, the FBI has kept dossiers on everyone from Frank Sinatra of the Rat Pack to Ol’ Dirty Bastard of the Wu-Tang Clan. These were files tracking, among other things, their possible criminal gang activity—in Sinatra’s case, the Mafia; in O.D.B.’s, the Bloods.

And, in recent years, you may have heard about the Steele Dossier. These are memos kept by a former British secret agent containing allegations of collusion between Russia and Donald Trump’s presidential campaign to help him win the election. 

Note that dossiers don’t necessary mean crimes have been committed or that a person has been convicted. The FBI never charged Ol’ Dirty Bastard or Ol’ Blues Eyes. As for Trump?

Let’s just that when the intelligence community has a dossier on you, you might really feel like you’re back is to the wall. Literally, in the case of dossier. The root of dossier in French is dos, [doh] meaning “back,” from the Latin dorsum, like a dorsal fin on the back of dolphin. Apparently, dossiers were likened to the way big bundles of paper bulge like curve of the back. Or, it could just be they had a label on their backs for what they were about.

[ADDITIONAL CONTENT IF DESIRED > Fun fact: Square dancing seems a long way from France and its tricky words like dossier, but if you’ve ever danced the do-si-do, you’re doing a move where you pass your partner around the back. It comes from the French dos-à-dos, literally “back to back.”]

Don’t let a word like dossier be any skin off your back. Sometimes there’s the perfect word to describe something—like dossier—but we aren’t confident enough to use it because its pronunciation is hard because its origins are French or because it’s too hard to spell because its origins are French! We’re all insecure about words. There’s no need to … “back” off from them.

acquit.name: What Does "Acquit" Actually Mean?
acquit.description: Armchair lawyers and judges will remember this phrase from the 90s: If the glove doesn't fit, you must acquit!  But, what does "acquit" actually mean?
acquit.transcript:
Armchair lawyers and judges will remember this phrase from the 90s: If the glove doesn’t fit, you must acquit! I couldn’t stop watching that trial … the drama!

This rhyme worked well for Johnny Cochran and OJ Simpson, but acquitted has a more nuanced history beyond OJ … which, of course, I found out while researching everything and anything about him. I admit it, I’ve been found out … unlike my bestie OJ haha!

In fact, the term originates from the French acquiter meaning to “pay, pay up, settle a claim.” So acquitted used to refer to settling a debt.

Then, there’s also the Latin root quietus, meaning free. And, with the combination of these two words we found the meaning “free from claims.” That transitions pretty easily to the current definition you may hear on Law & Order: “to relieve from a charge of fault or crime; declare not guilty.”

So, yes, OJ was acquitted … he was declared not guilty of killing his ex-wife and her friend … and we’ll never forget his catchphrase because of this verdict.

But, don’t worry … things didn’t actually turn out so great for him, he was charged for many other crimes, went to jail, and was only recently released. Acquittal or not, OJ did the time.

pawn.name: Was The Word "Pawn" Always An Insult?
pawn.description: When you call another person a "pawn," is it an insult ... or a compliment?
pawn.transcript:
If we hear someone calling another person a pawn … we know they’re insulting them, right?

Well, believe it or not, they may actually be paying that person a compliment.

Pawn comes from a place of kings and queens and knights and castles. Literally. The word pawn stems from the Latin pedon, or “foot soldier.” These were the infantry of an army, the ones running bravely onto the battlefield at the front of the line.

But, then these men were embodied by faceless pawn figures who sought to protect the royals behind them in the ancient Persian game, chess.

And from this usage … a pawn soon implied that someone was expendable. They were lowly foot soldiers, after all, whose lives were put on the line for someone of a higher social standing.

To pawn something as a security loan, a concept that popped up around the 1560s, too, indicates a sense of sacrificing something for a higher social or financial standing. Then came pawnshops (first used in 1749) and even Pawn Stars—seedy affiliations of the word pawn due to its association with getting money in fast ways via expenditures. In the 1940s, pawned even meant getting imprisoned. Talk about taking a turn for the worse.  

Being a pawn isn’t 100% great, for sure. But that doesn’t mean we can’t put a positive spin on it, especially given the word’s origin: because in the game of chess, a pawn, if it makes the right moves, can become a queen.

affair.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Affair"?
affair.description: When most people hear the word affair, they automatically clutch their pearls and assume it’s referring to some sexy form of infidelity. But, the origins of affair aren’t sexy at all.
affair.transcript:
When most people hear the word affair, they automatically clutch their pearls and assume it’s referring to some sexy form of infidelity. But, the origins of affair aren’t sexy at all.

In fact, the meaning of the word affair, back in the 1300s, was very buttoned up—“what one has to do, ordinary business.”

However, that’s certainly a bit more interesting than the original Latin phrase, à faire, which simply means “to do.” Yawn.

Affair didn’t get juicy until around 1702. The word took on the meaning  “vague proceeding,” and, yes, we’re talking about that kind of “proceeding.” Phrases such as to have an affair with someone as well as have an affair of love all started to come about in the 1700s, as well.

Oo, the 1700s were scandalous.

The French (unsurprisingly) were the ones that gave affair a bit more passion when the phrase affaire de coeur was translated into English as “an affair of the heart.”

Of course, affair still has a businesslike side to it today, but our eyebrows will always raise suggestively when the word comes up in conversation … it’s inevitable.

dirty.name: When Did The Meaning Of The Word "Dirty" Change?
dirty.description: When did the word "dirty" begin to mean promiscuous? Was Christina Aguilera to blame?
dirty.transcript:
When we were kids our mothers always told us to “wash up, you’re so dirty.” Then we hit puberty, Christina Aguilera is singing on the TV, and all of a sudden getting dirty is something a bit more intriguing.

What. Just. Happened? When did dirty start to mean sexy?

Well, obviously, there are several meanings of dirty at play here (we hope).

That dirty your mom yelled at you for? It’s associated with actual physical filth. It comes from the late 14th century word, dritty, which is defined as “feculent” or “muddy.” It was the physical, harmful type of dirty that could spread disease and kill you.

In the 16th century, it took a spiritual turn; dirty came to mean “morally unclean,” implying questionable ethics or actions. For example, if you had dirty linen back in the 1860s, it meant that you had a few skeletons hiding in your closet; if you got a hold of some dirty money in the 1910s, you probably got it in a less-than-legal way.

By the 1950s, people wanted to get dirty for a different reason. The word began to develop a sexual association—it meant that you were promiscuous, kinky, like Christina Aguilera cage-fighting in tight leather pants. It was still a little morally filthy, but that was OK so long as you kept it behind closed doors.

my.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "My"?
my.description: One tiny word, two letters, yet it has a long history and a powerful punch. How did we start using "my" as an exclamation?
my.transcript:
When I was little, I always played with my grandma outside. And, I remember this time I made a really crazy jump from the jungle gym … and landed it, it was so cool. And, the best part was she was so impressed—I could tell from her excited “Oh my!” I have honestly never felt so proud.

My is such a tiny word, though. It’s funny it had so much of an effect coming from such a tiny old lady sitting on a park bench.

And, when I started to think more about it for a second, I wondered if it had to do with where the word got its start. Since way back, it’s always meant the possessive “my” or “mine,” whether it’s the Old English mīn or the Middle English mi.

Weirdly enough, people would use my in front of words starting with vowels and mine with consonants, a fact my grandma would’ve been equally impressed with, but I digress.

A lot of times, people would use the word my in tandem with the word God, as in “my God!” Over time (around 1825, to be exact), it looks like the “God” was occasionally dropped from the sentence and my stood all by its lonesome … yet it still held the power of the original interjection.

So, one tiny word, two letters, yet it has a long history and a powerful punch. Kind of like my Grandma to think of it … she may look tiny, but I wouldn’t want to be on her bad side. I’ve seen how she talks to the butcher when he gives her a bad cut of meat. My, my, my, Grandma.

to.name: What Is The Actual Definition Of The Word "To"?
to.description: There’s no real definition for the word "to" because it's a word that primarily just serves a function … 22 of them, actually. Yup, there are 22 uses for the preposition “to.”
to.transcript:
There’s no real definition for the word to … because it’s a word that primarily just serves a function … 22 of them, actually. Yup, there are 22 uses for the preposition “to.”

That’s because prepositions, like to, help form phrases. They are connectors that explain the meaning of a sentence just a little bit more.

Sometimes, to can show direction or distance, like when my grandmother came to my house the other day (She drove from Southern California all the way to Northern California, which is a lot for a grandma!).

It’s also great for expressing movement or contact … like when my grandma was so tired after that crazy drive that she slumped to the ground. I was so worried about her that I put a cold washcloth to her head.

Another thing that little two-letter word does (Two is a number; don’t get that one confused here) is show purpose or intention, as well as an end point or destination. Very versatile. That’s why when Grandma visits next month I’m going to drive with her to my house to make sure she is OK.

And, this isn’t even half of to‘s uses … because this small word has a big impact on the English language. We bet that’s why you’re looking up this word, too (Warning, warning: this version of too means “also,” but it’s not a preposition.).

cognitive.name: What Does The Definition Of "Cognitive" Actually Mean?
cognitive.description: We have to be 16 to drive. Why? That's when we're cognitive enough to make good judgments while on the road. At 18, we can watch R-rated movies. So, that means we can deal with complex situations and narratives. This is what "cognitive" is all about.
cognitive.transcript:
Cognitive is a pretty complex word.

It’s probably mostly associated with the term cognitive development. And this relates to, like, kids picking up basic skills between the ages of one and three. I would imagine that toy manufacturers have spent billions of dollars developing games and toys that help raise cognition.

But, it’s also a frightening term. I mean it is measuring mental capacity. You’re probably worried that your two year old isn’t as smart as the two year old down the street. It’s like the ultimate “keeping up with the Joneses” match.

But, it doesn’t end there. The definition is “relating to the mental processes of perception, memory, judgment, and reason.” These become very applicable as you continue to grow.

I mean when you turn 16, you get a driver’s license. The understanding is that you have now developed the mental, cognitive ability to make good decisions while you’re on the road.

Then when you turn 18, you can go see R-rated movies because your reasoning skills and your cognition have developed to the point where you can deal with complicated situations and narratives.

But, what happens when you get older? You go from cognitive development to cognitive functioning.

Your cognition starts to diminish, and that’s a whole new stressor because now you’re in decline. And, maybe some of the privileges that you got because of your cognitive ability, they start getting taken away. Like driver’s licenses or living on your own.

And, maybe your memory starts to slip.

Cognitive. It, it follows us through our whole life. It is our measurement of mental capacity and goals. And, when it starts to slip, it’s upsetting. But, just because it’s defined as mental capacity doesn’t mean it has to define you.

r-i-p-.name: What Does "R.I.P." Stand For?
r-i-p-.description: R.I.P. is a rather serious concept that’s been turned into an almost comical abbreviation on, you guessed it, the internet! Yet, R.I.P.’s roots have a bit more gravity to them.
r-i-p-.transcript:
R.I.P. is a rather serious concept that’s been turned into an almost comical abbreviation on, you guessed it, the internet!

You’ll see it a lot on social media today in contexts that aren’t so grave and somber … like that chicken sandwich. It’s become a lighthearted affair, and the only gravestones it shows up on are of the Halloween decoration variety.

Yet, R.I.P.’s roots have a bit more gravity to them. The acronym stands for the Latin “requiescat in pace,” meaning “may the deceased person rest in peace” and it has been embedded into Western headstones for centuries because many faiths believe those beneath the headstones will rest until Judgment Day.

The spelling with periods began as an acronym for this Latin phrase … however, in the 1600s it also became an acronym for the easier to pronounce “rest in peace,” that we English speakers created.  

And, even though R.I.P. does still make appearances during funerals, or in obituaries, or occasionally on tombstones, RIP and rip (yup, some people really pronounce it as the word rip) appear more often in funny, satirical social-media posts and hashtags.

R.I.P. chicken sandwich that I just dropped on the floor!

Because if we can’t make light of death … life seems pretty grim.

abandoned.name: Why Is The Word "Abandoned" So Interesting?
abandoned.description: There's often more to the story when it comes with the word "abandoned." It's one of those words that makes a story a bit more deep and interesting.
abandoned.transcript:
Some words carry a paint brush. Drop in one little adjective and you’re immediately telling a story.

Abandoned is one of those words … like when you say “abandoned building.” You’re totally imagining broken windows and overgrown grass … and maybe this innate need to want to explore it, right?

What about abandoned child—there’s a desperate story to be told here … and we just want to help them.

Or, abandoned amusement park … uh, creepy clowns are lurking here for sure. This is the stuff horror movies are made of.

Aw, an abandoned kitten: So sad, and cute, and in need of rescue; we’ll do it!

How about this one? Abandoned enthusiasm … if you’re ever able to experience this, you’ll know you’ve found your passion because that unrestrained and uninhibited feeling is hard to come by …

OK, maybe not all of these stories are true, but with a word carrying the definition “forsaken or deserted” or “unrestrained or uncontrolled” … there’s often more to the story when it comes with the word abandoned.

accident.name: Are Accidents Always Bad?
accident.description: As a teenager, I had this one friend who used to call his kid brother “The Accident” every time he got annoyed with him. Does that mean all accidents aren't bad?
accident.transcript:
As a teenager, I had this one friend who used to call his kid brother “The Accident” every time he got annoyed with him. Of course, the kid was too young to realize how or why this was an insult. His mom sure knew, though, and she got real mad whenever she overheard him.

That insult always made me realize, though, that not all accidents are bad (unless, you know, it’s the accident of your mom overhearing you making fun of your brother).

And the original Latin word—accidēns—(which is the root of accident) agrees; it translates into “falling down upon,” “occurring,” or “circumstance.” These are all words pertaining to fate, but not necessarily something bad.

However, during the times of Middle English, accident began to be associated with a “diseased condition” or a “disturbance of the mind.” And then cars came around, so there were car accidents. It was also in the 20th century when a child born out of wedlock was deemed an accident … and at the time, these were all negative.

And even though we tend to associate accident with bad … it’s not always the case (just as the original meaning of the word intended).

Serendipity is unplanned but good, right? So is the concept of divine intervention. Miracles, too! And, of course, my friend’s kid brother—because babies. These are all good things, all unplanned, all basically accidents!

Not a bad way to put a positive spin on a lot of things we can’t control, right?

indulge.name: Is "Indulge" A Positive Or Negative Word?
indulge.description: "Indulge" actually started off as a good thing ... so what is it now?
indulge.transcript:
Hey guys. I just came back from indulging in my favorite guilty pleasure, really bad reality TV.

I indulge in really, really trashy reality TV at least once a week. Or, am I? Because indulge actually started off as a good thing. It stems from the Latin indulgere, which means ”be complaisant, be indulgent, yield or give oneself up.” It came to mean “a freeing from temporal punishment for sin” around the mid-14th century and was popularly used by the Church. So, for centuries the Church deemed people could become free from sin through indulging.

But, then people started to push how we could indulge, ya know? That whole selling of indulgences thing, which is where the rich were able to buy their way to heaven. Taking advantage of the system, you know what I mean? That’s probably how it ended up indicating  ”to grant as a favor” back in the 1630s.

It is probably why indulge has such a bad rep today. It’s been tainted from that part of history indicating people can take part in excessive bad behavior without any sort of consequence. In fact, this behavior supposedly got them into heaven. Right?

Indulge you have quite the sordid past. In any case, I’m going to go ahead and start watching the teaser for next week’s bad reality television. I need to know what’s coming up next. I need to know who’s getting in a fight with who  so that I can take a side early, of course.

hike.name: How Are There So Many Different Meanings For The Word "Hike"?
hike.description: This football player aptly illustrates how the word "hike" is truly applicable in a ton of situations. Who knew?
hike.transcript:
It’s dark, you’re on the field, you hear cheering, you hear plays being called, you hear “hike!”

The ball is in the quarterback’s hands, your part is done. So you look over at the crowd, at the cheerleaders, and the closest woman’s skirt is hiking up … uh … you quickly look away, you can just imagine her saying “take a hike,” because you know what it’s like to be stared at … and you respect that.

So, you start messing with your sock … you hike it up so that it’s even with the other one. And, that immediately triggers a memory: that time you went on that hike with your father, and his jacket was falling down, and you helped him hike it back up over his shoulder, and you had a moment, one you won’t ever forget, and that was special.

And, the ball is back … you’re up again … dark, field, cheering, plays, hike!!

pros-and-cons.name: What Is "Pros And Cons" Short For?
pros-and-cons.description: Do you know what "pros and cons" is short for? This guy can explain.
pros-and-cons.transcript:
I didn’t know if I should make this video. It’s, uh … just, it’s not an easy phrase to explain. I mean, well, let’s, let’s, let’s think here.

A pro of making this video would be, uh, ya know documenting these super old prefixes. Uh, pros and cons actually originates in Latin. So, so you know it’s old. But, it’s been used as abbreviations since the 16th century. That’s like…well it’s been around the block a few times, ya know. But on the other hand, uh, a con of this video would be would people find this boring?

I mean, is this phrase too old and overused? Betty White’s pretty old, but…everybody still loves her. Another pro would be nobody knows the origin of the phrase. Pros and cons is actually an abbreviation of the Latin phrase pro et contra, which means “for and against.” Pro basically means “in favor of.” Contra means “against” obviously. Contra’s also a sweet 80s video game.

Con. The word con actually probably gets confused the other prefix con, which means ”with, together, joined.” That kind of complicates things a bit. But a solid pro, talking about Latin makes you seem smart.

Con. You might sound like a newb to people that actually know Latin.

So, what do you think? Are we doing this or not? Oh, wait. I guess the pros outweigh the cons. We’re done.

allow.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word Allow?
allow.description: Allow is an incredibly old word, but doesn’t it make you feel young again when you hear it? Why?
allow.transcript:
Allow is an incredibly old word, but doesn’t it make you feel young, like so young you’re back at home with your parents wondering if they’ll allow you to go out on Saturday night with your friends?

Well, maybe that feeling comes from the Latin word allaudāre or “to praise greatly,” which allow stems from. Parents are definitely known to dole out the praise.

Over time though, this merged slowly with the Middle Latin allocō for “assign.” And then by the time the Middle English allouen rolled around, it was a mixture of “assign with approval.”  

These origins certainly help explain why we revert back to childhood when we hear the word allow … but is there more to it?

Maybe it’s also because as adults we expect to be in control of our actions and choices … without others allowing us to do (or not to do) them. But, in fact, we’re still under the rules and permissions of our government, our workplaces, our HOAs. So, allow isn’t purely a kid thing … it follows us throughout life, helping to guide us through our choices based on our allowances.

Sometimes, that’s a great thing … and, sometimes, just because we’re not allowed to challenge the status quo doesn’t mean we shouldn’t try. That teenage rebellion also lives on.

excoriation.name: When Should We Resort To Excoriation?
excoriation.description: An excoriation is like being flayed with words... ouch! Some words can really get under your skin.
excoriation.transcript:
Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me. But, what about your skin?

I’ve my fair share of tongue-lashings in my day. There was the time I wrecked my car because I was driving too fast. It was raining too, which is bad, I know. But, you know, I learned my lesson, and I also learned a new word from it: excoriation.

Excoriation means “to denounce or harshly criticize somebody.” My dad excoriated  me for my irresponsibility with my driving.

An excoriation is like being flayed with words, like, if you look at the origin of the word, it means to… “to strip of skin.” Not like exfoliate. Exfoliation I can handle, but excoriation, it’s gruesome. It’s a powerful word that should be reserved for powerful moments, like if somebody is knowingly being irresponsible.

But you could also use the word for like, uh… a newspaper might write an excoriating article about a bank that was cheating elderly people out of their money. Or, a company that was dumping chemicals into a town’s water supply and knew that that’s what they were doing.

A politician might make excoriating remarks about their opponent. Or, someone might right an excoriating Facebook post about a person that they worked for who was inappropriate.

Some words can really get under your skin.

nepotism.name: What Is The Origin Of "Nepotism"?
nepotism.description: Do you know the sordid history of this word?
nepotism.transcript:
You’ve probably heard of political and business leaders being accused of nepotism. This is “favoritism shown on the basis of family relationship,” such as giving an important job to a son or daughter, say, over a more qualified candidate. But you might be less familiar with where this word comes from.

The word nepotism came into English in the 17th century based on the Italian nepotismo [ney-poh-teez-moh]. This referred to a historic practice in the Catholic Church where popes and bishops put relatives, including nephews, into positions of privilege.

Nephew is the key word here, as the origin of nepotismo is the Latin nepos [ney-pohs], meaning “nephew.” Our own word nephew comes from this same root.

Nephew is also the key word because, in the Middle Ages, popes commonly made cardinals out of the nephews of existing cardinals. They were known, appropriately enough, as Cardinal Nephews.

Other popes, however, appointed or bestowed church land and money on secret lovers and illegitimate sons, who were conveniently called “nephews.” Clever euphemism, Il Papa.

Nepotism, as you can imagine, became a big problem for the Catholic Church, as favoring family corruptly consolidates wealth and power. In fact, it’s said to have contributed to the policy of celibacy in the Church and to the Protestant Reformation.

One of the most notorious nepotists in the Catholic Church was Pope Sixtus IV [say “the fourth” for IV], whose other claim to fame was restoring, oh, only a little something called the Sistine Chapel. The more aptly named Innocent XII [say “the twelfth” for XII] officially banned nepotism in the church.

Not that that stopped nepotism elsewhere. You know that new intern in the graphic design department? Only the daughter of an HR manager. Or that Senior Adviser to the president supposedly negotiating peace in the Middle East? Just his son-in-law. Sheesh.

easy.name: Why Is The "Easy Way Out" A Bad Thing?
easy.description: At school or at work or in a competition especially, if someone is taking the easy way out then it’s like they’re being lazy or they’re doing something wrong. Do we get more credit for doing something the hard way than we would the easy way?
easy.transcript:
I mean, so many things in life are hard when something can just be easy, isn’t it just a relief?

Like, at school or at work or in a competition especially, if someone is taking the easy way out then it’s like they’re, they’re being lazy or they’re doing something wrong.

Do we get more credit for doing something the hard way than we would the easy way?

Not necessarily. It doesn’t guarantee you more points or more, uh, money.

What I think is that we, as humans, know that we’re going to get more self-satisfaction and, and feel more accomplished if we challenge ourselves.

But it could also have to do with the origin of easy.

Back in the 1200s, to be at ease basically just meant that someone had money. They were rich, uh, or wealthy, so they didn’t have to work very hard.

It comes from the Old French word aisie. That just meant to be “comfortable” or “well-off” or “rich.”

And so, today we probably think of easy or having, having it easy as meaning that someone just doesn’t have to work as hard or maybe they don’t deserve what they have. They haven’t earned it. You have to struggle, if you want to earn something.

But, I honestly think that easy doesn’t have to be a bad thing. The world is hard enough.

I might pop a TV dinner in the microwave and, yeah, it’s not the same thing as making a full dinner for myself, but it’s easier, so then I can save my energy for working on that project that’s due tomorrow.

It’s OK to do the easy thing sometimes and then you can save your energy for something that’s really hard, like sitting through, a lecture at seven in the morning. That is truly not easy.

sought.name: When You Should Use The Word "Sought"
sought.description: Is sought a real word? Is it really the past-tense form of seek? That does not seem right!
sought.transcript:
Is sought a real word? Is it really the past-tense form of seek? That does not seem right!

Plus, I thought that sought was only used with the word after … you know, like “sought after.” I almost never see these two words apart from each other.

What is going on with this word?

Well, turns out, yes, sought is the past-tense form of seek and it means “try to find or discover by searching or questioning.”

But … no one really uses it that way, come on. It’s honestly so much easier to say I searched for the answer than I sought out the answer, right? (Plus, it sounds way less pretentious … oh, English.)

But what about that phrase … sought after. Actually, this is a whole new word; it’s an adjective (or describing word) instead of a verb.

And, the reason why we see the word sought with after so often is because it’s really applicable and really easy to use. It can be used to describe something “that is in demand; desirable.” That’s a lot of things.

So, even though I may not like the word sought by itself … I’m never going to forget this difference: sought is what I did to find the meaning. Sought after describes the meaning: I really wanted to know it!

jargon.name: We Asked: When Have You Been Overwhelmed By An Industry's Jargon?
jargon.description: Every industry has its own jargon ... have you ever been overwhelmed with the words and phrases at a new job?
jargon.transcript:
Hey, when you get a minute can you load a reel of two-inch up on the multi-track? We’re doing a bunch of thirties, sixties, and fifty-tens today. And, then stick a Sennheiser 416 on that mic stand.

Every industry has its own jargon, but it was a little overwhelming for me at 21 years old, when I got hired as an assistant audio engineer at a recording studio. Most of our clients were advertising agencies doing radio and TV commercials. So, our jargon involved words like ISCI codes and ISDN hook-ups and LKFS measurements.

So while it’s really not surprising that one definition of jargon is, “language specific to a profession.” But another definition is, “unintelligible or meaningless talk or writing, gibberish.”

It sure seemed like gibberish to me when I was first starting out. One day I showed up at work and I asked my boss what we were doing that day, and he said once the clients show up we’re gonna be recording a bunch of donuts for a bunch of radio commercials.

I had no idea what he was talking about. But, if clients were coming over with donuts we were gonna need a lot more coffee. So I went into the lounge to start a few more pots.

After a while, my boss wanders over and he goes, “what are you doing?” And I said, well if people are coming over with donuts, I’m gonna need more coffee. He goes, “Michael, you know how there are singers at the beginning of a commercial and there are singers at the end of a commercial? We’re recording the voice over that goes in the hole in the middle. The donut!”

You know, I can laugh about it now. But, I swear I thought the next two words out of his mouth were gonna be, you’re fired.

weather.name: What Is The Difference Between "Weather" vs. "Climate"?
weather.description: Although there is a wealth of scientific evidence, the difference between weather and climate can be difficult to understand. But all hope is not lost—we're here to help you learn the difference.
weather.transcript:
All you seem to hear about these days are droughts, polar vortexes and global warming! Whatever happened to 75 and blue skies?

Some of these problems can be solved with an ice cold beverage or a warm coat… but others are a warning sign of something more sinister. How do we know when we need need a soda, or when the remedy is a little more complicated? The debate seems to rage on, when really there should be no debate at all.

Although there is a wealth of scientific evidence, the difference between weather and climate can be difficult to understand.

But all hope is not lost! Between the brilliant minds at Dictionary.com, and the rocket scientists at NASA, we are able to set the record straight. Let’s see how the dictionary defines these two words…

You see, the key here is time.

Weather is your day to day rain or shine, whereas climate is the overall pattern of temperature, humidity and rainfall you can expect to see in a certain area.

This is corroborated by NASA, the guys who spend more time looking at the Earth than pretty much anyone else.

So, in other words, a sunny day in Alaska is a nice weather surprise, but that doesn’t mean it’s about to start challenging Florida for climate-based title of “The Sunshine State”.

Changes in weather are part of life on Earth; giving us the opportunity to build snowmen on some days and sand castles on others.

Climate change, however, is far more serious. Just consider the rate at which the sea level is rising. Disney World will be a lot less fun if it’s under water.

nemesis.name: Explain The Difference Between Enemy vs. Nemesis
nemesis.description: The difference between these two words may be subtle ... however, they're both extremely hard to defeat.
nemesis.transcript:
After my most recent root canal my dentist staged a tiny intervention of sorts.

She said that candy was an enemy that I had to defeat, or else I was going to lose all of my teeth.

But, I didn’t think she had it quite right.

An enemy is a foe who’s hostile toward the protagonist of a story.

A nemesis is an opponent or rival who can’t be overcome, a permanent fixture in the life of a protagonist.

So, obviously candy is my nemesis.

I’ve been fighting my love for sweets since I was a kid, and I plan on doing it until the day I die cause, quite frankly, what is life without chocolate?

awesome.name: Do You Remember This Radical 80s Slang?
awesome.description: When you re-hear to this 80's slang you'll feel like you've been transported back in time. Do you remember these totally 80's words?
awesome.transcript:
Contributor 1

My name’s AJ and I’m a child of the ‘80s! Much of my vernacular has been influenced by a certain quartet of reptilian practitioners of ninjutsu – the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Totally radical, dude! Righteous! Cowabunga! Totally tubular! For someone who’s never surfed I have a lot of surfer lingo in there thanks to Michelangelo. Let’s see…it’s pretty gnarly…except for when it was bogus!

Contributor 2

One word that I find myself using all the time is dude. I use it, usually, when I’m very serious: “Like, dude.” And, it comes from, back in the 1800s, it was actually an insult. Yankee Doodle Dandy. It was Americans that were trying to get gussied up and emulate the style of Europe at the time. So, it’s pretty funny that it was an insult, and now people use it as a sign of affection. Like, “Hey, dude!” Or, like me, “Like, dude.” Very serious. Another word that I find myself using is radical. I use it a lot in business meetings actually, like when someone has a great idea. It’s just totally rad. I can’t help it. I have to say it. That comes from the [Latin word for] root, actually, so it’s easy to remember. Radish is a root vegetable, and radical is the word that comes from that.

Contributor 1

That’s all I got…PSYCH! See you weren’t ready for that. I…PSYCH!…got ya! PSYCH! I don’t say that too much anymore. That was really annoying back then and, eh, it continues to be so today. 

Contributor 2

Another word I find myself using is awesome, because, you know it’s a great word. Awesome.

Contributor 1

If I got a problem with somebody, “What’s your damage?” Even today I still say that.  Actually, if I, I’ve got a problem with somebody, I’ll ask, “What’s your damage?” But in closing for real this time…Be excellent to each other. And party on, dudes!

check.name: The Word "Check" Has A Very Regal Origin
check.description: Asking for checks and filling out forms with checkmarks is boring, so it’s easy to forget that "check" was a word that originated from a game of knights, kings, and queens; basically the stuff Game of Thrones is made of.
check.transcript:
When someone cries “Check!” when they want to pay the bill, they probably don’t stop and think about how regal a word it is.

It’s understandable. Because asking for checks and filling out forms with checkmarks is boring … so it’s easy to forget that check was a word that originated from a game of knights, and kings, and queens; basically the stuff Game of Thrones is made of.

The beginnings of this little word began in Persia with the word shah, meaning “king.” As time moved forward, shah became the Old French word eschec, a word specific to the instance in the game of Chess in which the king is moved or covered. Interestingly, eschec also refers to “the act of failing.” When the king is gone, game over, the player’s moves are now limited—this developed the word’s meaning of “a sudden stoppage, hindrance, restraint.”

This origin is how we became able to write a check (a restraint on an amount of money). It’s also how we can check our coats at a restaurant (an act or means of checking or restraining), and it’s how we can check to see if our coat is still there at the end of the night (a hindrance on error).

For one seemingly insignificant word … check has quite the history. So, check yourself before you wreck yourself and realize you didn’t pay proper respect to the regal word check.

cancel.name: What Does It Mean To Cancel Someone?
cancel.description: Canceling, today, is used like an informal boycott, usually on social media, when someone or something in the public eye is offensive … or when we’re just over them.
cancel.transcript:
[Girl talking to friend on the phone] Oh my god, don’t worry. Jessica is so canceled after the awful things she said about you on Twitter. Oh, hold on… I have a customer.

[Puts phone down looks to camera] Oh, hi! Seems like you might be looking up the word cancel on the dictionary! I can totally give you the scoop.

Canceling is something we’ve all done. You cancel your plans, you cancel your subscriptions, or, if you have my luck, your credit cards and favorite TV shows are always getting canceled. [ugh, eye-roll]

Something you might not know about the verb cancel is that, back in the 1400s, it meant “to cross or strike out” a piece of writing. Like, literally drawing an X through it. The word’s Latin root literally refers to “cross-bars” or “lattice,” like on a fence.

So, if you “cross” something out, it’s like you are voiding it, revoking it, calling it off. You’re canceling it. This sense, which we still use today, comes about by the 1500s.

In the 2010s, canceled took on some big-time social connotations. It’s being used to declare people null and void, like my ex-friend, Jessica.

Canceling, today, is used like an informal boycott, usually on social media, when someone or something in the public eye is offensive … or when we’re just over them.

Remember when Kanye West said “slavery was a choice” in 2018? Yeah, he got widely canceled for that. Meaning, people wanted others to stop buying his music and giving him a platform thanks to those … unusual … views.

Calling for someone to be canceled in this way can be serious, and it’s become so common that we talk about a cancel culture online.

But, we also often use cancel to be funny or dramatic. Like, if you get a flat tire on your way to work, you might cry out, Today is canceled.

Which makes me think … maybe we can all be too harsh and knee-jerk sometimes on social media. What if someone gets canceled before the whole story comes out? And, imagine feeling attacked and victimized by the entire internet? Rough.

[Thoughtful pause and then picks back up the phone] On second thought, maybe we should give Jessica a chance to explain.

[Puts down phone and makes skeptical look] Kanye, however …

capeesh.name: How Do You Spell "Capeesh"?
capeesh.description: No matter how you spell it, capeesh can be a colorful way to check for someone's understanding with a some Italian gusto. Capisce?
capeesh.transcript:
Do you capeesh the spelling of capisce?

There are several ways people spell it out: like this (points to a different location on the screen where the spelling appears for each word) C-A-P-I-C-H-E, like this, C-A-P-E-E-S-H,  like this, C-A-P-I-S-C-E, or even like this K-A-P-I-S-H.

That last way, with a K, may lead some to believe capisce comes from Yiddish, but, as any good paesano will know, the word is Italian.

Capisce, spelled C-A-P-I-S-C-E and pronounced [kuh–pee-shey], means “he, she, or it understands” in Italian. This is a form of the verb capire, “to understand,” from the Latin capere, which literally means “to grasp”—like capture.

The best we grasp, capische immigrated with Italians to the United States in the late 1800s and morphed into a questioning capisce, as in “Do you understand?” This meaning was also influenced by capisci [kuh–pee-shee], the form for “you understand” in Italian and pronounced much like capisce.

Capisce is recorded as early as the 1870s, when tens of thousands of Italians fled war and poverty to start a new life in America. It’s also around this time when the Italian-American Mafia began forming its network of organized crime.

It’s portrayals of the mob in popular culture—from The Godfather and The Sopranos to The Simpsons and Jersey Shore—that have given capische its tough-guy, gangster stereotype, with capische issued as a threat. “You’re going to do what I say, or else. Capisce?”

But, capisce isn’t all Corleone or guido. No matter how you spell it, capisce can be a colorful way to check for someone’s understanding with a some Italian gusto. Capisce?

crepuscular.name: How Does The Word "Crepuscular" Relate To Nighttime?
crepuscular.description: Do you like to stay up all night? Are you most active right after sundown? Then you might be crepuscular. No, that’s not an insult ...
crepuscular.transcript:
Do you like to stay up all night? Are you most active right after sundown? Then you might be crepuscular.

No, that’s not an insult. Crepuscular is a fancy adjective that refers to “twilight, or general dimness.” It also is what we use to describe animals that are most active in the evening, like night owls, deer, ocelots … or you.

The word crepuscular comes from the Latin crepusculum which means “twilight or dusk.”

It was first used in the 1660s to figuratively refer to lighting that was dim or indistinct.

In the early 19th century, zoology, or “the study of animals,” became a hot topic in the scientific community. Animals that took flight or were particularly active right after the sun set were referred to as crepuscular—like rabbits, moose, moths, and barn owls.

Oh, and ocelots.

Of course, fans of the TV show Archer already know this because they are familiar with millionaire Cheryl Tunt’s pet ocelot Babou (Cheryl it’s not pronounced “crupuscular,” sorry).

The way the characters in the show use the word, though, suggests they don’t really know what it means. Somehow, we aren’t surprised by that.

Maybe if they watched this video, they would have a better idea of what this whole crepuscular thing is all about.

bosom.name: How Old Is The Word "Bosom"?
bosom.description: Do you have ever specific memories associated with certain words? This woman explains her specific connection to the word "bosom" and how the word originated.
bosom.transcript:
Every time that I would go to see my grandma and visit her. She would scoop me up in her arms, pull me to her chest and squeeze and tight as possible. She would squeeze me to her chest so hard sometimes that I couldn’t even breathe. But, I think I was pretty happy to be smothered with all that love.

Do you have ever specific memories associated with certain words? I do, like with the word bosom.

Bosom, yes, refers to the “breasts of a woman,” but the word is, um, much more bountiful.

Bosom doesn’t just sound old-fashioned. It is. From an ancient Germanic root, bosom is recorded in Old English before the year 1000. Back then, the bosom was the breast of any human being—not just well-endowed people of the female persuasion.

To be in someone’s bosom is to be in their arms, hugged and held close to their heart, which we associate with deep feelings. That’s why a bosom friend, a phrase found in the 16th century, is one you can confide in.

A modern version is bosom buddy, which comes about around the 1920s or so. That has nothing to do with milkshakes and bringing boys to the yard: it’s all about affection and intimacy.

Those warm, fuzzy feelings are also why we see bosom in more poetic expressions, such as the bosom of the earth or the bosom of the family.

By the 1950s, though, bosom was specifically referring to a woman’s breasts. We especially see it in the phrase ample bosom, or “large breasts.” And, speaking of breasts, bosoms, in the plural, almost always means “a woman’s breasts.”

Why would this old and much more general word bosom get narrowed down to female anatomy? I could venture to guess… [fake cough – says sexism under voice]. 

Besides, I feel like the more interesting questions is how was my grandma so strong back then? Was she lifting weights? Should she be my workout buddy?

rhyme.name: Are There Any Words Without Rhymes?
rhyme.description: It's the age old question ... at least the age-old word game question: Are there any words without rhymes?
rhyme.transcript:
(Person starts by musing on words like silver, angel, orange.) (Tries to come up with some rhymes for them.)

It’s the age old question … at least the age-old word game question: Are there any words without rhymes?

Seemingly, a lot of words would be hard to rhyme with another word. There’s so many strange English pronunciations it’s hard to find another word that would be pronounced exactly the same.
