That’s totally the case when it comes to a word like orange. This word is weird. And nothing rhymes with it right?! Wrong … these super obscure words actually do rhyme: Orange rhymes with Blorenge  (a mountain in Wales) and sporange (a technical word for a sac where spores are made) … oh yea, and blorange: re-popularized by the one and only Jonathan Van Ness.

OK, OK, what about silver. Can’t think of a damn thing that rhymes with that … but, come on, we have the dictionary at our fingertips. Silver actually rhymes with Wilver (a nickname) and chilver (a ewe lamb).

I found it, I found the one word without a rhyme: angel.

Angel, which comes from the Greek word, angelos, which meant “messenger of God” truly has new rhyme, phew. I was right.

Similarly, there are a couple of other words without rhymes (remember this the next time you go to Trivia night): Bulb (from the Ancient Greek word for onion, bolbas) still hasn’t found a word to rhyme with.

Same goes for the word month. Who knew?

mexico.name: Did You Know Mexican Independence Day Is Not Cinco De Mayo?
mexico.description: Most people know Cinco de Mayo is on May 5th. However, what they don't know is that Cinco de Mayo is not Mexico's Independence Day. So, when is it? This woman helps us explain ...
mexico.transcript:
Cinco de Mayo is a small battle that took place in Puebla, Mexico. Um, it was a small battle against the French, uh, and it’s really only celebrated in Puebla. It’s not a national holiday.

It’s interesting. If you ask someone here in the United States, uh, when Mexican Independence Day they probably won’t say September 16th. Most people know it’s also not May 5th, um, but, they still celebrate as if it were. And I really think it has to do with the whole “cinco de drinko.” Um, it’s a fun holiday to, to embrace the Mexican tradition.

Mexican Independence Day is on September 16th and it’s when Mexico declared their, um, beginning of a fight for independence from Spain. 

In Mexico it’s called dieciséis de septiembre, obviously, um, el dia de independencia.

So traditionally, in Mexico, when you’re there for Independence Day they start celebrating on the 15th, the night before, um, with, uh, just family dinners or parties of everyone dresses in traditional garment. Um, you have traditional dishes and you stay up all night, party. Uh, eleven o’clock they start the reenactment of the actual day. The next day on September 16th it’s kinda recovery day, um, and they have, um, parades, um, for everyone to watch and it’s, that’s a national holiday.

I spent, um, Independence Day in Mexico once, um, when I was a little girl and I remember the parade. I remember fireworks, um, and the food, of course!

The one thing that everyone chants on this night is, “Que viva Mexico!” and you respond, “Que viva!”

fleek.name: Why Was The Phrase "On Fleek" So Popular?
fleek.description: Let's be real, no one exactly knows what fleek means, but that didn't stop everyone from using it circa 2014.
fleek.transcript:
Mirror, mirror on the wall, are my eyebrows on fleek or what?

Oh, sorry, I didn’t see you there. I was just making sure my look was on point, hot, or on fleek as the kids used to say. Okay, let’s be real, no one exactly knows what fleek means, but that didn’t stop everyone from using it circa 2014.
The first definition of fleek popped up on Urban Dictionary back in 2003 where it was said to mean “smooth, nice, and sweet.” Then, in 2009, the definition of “awesome” was added. So, fleek means something ambiguous but definitely good, right? Sure. How do we know? Well, it’s all thanks to one visionary 16-year-old Vine user named Kayla Lewis a.k.a. Peaches Monroee who described her eyebrows as on fleek in a legendary video back in 2014. Rest in peace, Vine. Lewis claims she just made the word up herself—fleek just sounds like it should be a word, right?

Anyway, the term went viral on Vine from Lewis’ video and then was lapped up by millennials everywhere. Suddenly everything cool was fleek, for a couple years anyway. Kim Kardashian’s butt? Fleek. Taco Bell? Fleek. Steph Curry’s Sour Patch-inspired kicks? Fleek.

But, like they did with diamonds, Hooter’s, and mayonnaise, millennials eventually killed fleek. And while it’s still kicking around some corners of the internet, almost no one describes stuff as fleek anymore. But that’s not going to stop me from admiring my look, thank you very much. And anyway, my eyebrows are on fleek. There’s no better word to describe them.

witch-hunt.name: Why Is "Witch Hunt" A Political Phrase?
witch-hunt.description: The term witch hunt, recorded as such in the late 1800s, took a turn in the early 20th century. Here's why.
witch-hunt.transcript:
Double bubble toil and trouble! Fly my pretties, fly! *Cackles*

Uh, this is a video about the phrase witch hunt … not about actual witches.

Oh, really? Uh … that’s awkward.

Sorry, I got a little carried away there. So, does witch hunt have anything to do with witches then or was I just completely off?

Phew, OK, witch hunts reached their height in Europe and North America in the 17th century, when we first have record of the term witch hunt. At this time, people blamed tragedies they didn’t understand, such as babies dying or crops failing, on witches, who they believed had evil, magic powers.

Innocent people—especially women, and often marginalized ones like slaves or widows—were accused, tried, and killed for witchcraft. Historians estimate at least 40,000 people died because of witch hunts. 

One of the most notorious witch hunts culminated in the 1692–93 Salem Witch Trials. Here, unexplained convulsions some young women were having led to mass hysteria in colonial Massachusetts about witchcraft. About 20 people were put to death as a result of the hearings, 14 of them women.

But, the term witch hunt, recorded as such in the late 1800s, took a turn in the early 20th century.

It became a metaphor for unrelenting efforts to drag down people considered disloyal or subversive in some way—especially Communists. Amid the Cold War in the early 1950s, Senator Joseph McCarthy, for instance, ruthlessly targeted US citizens and government officials he alleged, without evidence, were Communists infiltrating the country.

While the term witch hunt in the early 20th century began to move away from the magical and misunderstood, it still kept with it the lack of due process and proper “innocence before prove guilty,” making witch hunt a political and social metaphor in the modern era.

And now (well at least since January 2017), Donald Trump has been calling claims of possible collusion between his presidential campaign and the Russian government a witch hunt. And he doesn’t just use the phrase here and there. Trump has tweeted witch hunt literally hundreds of times, most memorably in May 2017 after the start of the special counsel investigation. He called it “the single greatest witch hunt of a politician American history.” Hey what about those Salem Witch Trials we mentioned before?

Trump’s use of witch hunt is rhetorical, but, it discredits our legal institutions. And, it downplays the fact that Russia interfered in our elections—which is kind of big deal.

pertinent.name: We Asked: What's A Word Your Family Says That No One Else Does?
pertinent.description: Does your family have a word that you use all the time ... that no other family uses at all? Did you make up that word? Or are you just using that word in a "unique" way? We asked you all to answer ... here's what we found out!
pertinent.transcript:
So, the most common word my family misuses is the word pertinent. 

It all started back in high school when my friend, Justin, and I were both sitting around waiting for our friend, Sam. And my mom noticed that Sam was running unusually late and she made the off comment of, “Sam’s usually a little bit more pertinent than this.”, which both me and Justin, we just look at each other and it’s like, “Did she really just misuse the word?”.  And we’re like, “Mom, you mean isn’t he more punctual than this.” And she was like, “No, I meant pertinent. Pertinent’s the right word here.” And it just devolved into a 20-minute fight about what was the right word. 

So, the following summer, my dad and I just started doing this game where we put pertinent into sentences, just to make them sound more important or just to misuse it.  So, like, we’d be driving past an Applebee’s and my dad would be like, “Oh, I bet you that Applebee’s has a pertinent menu.”, or, uh, you know, we’d go to the ocean and I’d be like, “Hey, that ocean has a deep pertinence to it.”, you know?  And it just kept on escalating until my mom finally forbade us to ever use that word again.  

The definition of pertinent is “pertaining or relating directly and significantly to the matter at hand; and being relevant.”

rural.name: Why Is The Word "Rural" So Hard To Pronounce?
rural.description: Rural. It refers to things in the country, where things can be simpler and quieter than in cities. So, why is this word not simple to pronounce?!
rural.transcript:
R-r-rural. Rurrrh. Roar-uhl. 

Rural. It refers to things in the country, where things can be simpler and quieter than in cities. So, why is this word not simple to pronounce?!

OK, it’s clear Rs and Ls are just difficult for some people to say. Rural has three of them altogether, back to back to back.

And, all the sounds in the word rural, vowels included, are articulated in the same area. Let me explain …

To make different sounds, we move our lips, mouth, and tongue to different positions. Put your hand under your jaw and say rural. Feel your tongue lurching around in there?

Now, there are technical terms for all this phonetic business, but, to keep it simple (that’s what rural is all about, right?) … the double Rs and vowel sounds in rural cram our tongue up in the middle of our mouth. 

When saying rural, it’s as if our tongue is squished, kind of reminding me of that time I took the subway during rush hour, ugh.

But, then, at the last minute, the doors open and the tongue jumps to the front of the mouth for the final, L sound, finally getting some room and fresh air—just like that peaceful, simplistic rural countryside. 

Maybe I’ll just stick to saying countryside. So much easier.

hypochondriac.name: Where Did The Term "Hypochondriac" Come From?
hypochondriac.description: It wasn’t until the 19th century that hypochondriac described someone who suffered “illness without a specific cause.”  So what did it originally mean?
hypochondriac.transcript:
In the late 16th century, when hypochondriac first entered the English language, it described the upper abdomen. The word comes from Greek roots literally meaning “under the cartilage of the breastbone.”

Weird, right? Hypochondriac was related to an actual part of the body? Well, here’s why …

The upper abdomen, it turns out, was thought to be the seat of melancholy back in the 16th century. Melancholy, as we know it today, is kind of gloomy, pensive sadness.

But, we used to believe medical ailments—and even people’s personalities—were governed by body fluids called the four humors: blood, phlegm, yellow bile, and black bile, also known as melancholy.

Different proportions of these fluids were thought to influence a person’s mood and health. Too much melancholy was believed to make a person angry and sullen. So, actual, practicing, early doctors referred to a kind of melancholy as hypochondriac because that fluid was believed to be produced in this abdominal area.

We really take modern medicine for granted, don’t we?

In the 17th century, hypochondriac referred to people who suffered from “depression and melancholy without cause.” But, if you think about it … there was probably cause. It’s thought that many of these depressed patients complained of abdominal pains—and that’s where melancholy was believed to come from.

It wasn’t until the 19th century that hypochondriac described someone who suffered “illness without a specific cause.”

This sense is still widely used, though today we diagnose modern hypochondriacs by their overuse of the website WebMD. Oh, no. You just started feeling a little pang, a little tingle … in your upper abdomen? Don’t look it up. Don’t do it. We warned you.

blunt.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Blunt"?
blunt.description: The word blunt goes back way further than Lil Wayne or "You're Beautiful." And, it wasn't always related to so-called "wacky tobacky."
blunt.transcript:
When you hear the word blunt, what do you think of? Maybe it makes you think of weed. Or maybe blunt brings to mind a certain English pop crooner (shoutout to James).

But, the word blunt goes back way further than Lil Wayne or “You’re Beautiful.” And, it wasn’t always related to so-called “wacky tobacky.”

Back in the day, also known as the 1200s, blunt referred to someone who was not very sharp—mentally speaking. The origin of the word is obscure, but it might be related to blunder, related to an Old Norse word meaning “to shut one’s eyes.” A couple hundred years later, by the 1400s, blunt came to refer to weapons or tools that weren’t sharp—not just people. There’s a reason saying someone ain’t the [air quotes] sharpest tool in the shed is a thing.

To be blunt, blunt as in “abrupt” or “overly straightforward” is found by the 1580s. We might think of the dull but direct blow of a blunt weapon for this metaphor. That’s right, people have been aggressively impolite for hundreds of years. Go figure.

So, how did blunt become associated with large joints of marijuana [“marijuana cigar,” while accurate, just sounds odd]? It’s not because weed makes you less-than-sharp, although that would seem logical.

The slang blunt is thought to originate in New York City in the 1980s. The name is said to be taken from the Phillies Blunt brand of cigars. Since the 19th century, blunt has referred to a certain size of cigar, perhaps named for a stodgy shape, like a blunt sword. The tobacco leaf wrapper on the Phillies Blunt brand of cigars is said to be ideal for smoking marijuana—not that we would [clears throat] know anything about that ourselves. These days, any tobacco-leaf-wrapped marijuana is referred to as a blunt, whether it began as emptied-out Phillies Blunt or not.

The next time you’re out, cruising around, enjoying a blunt (of the musical variety, of course), you can rest assured that the name blunt has nothing to do with the effects of weed—or cheesy pop music—on your intelligence.

karma.name: What Does The Word "Karma" Really Mean?
karma.description: Let's start from the beginning—the very beginning. Karma comes from Sanskrit, an ancient Indian language going back some 3,500 years.
karma.transcript:
You’ve probably heard the expression karma is a b!tch, right? Well, what is this karma, exactly?

Let’s start from the beginning—the very beginning. Karma comes from Sanskrit, an ancient Indian language going back some 3,500 years.

The word literally means “action” or “fate,” and it appears in some of the most foundational scriptures of the Hindu religion, the Vedas.

In Hinduism and other Eastern religions like Buddhism, karma is “the idea that certain actions reap specific consequences either in this life or the next.”

So, a good act results in some sort of a good circumstance later on. But, bad behavior? Something nasty is in store for you.

The goal of karma is to act as honorably as possible to ensure good things come your way.

For Hindus and other believers, karma is central to the cycle of reincarnation, or “the regeneration of a person’s soul throughout different lives.” 

To put it simply, bad karma means the soul gets reborn—or reincarnates—into a lower life form, like a bug. This explains why bad things happen to good people: They must have done something nasty in a past life.

Good karma means the soul ultimately gets freed from physical bodies to become one with the universe in a state of bliss. Buddhists call this nirvana.

In everyday life and language, though, karma is similar to expressions like you reap what you sow or you get what you deserve.

So, acting like a jerk? It’ll come back to haunt you.

bizarre.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Bizarre"?
bizarre.description: Strange, but true: bizarre is a word with a debated and murky background.
bizarre.transcript:
Strange, but true: bizarre is a word with a debated and murky background.

For a long time, it was thought that bizarre is of Basque origin, coming from the word bizarra, meaning “beard.” Yup, you heard right … beard.

This same word supposedly passed into Spanish and Portuguese as bizarro, with the meaning “handsome” or “brave” … I guess they liked beards.

From there the word was adopted by the French, who apparently did not think bearded men were quite as handsome and brave as the Spanish and Portuguese.

In French, bizarre means “odd.” Ouch.

Recently, a more likely origin of the word has been found—rather than from Spanish, the French word is thought to have come from, an Italian word meaning “angry.”

Now, this still means that we have to get from a word meaning “angry” to one meaning “odd,” but that’s, perhaps, a less bizarre journey. (Shrug emoji)

behemoth.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Behemoth"?
behemoth.description: What exactly is a behemoth? Well, the original behemoth was found in the ... duh, duh, duh ... Bible.
behemoth.transcript:
What exactly is a behemoth?

Well, the original behemoth was found in the … duh, duh, duh … Bible.

Job 40:15-24 describes a land- dwelling beast having mythic proportions (a tail like a cedar tree) and supernatural characteristics (bones like bars of brass and iron).

Since then, much folklore has arisen around behemoth.

One story has it that behemoth, separated from its aquatic counterpart leviathan at the dawn of creation, will be reunited with it in an epic battle on Judgment Day in which each will slay the other.

Following this biblical King Kong vs. Godzilla match, both animals will be served up as a feast for the remaining faithful.

That would be a classic movie … for sure.

Behemoth also makes an appearance in such classics of literature as John Milton’s Paradise Lost, Shelley’s Prometheus Unbound, and James Joyce’s Finnegans Wake. So, it’s a pretty well-read monster too.

Wait, is it a monster? Well, the Hebrew word that is used in the Bible ( bəhēmōth ) is the plural form of the word for “beast” or “animal.”  Today, we use it to apply to anything “large, powerful, and often unwieldy.”

Got it, monstrous animal or powerful, unwieldy thing. We’re steering clear either way.

rapture.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Rapture"?
rapture.description: The key to understanding the wide-ranging rapture is its origin. So, where did it come from?
rapture.transcript:
Rapture: It can mean “extreme joy.” As in, “I watched the new Game of Thrones trailer with rapture.” But, put the word “the” in front of it, and it can mean something completely different. The Rapture, for some Christians, is about the Second Coming of Jesus Christ. So, what exactly does “ecstasy” have to do with “end times?

The key to understanding the wide-ranging rapture is its origin. It comes from a Latin verb, rapere [rah-puh-rey], which means “to seize and carry off.” Yes, this gives us the word rape. It also gives us rapture, literally a “snatching up” or “kidnapping”—especially of women, which was one of the senses of rapture in the 1500–1600s.

Ungodly stuff, for sure. So how is it that rapture is also related with the divine? Well, in the late 1300s, an older cousin of rapture, rapt, was used in Christian contexts to describe people, such as saints, who were carried up and away to heaven. Sometimes this was meant literally. Other times, this raptness referred to spiritual visions of God, as if in heaven.

Intense experiences of delight and joy, of enthusiasm and absorption, can make one feel as though they have been “transported” to some higher plane or “taken” out of their body—rapt. This metaphor is how we get rapture for “joyful ecstasy,” like rapturous applause or the rapture of poetry and music.

For some fundamentalist Christians starting in the 18th century, however, rapture is no metaphor. They think believers in Jesus will actually be “carried off”—again, think rapt—in the sky to heaven to join Jesus Christ when he returns at the end of the world. This is called the Rapture, usually with a capital R.

Hey, different things bring us joy in life. For some Christians? Their rapture is that “Jesus is coming.” For me? My rapture is that “Winter is coming.”

activist.name: A Video About Activism
activist.description: Activism can be inspirational, motivational, and progressive. What does activism mean to you?

pariah.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Pariah"?
pariah.description: There's nothing worse than being a social pariah—in other words, "an outcast," someone banished to the fringes of the cafeteria with no one to sit with. But, did this word always have a negative meaning?
pariah.transcript:
There’s nothing worse than being a social pariah—in other words, “an outcast,” someone banished to the fringes of the cafeteria with no one to sit with.

But hey, being a pariah used to mean something way worse than having to eat your cold bologna sandwich all by your lonesome.

The word pariah comes from a word in Tamil, a South Indian language, for a large drum, call a parai, played at festivals or beaten to signal messages.

As is traditionally said, these ceremonial drums were made of leather, and in the Hindu religion, the leather used to make these drums was considered unclean.

So, the people who beat the drums, called the Paraiyar, came to be considered the lowest caste in India around the 11th century onward. They also became known as the “untouchables,” because of the menial, dirty work they had to do.

Since the 1800s, anyone shunned by society, as the Paraiyar historically were, could be called a pariah. And, it’s not just me. Pariah dog, for instance, is a term for feral or stray dogs who scavenge for food.

I bet they’d find this bologna pretty tasty.

manifest.name: What Part Of Speech Is The Word "Manifest"?
manifest.description: In English, manifest can be an adjective, verb, and a noun. Oh yea, and at one time, it was even an adverb. Great, one word showcasing how crazy confusing the English language can be.
manifest.transcript:
In English, manifest can be an adjective, verb, and a noun. Oh yea, and at one time, it was even an adverb. Great, one word showcasing how crazy confusing the English language can be.

Where to start … how about with some history? History = facts and facts should help with some clarity on how to use this word … right?

Manifest (as an adjective) is recorded in the late 14th century and described something that was “clearly obvious” to all who could see it. That Beyoncé is a queen, for example, is manifest to anyone who ever sees her perform.

One popular use of manifest as an adjective is: manifest destiny? In the mid-1900s, this expressed the “clearly obvious” belief that the United States would—and should—continue to annex new territories.

The phrase is credited to the journalist John O’Sullivan in 1845. To O’Sullivan, it was manifest, it was obvious and inevitable, that it was America’s destiny to expand.

Manifest is also found as verb around the late 1300s or so. It variously means “to show plainly, reveal, prove, or appear.” As in, my Spotify manifests how much I love Beyoncé. Or, ships manifested on the horizon.

Speaking of ships … we have manifest as a noun. In the late 17th century, a manifest named an official list of a ship’s cargo. This was later extended to passengers, like on an airplane.

This “ship inventory” sense of manifest was partly influenced by the Italian manifesto, which gives us, well, manifesto, “a public declaration or intentions, opinions, objectives, or motives,” such as issued by organizations or artists.

The idea is that such a declaration is making the ideas “clear,” “evident,” … manifest, as I hope my little manifesto on manifest has done for you here.

text.name: We Asked: What Are The Most Annoying Words To Use When Texting?
text.description: Ugh, texting is the worst. This woman has been talking with someone she has a crush on but she has no idea what their texts mean.
text.transcript:
Ugh, texting is the worst. I’ve been talking with someone I have a crush on but I have no idea what their texts mean.

OK, so I texted, “Do you want to go to the movies tonight?” And they texted back, “OK fine.” Fine? Is that a yes? Or a “I’m annoyed and this is a terrible idea”?

Or “I don’t really want to but if it’s what you want to do.” Fine is so vague. And, what’s with that period?!

Anyway, I got really nervous so I said, “Or not. We can do whatever you want.”

To which he said, “Thanks. I’ll think about it.”

“Thanks” is even worse! When it’s on its own in a sentence, it could mean a genuine “thank you, I will take you up on that.” Or it could be sarcastic, as in “Thanks but no thanks.” 

It gets worse! Then they texted me saying: “See you later” with a yellow heart emoji. A yellow heart!

That could be “I love you” sincerely. But it could also mean “I love you like a friend.” Or even just, “you’re a nice person but I’m not that interested.” If it was a red heart emoji it would be so much clearer—that definitely would mean they were into me.

I haven’t even gotten to the worst part yet. I was trying to seem cool and collected so I texted back the “sign of the horns” emoji. You know, just to say “rock on.” And you’ll never guess what they said back.

They said “um…did you just say you love me?”

Because the “sign of horns” emoji looks like “I love you” in American Sign Language. Yikes. Don’t they know that the “I love you” emoji has the thumb sticking out to the side?

I guess not…this whole thing is so awkward and confusing. Texting is the worst. I vote to bring back phone conversations. Who’s in?

aloof.name: Who Would You Describe As "Aloof"?
aloof.description: Cat person or dog person? Everyone is different. But, would you go so far as to call them "aloof"?
aloof.transcript:
I’m a cat person. Always have been. Cats are self-sufficient. They’re not clingy. And, better yet, you don’t have to take them outside to go to the bathroom.

My uncle, on the other hand, is a dog person. He likes that his dog is loyal, comes running when he calls, and just … generally pays attention to him.

Whereas cats ignore you when you talk to them, look unimpressed at your attempts to play, and are nowhere to be found when you come home from work.

He calls them aloof.

Aloof can be an adverb, meaning “at a distance, especially in feeling or interest.” It can also be an adjective, meaning “reserved or reticent.” Yeah, I had to look that word reticent up, too. It means “restrained,” which, yes, my cat is.

As for aloof, it started out on the last place my cat would want to be: on the sea. Back in the 1500s, aloof was a nautical term referring to keeping a ship close to the wind. The a- part means “in” or “on” and the loof part comes from a Middle English word that had the sense of “windward.”

Sailing ship in this way helped kept it clear of any land it could drift into. It’s like the ship is keeping its distance. See the connection here?

By the 1600s, aloof spread as a metaphor for “distant,” “disinterested,” or “uninvolved,” often in a cold, unfriendly way.

But listen… it’s really just an act. At night, when no one is looking, my seemingly disinterested cat is always curled up on top of me. Sure, it may just be because I am warm and not because she loves me… but whatever, I’ll take what I can get.

except.name: It's Back! Round 2 Of The Gigantic Grammar Gameshow
except.description: Hello grammar geeks. We're back with Round 2 of the Gigantic, Gratifying, Grammar Gameshow.
except.transcript:
Hello grammar geeks. We’re back with Round 2 of the Gigantic, Gratifying, Grammar Gameshow.

If you didn’t catch Round 1 … it will probably come on right after this so enjoy.

Let’s jump right in.

First up: When do you cap the “P” in president?

The 42nd _____, Bill Clinton, was born on August 19, 1946.

Hello, Mr. _____.

The answer is:

The 42nd president, Bill Clinton, was born on August 19, 1946.

Hello, Mr. President.

Here’s the thing, you only capitalize the word president when you are using it as a title (President Abraham Lincoln) or when you are addressing the president to their face. That’s it. Not so complicated, right?

OK, next up: accept or except.

I like all of the characters in Stranger Things ____ Barb, who I absolutely love.

The answer is: except.

Here’s a hot tip, one easy way to keep these two terms straight is to remember the ex- in except and associate it with exclude. Barb is excluded from the other characters here because she’s the best.

Alright, we’ve arrived at our bonus question: blond or blonde?

Yup, there are two spellings in case you didn’t already know. So when do you use each?

The woman’s hair was _____.

The answer is: blonde.

Here’s why. When the word blonde came over into the English language (from French) it was gendered: blonde was used for women with light hair and blond was used for men with light hair. Weirdly, English kept this gendering … even though we don’t have other gendered words. Maybe it’s time to get rid of this gendered distinction … right, English?

language.name: Calling All Wordies: Why Do You Love Language And Words?
language.description: We're asking you, Dictionary.com wordies (a person with an enthusiastic interest in words and language; a logophile), to tell us why you love language and words. Go!
language.transcript:
Me and words, oh, we go way back

A specific moment, I can’t be exact

It was probably something in my childhood

That words and language, they got me good

Was I read to as a child? Oh, you bet

At snack time, at bedtime, even on the toilet

There was Hansel and Gretel, The Berenstain Bears, 

Dr. Seuss, The Little Miss and Misters 

I could go on about my favorites, so many to list

Books are my gateway, you get the gist

When I got older there was Matilda and others by Roald Dahl

This video won’t end if I list them all

Discovering poetry shattered my world

I learned about rhymes and syllables as a fifth grade girl

Haiku, limerick, sonnet, narrative

With words I could be infinitely creative

Instead of saying “loyal” or “obvious”

I could say “pliant” or “conspicuous”

Language was deep as the ocean,

no story I couldn’t craft or make

and then, I discovered Willy Shakes.

His ponderings on love–woo!–cool it down!

It’s no wonder he’s historically renowned.

“Uhh, you’re really hot, Sheila.”

Is that what you wanna say

when you could compare her to a summer’s day?

When I was in love, there was Rumi;

when I was sad, there was Bukowski.

A writer, a word for every mood.

If air was my lifeline, and language my food;

a toy I could carry around in my pocket,

subtle as a star, or as extra as a rocket.

So words, I adore them … 

they are my summer’s day.

My love for them,

it’s agape.

annoy.name: What Words And Phrases Make Your Eyes Roll?
annoy.description: This dad and daughter help us explain why there are just some words and phrases your parents (or kids!) say that automatically make eyes roll.
annoy.transcript:
My name’s Collette and these are things that my dad says that annoy me.

Sometimes my dad says, “We need to talk.” and then me and my siblings are all nervous on what it’s going to be and it ends up not being a big deal.

Hi, this is David. I have three kids. They’re all teenagers and they say some pretty annoying stuff. 

One of the annoying things my kids, like, say, like, is, like, they’ll want to tell me something, like, and, like…

Sometimes we’ll be riding in the car and my dad will ask, “What are you thinking about?” and I’m not thinking about anything specific so I don’t know what to tell him. And that’s annoying!

Like, it’s like, it’s so hard for them, like, to get it out, like, because, like, you know, like…

Sometimes my dad says, “Why is the door closed?” and, uh, it’s ‘cause I want it to be!

What’re ya doin’ in there?

On my phone! I don’t know?! I need my privacy.

“Will you take out the garbage?”…”Now?!”  “Will you wash the dishes?”…”Sure. Now?!”

The truth is, we’re all annoying. I’m annoying. My kids are annoying. And, at the end of the day, if they’re talking to me at all, I actually count it a blessing.

The end!

halloween.name: Why Do We Say "Trick Or Treat" On Halloween?
halloween.description: "Trick or Treat" is the quintessential Halloween greeting but why do we say it?
halloween.transcript:
Trick or Treat is the quintessential Halloween greeting …

… but why do we say it?

The custom is believed to have been borrowed from England, Scotland, and Ireland.

They practiced guising or mumming …

… which means performing a song, card trick, or story for a treat.

The routine took hold in the US in the ‘30s,

but not everyone was on board.

Some adults were angered by the entitlement of asking for treats.

Rumor has it that in a 1947 Halloween parade,

the Madison Square Boys Club held a banner that read: “American Boys Don’t Beg.”

Eventually, people got over it,

and we’ve been trick or treating excitedly since the 1950s!

principal.name: Words Of A High School Principal
principal.description: A high-school principal may not be a very glamorous profession, but this woman recognized it as a chance to influence the young minds of the next generation.
principal.transcript:
With a focus on changing the world, this woman targeted the youth (not law, not government) to become an agent of change. A high-school principal may not be a very well-respected profession, but she recognized it as a chance to influence the young minds of the next generation and to maybe inspire change early on instead of trying to change things after they’ve happened.

Here’s her story:

By definition, I am a high school principal. I do all of the daily administrative tasks that you would assume a principal does. But to me, it’s so much more. My name is Kendra Carr, and I’m the high school principal of Holy Names High School, an all girls Catholic school in Oakland, California.

I initially pursued a career in law, thinking that that’s how I would make the most impact on the world. But after an internship, working with young people at a high school in South Africa, I realized that education is where I could make the most change.

As a school community committed to service, justice, developing the next generation of leaders, we are really intentional about creating a space here on campus where students come in and discover who they are. When a freshman comes, she uses words that are very different than what a senior uses upon graduation. When a freshman enters, she is timid, she is unsure of herself, she’s trying to find her place. When a senior talks about herself, she really has become comfortable in her skin. She uses words like impact and purpose and passion. When I hear words like I can’t or that’s impossible, or it’s too hard, or that’s not me, I remind them that anything is possible. That’s why we’re here.

Our school motto is Noblesse Oblige. It’s Latin and means “to whom much is given, much is required.” That’s a motto I really try to live by and instill in the minds of these young women.

But, they’ve also taught me things too. I’ve learned terms like dab, bae is a big one, my bae, you know, my bestie. Oh, tried it, tried it, we all know what tried it means. But it’s when someone is basically posturing and trying to be someone who they’re not, and you have to call them out. Say, “You tried it.”

They’ve taught me blim. It’s something on social media where someone disses another person. Blim is short for subliminal messages, which is a comment directed at someone that doesn’t specifically name them. You know what? I have to blims in disciplinary conversations because cyberbullying unfortunately is a reality that we deal with now. It’s a precise way to identify to a student what it is that she’s done to disrespect her sister.

Education has the power to truly change a young person’s trajectory because young people have a vision. They believe in peace. They believe in justice. They believe in inclusivity. We can have the most impact on the future by supporting the visions of young people. My words matter because as a high-school principal I am an agent of change.

teacher.name: Do You Remember Your Favorite Teacher?
teacher.description: Watch Chuck Wendig, Stephanie Land, Chris Grabenstein, and Veronica Roth thank their favorite teachers and talk about how they helped inspire their writing careers.
teacher.transcript:
I knew that I was a writer when I was in the fourth grade. I had a teacher named Mr. Birdsall. This is my very first journal when I was in his class, and it stretched to … there are two shelves of journals here!

Writing is pretty much my favorite activity in the whole world. My favorite thing about being a writer is that I get to do it all the time, and make a living off of it, which is really the dream! One of the reasons that I’m here and I’m able to do this for work is that I had a really significant teacher in my life. That teacher’s name is Ryan Gobel. He was my sophomore year English teacher. He had a really inventive and engaging and unique teaching style. Um, and he interacted with us like, um, in a more, I don’t know, collegial kind of way, which was great and the first time that had ever happened to me. What he mostly did is he encouraged me to take my writing seriously, as something that was worthy of my time and worthy of attention.

My seventh grade English teacher, Mrs. June P. Garrett, at Signal Mountain Junior High School in Signal Mountain, Tennessee. Mrs. Garrett loved to laugh, and I liked to write funny essays whenever I had a homework assignment. And she liked what I wrote so much, she wrote in the margins of one of my papers, “You will make your living as a writer someday!”

I was a daily writer for a very long time, and it grew into a book that’s called Maid and it has been translated into, I think, maybe twelve languages. Most of my English teachers have, in some way, given me something. Uh, you know, Mrs. Book from fifth and sixth grade, Mrs. Strasnefski in high school. Uh, but the really, the one teacher I think who uh imprinted me most significantly is probably uh Doctor Kobre, Mike Kobre, a professor of mine in college. To him I just want to say, “Thank you!”

If you’re watching, Mr. Gobel, thank you.

gesture.name: These Hand Gestures Have Very Different Meanings In Other Cultures
gesture.description: Hand gestures, of course, can have very different meanings abroad. With the OK sign, maybe you meant to communicate "I am loving this spaghetti," but the waiter saw :"You're an a**hole."
gesture.transcript:
Imagine you’re on vacation. It’s a foreign country. And, you don’t speak the language.

So, you’re forced to rely on hand gestures to communicate.

You’re at dinner and want to show the waiter you’re enjoying your meal by flashing an A-OK [speaker holds thumb and forefinger together with the other fingers sticking straight up].

But, the waiter looks miffed and storms off.

What on Earth did you just say?!

Hand gestures, of course, can have very different meanings abroad.

With the OK sign, you meant to communicate “I am loving this spaghetti,” but the waiter saw :”You’re an a**hole.”

That’s because the OK sign, in parts of the Mediterranean, Middle East, and Latin America, can be considered obscene and offensive, referencing a certain … part of the body and, uh, act.

OK, not gonna use that symbol anywhere anymore.

Let’s run through some other ones that can get you in trouble.

Crossing your fingers [speaker crosses fingers]: In many cultures, this can be done when hoping for good luck. But, in Vietnam? It’s like giving someone the middle finger.

Thumbs up [speaker makes a thumbs up]: This gesture of assent and approval gets a big thumbs down in parts of the Middle East. It’s said to resemble a different, um, body part and is considered insulting.

Then there’s the peace or victory sign [speaker holds up index and middle finger in a V]: If you flash this fellow with your palm toward you, that’s like saying “Up yours!” in such places as the UK, Ireland, and Australia.

At this point, you might be thinking “enough is enough” [speaker holds up five fingers slightly separated with their arm outstretched], but here’s a parting warning. This gesture means “stop” or “enough” in many cultures—or, for ’90s kids, “talk to the hand.”

Not so in Greece, where it’s an ancient gesture called the moutza and can have the cursing force of a “To hell with you!” It comes from an ancient practice of throwing or thrusting, er, poop into the faces of prisoners of war.

Safe travels!

conversate.name: Words In The Dictionary That People Hate
conversate.description: Listen up, word nerds, this video is for you. Firstly, don't hate ... watch with an open mind. Because words like firstly may be nonstandard, sure, but that doesn't mean they're wrong.
conversate.transcript:
Listen up, word nerds, this video is for you.

Firstly, don’t hate … watch with an open mind.

Because words like firstly may be nonstandard, sure, but that doesn’t mean they’re wrong, OK.

Formal usage is for the birds … at least in this video … because we’re all about the fluidity of modern English, which takes into account all the different types of English spoken in our diverse culture.

Everyone is legitimate and valid in our dictionary (go ahead, go look up firstly, it’s in there).

And, what we really need to conversate about is accepting all the dialects and regionalisms that exist within this here US of A.

Yup, we said conversate.

It’s not just us … a lot of other people have been using conversate since the 2000s, too.

Yes, it has the same function as converse but isn’t that why we have a Thesaurus … because words have synonyms (or other words that have similar meanings).

We bet you think this video is funner then an English class, because it sure is!

And, funner is most definitely a very informal substitute for more fun yet acceptable all the same.

So, now that you’re fuming because we’ve used these nonstandard words in very standard ways … let’s all remember to respect one another, irregardless of grammar rules.

(Come on, we had to throw irregardless in).

bully.name: The Word "Bully" Used To Mean ... "Sweetheart"?!
bully.description: The word bully is first recorded around the mid-1500s, when it actually meant—wait for it—“sweetheart.” What?!
bully.transcript:
Bullies. They push us around on the playground, insult us on Instagram, and make us feel awful at the office.

But, they’re not so tough. Deep down inside we can find gentle souls—or at least in the word bully, we can. [shrug]

A bully might try to run over us like a bull, but the two words are unrelated. The word bully is first recorded around the mid-1500s, when it actually meant—wait for it—“sweetheart.” 

I know, I know, I am as shocked as you are, but it’s true! Bully started out as a term of endearment, like darling or honey, for a person of any gender. It’s thought to come from the Dutch boel [bool], “lover,” which might be a diminutive of broeder [broo-dair], “brother.”

So, how on Earth does bully go from “sweetie pie” to “tough guy?”

Well, in the 1600s, the definition of bully began to narrow in sense to “fine fellow.” A bully-boy was like Shakespeare’s equivalent of our “good guy.”

As we approached the 1700s, the word began to shift even further. Around this time a bully was a “macho man,” then a “pimp” (who protects prostitutes), and “goon” (who is hired to do violence).

We’re not sure exactly why bully took this turn, but these new meanings definitely seemed to stick considering that the current definition has arrived at “a blustering, quarrelsome, overbearing person who habitually badgers and intimidates smaller or weaker people.”

This meaning was established by the 1700s, almost 300 years before cyberbullying, which began in the early 1990s.

The next time someone bullies you, stand up to them with a little etymology and kill em’ with kindness! Or, report them. Yeah … we definitely recommend reporting them to an adult or professional.

single.name: Was "Single" Always A Negative Word?
single.description: The word "single" may seem like a lonely word, but does it just get a bad rap?
single.transcript:
So, I think the word single gets a bad rap.

I’m sure when most people hear single they think of someone being alone or lonely, but I … I don’t think it has to be that way.

To be fair, back in like, the 14th century, if a woman was single, coming from the French sengle, which just meant she was “alone or unmarried or otherwise unengaged.” It was a bad thing. It was something that was looked down upon because women were judged based on whether they were married and who they were married to.

If women chose not to marry, then they were referred to as spinsters? Which is a kind of funny, nasty-sounding, derogatory term that just meant they were women who chose not to be married and were past the age of marrying. Whatever that means.

But, I think that we need to reclaim the word single for our time. Because it is not the 14th century anymore, and nobody has to feel ashamed of not getting married.

I mean, today we can think of single in a positive light. Giving yourself your single, undivided attention, so that you can really show yourself some love. Or, you can think of single as being unique, like “I am a single example of awesomeness in the world.”

You know?

So, the next time you’re feeling down about being single—and trust me, I’ve been there, just remember, it’s not the 14th century, and we do not have to be ashamed if we’re living life sans marriage. You know?

Also, cats make pretty good companions too.

phenomenon.name: Don't Laugh At This Similar Sounding Slip-up
phenomenon.description: Malapropisms are slip-ups we all make ... sometimes you read one word and you just say another. This woman laughs at her unfortunate slip-up in the workplace. We relate!
phenomenon.transcript:
In my defense, those two words look crazy similar.

Here’s the story:

I was in a room with really smart people: scientists, doctors, and somebody saw something on the screen. It said something about a new pneumonia virus going around.

I really wanted to fit in with this group, so I thought I’d start the conversation. So I read the screen.

I was like, “Wow guys, that phenomenae looks really scary.”

They all started laughing, and I didn’t know what I had done wrong, until my sister took me into the other room and told me.

I read the word pneumonia on the screen as phenomenae.

That’s a malapropism: “misusing words ridiculously, especially by the confusion of words that are similar in sound.”

shitfaced.name: The Loaded History Of "Shitfaced"
shitfaced.description: Here's a little-known origin story of one of our most loaded words ...
shitfaced.transcript:
Here’s a little-known origin story of one of our most loaded words …

Long ago, in the 1825 edition of John Jamieson’s Dictionary of the Scottish Language, a little word lived a simple life. It was childlike, innocent, angelic.

It went by the name of shit-faced, and to the Scots, it meant, “having a very small face, as a child, chit-faced.”

Yup, the Scots were fond of calling their children, their friends’ children, children they didn’t even know, “little shits.” Apparently, chit (pronounced like shit) in Scotland means “kitten,” and so children and kittens alike were beautiful little shit-faced beings.

Fast forward to the 1930s across the Atlantic ocean, and shitfaced resurfaces … this time as slang for “drunk” and sometimes “undesirable person.” This is the shitfaced we know today … and it’s not so angelic.

How can this word have meant such vastly different things? There are theories:

Cracked.com: “It’s Scottish law that all children begin drinking at age 4, so there’s that.”

Dictionary.com: “The Scottish version of shitfaced isn’t actually vulgar … it exists but is etymologically unrelated to the American version.”

Person off the street: “When you’re drunk, you act worse than a child.”

But, the fact of the matter is, with shitfaced‘s loaded meaning, the childlike essence of the word is better left in the past.

Don’t call a child a “little shit.”

gesticulate.name: We Asked: Why Do Some People Gesticulate So Much?
gesticulate.description: For this woman, gesticulating helps her access memories and emotions and put them into speech. Why do you gesticulate?
gesticulate.transcript:
I am wearing my cat shirt in honor of today’s story.

I had gotten off work at five o’clock. And, I realized as I’m driving home that my cat is out of food. So I drive over to the pet store, and I walk into the pet store, and I grab the biggest cat food bag that they have when I realized that I had left the coupon at my house. So I get back into my car, drive on back home, grab the coupon off of my dining room table, head to the pet store, grab a big bag of cat food, put it in front of the cashier. At this point, I’m exhausted. But, you know what? My cat ate food, and that’s what matters.

Now, you may have been noticing how much I was just gesticulating just then. My words aren’t enough to express my feelings. So, my hands start to take over to really emphasize my point.

For me, gesticulating helps me access my memories and emotions and put them into speech. It’s like a bridge from my emotional brain to my logical brain. It probably burns a few calories or two.

Just like the whole cat trip, right?

persiflage.name: Better Your Banter With This Playful Term
persiflage.description: Join this conversation: Can you guess what "persiflage" means before the end of this illustration?
persiflage.transcript: Join this conversation: Can you guess what “persiflage” means before the end of this illustration?

flexitarian.name: You’re Not A Picky Eater, You’re Just A Flexitarian
flexitarian.description: Isn't it funny that we have our own word now? We're not carnivores, we're not vegetarians or vegans, we're not pescatarians, we're flexitarians ... and it sounds so fancy!
flexitarian.transcript:
I recently found out I’m a flexitarian. Don’t know what that is, I didn’t either … but it’s basically a word for the “rest of us.” You know, people who eat vegetarian most of the time because health, money, animals, big corporations … but eat meat every once in a while at a nice place, or on payday.

But you have to admit, it’s funny that we have our own word now? We’re not carnivores, we’re not vegetarians or vegans, we’re not pescatarians, we’re flexitarians … and it sounds so fancy!

And, the word is way smoother than lowmaintancetarian and much easier to say than everyoneelsetarian.

So flexitarian I am, which got me thinking … if I’m not too heavy of a drinker, but also not sober, does that make me a partakitarian?

Everyone knows I’m not a gym rat, but I’m not totally comatose, so maybe I could be a strollitarian?

Ok, maybe those words haven’t made it into the dictionary yet … but we’re guessing words for the “rest of us” will be popping up more and more. Because who wants to live in a world without an abundance of words for your own personal adjective piggy bank?

Drabitarians … that’s who.

frisson.name: Have You Ever Felt A Frisson?
frisson.description: A frisson is "a sudden feeling or sensation of excitement, emotion, or thrill." What's made you experience this feeling?
frisson.transcript:
What’s that?

[laughing]

Oh my gosh. Ah, hey everyone!

Meet my best friend, Buster. Say hi, Buster!

[pretending to be Buster] Hi, guys!

Do you remember the first time you cried at a movie theater?

‘Cause I do.

I was nine-years-old, and I was getting ready to watch the hottest new Will Smith movie: I Am Legend.

Do you remember that one?

Now, spoiler alert: Smith’s character, Robert Neville, fights apocalyptic, zombie-like mutants in New York City alongside his best friend, Sam.

Sam is a beautiful, wonderfully loyal German shepherd that’s been by Robert’s side throughout this whole dystopian storyline.

So much so that, after a while, I started to look at Sam as if she were my own dog.

At a certain point in the movie, Robert and Sam are fighting a pack of mutant dogs.

And … Sam gets bitten.

In that moment, and the minutes thereafter, I felt a … a frisson.

A frisson is “a sudden feeling or sensation of excitement, emotion, or thrill.”

Frisson can be used in a variety of contexts to describe that jolt of happiness, tenseness, drama, or thrill.

Or, in nine-year-old me’s case, the anxiety of whether or not Sam was going to die.

Hey Buster, if we were in a zombie apocalypse and we had to fight off a horde of zombie dogs, you’d … you’d protect me, right?

facade.name: How Do You Pronounce Facade?
facade.description: One man gives us the story of how his coworker pronounced facade ... and how he courteously had to tell him that he was wrong.
facade.transcript:
One man gives us the story of how his coworker pronounced facade … and how he courteously had to tell him that he was wrong.

And he looks me right in the eye, and he goes… “It’s [fuh-kah-day] isn’t it?”

I’m a recording engineer, and about ten years ago we had this young writer in the studio and we were recording this radio script. I don’t remember what the product was, but we had about a half a dozen people in the room with us, and the voice over artist was in the booth on the mic, and we run through the script and she did a pretty good job on it.

And the writer reaches over, and he hits the “talkback button,” and he goes, “Facade?” “It’s [fuh-kah-day].”

And everybody starts laughing thinking he’s cracked a joke. And I turn to look at him, and he looks me right in the eye, and he goes … “It’s [fuh-kah-day] isn’t it?”

And the room got very quiet. I didn’t know what to say, so I go, “Well, maybe they say it like that in some parts of the country, but here I’ve only ever heard facade.”

It’s ok. We all say words wrong. It didn’t seem to hurt his career at all because I just read last week that he’s now the chief creative officer at a at a mid-sized agency in Chicago.

sunken.name: How This Horror Movie Term Became A Real Life Metaphor
sunken.description: How did the fictional term "sunken place" become an actual term that the black community uses in real life?
sunken.transcript:
In the film, Get Out, the sunken place can be described as this trans-like state of mind that black victims of hypnosis are put under when their bodies are taken over by white hosts. But, in real life the sunken place can be used to describe the feelings of helplessness and subjugation that black people experience on a day-to-day basis.

Does institutionalized and systemic racism ring a bell?

And, now? The sunken place is no other than a meme that features photos or written examples of black people showing coerced deference to white people along with a quote from the movie: “Now you’re in the sunken place.” Jordan Peele produced a notable example himself …

You’re probably wondering why the black community has really taken on to the concept of the sunken place.

It’s a way to describe a lot of things we experience all the time. When we’re told to just ignore racism, and when people tell us that they don’t see color, the sunken place is a way to laugh a little bit and just connect over an issue that a lot of us experience.

And, quite frankly, it’s a way to remind ourselves that if we don’t stay sharp, we might end up in the sunken place.

bardolatry.name: This Word Of The Day Fan Explains Bardolatry
bardolatry.description: We asked this Word of the Day fan to explain his "bardolatry." Do you know as much about this word as he does?
bardolatry.transcript:
To be, or not to be; that is the question.

Some people may know that this famous line comes from the play Hamlet, written around 1600, by one of, if not the most famous playwrights in the history of playwrights, William Shakespeare.

Now, I don’t know about you, but William Shakespeare …

… is my man crush.

Like, I’m obsessed with him. Some would even say, my bardolatry is “as boundless as the sea.”

Bardolatry is described as a “great or excessive adoration of or for William Shakespeare.”

The word itself is the sum of two parts: bard and (o)-latry. Bard, of course, comes from Shakespeare’s designation as “The Bard of Avon” and “(o)-latry” is a suffix that means “the worship of,” like in idolatry.

The word was coined in 1901 by a playwright many consider second only to Shakespeare himself, George Bernard Shaw in the preface to his Three Plays for Puritans, where, Shaw uses bardolatry, ironically enough, to criticize Shakespeare’s followers, essentially saying the Bard is overrated and his supposed “fans” were misrepresenting his plays.

Everyone, I present to you George Bernard Shaw, unapologetic critic of Shakespeare, unintentional coiner of his worship.

The love and adoration for Shakespeare and his plays knows no bounds—no matter what cranky, ol’ Shaw may have thought. And as we celebrate the life and work of the Bard, let’s be sure to display our bardolatry proudly.

fashion.name: Bendy Redefines Eco-Fashion
fashion.description: Products like the Bendy show that eco-fashion can be more than just an expensive ideal. Now, you can choose products that look and feel great while being kinder and gentler on the planet. Watch more to find out how.
fashion.transcript:
Some people say that fashion defines you; it can be a statement about who you are. Your style choices show self-expression and allow creative exploration. And with the rise of eco-fashion, your clothes and shoes can make a statement about your personal values, too.

 

Products like the Bendy show that eco-fashion can be more than just an expensive ideal. Now, you can choose products that look and feel great while being kinder and gentler on the planet. Because for the Bendy team, they’re determined to rethink fast-fashion in an accessible and affordable and modern way. Buy now at early-bird pricing here.

 

But, how do you define eco-fashion? If you’re thinking hemp, ponchos, itchy fabrics, lots of grey, and earthy shoes—think again.

 

Eco-fashion is actually pretty simple: It’s the philosophy that fashion should be sustainable and ethical. It emphasizes consideration for the environment and the health of the people making the product. And now, modern brands are intrigued. They’re even redefining what eco-fashion means: trendy, colorful, comfortable, and accessible.

 

Look at the Bendy Shoe. It’s a sneaker flat made ethically in the US with significantly less C02 emissions than an average sneaker. It’s created from four simple components: a flexible bottom, soft leather, thread, and a cushioned footbed. Plus, the shoemakers in Los Angeles are treated fairly and work in safe conditions.

 

Redefining eco-fashion is a fashionable step toward making a difference.

drama-queen.name: Women: Stop Saying These Words
drama-queen.description: When we asked this woman what words she thought women should stop saying, she responded in rhyme. Watch to hear more about her views on these two phrases that convey unintentional gender bias.
drama-queen.transcript:
When we asked this woman what words she thought women should stop saying, she responded in rhyme. Watch to hear more about her views on these two phrases that convey unintentional gender bias.

There are words used by all of us

that convey an unintentional gender bias.

One of these is attention whore,

something we probably shouldn’t say anymore.

Because, see, attention is a human need.

Don’t believe me? Scroll your Instagram feed.

Guys, girls, selfies at the gym.

Be like her. Look like him.

When women do it,

we’re the needy, fame-seeking ones.

But when the guys from Jackass do it?

Well, that’s just for fun.

Next up: drama queen.

This one’s actually kinda mean.

It refers to a woman acting “psycho,”

not her best, but the truth is

guys break down too.

Kanye West?

What’s worse is this phrase ends dialogue

sending emotions into a dramatic fog.

“You’re such a drama queen,” makes me feel

crazy … absurd …

versus, “You’re experiencing a lot right now,”

which says, “You’re seen. You’re heard.”

So let’s bury the drama queen deep in her grave.

By talking instead of name-calling

it could be a life you save.

When people express, they may cry or wail,

and that’s ok, whether you’re male or female.

undulate.name: What Do "Undulate" And Flag Day Have In Common?
undulate.description: Waves undulate, flags undulate ... and in this video both of those meanings work together to create the perfect image. Watch our favorite Word of the Day illustrator bring the word to life.
undulate.transcript: Waves undulate, flags undulate … and in this video both of those meanings work together to create the perfect image.

ghost-word.name: What Scares A Dictionary? Ghost Words!
ghost-word.description: Ghost words haunt dictionaries like ours because they came into existence by error like a mistaken reading of a manuscript, a scribal error, or a misprint ... eerie.
ghost-word.transcript:
Have you ever heard of the term ghost word?

Well, they are little words that haunt dictionaries like ours because they came into existence by error like a mistaken reading of a manuscript, a scribal error, or a misprint.

Basically, someone somewhere tossed out a word in error, and it didn’t really look like a typo, so it rolled by many a copyeditor without anyone flagging it.

You know, before you know it, the ghost word becomes a word!

Phantomnation appeared in the 1864 edition of Webster’s. They called it a rare word meaning “‘the appearance of a phantom, illusion,” and attributed it to the poet Alexander Pope in his translation of The Odyssey, which contained the line “all the phantom nations of the dead.”

Then, there’s syllabus. 

A Roman philosopher Cicero, who died in 43 BC, wrote two “Letters to Atticus,” and they contained the word sittybas (or maybe sittubas). There’s some debate on that. This was a Greek word meaning a “label for a papyrus roll.” However, it’s suspected that one printing of this work misspelled it as syllabus. The spelling stuck, and so it began to also mean “a label for a papyrus roll.”

Maybe these ghost words don’t get a lot of use (or maybe they’ve taken on whole new meanings), but they’re still out there floating in the ether, waiting for their next opportunity to haunt those poor original dictionary editors who didn’t have the internet or spellcheck.

anachronism.name: What Are Some Examples Of Anachronism?
anachronism.description: For as realistic as they try to be, movies are rife with anachronisms. Here are a few examples ...
anachronism.transcript:
Going to a Renaissance Faire is always a good time. Not only do you have the ability to drink mead and watch knights joust in real time, but you can pat yourself on the back for being able to walk through an anachronism.

An anachronism is “something or someone that’s completely misplaced chronologically- or historically-speaking.” Recorded in English by the mid-1600s, anachronism ultimately comes from a Greek word made up of the roots, ana– [ah-nah], meaning “backwards,” and chronos [kroh-nohs], meaning “time.” So, anachronism literally means “referring to the wrong time.”

For as realistic as they try to be, movies are rife with anachronisms. You know the kilts Mel Gibson sported in Braveheart? They didn’t come about until centuries after William Wallace fought the English in the late 1200s. But hey, even the great Shakespeare was guilty of anachronisms. In his Julius Caesar, Brutus mentions clocks, but it would be well over another 1,000 years until that 1st-century a.d. backstabber could have told time using one. 

The word anachronism isn’t just about getting history wrong by placing things from the future in the past. In today’s day-and-age, people can willingly partake in some pretty obvious anachronisms in the name of fun. Going to the Renaissance Faire is certainly an example; then there are all those jazz festivals that are strictly set in the 1920s were people can dress in flapper fashion and dance the Charleston. If these were all set in 1923, it’d be current and appropriate. Now? All anachronisms.

Then there are the less obvious anachronism. The record and cassette players someone can purchase at trendy fashion outlets? Anachronisms. CDs? Anachronisms. Even DVD players.

So, maybe it’s a little weird that old technologies seem to come back in style again after becoming anachronistic. But hey, why not take some enjoyment in the past while being in the present? Everything becomes an anachronism at one point; might as well appreciate the old while ringing in the new!

tapas.name: How Are Tapas Different In Spain?
tapas.description: Yair and Mara are from Spain, but they currently live in America. When they went back to visit family and friends, we asked them to explain how tapas are different in Spain.
tapas.transcript:
Yair and Mara are from Spain, but they currently live in America. When they went back to visit family and friends, we asked them to explain how tapas are different in Spain.

In the US, tapas are small plates, typically shared among the table. But, in Spain tapas are served with drinks and can be free. They can also be called pinchos or raciones, depending on what area of Spain you are in.

Watch Yair and Mara explain the differences while they explore Valencia on one of their night’s out. Don’t be too jealous … flights aren’t that expensive right?

read.name: Why Is The Word "Read" In Read Receipts So Terrifying?
read.transcript:
Read receipt (real definition) = tells someone the recipient of a text message has opened the message and has viewed it, typically by showing the word “read” under the message.

Read receipt (emo defintion) = scary, anxiety-inducing caption to your message, typically because it showed you the word “read” with a timestamp under your message … and the recipient hasn’t responded.

Read receipt (new definition) = not that bad. What’s really so scary about the little word “read”? It’s a simple word with a simple meaning.

read means good to go

read means open

read means honest

read doesn’t mean ghosting

read doesn’t mean ignoring

Read is simple … and what’s wrong with that?

nice.name: What's So Wrong With "Nice"?
nice.description: Why does the word "nice" rub us the wrong way? Why don't people want to date the nice guy? What's so wrong with nice? Doesn't every mom wish you would meet a nice guy?
nice.transcript:
Why does the word nice rub us the wrong way? Why don’t people want to date the nice guy? What’s so wrong with nice? Doesn’t every mom wish you would meet a nice guy?

Well, we recently found out nice used to be a negative—derived from the Latin word nescius meaning “ignorant.” And, in the 14th century, it was used to refer to a stupid, ignorant, or foolish person.

Ok, so you really didn’t want to be the nice guy back then. Hey mom, here’s my new stupid boyfriend …

However, by the 15th century, it started to refer to a person who was finely dressed, shy or reserved, or precise.

Kind of vague, but maybe nice was getting nicer?

Is that the reason why people don’t want to date the nice guy and why you don’t want to be just the nice guy? Because it started out describing stupid idiots … great. And, then it was used for generic, plain, people nobody remembers … even better. And now, it’s ended up as a synonym for okay and obliging (yes we found that on Thesaurus.com).

Yup, that’s exactly why … but just because we don’t want to be nice anymore, doesn’t make us mean.

k-pop.name: How K-pop Is Brilliantly Using Language
k-pop.description: Dictionary.com is announcing our alliance with the BTS ARMY ... we freaking love k-pop.
k-pop.transcript: Dictionary.com is announcing our alliance with the BTS ARMY … we freaking love k-pop.

wanderlust.name: Travel Words For People With Wanderlust
wanderlust.description: No rest for the weary? Ha! It should be no rest for the wanderlust because it's exhausting preparing for a trip.
wanderlust.transcript:
No rest for the weary? Ha! It should be no rest for the wanderlust because it’s exhausting preparing for a trip.

 

The Swedes may call it resfeber but here in the US we call it jitters. 

 

How about the airport security lines … with kids? Or, trying to eat a healthy lunch at the nearest food court? By the time we’re volant we’re ready for the stress of traveling to be over. Landing isn’t much better—now we get to find our baggage in a new city!

 

But, when that numinous feeling finally hits us as we arrive at our nirvana … we remember why we put up with all the travel. Ahh, six days of peace before we do it all over again.

pet.name: For The Love Of Pets: These Quotes Are Pretty Purrfect
pet.transcript:
We all love our pets, they don’t judge us, they always listen, and they’re the best at cuddling. These quotes will remind you of all that and more about your four-legged furry friends.

Want to read or listen to the books these quotes came from? Check them out below:

  • The Portable Atheist: Essential Readings for the Nonbeliever
  • Marley and Me: Life and Love With the World’s Worst Dog
  • My Name is Red
  • A Big Little Life: A Memoir of a Joyful Dog
  • “My Cats” from The Pleasure of the Damned
  • Love Is the Best Medicine: What Two Dogs Taught One Veterinarian about Hope, Humility, and Everyday Miracles

And, don’t forget the song we featured: “Martha My Dear.”

jail.name: What Is The Difference Between "Jail" And "Prison"?
jail.description: Would you rather go to jail or prison? We'll help you with this hypothetical decision, don't worry!
jail.transcript:
Would you rather go to jail or prison?

Same difference, right? Well, not exactly …

Jail is a very physical, very real place, which probably has to do with where the word comes from. Its Latin root, cavea, means “hollow,” “cavity,” or even “birdcage”—all indications of a place that something (or an unfortunate someone) can physically be put into.

Over time, it transformed into the Middle English jaile and finally formed into the American term we all know and don’t-really-love, jail.

Fun fact time: The British traditionally spell it “G-A-O-L,” probably stemming from the G-based gaile and gaiole, which were found in manuscripts dating all the way back to 1225. And … that’s where jail stops being interesting.  

Prison, on the other hand, doesn’t necessarily have to be a place. It comes from the Latin prehensiō, or “laying a hold of.”

By the early 12th century, it developed into the Old French prisoun, meaning “captivity.” But think about it—captivity doesn’t necessarily mean a physical place: you can be a prisoner in a basement, by stuck watching an awful movie, or in your own mind.  So … a jail is a prison, but a prison is not a jail. Get it?

So … which would you rather: jail or prison? Friendly reminder: It’s called a “Get out of Jail Free”card, for a reason.

prison.name: What Is The Difference Between "Jail" And "Prison"?
prison.description: Would you rather go to jail or prison? We'll help you with this hypothetical decision, don't worry!
prison.transcript:

Same difference, right? Well, not exactly …

Jail is a very physical, very real place, which probably has to do with where the word comes from. Its Latin root, cavea, means “hollow,” “cavity,” or even “birdcage”—all indications of a place that something (or an unfortunate someone) can physically be put into.

Prison, on the other hand, doesn’t necessarily have to be a place. It comes from the Latin prehensiō, or “laying a hold of.”

By the early 12th century, it developed into the Old French prisoun, meaning “captivity.” But think about it—captivity doesn’t necessarily mean a physical place: you can be a prisoner in a basement, by stuck watching an awful movie, or in your own mind.  So … a jail is a prison, but a prison is not a jail. president.name: Quotes That Show How Our Greatest US Presidents Coined Some Of Our Most Common Words
president.transcript: From George Washington to Abraham Lincoln to Franklin D. Roosevelt, our greatest presidents weren’t just great rulers, they were also top-notch innovators. Here’s a small list of common words we use today that were actually coined by our late great presidents. Hey, we voted them in … they can say what they want.

moribund.name: Moribund: Visual Word of the Day
moribund.description: Learn more about this Word of the Day here.
moribund.transcript: Learn more about this Word of the Day here.

shut--up.name: How Shut Up Became So Mean
shut--up.transcript:
Shut up began as a verb phrase meaning “to secure something away in a receptacle.” Shut it up! By the 1500s, it meant “to confine someone,” “to close a door or window,” or “to bring to a conclusion.” Creepy … Then Jane Austen and Charles Dickens came around, and they used it a bit more rudely. (Kind of like how this guy used it, too.)

It’s an angry-sounding command.

But when it’s not directed at you, maybe it doesn’t seem that bad. We do feel for that teacher though.

However, most people view it as a mean, uncompassionate dismissal … no matter at whom it’s directed. Some phrases, words … and people are mean. No judgment, people change, phrases evolve.

“Shut up” lost its actionable quality back in the 1500s. And now, no matter how many times you use, shout, or scream, “SHUT UP,” most people won’t. We won’t … (And neither will Lebron. Yup, we just compared ourselves to Lebron.)

Lesson? Save your voice for a better word choice.

-tis.name: 'Tis the Season To Learn More About 'Tis

opposite.name: Common Words With Uncommon Opposites
opposite.description: As we all know every lone sock has a long-lost twin, some words we use every day also have pairs that we just forgot about. Here are some of the English language’s best uncommon opposites.
opposite.transcript:
Like mismatched socks …

As we all know every lone sock has a long-lost twin, some words we use every day also have pairs that we just forgot about. Here are some of the English language’s best uncommon opposites.

Do you want to learn more? Find out the details on these forgotten pairs.

insight.name: We Asked: Do You Like The Word "Insight"?
insight.description: I love the word "insight." But, the thing about it, it’s so overused in the corporate world.
insight.transcript:
I love the word insight. But, the thing about it, it’s so overused in the corporate world.

You hear things like, ”I need to pull insight on that XYZ project.” Or, “What is your insight on Jerry’s proposal?”

But, the thing about insight is it’s actually Scandinavian in origin, and it stems from all the way back to the 13th century. The actual meaning of insight is, ”the act or result of apprehending the inner nature of things.”

See, insight is about going deep down into the insides and getting inside of things. It’s nothing superficial like how the corporate world uses it.

As a transformational coach, I give my clients tools and exercises so that they may gain insight into their authentic, true selves. See, once you gain insight on who you really are and the root of the problems you can solve them. See, that’s way deeper than some corporate mumbo jumbo.

No, no. No, no, no, corporate world, insight is ours, not yours.

celebrity.name: Celebrity Names We Are All Pronouncing Wrong
celebrity.description: Here’s an A–Z guide to making those hard-to-pronounce names roll off the tongue like …”Will Smith.”
celebrity.transcript:
Say these names out loud. If you said, “SAY-or-see”, “Ree-AH-nuh,” “EE-va,” and/or any combination of “Buh-SHEE-mee,” “BOO-shuh-mee” or “Boo-‘scheme’-ee,” get out! No, no, just kidding, you definitely need to stay … because, unfortunately, you are butchering the exquisite pronunciation of these celebrity names. Here’s an A–Z guide to making those hard-to-pronounce names roll off the tongue like …”Will Smith.”

Stop saying: SEE-free-d, start saying: “SIGH-frid”

Stop saying: CARE-uh Dee-lee-VING-nee (this is horribly wrong). Start saying: CAR-uh Del-uh-veen. The British supermodel was born in London but her last name (from her father) is French. Très chic. Stop saying: Chee-WEE-tell EDGE-ee-oafer. Start saying: CHEW-ih-tell Edge-EE-uh-for

The star of 12 Years a Slave has always had to correct people’s pronunciation of his name. One of his nicknames at school was “Duracell” — Chiwetel says it was a fun “on-purpose” mispronunciation.

KLO-ee, isn’t the culprit here. But for the last name … Stop saying: Suh-VAY-nee, start saying: Sev-uh-nee. 

Stop saying: TEE-gehn. Start saying: TIE-gehn

Stop saying: Oh-yee-loh-woo. Start saying: Oh-YEH-luh-whoa. Anyone who plays the role of Martin Luther King, Jr. (in the 2014 film Selma) deserves accurate pronunciation.

Stop saying: Dom-nall. Stop trying to be fancy: Dom-HH-nall, Dom-HHUH-nuhl. Start saying: DOH-nuhl. 

Stop saying: Guh-DOUGH. Start saying: Guh-DOT. Translated from Hebrew (Gal is Israeli), the actresses’s full name means “wave riverbanks.” So basically Gal is both Wonder Woman and Mother Nature, and she’s kind of the most powerful woman on earth.

Stop saying: “the actor from 12 Years a Slave,” “the actor from Black Panther.” Start saying: Loo-peet-ah nYON-go. With an international pedigree, the movie star (and also People Magazine’s Most Beautiful Person in 2014) anticipated people would stumble over her Mexican-Kenyan name. The name “Lupita” pays tribute to the actress’s birthplace in Mexico City, Mexico. Her last name comes from her Kenyan parents.

Stop saying: Wah-sih-COW-skee. Start saying: MEE-uh VAH-shee-KOF-ska or Vash-KOV-ska. Mia’s name can be pronounced a couple ways: either with correct Polish articulation of each syllable (VAH-shee-KOF-ska) or with “fake-it” Polish fluency condensing four syllables to three (Vash-KOV-ska).

Stop saying: Say-OR-see, See-OR-say. Start saying: SIR-shuh Roh-nun. It’s not “sheesha,” “see-saw,” “say or see,” or “see or say.” It’s SIR-shuh. The star of Lady Bird is kin to Domhnall Gleeson in that her name is also Irish and also has letter combinations that make no sense in English. Saiorse means “freedom” FYI.

Stop saying: Buh-SHEEM-ee, start saying: Boo-SEM-ee. In a comedy show interview, Steve Buscemi appreciated being introduced correctly (“Boo-SEM-ee”), but he also admitted Boo-SHEM-ee works, too. 

Maybe not exactly stop saying: TIM-uh-thee. Definitely stop saying: Cha-luh-MEHT (for shame!). Start saying: Timo-TAY Sha-luh-MAY. Ok, is it TIM-uh-thee or Timo-TAY? Don’t get your briefs in a bunch over this one. Both pronunciations are correct, according to the Beautiful Boy actor. 

Stop saying: Zoh-sha (but, hang on a sec) or Zoh-see-uh, or Mam-EH. Start saying: ZA-sha MAM-eht.

minimoon.name: Why Are People Taking "Minimoons"?
minimoon.description: This Word Of The Day inspired one poet to rhyme about "minimoons" ... and why sometimes they are a better (and fun) choice after a costly wedding.
minimoon.transcript:
Let me take you on a little trip

Just a short one, here and back.

A minimoon to be exact.

This vacation is for the lovers

recently joined in matrimonial bliss.

You just spent a small fortune on

a dress, a bustle?

What even is this?

Despite the feels from your fresh

post-wedding glow,

you’re bummed!

Because a honeymoon is something you’ll have to forgo.

The thousands you dropped on mini-cakes for your theme: Lilipution.

Married friends, I have a solution.

MINIMOON.

A low-key way to celebrate your union.

Not fancy, but better than wine and a bag of Funyons.
