(Mmm. It’s actually pretty good.)

You can still Eat Pray Love like Julia Roberts

AND keep it all within a budget!

Choose a destination that’s fun but local.

And when it comes to time off

make sure to be vocal

with work, friends, and fam

that this is still a couples retreat.

In other words, SCRAM.

Try a new restaurant while you’re away

or take in the park, a museum, a zoo for a day.

There’s no need to break the bank or sell your spleen,

a minimoon is a very sweet in between

rhubarb.name: How Is "Rhubarb" Used In Baseball?
rhubarb.description: He's back ... our favorite Word of the Day fan helps explain how the word "rhubarb" is used in baseball.
rhubarb.transcript:
All right, everyone, where are my baseball fans? Some of you enthusiasts may already know this term in this context.

Today’s Word of the Day is rhubarb.

 

Not this kind of rhubarb. This definition isn’t nearly as tasty.

 

Like I alluded to, this version of rhubarb comes from that great American pastime, baseball.

 

Its official definition, taken from Dictionary.com, is “a quarrel or squabble.”

Historically in the sport of baseball, a rhubarb is a dispute, especially between players or coaches with umpires. Why this plant and popular pie ingredient was so used for “an argument” isn’t known, exactly, but it was popularized by the famous sports commentator Red Barber in the 1940s.  Let’s see this in action.

 

Allow me to set the stage.

May 30th, 1988. The New York Yankees are facing the Oakland Athletics.

Athletics’ player Walt Weiss hits a line drive to the Yankees second baseman, who catches the ball and chooses not to throw it to first base, as it’s an obvious out.

Or so he thought.

The second base umpire decides to call Walt Weiss safe, which not only riles the crowd, but brings Yankees’ manager Billy Martin out to the field to dispute the call.

This, my friends, is what you call a classic rhubarb.

 

Thank you for watching, and I’ll see you logophiles later.

sorry.name: When You Should Not Say Sorry
sorry.description: Sometimes saying sorry isn't the right thing to do ... just ask "the apologizer."
sorry.transcript:
(Mic’s in the shot.)

Oh, sorry.

Have you ever been told that you say sorry too much?

Yeah, me too.

Usually women are accused of apologizing often and according to some, too often. We don’t think that that’s strictly a female characteristic anymore.

TV shows and movies have shown us that men, women, and even robots, looking at you C3P0, have often fallen victim to the role of the apologizer. Because once you start saying sorry, it’s too hard to stop.

“I’m so sorry, I…”

“I’m sorry.”

“I’m sorry, Dave.”

“I’m terribly sorry about all this.”

“I’m sorry.”

“I’m sorry to everyone.”

“I’m sorry, Wilson.”

Being an apologizer is an easy way to hide. It’s a defense mechanism against rejection and conflict.

But, it’s a negative word, and using it too often puts the negative light on you instead of the situation you’re trying to hide from.

(Cut.)

Oh, sorry.

Don’t be like me. Don’t apologize for things you can’t control or for making others uncomfortable. Instead, save your sorrys for the real problems … like finishing the last glass of wine, or eating the last piece of pizza, or cuddling with your dog over your partner. It would mean so much more.

(I’m sorry, we need to do it again.)

Ok, sorry.

cosplay.name: "Cosplay": It's Not Just For Halloween
cosplay.description: Cosplay: The internet is full of it, there's no shortage, but that's the beauty of it is that everybody has a voice in that who wants to. How have you participated in "cosplay"?
cosplay.transcript:
What is the deal with cosplay?

What is cosplay? Well, I don’t know.

Is it a yearlong invitation to Halloween? Is it the greatest outlet for nerd creativity? Is it just a way to homage to your favorite storytellers, actors, and creators?

I mean, it’s really all of those things. It’s a culture. The internet is full of it, there’s no shortage, but that’s the beauty of it is that everybody has a voice in that who wants to.

One of my favorite cosplays that I ever did was … For my birthday, I took myself over to Ireland, a return visit to the Emerald Isle, for the Bram Stoker Festival.

I’ve had this piece for a while and had purchased it with the intent of using it for a costume and I thought it was the perfect opportunity so I got the robe, this yellow hands, a hag nose, a bald cap, and just enough Simpsons yellow paint to pull it off and I went as Burns Dracula from Treehouse of Horrors. Oh snap!

Which I thought was perfect and some people got it. Some people were like, “Oh, you kind of look like Gary Oldman.” I was like, “Does nobody care about The Simpsons?”

But that’s the thing, it’s like the obscurity is almost reveled in with cosplay.

It’s like you have people who are just diving into like the most succinct, like the most specific sort of characters, inside jokes, allusion, you know, within the world of their fandom that they celebrate.

It’s a manner of being able to speak into your experience and share in your nerdom with friends and express your creativity. It’s beautiful.

Now everybody, get up to date on Burns Dracula already.

zigzag.name: We Asked: The Hardest Words You Have To Explain To Kids
zigzag.description: Some words don't seem very complicated or unique ... until you have to explain them to your kid. This father gives us insight into a word he had to explain to his three-year-old, and it wasn't easy!
zigzag.transcript:
Some words don’t seem very complicated or unique … until you have to explain them to your kid. This father gives us insight into a word he had to explain to his three-year-old, and it wasn’t easy!

One of the hardest words I ever had to teach my three-year-old son was zig-zag.

The other night before bedtime we’re playing with Duplo Blocks, and I start building a tower out of the smaller blocks, and I’m just zig-zagging them back and forth.

And, you can’t get this too high because it’s not very stable. And before you know it, it fell down. And then, he got excited. He wanted to build a tower out of zig-zag blocks.

The problem was he didn’t understand what zig-zagging meant.

He was building things with staircases in it, and all kinds of different shapes, but it wasn’t zig-zagging.

I couldn’t figure out how to tell him what it meant.

Then, I remembered that one of his favorite books is Little Green. And, in Little Green is the story of a hummingbird in the garden, and the hummingbird is flying up and flying down, and towards you and away, and zig-zagging from flower to flower.

So, once I re-read that story to him he understood what zig-zagging was supposed to be, and he was finally able to build his own little tower.

And he did a really great job on it too … but it wasn’t as tall as my tower.

date.name: These Words Describe The Many Feelings We've All Had About A First Date
date.description: No matter if we're feeling apprehensive or eager ... first dates are intimidating. Why though?
date.transcript:
We’ve all been there … the hours, minutes, seconds before a first date!

No matter if we’re feeling apprehensive or eager … first dates are intimidating.

Why though?

Well, the unknown certainly plays a part … will we jibe, be cohesive, be in sync?

Or, will we fall flat, have awkward silences, feel blase?

And just because the date is over, it doesn’t mean we feel any more at ease, right?

Should I call? What did that text mean?

We’re agitated … that means excited, yet disturbed. Help!

Listen … whether it works out or not, whether trips are taken, whether intimate conversations are shared, or even whether break ups occur), don’t jump ahead, stay in the moment.

Because first dates are just that … the first chance to get to know someone and decide whether they deserve a second chance … or whether you need to change up the wording in your dating profile, because that date was unpleasant.

indecisiveness.name: This Couple Explains Why Indecisiveness Is A Common Pet Peeve
indecisiveness.description: All couples have fights. But are most of them just caused by indecisiveness? Let this couple explain ...
indecisiveness.transcript:
[A couple sits together on a couch. One of them is texting while the other looks slightly miffed.]

Partner #1: Are you looking up places to go still?

Partner #2: [not looking up from phone] Yup.

Partner #1: Have you decided yet?

Partner #2 [sighs] I still don’t know whether I want to Mexican or Mexican-Thai fusion.

Partner #1: [groans] You’ve been going at this for an hour, I’m so hungry. In fact, I’m hangry and I have to say, your indecisiveness is one of my biggest pet peeves.

Partner #2: And your impatience is one of mine. Besides, I’m not indecisive, just picky.

Partner #1: Well let’s just see what Dictionary.com has to say about that. [types in phone] The exact definition of indecisiveness is “characterized by indecision, as persons; irresolute; undecided.” There’s two others, but I’ve decided to go with one that best fits you. It’s actually been defined that way since the 1700s, so even back then they were able to decide on things.

Partner #2: [still looking at phone] Sheesh, why is it such a big deal?

Partner #1: Because it shows a lack of direction or initiative; because it wastes time and energy; because it severely drops the blood sugar level of someone you care about dearly.

Partner #2: [perks up at phone screen] Okay, I think the winner is Mexican!

Partner #1: Thank GOD!

Partner #2: Just let me check Yelp real quick…

Partner #1: [groans and face palms]

clout.name: How The Word "Clout" Took Over The Internet
clout.description: Today, the slang "clout" is like a mix of popularity and power on social media. So, what does it mean?
clout.transcript:
It might seem hard to believe, but Kylie Jenner and Donald Trump actually have a lot in in common.

For one thing, neither are self-made [emphasize self-made and lean in to camera] billionaires. We kid, we kid. For another, they both have clout. They both have a great deal of “influence.”

Today, the slang clout is like a mix of popularity and power on social media. If Kylie Jenner posts a pic of herself wearing, say, a pink mini-dress, you better believe her millions of followers going to want it. She’s an influencer.

Trump also wields a lot of power online, but he’s, well, the president. His clout calls backs to an earlier sense of clout that specifically referred to “political influence.”

The political clout has been found in the 1860s. It packs a punch—literally. The slang is thought to come from an older clout, found in the 14th century, meaning “a heavy blow.” Having clout, then, is like being a heavy hitter.

If we go back even earlier to Old English, clout was a mere rag, like a scrap of cloth or other material. That’s a far cry from Jenner’s dresses. Perhaps the “punch” sense of clout comes from some idea of a “lump” of something?

Whatever the case, fashion may have helped bring clout into the slang of the 2010s. In a 2017, rapper Denzel Curry dubbed a pair of white, round sunglasses—the same kind grunge legend Kurt Cobain donned in the 1990s—Clout Goggles in a YouTube video. (show clip of video- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OsWy5X9xIEk)

Curry, and other rappers wearing the sunglasses, has cred. He has swag. And, after his clip, everyone just had to have a pair of the shades. [Puts on pair of similar glasses]. What can I say? The man has clout.

prismatic.name: Capture The Whole Rainbow In Just One Word
prismatic.description: This brilliantly colorful word is a must have when describing all things rainbows, butterflies, and unicorns. You're welcome.

quinceanera.name: Quinceaneras: More Than Just A Pretty Dress
quinceanera.description: Sure, some quinceaneras can get over-the-top, but that’s not the point of the ceremony. There’s a lot more to it ...
quinceanera.transcript:
When people talk about a quinceanera, they think a lot of glittery dresses and young kids rolling in big cars, basically over-the-top. And sure, some quinceaneras can get over-the-top, but that’s not the point of the ceremony. There’s a lot more to it …

To start, a quinceanera doesn’t actually refer to to the party the way everyone thinks it does (that’s actually called a fiesta de quinceanera). A quinceanera is the girl who the party is for, and it literally means “fifteenth year,” referring to the age which symbolizes a girl’s entry into adulthood and the responsibilities that come with it.

Then, there’s the dress, which is called el vestido de quinceanera, and it’s the way the quinceanera greets adulthood. At the start of the day, the quinceanera wears las zapatillas—flat shoes—and holds los ramos, a bouquet of flowers. It’s all very refined and mature, qualities a young lady should maintain.

The tiara (la corona) usually doesn’t come until la misa (mass), where the priest presents it to the quinceanera during the ceremony. She is flanked by her madrinas and padrinos, an older man and woman who serve as patrons of the quinceanera. Being crowned in church with so many people present shows you have a duty to those other than yourself.   

If a family comes from Mexico, it’s also tradition for the quinceanera to choose a group of friends who will stay close the whole night—the corte de honor consisting of damas and chambelanes. These are people who are trusted and loved enough by the quinceanera that she trusts and who will be on the journey with her to the next stage of her life. One of them is the chambelán de honor, the number one escort who will change the quinceanera’s zapatillas to los zapatos de taco alto (high-heeled shoes) during a ceremony that is known as “The Changing of the Shoes,” for real.

This, and her receipt of la muneca—”The Last Doll”—officially symbolize her transformation from a girl to a woman.

Everything moves at the end of the night: the people when they dance during the traditional Quinceanera Waltz and the girl moving from childhood to adulthood. It’s beautiful and special and, definitely, definitely more than just wearing a pretty dress.

multilingual.name: What Are The Most Fun-to-say Words In Different Languages?
multilingual.description: We asked this woman, who speaks six languages, what the most fun-to-say words are. Do you know any of the words she chose?
multilingual.transcript:
Hi, my name is Adinett Nsabimana. I am from Burundi, which is East Africa. Today I am going to do different words in all the languages that I speak. I speak six languages. And, uh, we’ll say words that are fun to say! 

The languages are: Kirundi, because in Burundi we speak Kirundi. Then we speak French because we were colonized by Belgium. And then we speak Kinyarwanda because Burundi and Rwanda used to be the same country. So it’s like a different accent, but some words are different. Then we speak Swahili because some parts of Congo, Tanzania, came to Burundi, so most people speak Swahili in some neighborhoods. And then we’re gonna do English and then Spanish because I came to America and I learned both. 

We’re gonna start with “whatever”. In Spanish, it’s “lo que sea”. As soon as I learned “lo que sea”, I started walking around saying “lo que sea” to everything. And French, “love”. In French is “amour”. Now, “hello”, because I’m very friendly and I say “hi” everywhere even when people don’t want to say “hello” to me, I be like, “hello!” In Kirundi, it would be “yambu”. “Yambu”. And then, “grateful”, because who’s not grateful, right? In Swahili, it’s “gushukuru”. “Gushukuru”. My favorite word, “I don’t care”. 

“What movie do you want to watch?”…”I don’t care!”  

In Swahili, it’s “mafu”. That’s Swahili for “I don’t care.” And then, Kinyarwanda, it’s like “peace” or “how are you?”. You say, “muraho”. Kinyarwanda. That’s the language. “Muraho”. Now my favorite one is, is when people tell me stories that I didn’t ask for. I’m like, “interesting…”. That’s English for “interesting”. So, let’s recap!

“Whatever” in Spanish is “lo que sea”.

“Love” in French is “amour”. 

“Hello” in Kirundi is “yambu”.

“Grateful” in Swahili is “gushukuru”.

“I don’t care!” (laughs) in Swahili is “mafu”. You know, it’s just like, I do like, “I don’t care!” “Mafu!”

And then, “peace” or “how are you” in Kinyarwanda is “muraho”.

And then my favorite one is … drumroll please !… English word for “interesting”. “Interesting!”

body.name: Can You Name These Forgotten Body Parts?
body.description: Did you know that every part of our body has a name? And we aren't just talking about elbows and toes. Can you name these small, sometimes forgotten, body parts?

kind.name: What Are The Best Words To Describe Kindness?
kind.description: What is your favorite way to talk about "kindness"? These people shared their favorite "kind" words ... are they your favorites too?
kind.transcript:
CONTRIBUTOR 1: Kindness : I think being kind is one of the best things we can aspire to be,
and in honor of National Kindness Day, I would love to talk about some of the different words we
can use to describe people who are kind . If someone is affectionate , if someone is altruistic , if
they are … if they have goodwill , like in the Christmas song, goodwill towards man … or woman.
One word that I really like is benevolence or benevolent . It actually sounds kind of evil and
mysterious, like Maleficent , but it’s not. It is another word for someone who is kind.

CONTRIBUTOR 2: So, I am totally a words person. My friends kind of think it’s a little silly, but,
um, when I like to tell somebody they’ve been kind to me, I’m a words-of-affirmation kind of
person, so, I say things like, “Oh, that was so sweet.” Or, “Thank you so much for being
gracious” or “patient with me” or “the sympathy that you’ve shown me.” “Thank you so much for
your hospitality.” “I appreciate your goodness.”

CONTRIBUTOR 1: Um, if I were going to call someone kind (I really love the word kind ), but I
think I would rather use the word, um, thoughtful . To me, thoughtful is at the heart of kindness ,
because kindness means thinking about someone else’s needs and putting someone else’s
needs before your own.

CONTRIBUTOR 2: Solicitude ? Never

spell.name: Why Do Some Words Look Wrong When Spelled Correctly?
spell.description: Do you ever spell a word you’ve spelled a thousand times only to second guess yourself? Just blame wordnesia!
spell.transcript:
Embarrass. E-M-B-A-R-R-A-S-S.

No, wait. Are there really two S’s and not just one R?

And, is it really E before I in the word weird? That just looks … weird.

Do you ever spell a word you’ve spelled a thousand times only to second guess yourself?

A word that, the more you look at it, the more convinced you are that it’s spelled it wrong because it just looks so strange.

It’s OK. You don’t have to head back to second grade for a spelling refresher!

Just blame wordnesia!

Wordnesia is a made-up term sometimes used to describe the experience of forgetting how to spell everyday words. It’s like amnesia, a “loss of memory,” but with spelling.

Lawyer. (Spelling) L-A-W- Y E-R? That certainly looks off.

Jewelry. (Spelling) J-E-W-E-L … L? Ah!

Don’t worry. Wordnesia happens to all of us.

English spelling is notoriously hard and random-seeming. It’s the worst!

So, don’t feel embarrassed, we’ve all been there, that’s why some of us even made a word for it. (wink) And that’s two R’s and two S’s, by the way!

cornucopia.name: What Exactly Is A Cornucopia?
cornucopia.description: It’s Thanksgiving, you’re sitting around the table, the food is coming out, and you look up, salivating, only to see a giant horn full of fruits and veggies sitting in the middle of the table. Why is this here, and what does it mean?
cornucopia.transcript:
It’s Thanksgiving, you’re sitting around the table, the food is coming out, and you look up, salivating, only to see a giant horn full of fruits and veggies sitting in the middle of the table.

Why is this here, and what does it mean?

 

Cornucopia.

 

Maybe you’ve heard that word before, maybe you already know that it’s the name for that horn-shaped basket. But do you know why?

 

Cornucopia, also known as the Horn of Plenty, comes from the Latin cornu, meaning “horn,” and copiae, meaning “of plenty” (think: copious). But, it also has a long history in ancient mythology.

 

For example, the Greek god Zeus was said to have been fed by the food-filled horn of the goat Amalthea when he was a baby.

 

Another myth, as told by Ovid, has it that Hercules ripped off the horn of a river god in a wrestling match. Then the nymphs turned it into a cornucopia full of fruit and flowers to commemorate his triumph.

 

So, the cornucopia has been around for a long time.

 

Today, in addition to its use as in Thanksgiving symbolism, cornucopias show up in popular culture as well.

 

Think The Hunger Games, where the cornucopia is used a few times, from the horn-shaped cache of weapons that’s the center of the games to the national anthem of the land of Panem, called “Horn of Plenty.”

 

Cornucopia is also used metaphorically to express the idea having a large variety of something in abundance, like a cornucopia of books or a cornucopia of clothes or even, if you’re lucky, a cornucopia of love. Now that’s something to be thankful for.

thanksgiving.name: Do Other Countries Have A Thanksgiving?
thanksgiving.description: Is the United States the only country in the world to celebrate Thanksgiving? These two hosts figure it out.
thanksgiving.transcript:
1st Host: [mid conversation] As the story goes, the colonists from the Mayflower and the Wampanoag Natives held an autumn harvest feast in 1621, known as the First Thanksgiving. In 1863, President Abraham Lincoln declared Thanksgiving a national holiday in the United States.

 

2nd host: [yawns] Cool story. [has a look of curiosity spike]

 

Is the United States the only country in the world to celebrate Thanksgiving? That would actually be a cool story …

 

1st host: In my home country of Canada …

 

2nd host: Uh, you’re Canadian, since when?

 

1st host: [eye roll] Do you even know me at all? Anyways … we have our own Thanksgiving celebration the second Monday of October. Since Canada is a bilingual country, Thanksgiving is also known as L’Action de grâce, particularly in French-speaking Quebec (although it’s not nearly so popular in that province).

 

The Canadian parliament declared Thanksgiving a holiday in 1957 to celebrate the bounty of Canada. Like our American neighbors, we have a cornucopia of delish foods like turkey and pumpkin pie. We even have a Canadian football game to watch.

 

2nd host: Huh? What about across the ocean? Do they celebrate Thanksgiving over there?

 

1st host: Well, Thanksgiving is a big deal on Norfolk Island in the South Pacific, between Australia and New Zealand.

 

See, the holiday was imported by American whalers back in the 19th century. It was especially promoted by a Norfolk Island resident named Isaac Robinson, who acted as an American consul on the island.

 

Since there aren’t really turkeys in the South Pacific, Norfolk Islanders instead feast on pork, chicken, Tahitian fish salad, and bananas. Like, so many bananas.

 

The churches on the island are loaded up their agricultural bounty, which is then sold as a fundraiser. After services, there’s a massive feast. Not a bad way to celebrate on an island that prides itself on self-sufficiency.

 

2nd Host: Whether your feast features fish, cassava, or traditional pumpkin pie, eating a good meal with friends and family is something we can all be thankful for … [tries to hug 1st host]

squirt.name: The Disgusting Origin Of The Word "Squirt"
squirt.description: If you’re a ten-year-old boy, this host is about to become you’re new hero. Everyone else? Sorry we ruined ketchup.
squirt.transcript:
If you’re a ten-year-old boy, I’m about to become you’re new hero. Everyone else? Sorry I ruined ketchup.

What is the disgusting origin of squirt?

A squirt is “a spurt of liquid,” like a squirt of lemon or water. To squirt is “to eject liquid in a jet,” as in to squirt some ketchup on a hotdog.

A couple centuries ago, though, squirt wasn’t what you put into your body. It was what, uh, came out of it.

Back in the 1400–1500s, squirt could mean “diarrhea.” It’s one of the oldest recorded senses we have of the word, and it’s why we call it the squirts. That, and the whole liquid, uh—I think you get the picture.

We don’t know where the word squirt comes from, exactly. And honestly, I’m fine with that.

Now, the good news is that squirt can do double duty (sorry) if you want to poke fun at your kid brother by calling him a little squirt. It’s the smallness of a squirt that made it an insult, originally, back in the 1800s.

The bad news is that you’re never gonna think about a squirt gun—or a bottle of ketchup—the same way again.

candid.name: Is Being Candid A Good Or A Bad Thing?
candid.description: Let us be candid with you. It can be hard tell whether being candid is a good or bad thing.
candid.transcript:
I’ve been told I’m a candid person. I’m honest. I’m open. I tell it like it is. But, whenever I hear about someone making “candid remarks,” I know things got real.

Let me be candid with you. It can be hard tell whether being candid is a good or bad thing.

Candid comes from the Latin candidus [kahn-di-duhs], which means “shiny white.” Words like candle and incandescent are related. So is candidate, as ancient Romans wore white togas during election campaigns.

Candid as “white” became a metaphor for “pure,” “just”,” and “sincere” in English when it was borrowed in the late 17th century. It also was extended to traits like “honest,” “sincere,” and “frank.” 

These are all virtuous and attractive qualities, right? We don’t like it when people are  fronting or being fake. Remember that show Candid Camera? It caught people in genuine moments—not pretend… also not always pretty.

But, the truth can hurt. In recent decades, especially in politics and journalism, we’ve really taken to the word candid to mean “frank,” that is, “direct” and “unreserved,” especially about difficult topics. A candid interview with a celebrity tackles tough and personal questions. A candid discussion in the Oval Office doesn’t sugarcoat reality.

And, for as much as a candid photograph means a person is unposed and informal, it can also be unflattering. Why do you think we all spend so much time perfecting our selfies?

So, is candid good or bad? We value when people, especially politicians, don’t b.s. us, but facing the facts is very challenging and uncomfortable. Again, I have to be candid with you. It’s a little bit of both, because this word isn’t so black…or white.

tessellation.name: What Are The Most Fun Words In The English Language?
tessellation.description: These three people told us their favorite words from the English language. What are your favorite words?
tessellation.transcript:
My favorite word is tessellation, which is a complex design made up of shapes, closely fitted together to create a pattern. Kind of like these adult coloring books. Not that I color every day or anything. 

[male voice off camera] Are these your crayons?

No, Dad!

It brings me great elation

To say the word tessellation.

It kinda sounds like constellation

Which are also patterns, just in the sky.

I love to say it!

I don’t know why!

Contributor 2

Big fan of the word blasé…yes, i know, it’s technically French. But it’s very commonly used in the English language.  I’m not typically bored, but I guess I, I might describe things a lot as sort of uninteresting or boring or sort of substandard to my…needs.  But I do use it way more than I probably should. [laughs] Like, everything is blasé. Umm, but I’m not truly bored with life.

Contributor 3

One of the most absolute fun words to say in the English language, in my opinion, is the word persnickety. [laughs] It’s something about how explosive it is coming off of the tongue. Persnickety is an adjective and it’s usually describing someone that, um, tends to be placing too much emphasis on trivial or minor details. Someone who’s really fussy or picky. One of the best ways to use it in a sentence is: “I have a friend who’s really persnickety about their food and so they won’t eat bananas.” [laughs] They’re, you know, the people who have the texture thing, which I never quite get. But yeah, I have a friend who’s persnickety about her food because of texture.

agnostic.name: Is "Agnostic" Only About Religion?
agnostic.description: Can the word "agnostic" be used outside of religion? What other things are considered "agnostic"?
agnostic.transcript:
The word agnostic was coined by the English biologist T.H. Huxley in the late 1860s as a member of the (now defunct) Metaphysical Society, in response to what he perceived as too many strongly held beliefs.

The original usage of the term was confined to philosophy and religion, and referred to the fact that anything beyond the material world, including the existence and nature of God, was unknowable.

Today, the word can be seen applied to a lot of other things … questions of politics, culture, and science, as when someone claims to be a “political agnostic.”

In a more recent trend, one can be agnostic simply by not taking a stand on something.

In 2010, President Obama called himself “agnostic” on tax cuts until he had seen all available options.

At a forum on sustainable energy in 2008, GE CEO Jeff Immelt said he was “fuel agnostic fundamentally.”

In technology, software or hardware can be said to be agnostic as well.

Computer code that can run on any operating system is called “platform agnostic,” and such services as phone and electric may be considered agnostic if not linked to a particular carrier, device, or user interface.

Agnostic: not just a religious word anymore.

carte-blanche.name: What Is The Meaning Of "Carte Blanche"?
carte-blanche.description: Carte blanche entered the English language as a French loan word in the mid-17th century, when card games were all the rage, of course. But what does it mean now?
carte-blanche.transcript:
Carte blanche entered the English language as a French loan word in the mid-17th century, when card games were all the rage, of course.

A highly fashionable game of the time was piquet, and if you had a carte blanche then you had a hand with no face cards. We don’t know if that’s a good or bad thing … but that’s besides the point.

And when not playing piquet, English speakers used carte blanche in a literal sense to refer to physical pieces of paper (“carte”) that were blank or white (“blanche”). How creative. Later it came to mean a blank signed contract (not just a blank piece of paper.)

Nowadays, if someone has been given carte blanche, it does not mean that they are holding a blank contract or playing cards. It means that they are free to do or say whatever they please.

OK, cool. This term is awesome because we love freedom of speech and freedom to act. But … how do you actually use this phrase in a sentence … because I’m stumped.

First: Don’t say “a carte blanche” unless you are talking about a piquet hand or a blank, signed contract.

Second: When used in the sense of giving someone free rein, say they have been given carte blanche. (No a please.)

Hey, you know what this phrase reminds me of … that movie … Blank Check from the 90s. That was a good one.

Strangely enough, I’m not totally off because blank check, has very similar meanings to carte blanche. Fun fact of the day.

stuffed.name: Ways To Say You Can’t Eat Anymore
stuffed.description: Learn how to politely decline those 3rd and 4th helpings by dazzling your family with some sparkling synonyms. They won't know what hit 'em.
stuffed.transcript:
Do you have a family that loves food? Does your family keep giving and giving … more helpings of turkey, and stuffing, and potatoes, that is? If you say, “no thanks, I’m full” do you get that notorious mom side-eye?

Yup, me too.

That’s why I went on a mission before this Thanksgiving: I’m not going to stuff myself until I’m sick. Instead, I’m going to politely decline those 3rd and 4th helpings by dazzling my family with some sparkling synonyms. They won’t know what hit ’em.

Honey, you’re skin and bones. Have some more potatoes please.

Aw mom, you’re so thoughtful but I’m:

filled

jammed

loaded

packed

glutted

gorged

overflowing

saturated

satisfied

What … you don’t like my apple pie anymore? You used to love it as a kid!

Oh, dad. Of course I still love it, but after one piece I’m:

bloated
bursting

distended
up to here
stuffed
sated
surfeited

Sweetie? Did you even taste the Jello salad I made just for you?

Grams … wow, I love Jello salad, of course … but I just can’t fit one more:

bite
taste

drop

nibble

nosh

morsel

Nailed it!

woodstock.name: What Are The Words That Defined Woodstock?
woodstock.description: Woodstock '69 was one of the biggest festivals of our time. And there were many words to describe it. So, we found some people who attended the original Woodstock and they gave us the words they believe define it.
woodstock.transcript:
Janice I.: I can see us walking, and it was just droves of us and droves of people meeting us. I can remember, um, sitting. And I can remember looking back. As far as I could see, there were people, no matter which direction I looked: masses and masses of people, and everything was just fine.

Jeanne P. B. : It was just mind-blowing to see how many people were packed into this particular ... You know, we've taken that road hundreds and hundreds of times before that, and you know, you just passed Yasgur farms, and you see that beautiful red barn and that scene is gorgeous. And to see it that way, you know, it's just sort of emblazoned in your memory. It's just so different and … but it's amazing that it happened.

Travis Broxton: Just to see the expanse of people just kind of blew me away. Hey, you know, I'm trying to be cool. You know, I don't, you know … never let them see you sweat. But I was like, "Man oh man, where are we going to eat?" [laughs]

Glenn Wooddell: The intentions of the Food For Love people was that we would serve food and beverage for the entire festival. You know, if you know the history of Woodstock, everything was altered or … and canceled because of the, um, horrendous thunderstorms that we had from the second day, on and off. So, we were actually only open and in full swing an afternoon, an evening, and the beginning of the next morning.

Jason Stone: Every five minutes, there was another rumor going around at … at the original Woodstock. And those rumors were everything, uh, uh down to: You can't get in, you can't get out. The highways are closed. It's impossible. It'll take you five hours to get out of here. There's no water, there's no facilities. It's a disaster area. They're sending in the National Guard. Just about anything and everything that could be a rumor was said that day, and it didn't matter—because we were all there and we were all together and we were all one.

Janice I.: The chain-link fence: I can still look down and see this chain-link fence on the ground, and thinking “There's no barrier to keep people out!” I'd not experienced that before. And what a wonderful thing that it was just “Come!”

John M. : But, Woodstock was all about all of these people cooperating and getting through that weekend together. And, what they say, there was one birth and one death, and it was a universe of its own. And, it will never be repeated again. But, you know, of course, for a new generation they become new festivals for their music, but there'll never be another Woodstock.

Steve Alexander: The life-changer for me, of course, was looking back and realizing: Here was about a million people gathered together, no fights, nobody was grappling over who had what. Everybody shared everything. There was peace in the air. People were joyful about the music. They were joyful about where they were and who they were with. And we looked around and for the first time in our lives, living the kind of lifestyle we were as hippies, freaks—call us what you will. We see … we could see a lot of us. And we could see a lot of us around us and, and in the crowd and in the eyes of the people that were there.

Philip R. : Woodstock was the first time I actually felt that I belonged to a group. It was an awakening for me to realize that there were half a million, three hundred and ... three-quarters of a million people just like me with the same attitudes towards life. So for that reason, it changed my life at that time. All of a sudden, I felt like I belonged to something, uh, which was later termed the Woodstock Generation.

Graham Nash : The lead-up to to Woodstock was kind of interesting. You know, we, uh, we knew that we were gonna play … but when we committed to doing it, there were supposedly like 25,000 people gonna be there. And then, you know, two weeks before that there was 100,000 people gonna be there. And then a week before they were 250,000 people gonna be there. And the day of the show? Lotta people.

Graham Nash : When we first saw the amount of people that were there, we kind of had a little trepidation about doing a song like “Guinnevere,” for instance, which is just one guitar and two voices. But I believe our experience, particularly mine with The Hollies, you know, we had a, a bunch of hit records before I ever met David and Stephen. And, and David's experience with The Byrds, and Steven's experience and, uh, Neil's experience with the Buffalo Springfield, probably put us in good stead for handling a crowd of that size.

Graham Nash : And what you do, kind of, is concentrate on the first, you know, 20 or so rows that you can actually see, you know, and then try and project, knowing that, you know, the 300th, 400th thousandth person can hear you just as well as the people on the front row. And that's something that we had to learn to do, and we had to learn to do that very quickly.

Rube Goldberg : The, uh, stage itself was a Rube Goldberg event. The catwalk to the stage was something

hashtag.name: How Did April Reign Create The Hashtag #OscarsSoWhite?
hashtag.description: Hashtags are great for getting a conversation going. But how do you create one, and how does it go viral? April Reign answered some of these questions.
hashtag.transcript:
Hi. I’m April Reign, the creator of OscarsSoWhite.

In January of 2015, I was still a practicing attorney, um, and I had no connection whatsoever to the entertainment field, other than the fact that I was a rabid consumer of film. Uh, so the Oscars particularly were like my Super Bowl. There were special snacks involved. I’d rope off the TV so everybody knew this was mommy’s night. I’d watch the pre-show, the show, the after show, the show the next day. Everything about the Oscars I loved.

Uh, so I was… That morning, January 2015, I was watching the nominations on one of the morning television shows, and it just struck me for no particular reason that year because, unfortunately, it happened both before then and since, um, there were no people of color nominated in any of the acting categories. 20 different spots. So I picked up my phone, um, which is typically embedded in my forearm, and got on social media and tweeted, “OscarsSoWhite they asked to touch my hair.” And that was it. I then went on to work, uh, and then when I checked in on Twitter around lunchtime, the hashtag based on that one tweet was then trending internationally.

Um, as I said, this was a very organic campaign, I guess. I wasn’t even planning for it to be a campaign or a movement initially. Uh, I was just thinking out loud. (laughs) Very often, I think out loud on Twitter to share my thoughts, um, with my followers and whoever is interested.

I know generally, having had hashtags go internationally viral both before OscarsSoWhite and since, that hashtags have to be short, um, first and foremost. You know, in January of 2015, we were still relegated to 140 characters, not the 280 that we have now, uh, so every single letter, every single word or phrase matters. Um, and so I knew that OscarsSoWhite was short. I was hoping that it was to the point, (laughs) even though, um, years later, people still pretend at least to misunderstand what my meaning was with that phrase. Um, and I was hoping that it would be memorable. And, in fact, it was. Uh, and so now, um, here we are now in year six of OscarsSoWhite, and people are still using the hashtag. And, in fact, um, the phrase has broadened. You know, now there is a JournalismSoWhite and an EducationSoWhite and even a BrooklynSoWhite, none of which I started, um, I think that goes to show that, um, when you are doing something that makes sense that can be universal, and that’s what you want a hashtag to be, people may take it and riff off of it, um, to make it their own, and then I think that’s great.

Um, so hashtags sh- should be short, they should be to the point, um, they should ensure that your message is getting across in just that one phrase, um, and hopefully they are memorable.

To people who are interested in creating their own viral movements or campaigns, um, you know, I would say you can absolutely start on social media, but don’t stay there. Um, remember that there are people who don’t use social media (laughs), surprisingly enough, uh, so you need to meet people where they are. Hashtags are great for getting a conversation going, and hopefully that conversation will continue, even if you’re not leading it. Um, but you also need to write. You need to speak. Um, i- but if you have an issue that touches your heart, um, something that you feel passionate about, um, something that you want to see changed, absolutely get on social media, regardless of the size of your platform, and start talking about it using that hashtag, and then get your friends, family, and followers involved, um, to help you with your campaign. Good luck.

misinformation.name: These Experts Help Explain "Misinformation" In 2018
misinformation.description: These experts around information, the environment, technology, medicine, activism, and journalism help us explain why we chose "misinformation" as 2018's Word of the Year.

wordie.name: Why Are You A "Wordie"?
wordie.description: It's Dictionary Day on October 16! To honor the day, we've asked some of our favorite wordies (a person with an enthusiastic interest in words and language; a logophile) to tell us why they love language, words, and, of course, the dictionary!
wordie.transcript:
LAURA: You know, I’ve always really enjoyed words and, and language. Uh, obviously that, that lead to me wanting to become an English teacher.

ANGIE: Hi, Dictionary.com, this is Angie Thomas, the author of The Hate U Give and On The Come Up. I started loving language when I first fell in love with hip-hop music. One thing that people don’t give rappers enough credit for is their ability to use language and to use words to, not only convey their thoughts and their feelings, but to create images.

JAKE: But, yeah, I’m really annoying with words. That’s definitely the case.

KRISTEN: Ok, so my favorite word is vitriol. It literally means “sulfuric acid,” but over time the British, I think, adapted it to start using it to refer to negative and/or critical speech. I just really like it because instead of saying, “Hey, you’re being a negative Nancy”, you can say, “Hey Nancy, you’re being vitriolic af right now. Ya gotta cut it out.”

ANGIE: My absolute favorite word actually ended up becoming the name of a character in my book, The Hate U Give, and that word is maverick. I absolutely love that word and what it means and what it stands for and just how powerful it sounds.

JAKE: I think my absolute favorite word is mellifluous. I also like cacophony. Kinda the opposite.

LAURA: On Dictionary.com the feature that I find myself using the most, uh, is the pronunciation guide. I am a middle school English teacher and the last thing I wanna do in front of my students is pronounce one of their vocabulary words incorrectly.

SELENA & LOGAN’S MOM: And what is your favorite thing about Dictionary.com?

SELENA & LOGAN: Word of the Day, Word of the Day, what’s gonna be the Word of the day? Ma! [giggles]

LAURA: The last thing I looked up on Dictionary.com, uh, were the, uh, the two words flotsam and jetsam. Uh, this came about because I was watching The Little Mermaid with my three-year-old daughter and, if you’re not familiar with the story of The Little Mermaid, uh, there’s Queen Ursula, the sea witch. She has two sidekicks, they’re eels, and their names are Flotsam and Jetsam, a term for describing floating debris or wreckage from a ship.

JAKE: I looked up the word treason, uh, because it’s being thrown around Washington quite a bit.

ANGIE: The last thing I looked up in the dictionary was the word aw. And the reason I looked it up was because I’m using it as I’m working on my book, and I wasn’t sure if you use one W or two Ws. I’m so used to seeing it with two, but I was pretty sure that you only use one.

KRISTEN: So, the coolest word that I’ve ever learned on Dictonary.com is xx. It turns out that it’s an abbreviation for sugar. Um, baker’s, back in the day when they had to write out all their recipes by hand, they would write xx instead of sugar.

SELENA & LOGAN’S MOM: Logan, what’s your coolest word?

LOGAN: Contronym.

SELENA & LOGAN’S MOM: What’s a contronym?

LOGAN: It has two meanings of opposites.

SELENA & LOGAN’S MOM: Can you think of an example of a contronym?

LOGAN: No. Wait. Are we contronym? Sometimes?

SELENA & LOGAN’S MOM: I hope my children aren’t contronyms!

LOGAN: Wait, I re- I remember one! Cleave! Cleave! Cleave! Cleave! Cleave!

SELENA & LOGAN’S MOM: You’re gonna cleave to each other?

SELENA & LOGAN: Cleave! Cleave!

SELENA & LOGAN: I’m a Dictionary.com wordie!

existential.name: What Does "Existential" Mean To You In 2019?
existential.description: We asked these people what they thought the word "existential" means and why it's relevant in 2019. Does it have the same meaning for you?
existential.transcript:
Speaker 1: The word existential, to me, has always meant something relating to life, or concerning the human experience. You might feel a little existential when you're starting to wonder what it is you want to do with life, or what it is life is all about.
Speaker 2: To be, to exist, to think. To do things, nice things, like to create stuff. To do more than just pay bills.
Speaker 3: Human existence, freedom.
Speaker 4: It means that we work our whole lives in a job that we hate, so that we can still pad our deathbed with all of the regrets and remorse of our time on this planet.
Speaker 5: The human existence, particularly as it relates to free will and the futility of existence without action and forethought and decision on the part of human beings.
Speaker 1: To me, the best use of the word existential is when you are describing an existential crisis. For me, personally, growing up, I was always very confused and weirded out by these very strong gender norms around me. I went through this whole existential crisis trying to figure out what is it about me that is so different from all these people? Eventually I was able to work through this existential crisis and I was meeting new people and discovering new things about myself, and it turns out I'm non-binary.
Speaker 2: The fact that I exist and I am aware of it make me think and act to accommodate that. So, I want to exist to be significant. I become anxious because I want to fulfill this existence, and then I'm wondering if I will be able to do something, if I will be able to exist for real. I know I'm here, but to the full purpose of it. Sometimes it give me really bad anxiety.
Speaker 1: While things might feel heavy and confusing in this existential experience, it's not always a bad thing. You can use things that you have learned from this existential crisis, of digging deep and really trying to pinpoint what it is you want in life and what it is life can mean to you.
Speaker 4: It's looking for truth and it's looking your fellow man in the eye and talking to people, We've got to still hold each other up. That's how you cut that dragon's head off.
Speaker 6: Do you know what existential means?
Speaker 7: No idea.
Speaker 6: Do you know what existence means?
Speaker 7: That means your life.
Speaker 6: Yeah, okay. Existential is relating to existence.
Speaker 7: Fart.
Speaker 6: So, when we talk about existentialism-
Speaker 7: Fart. Fart.
Speaker 6: I guess when you're five, everything relates back to that, doesn't it?

wifi.name: What's The Best Typo You've Ever Made?
wifi.description: What's worse than an embarrassing typo? How about one that goes out to your whole company ...
wifi.transcript: Now at my current job I do mostly technical work. Anything from building maintenance to dealing with computers. In fact, that last part takes up most of my time and the other week was no exception. Towards the end of the day, the Wi-Fi went down. It’s something that happens, but it’s something I’ve gotta deal with. And of course, I did the norm-, normal tricks but I, I couldn’t get it back up. Uh, but at that time it was after hours and it was only the evening crew so it was something I could let go for awhile since regular computers still worked, just not the Wi-Fi. All I had to do was basically send an email out to the company in case anybody came in and tried to use the Wi-Fi that they would have to plug their computer in. Not a big deal. Fun fact, uh, most people don’t spell Wi-Fi correctly. Um, most people would say, “How do you spell Wi-Fi? w-i-f-i, right?” No, no, it’s actually capital W-i-capital F-i. Uh, if you just spell it “w-i-f-i” it’s gonna, there’s a good chance your computer might auto-correct it to a similar word, such as, uhhh…wife. I’ve got a wife, so I guess it’s not a big deal unless I’m, uh, sending out a company-wide email about, uh, how “the wife’s down” or how “the wife’s not working”, how “you’re gonna have to learn to deal without the wife for now” and “hopefully the wife comes back”. Yeah, I did that. Um, I didn’t really catch it ‘til the next day when a lot of people asked me, uh, how my marital status was doing. Thankfully the Wi-Fi came back and my wife never knew about it.

carol.name: Can You Guess What These Christmas Carol Words Mean?
carol.description: Like many of us, these contestants have no idea what figgy pudding or many other words from Christmas carols actually mean. Contestants ... you're up.
carol.transcript:
Have carolers ever camped out on your porch demanding figgy pudding, making threats like “We won’t go until we get some!” Don’t be alarmed. You’re not caught in a protest. It’s just another old Christmas carol: “We Wish You A Merry Christmas.”

But, like many of us, these contestants have no idea what figgy pudding or many other words from Christmas carols actually mean. Contestants … you’re up.

Question #1: What does figgy pudding mean?

A distant cousin of the fruit cake, figgy pudding is a traditional, steamed, cake-like dessert originally made with figs or other dried fruits. It was common around the 1500s.

At the time the carol became popular in the 1900s, a similar dessert, Christmas puddings, were more popular. They are also called plum puddings. But they those “plums” are actually raisins.

Whatever they may be, there is little known about anyone carolers actually receiving … or wanting … any figgy puddings.

Question #2: Sure, we all know the song, “The First Noel.” And, chances are most of us sing along to it every time it’s played. But, does anyone know what a
Noel actually is?

Noel is actually a very simple word meaning, in French, “the Christmas season” or simply “a Christmas carol.”

Question #3: “You’re a mean one, Mr. Grinch / You really are a heel.” But we have to ask, what is a heel exactly?

This is an old phrase used to describe a “bad or selfish man.” And, we won’t even go into other lyrics from this song like “You’re a three-decker sauerkraut and toadstool sandwich with arsenic sauce.” We’ll save that for Episode 2. Happy holidays!

blossom.name: Watch This Word Come To Life: Blossom
blossom.description: Roxane Gay selected "blossom" as our Word of the Day. And, this video helps illustrate why it's such an engaging word.
blossom.transcript:
blossom

verb [ blos–uhm]

“to flourish; develop”

cousin.name: Cousin Relationships Explained: First, Second, & Once Removed
cousin.description: Family is complex. Especially when it comes to figuring out what the difference is between "first cousins," "second cousins," and those that are "once removed"!
cousin.transcript:
When I got my DNA test back … because, you know, I wanted to see where I come from … my results were different from some of my cousins. How could that be? Well, I realized that because some of my “cousins” were actually my first cousins once removed, my second cousins, my … third cousins twice removed! Got it? Yeah, let’s break all this cousin business down.

We all pretty much know what first cousin means. Those are the people who

have the same grandparents as you
are your aunt’s or uncle’s kids
are from the same generation [show first cousin and then list on screen]

Ok, what about first cousin once removed. Now it starts getting tricky. These people are:

your mom’s or dad’s first cousin
or your first cousin’s kids
one generation older or younger than you [show first cousin once removed and then list]

When you add the word removed [show word on screen], it’s because these people are a different generation from you. Once removed means a difference of one generation, twice removed means two generations’ difference, and so on. [show once removed = one generational difference, twice removed = two generational differences on screen]

Second cousins, eek. What does this mean? These people:

have the same great-grandparents as you
are your first cousin once removed’s kids
have grandparents who are your great-aunts and -uncles [show second cousins and list on screen]

Third cousins have the same great-great grandparents as you. And, fourth cousins? You guessed it, the same great-great-great grandparents. Phew, that’s a lot of greats.

No wonder my DNA results were so different from my third cousin twice removed!

geek.name: What Is The Difference Between "Geek" And "Nerd"?
geek.description: These two words have a lot more in common than you might think, from their original meanings to the way they've changed over time.
geek.transcript:
Geek and nerd. Both words call up a similar stereotype: The awkward kid who’s really good at math and science in school, who loves Star Trek and computers, who’s got thick glasses, lots of pimples … but no friends.

But, these two words have a lot more in common than you might think, from their original meanings to the way they’ve changed over time.

Geek goes back to the 1870s, originally making fun of “a foolish or worthless person” and maybe coming from a Germanic root meaning “to croak.” In the early 1900s, a geek was a circus performer who horrified audiences with freaky things like biting off the heads of live animals. That’s a long way from The Big Bang Theory.

The word nerd goes back to the 1950s, also originally making fun of “a foolish or worthless” person. It’s possibly a variation of nut, as in “a crazy person.” A nerd was also the name of a bizarre-looking creature in a 1950 Dr. Seuss book, If I Ran the Zoo. Maybe there was something in those green eggs and ham?

Come the 1950s, geek and nerd were slang for someone smart but unsocial and obsessed with some hobby or pursuit. When the 1980s rolled around, this meant “computers,” which were super technical at the time.

But, by the 2000s, geek and nerd were seeing more and more popularity, shall we say. For one thing, all of us were on computers nonstop and watching the latest Avengers flick. For another, we were priding ourselves on our pet passions. We were rejecting the idea that being really into something means you are a geek or nerd.

That’s why we call ourselves beer nerds if we love hunting down the best craft IPA or football geeks if we know all the stats in the game—things more stereotypically associated with jocks thanks dorks, right?

Now, don’t just go calling anyone a straight-up geek or nerd to make fun of them. That’s still uncool. But calling yourself one? That’s cool. Trust us. We’re word nerds, after all.

nerd.name: Why Are There So Many Different Kinds Of Nerds?
nerd.description: Not all nerds are created equally. And that's why there are a lot of different nerd names floating around out there that you may want to know about—or that may describe you.
nerd.transcript:
Not all nerds are created equally. And that’s why there are a lot of different nerd names floating around out there that you may want to know about—or that may describe you.

Like blerd.

A blerd is a “Black nerd.”

As archetypes go, nerds were typically considered white and male. The idea of a Black nerd—that nerdy things could be enjoyed by Black people, that nerdiness wasn’t just the domain of whiteness—was rare in popular culture.

Fortunately, in the late 1990s and 2000s, with the massive popularity of everything from Harry Potter to Marvel movies, the blerd was born.

In short, the word blerd says: “I’m Black, but I can enjoy nerdy things, too, and I’m going to be visible and open about it.”

Host 2: Or how about wonk.

A wonk loves the down-and-dirty details of a discipline, especially political science. Inside the Beltway (i.e., in Washington, DC), a wonk is specifically someone who is obsessed with the details of public policy.

The expression wonk even inspired the title for Wonkette—a US political news and commentary website known for its satire and gossip. [show site?]

Host 1: Here’s a good one: otaku.

Borrowed from Japanese, otaku refers to a person who is obsessed with manga, anime, and other forms of Japanese or East Asian popular culture. [show anime clip]

Otaku is a Japanese slang word roughly meaning “geek” or “nerd,” especially one who is deemed unhealthily obsessed with anime/manga. As it has been adopted in the US, however, otaku is a term more likely to be used by anime/manga fans to describe themselves.

And if none of these are calling out your name, you can always just hide behind the nerd face emoji, 🤓

The nerd face emoji caricatures a nerd with thick black glasses and buck teeth. It’s used to signify learning, reading, being smart, acting dorky, or “geeking out” to your guilty pleasures. The emoji usually has a positive tone, though. Because nerds are cool. Plus, we’re all secretly nerdy.

The nerd face emoji is often used on social media to describe a fanboy or fangirl’s “nerdy” love for a performer, franchise, television show, movie character, or whatever else they are obsessed with.

So, rock on nerds. And if you don’t have a word yet for your nerd-dom, make one up—or ask a fellow word nerd like us.

christmastime.name: We Asked: What Are Your Favorite Christmastime Words?
christmastime.description: Christmas is right around the corner and there’s a lot of things that come to mind around this time of year. What words reminds you of Christmastime?
christmastime.transcript:
Christmas is right around the corner. It’s here. Now, there’s a lot of things that come to mind around this time of year. You know, it’s cold outside, maybe it’s snowing, and people are coming together with their friends and their families to celebrate and exchange gifts and presents. But there’s one word that always comes to mind, and that’s cheer. I believe there’s no greater gift than spreading a little bit of holiday cheer and joy. 

C2 = It’s Christmastime, and you know what that means: eggnog. I really like the word eggnog around Christmastime because it’s just such a festive drink that really just divides families. I’ve seen eggnog cause bigger fights than politics and religion combined. There’s no in-between with eggnog. You either love it, or you hate it. And there’s only one right answer to that, and I’ll leave that up to you to figure out which one it is. 

C3 = One of my favorite words in the winter time is mistletoe, and the reason why is because, when I was younger, I used to get in trouble during winter all the time. I’m not kidding. Because I used to imagine my toes had missiles on them, and I was shooting people under my desk, like da-da-da-da-da [explosion noise], in my head and making the sound effects out loud. But the word mistletoe, being a noun, it–actually , it’s something. It’s a parasitic plant that attaches itself to trees and shrubs. And what it does, when it attaches itself to trees and shrubs, it sucks the life out of it. 

C1 = As once said by the wise, old Buddy the Elf, “The best way to spread Christmas cheer is by singing loud for all to hear.” Now, you don’t really have to do that, but, no matter which way you find to spread a little Christmas joy and holiday cheer this year, I hope you all have a happy holidays and great Christmas!

gratitude.name: Thoughtful Quotes About Gratitude
gratitude.description: Having a rough morning? Remember all there is to be grateful for with these quotes about gratitude. Your day will get better, we promise!
gratitude.transcript: Having a rough morning? Remember all there is to be grateful for with these quotes about gratitude. Your day will get better, we promise!

christmas.name: When Exactly Are The 12 Days Of Christmas?
christmas.description: Are there actually 12 Days of Christmas? And if so when are they? Let's take a little stroll down Christmas Carol lane to find out ...
christmas.transcript:
… “and a partridge in a pear tree!”

The 12 Days of Christmas.

Perhaps you’re most familiar with them in the form of the beloved—and seemingly never-ending—Christmas carol?

Fun fact: PNC Bank estimates that it would cost over $39,000 to give your true love all the gifts mentioned in that old English carol.

But, are there actually 12 Days of Christmas? And if so what are they?

Let’s take a little stroll down Christmas Carol lane to find out …

First up: The 12 days of Christmas are not the 12 days leading up to Christmas. In Christian tradition, the roughly four-week period before Christmas Day is actually called Advent.

Advent means “arrival,” referring to the coming of Jesus Christ to the world, which is celebrated on December 25th: Christmas Day.

For Christians, the 12 Days of Christmas start either on or the day after Christmas. Fun fact: Christmas Day marks the Nativity. Nativity means “birth,” and Christians celebrate the birth of Jesus on this day.

OK that was a lot … but basically this all means that the 12 Days of Christmas go to December 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, January 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and January 6th.

What’s so special about January 6th? That’s the feast of the Epiphany. Epiphany, here, means “manifestation.”

In Christian belief, Jesus Christ was manifested—or “revealed”—as the son of God to the world in the form of the Three Wise Men, or Magi.

The Epiphany is also called the Theophany. That’s a “revelation of God to a person.”

Now, as I noted, the Epiphany is the 12th and final day of Christmas. So, it also goes by … Twelfth Day.

The night before may have a familiar name to you as well: Twelfth Night. 

I guess this my chance celebrate (cough, cough to take off of work) until the Twelfth Day this year … right?

cold.name: Favorite Ways To Say "I'm Cold" All Winter Long
cold.description: No matter how you say it, it’s going to be pretty cold this winter, so make sure you bundle up ... and if you get tired of complaining about the cold, we've got some synonyms for ya!
cold.transcript:
[Brr] It’s winter time. You know what that means. Sun’s going to set at 5 pm, and it’s going to feel like it drops 20 degrees nearly every day. I don’t know about you, but I love the cold. I love being able to bundle up with a nice blanket and a warm cup of hot chocolate at the end of the day, but I also love to complain. Uh, if your friends are anything like mine, they’re going to get pretty tired of hearing you constantly say, “I’m cold. I’m cold!” So, here are some ways to switch it up and continue complaining about the weather using different words. 

Now, my favorite winter word and my favorite homophone is chilly. Yes, chilly and chili. Chilly, as in “cold,” and chili as the most delicious meal that goes with cinnamon rolls–ever. So, a homophone is where two words that are pronounced the exact same have two different meanings, like right, as in your right hand, or write, as in write. [gestures writing] You know, it’s so funny when people say chilly. I feel as though, that whenever you’re describing how cold it is, you’re gonna be usually in a calmer, more happier mood, more mellow mood, if you describe it as chilly. 

You might also say something like, “It’s a little crisp outside, it feels a little crisp.” You know, if it’s crisp, you might step outside, take a deep breath, [breathes in] and the air feels a little, it feels kind of sharp entering your lungs and against your skin. 

There’s no other way to describe it other than it’s just, really frosty weather. There’s different kinds of cold, right? There’s, like, the really windy cold. But, frosty makes me think: snow. Right? Frosty the Snowman. It’s a wet kind of cold where you just feel it in your bones. 

Or, you know, maybe it’s snowing outside, or it just snowed, or it’s just cold enough that everything’s covered in frost, which is pretty much just a thin layer of ice. You might describe that as frigid. Frigid’s an intense type of cold that might make your fingers and your toes numb and tingly, and all you want to do is get inside and bundle up, and get out of the cold. 

The term frigid is actually pretty fascinating ‘cause of how we use it. Um. the term frigid means “very cold.” Um. it stems from the Latin root word of frīgidus, which means “cold, chilly or indifferent.” I find this word funny, because the only people who use it, like your parents don’t use it, your teachers don’t use it … the only people that use this word to describe “cold” are meteorologists, and when they use this word, you know it’s going to be pretty cold outside. 

No matter how you say it, it’s going to be pretty cold this winter, so, just make sure you bundle up.

alien.name: Are "Immigrant," "Ex-pat," And "Alien" Synonyms?
alien.description: The words "immigrant," "expat," and "alien" all have some history and tensions behind them. Is one word better to use than the others? This man helps us figure it out.
alien.transcript:
In Ireland, US immigrants are often referred to as expats. Is this a contentious term or … do immigrants even care? 

Expat can mean “to banish a person from his or her native country” or “expatriated, exiled.” Is it a bad thing to be called one? 

Is it bad calling someone…alien? Alien means, often disparaging and offensive, “a resident of one country who was born in or owes allegiance to another country and has not acquired citizenship by naturalization in the country of residence”. This is distinguished from citizen. Or “a person who has been estranged or excluded”. 

I mean, if I think about it, there’s nothing great about either of those definitions. I mean, even an extraterrestrial would not want to be labeled that way. 

And there’s immigrant, which means “a person who migrates to another country, usually for permanent residence” or “an organism found in a new habitat”. Seems pretty harmless, right? But, if you tag the front end with a term like illegal, well, then the tone changes and you’ve lost the neutrality. Is one term better than another? 

I remember July 4th, years ago, walking in a parade with my sister and it was just after 9/11. And we got some derogatory, uh, slurs hurled at us. They landed heavy and they landed hard. And it really did feel like we weren’t a part of the country we were trying so hard to be part of.

brooding.name: What Makes Attractive People "Brooding"?
brooding.description: What do Ryan Gosling and a mother Canada goose have in common? They are both dark and brooding.
brooding.transcript:
What do Ryan Gosling and a mother Canada goose have in common? They are both dark and brooding.

Thought we were going for the whole “baby goose–Canadian” thing? Ha! Too easy! No, no. We’re playing the ole “handsome—egg” angle, because this is how a word like brooding can span “introspection” and “incubation.”

When someone is brooding, they are “preoccupied with depressing, morbid, or painful memories or thoughts.” We swoon for certain celebrities, like a Ryan Gosling, who have a brooding look. They look serious, moody, hurt, lost in thought.

Brooding comes from a 16th-century verb brood, which is “to dwell or meditate on” some difficult or dark subject. I, for one, brood over the fact that Ryan Gosling doesn’t respond to my tweets … or my Instagrams … or Facebook messages … or my letters.

The original brooders, though, are birds. They sit on their eggs so as to hatch them—they brood their eggs, a sense of the word found in the 1400s.

We’re dealing with metaphor here! A bird brooding eggs is a like a person sitting on some emotion for a long time—not unlike how we nurse anger or resentment, as if keeping those feelings warm and holding them close like a bird does its eggs.

Brooding darkness, meanwhile, hovers heavily over us. This use of brooding is like how nighttime can overhang us as a mother bird does over its nest.

Now, the verb brood comes from the noun brood, recorded as early as the year 1000 for “the offspring of animals that lay eggs,” like reptiles, insects, and, especially, birds. This is why we sometimes joke about a large family as a brood.

Our noun brood is hatched from the Old English bród [brohd], which comes from an ancient Germanic root meaning “to warm” or “heat”. So yeah, in other words, this means that when we call Ryan Gosling brooding, we are also literally calling him “hot.”

Hey Ryan – I just liked your latest post on Instagram! Could you at least give your biggest fan a follow?

hanukkah.name: We Asked: What Are Five Words To Describe Hanukkah?
hanukkah.description: We asked these people who celebrate Hanukkah to give us 5 words they think of when the holiday comes around every year.
hanukkah.transcript:
Speaker 1: I’m here to talk to you about something very close to my heart, and that is the holiday of Hanukkah.

Speaker 1: When I think of Hanukkah, one of the first words that comes to my head is custom. A lot of people believe that Hanukkah is a Jewish law type of holiday, like all of the other Jewish holidays, it is not. It is not even in the Torah. It is completely customary because of word of mouth history that as been passed down.

Speaker 1: Another word that comes to mind is winter, because it usually comes around Christmas time for Hanukkah, so that’s why you’ll see people celebrating Hanukkah or saying happy holidays instead of Merry Christmas, because there are Jews out here, and we are out here, we would like to be recognized to.

Speaker 2: This third word is miracle, and I think that word is really indicative of what Hanukkah is.

Speaker 1: In the original story of Hanukkah, there were candles that they had to light and make last for longer than the amount of wax that they had, and it was only supposed to last one day and they didn’t even have enough for that, and by miracle it ended up lasting for eight whole days.

Speaker 3: Number four is latkes, we make latkes, they’re little potato circles that you make with the oil, and they’re very delicious.

Speaker 2: And that is food that people traditionally eat on Hanukkah, and I love eating latkes with applesauce.

Speaker 1: Another word that comes to mind when I think of Hanukkah is dreidel. I don’t know if you’ve ever seen a dreidel, it’s a little top spinner. It’s a little, sort of gambling game that they played way back in the time of Hanukkah. Fun fact, the four letters are nun, gimel, he, shin, nes, gadol, haya, sham. That means a big miracle happened there, to signify the eight days that the candle stayed lit.

relationship.name: Can You Define These Modern Relationship Words?
relationship.description: Are you currently in the dating scene? Well, if you aren't (or haven't been in the last 5 years) you may be completely unfamiliar with a whole subset of dating and relationship terms out there. Time to find out!
relationship.transcript:
Are you currently in the dating scene? Well, if you aren’t (or haven’t been in the last 5 years) you may be completely unfamiliar with a whole subset of dating and relationship terms out there.

Time to find out!

Question 1: What does cuffing season mean?

[contestants guessing]

Answer: This is when someone “shacks up” with someone else during the fall and winter months. [show answer on screen]

The metaphor is of handcuffing oneself to a partner (i.e., being exclusive) during these times as opposed to being single in spring and summer, when people want to be outside playing.

The term was popularized by rapper Fabolous’s 2013 song “Cuffin Season.”

Question 2: What does Instagram husband mean?

[contestants guessing]

Answer: A person who helps a partner manage their Instagram social media channel, especially by taking photos. [show answer on screen]

Ever wonder how your favorite insta influencers look flawless in every photo? Well, it may be thanks, at least in part, to the person behind the camera: their Instagram husband.

Celebrities and public figures such as John Legend, Jay Z, and President Barack Obama have all been dubbed Instagram husbands thanks to their famous, glamorous, and accomplished wives (and their popular Instagram accounts).

Question 3: What does DTR mean?

[contestants guessing]

Answer: It stands for define the relationship. [show answer on screen]

If you’ve been going out with someone for a while, it might be time to have the DTR talk with that person, where you clarify where you stand with respect to each other and what your expectations of the relationship are.

Of course, DTR‘ing can be a make-or-break moment.

No matter what new technology we have, no matter what new terms we use, one fact will never change: relationships are hard.

goals.name: How To Set Winning Writing Goals For The New Year
goals.description: Setting writing goals is the same as setting goals for anything: it's hard. That's why we asked these writers for their best tips.
goals.transcript:
Contributor 1

You want to come up with a goal that is not dependent on somebody else. For instance, maybe you’re thinking, “This year, I want to get published!” That would be awesome! But, it’s not always in our control whether we get published or not. A more attainable goal, and better way to phrase this, might be, “This year, I am going to submit my manuscript 50 times to 50 different publishers.” That way, you can meet your goal because it is dependent on whether you get up and you follow through on submitting the manuscript. And if you get published, that’s just a cherry on top. Set deadlines for yourself, and physically put in your planner when you are going to write. If you want to write, you have to make time for it. At least, that’s the way it works for me. I’m never gonna write if I don’t sit down and say, “OK, I’m gonna make time to write at this time today, for this long.” So physically put your writing time in your planner. You already thought ahead, you already put it in your planner, it’s already set to go. 

Contributor 2

Setting writing goals is the same as setting goals for anything. You need to set an achievable goal, you need to set a stretch goal, and you need to set your long-term, overarching goal. When it comes to writing, your long term, overarching goal comes first. “I want to complete my first rough draft of my zombie novel by the end of 2020.” That’s gonna be your long-term, overarching goal. Your second thing is, what’s your achievable goal? Your achievable goal may be, “By the end of March, I want to have written every idea I have about my new zombie novel down on paper.” Then you have a stretch goal. That’s the in-between goal. That’s kinda the tricky one, because you want it to be achievable, but you also want to challenge yourself. So your stretch goal might be that, “By Independence Day, I have started my rough draft of my zombie novel.” Giving yourself six months to get started seems like it’s a very kind goal, but it might not turn out to be. It’s achievable, but it’s also a challenge. That’s the best way to get yourself sitting down and writing, and not overshooting it and feeling like a failure before you even get started.

dreidel.name: What Do The Hebrew Letters On The Dreidel Mean?
dreidel.description: For those of you who have played dreidel, do you know what the letters on the dreidel mean? For those of you who haven't played, we've got instructions on how to play too!
dreidel.transcript:
This is a dreidel. It is a spinning top that is used, um, during the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah. 

On the dreidel, there are four letters: a nun, and these are Hebrew letters. A nun, a gimel, a hei, and a shin. And each one of these letters represents a word. So nun, nes, “miracle.” Gimel, “guh, guh,” gimel, stands for gadol, the word gadol, which is “big,” or “great,” in this case. Hei, haya. Haya means “was” or “happened.” 

And then this is always really interesting which I love. So here in the United States, or anywhere outside of Israel, in fact, your dreidel will say, will have a shin. It stands for sham, which means “there.” But if you bought your dreidel in Israel, it’ll have a “puh,” a pe. It’ll have a pe. And the pe stands for poh. The word poh means “here,” cause the miracle happened there. So, here in the US or anywhere outside of Israel, you would say, “a great miracle happened there,” And in Israel your dreidel will say, “a great miracle happened here.” And that is the symbolism of the dreidel. 

Now, how do you play dreidel? So, you want to start with some gelt. This is some Israeli gelt that my mom brought back for me from her latest trip. Um, and, I had to steal it away from my five-year-old son who like, holds onto this like its actual gold. 

So, let’s pretend we’re playing with two players, everybody puts in, a coin to start. And if you were to spin the dreidel and land on nun, we’ll start with nun, if you were to land on nun, the Yiddish etymology of the dreidel nun, or “none,” would stand for “nothing.” And so you would get nothing. “Wah-wah.” Move on to the next player. 

I’m gonna spin and I’m really going to hope for a gimel because it landed on gimel that time. But then that wouldn’t be any fun. So, you spin the dreidel, the next player spins the dreidel. If you land on gimel, gadol, this is the one you really want. So gimel, think “gimme gimme gimme.” That’s a really good one. You get everything. You get the whole pot. So you take all the coins. And then everybody would just put one back in, you’d start again. 

So, next player goes. Hei, now hei is not too bad to get. Hei, you get half. So hei, “half.” So you got two coins, you take one. If you have an uneven number, you round up. We’re generous, you get half the pot. Half and, a little. 

Lastly, if you roll and you get a shin. This is my son’s favorite, because there’s little song that goes with it to remember. So, if you get a shin, you put one in. Ah! Hey look at that! I actually got a shin! So, the shin song goes “Shin, shin, put one in.” So, my son likes to taunt me with that. So, “Shin, shin, put one in.” Most people will put people one coin into the pot.
