There are some traditions, um, as you can see the shin has three stems. And so some people put, the rule is they put three in. One for each stem. 

And that’s it. You basically go until either everybody has all the money, or one of the toddlers has a tantrum. Yeah, you can guess which one happens first, generally.

dramatic.name: This Or That: Dramatic vs. Melodramatic
dramatic.description: What's the difference between "dramatic" and "melodramatic"? The answer is very entertaining ...
dramatic.transcript:
Nooo! My screen just cracked! Shattered. Welp, today’s canceled. I gotta get it repaired, which means I have to go across town, and I’m going to have to figure out to pay for it, because my rent is due [facepalm]

Hey, it’s OK, it’s OK. It’s just a phone. You’ll get it fixed. No need to be so melodramatic.

Melodramatic? Ha. That may have been dramatic but not melodramatic.

This is melodramatic. Ah! My phone! What I’m going to do? I’m helpless. I’m hopeless. I’m worthless without my phone. I don’t have time for this. I don’t have money for this. I can’t even use my phone to figure out how to fix my phone! (Throws up arms) Oh, what a world. What a world!

Melodramatic.

2: Oh. Well, since you can’t use your phone. We might as well … have a conversation.

1: OK, all right.

2: What’s the difference between dramatic and melodramatic because to me both of your responses were melodramatic, friend.

1: I mean, this is what I know: Dramatic literally means “relating to a drama,” which refers to a play, film, or show that deals with very serious topics. Death, loss, social conflict

2: Cell phones?

1: But metaphorically, something dramatic is very striking, moving, and yes (said with self-awareness), showing a lot emotion.

2: K, then what is melodramatic?

1: Even more emotion. Over the top. Extra. Melodramatic is next-level dramatic.

2: Definitely not mellow.

1: It comes from melodrama, which is a drama with exaggerated characters and sensational plots. Like a soap opera. Or one of those cheesy made-for-TV movies.

2: Hey, I kinda like those. Did you ever see the one where the daughter kills her brother and father and runs away with her mother?

1: Let me just look it up on my phone … sounds kind of amazing

2: I’m not going to say it, I’m not going to say it!

melodramatic.description: What's the difference between "dramatic" and "melodramatic"? The answer is very entertaining ...

luck.name: What Is Your Favorite Way To Say "Tough Luck"?
luck.description: There are so many things you can say when it seems like things aren’t going right. Which saying is your favorite?
luck.transcript:
I definitely say, “Woof.” Which, I don’t know if that’s an English language word, or if that’s a dog language word, but when things don’t really work out for someone else and you don’t really know what to say, it’s a good open-ended word to just say, yeesh!  But it’s more succinct, you know, it’s woof. And then you let them continue talking and tell you why it’s the worst situation that they’ve ever experienced. And then you can woof it up again after that.

Contributor 2

So, my favorite phrase to justify somebody else’s misfortune definitely has to be sucks to suck. I mean, it’s all encompassing. I mean, it, it, it shows that that the situation that that person is in, that sucks. But the idea that that person is even in that situation, that sucks to suck. It, it, it, can be applied to almost any and all situations. It’s all encompassing. It, uh, “Oh I have … I have jury duty.” “Oh, sucks to suck.”  “Oh, I gotta write a paper.” “Oh, sucks to suck.” Some people have a negative connotation to this phrase. Some people think that it is childish. Some people think that it, uh, is a little inappropriate, um, and to those people, I have this to say, “Sucks to suck!” [laughs]

Contributor 3

One of my favorite things to say when it seems like things aren’t going right is, “Don’t let the turkeys get you down!” I first heard this phrase from a HeR Interactive Nancy Drew computer game called “The Final Scene.”  

Computer Game Clip During Contributor 3

Gotta go now! Don’t let the turkeys get you down!

Contributor 3

Uh, there’s this old man character on it and he would always say that phrase every time you stopped talking to him. And it just stuck with me. It feels like an old country “-ism”, I don’t know. I think that if your friend or someone you know is having a really bad day where it just seems like everyone’s out to get them. Like the kind of day where all of the little things go wrong, it’s the perfect time to say, “Hey, don’t let the turkeys get you down.”

friday.name: Four Reasons Why Friday The 13th Is Unlucky
friday.description: There are many theories as to why Friday the 13th is considered an unlucky day. Fortunately, there aren't 13 of them. Aside from that whole horror movie thing, there are some old reasons why this day has inspired so many superstitions.
friday.transcript:
There are many theories as to why Friday the 13th is considered an unlucky day. Fortunately, there aren’t 13 of them. Aside from that whole horror movie thing, which is, to be sure, scary AF, there are some old, like Bible old, reasons why this day has inspired so many superstitions.

Reason 1: Jesus. Anthropology professor Phillips Stevens Jr. has argued that fear of the date may have been inspired in the Middle Ages surrounding Christian beliefs about the death of Jesus Christ.

According to Stevens, Jesus’ Last Supper is said to have had 13 participants, including Jesus, and occurred on the evening before his crucifixion on a Friday, leading to dark associations between Friday and the number 13.

Reason 2: Vikings and numerology. Sorry, Friday, but the fears around Friday the 13th may have to do with the unlucky number 13 itself. Here are a couple:

Viking lore: where the trickster Loki is believed to be the 13th god in the Norse pantheon; numerology: where 13 is in low regard because it follows 12, considered a very “complete” number.

Reason 3: self-fulfilling prophecy. The general rule of a self-fulfilling prophecy is that if you think it’s going to happen, it probably will.

If you’re expecting unlucky things to happen, you might even change your habits on days like this. That means that, maybe Friday the 13th is unlucky … just because we say it is.

Multiple studies estimate that businesses lose millions of dollars in revenue each Friday the 13th because some people avoid regular behaviors like traveling or making investments.

Reason 4: paraskevidekatriaphobia. Yup, that’s a frighteningly long word there. It means … “fear of Friday the 13th.” Maybe the day is unlucky because you have to figure out how to pronounce this word each time it occurs on the calendar?

Or maybe it’s Jason … OK, it’s definitely Jason, because I sure won’t be able to get him out of my head tonight.

monday.name: Where Did The Days Of The Week Get Their Names?
monday.description: We're here today to talk about how our favorite (and least favorite) days of the week got their names. Here are the real stories ...
monday.transcript:
We all have a favorite day of the week. Yours is Saturday, right? Of course, everyone’s is Saturday … but that’s besides the point.

Because we’re here today to talk about how our favorite (and least favorite) days of the week got their names.

Have you ever wondered why Wednesday is spelled in that utterly ridiculous way?

And is Friday named after that delicious fast food? No, it’s not. Sorry to burst your bubble.

Here are the real stories …

The ancient Romans named the days of the week after the planets as they understood them at the time. The planets, in turn, were named after gods. Germanic peoples then adapted these names to their own language and gods. 

So, the beginning of the week started with the sun: Sunday is modeled on the Latin dies Solis. In Latin, sol means “sun,” and dies “day.” When we brought it over to English, it eventually became, naturally enough, Sunday.

Monday is the moon’s day. The name comes from the Late Latin lunae dies, which means “moon’s day.” Yeah, the ancient Romans considered the sun and moon planets—but hey, it was a different time back then. Just like Sunday, it eventually became Monday in English. 

Tuesday: right there in the middle of the week. Maybe one of the most boring days of the week, too, right? Well, the origin of its name is actually one of the most wild stories. The Latin name for Tuesday was Martis dies, “Mars’s day.” Mars was the Roman god of war, and way back when, Germanic peoples equated Mars with Tiw. 

Tiw was equivalent to the Norse god Tyr, god of sky and war. And he was pretty courageous. See, there was a huge wolf named Fenrir prophesied to kill Odin, king of gods. The gods decided to restrain the beast while he was still growing. Fenrir wouldn’t let the gods bind him unless one of them stuck their hand in the wolf’s mouth. Only Tyr was brave enough to do it. Dang, Tuesday, you literally took one for the team.  Tiw, is remembered in Tuesday, “Tiw’s day.”

The Old English word for Wednesday indicates that the day was named for the Germanic god Woden, also known as Odin, who was compared to the Roman god Mercury. Wednesday is “Woden’s day,” which might help you see why the word is spelled so unusually … Under Woden’s supervision, earth and sky were created from the dead body of a giant named Ymir. Woden also helped create the first man and woman from an ash tree and an alder. Take that, Hump Day.

Thursday is also godly because it’s named after Thor. As the strongest of the Norse gods, he was the god of thunder. His magic hammer Mjölnir was a fierce mountain-flattening weapon.

Roman documents going back to the first century intermix Thor’s strength and hammer with Hercules’ bronze and club, but also with Jupiter, the chief Roman god who controlled the thunder and sky. That’s why the Roman name for the fourth day of the week, dies Iovis, or “day of Jupiter,” became “Thor’s day.” Thursday.

Thank the gods it’s … Friday. The Latin name for this day of the week was dies Veneris. This refers to the planet and deity Venus, goddess of love. To the Germanic peoples, Venus was Frig, wife of Odin, queen of Asgard, home of the gods. Frig was also said to have the power of prophecy. Some scholars associate her with Freyja, an Old Norse goddess of fertility, gold, and death. What’s more, she rode a chariot driven by two cats. Hard to beat that. 

Alright, we’ve made it to our favorite day. Save the best for last, right?

Saturday day was named for Saturn the planet, which the Romans named after their god Saturn. Yep, we just kept the old Roman name for this one. But, here’s the best part: Saturn was the god of plenty, of renewal, of time, of liberation. Now that’s what Saturdays are all about.

Have a great week!

writer.name: We Asked: Why Did You Want To Be A Writer?
writer.description: Writing doesn’t require much. You need a paper, pencil, just your brain, and imagination. So, why did you want to become a writer?
writer.transcript:
Writing doesn’t require much. You need a paper, pencil, just your brain, and imagination. I would say that came about the way a lot of creative pursuits do in that I was just working with what I had. 

I’ve been writing ever since I was a kid because I just love stories. I love creating the idea of other people or other worlds and the things that take place in them. 

The reason that I got started writing and telling my own narrative was because I had a client who I went to an event with and I had my hair in a bun. And she pulled me aside and she said, “Natalie, next time we go to these events, make sure your hair isn’t in a bun because you look too Mexican when your hair is in a bun, and people don’t always think Mexicans are smart.” That really… one, hurt, but two, made me think how often, the narrative that we see about our community as Latinas and women of color are typically told, um, without our voices. And so, they’re told inauthentically. While, you know, a lot of creative writers do a lot of research and uh, use that to inform their writing, there’s something to be said about actually living the experience within our communities, and our cultures. And that really helps to create a very distinct and very authentic story. 

Once I got a little older, I think in the 5th grade and I learned about haiku, that was really game-changing because they’re so short. So at that point, I didn’t even need a paper and pencil. I just needed my brain. And it was something that I could do whenever, wherever. And it kept me occupied as a kid for hours. Still does. Especially on the train. [laughs] 

What I really enjoy about writing is being able to craft words and sentences, and put them together in a way that triggers an emotion in a reader. 

I would very much like to say that I have a very specific routine for writing. But if I had a specific routine for writing, I would have a lot more writing done. Oh, my routine right now is actually that I have a riding partner who I work with on screenplays. And we do get together every single night. I think that I love is finding that thing inside — That idea, that moment — that is so… creatively satisfying. That… You just wanna stay up and work on it. Forever.  

And you know, all a writer needs to do is write. Sit down. Write. Craft your story. Because your story’s important and the world needs to hear it.

kwanzaa.name: These Words Celebrate The Spirit Of Kwanzaa
kwanzaa.description: For seven days from December 26 through January 1, Black Americans across the US celebrate the joyous holiday of Kwanzaa. What are some of this holiday's celebratory words?
kwanzaa.transcript:
For seven days from December 26 through January 1, African Americans across the US
celebrate the joyous holiday of Kwanzaa, a social holiday that celebrates community, family,
and culture. Many people don’t know this, but Kwanzaa is not an ancient holiday. If fact, it was
only invented in 1966 by Dr. Maulana Karenga. As a professor of Black Studies, Dr. Karenga
was able to imbue nearly every aspect of the holiday with cultural significance. Much inspiration
around Kwanzaa actually comes from harvest festivals. The word Kwanzaa comes from the
Swahili phrase matunda ya kwanza, which translates into “first fruits.” Each day of Kwanzaa has
a special principle that’s associated with it. The first day, December 26, recognizes Umoja, or
“Harmony.” December 27 celebrates Kujichagulia, which means “Self Determination.” Then, in
order, we have: Ujima for “Collective Work and Responsibility;” Ujamaa for “Cooperative
Economics;” Nia for “purpose;” Kuumba for “Creativity;” and the holiday ends on January 1,
where we celebrate Imani, “Faith.” Just as there are the Seven Principles associated with
Kwanzaa, which are called the Nguzo Saba, and just as there are seven days to the holiday,
there are also seven symbols that are attached to Kwanzaa, as well. The Mkeka–the straw
mat–represents tradition and foundation. The Kinara–the candle holder–represents our roots.
The Mishumaa Saba–the seven candles–represent the Nguzo Saba, the “Seven Principles.”
There’s a black candle in the middle for Umoja (“Unity”). On the other side, there are three
green and three red candles, representing the six other principles. The Kikombe Cha
Umoja–the Unity Cup–isn’t just about unity. It is used to perform the libation in honor of our
ancestors. Mazao–the crop, which are presented in a bowl–are an essential part of any harvest
festival. The Mazao is not to get confused with the Muhindi–the ears of corn. One is placed on
the table to represent each child of the household. If there are no children in the household, two
ears of corn are still placed. Finally, Zawadi–the gifts–are meant to encourage growth. It’s not
about the lavish gifts that you get, it’s about how you use those gifts to better your life. Now,
everybody wants to know, “How do I say Happy Kwanzaa?” Well, you don’t! [laughs] In fact,
what you do say is, “Habari Gani,” which loosely translates to “What is the news?” From there,
the person who celebrates Kwanzaa would respond with the principle attached to that day. And
for anyone else who doesn’t celebrate Kwanzaa, the would say, “Joyous Kwanzaa!” There’s a
fasting from sun-up to sun-down, but every evening, we get together, and we light the candle
that represents that day, we talk about that principle, and we embrace our culture through
reading, through dancing, and through music. Each night closes out with seven cheers of one of
the most important ideas around Kwanzaa–Harambe, which means “Let’s pull together!” A
Joyous Kwanzaa to all. Harambe!

significant-other.name: Unique Words To Use To Describe Your Significant Others
significant-other.description: We asked these people what unique words they've used to describe their significant others. Have you used these words too?
significant-other.transcript:
Contributor 1

Words that I use to describe my husband: witty. He likes to go out in t-shirts that have pictures of a right triangle that says “I’m always right.” He’s so witty.

Contributor 2

One word I used all the time was sagacious. And, that would always trip people up. They were like, “I don’t know what that means. Can you just tell me whether he’s hot or not?” And he was. But, sagacious means that you are very discerning and you’re very judicious in your thought process. And he was always good at avoiding confrontation, uh, because he was very sagacious. He was also hot. 

Contributor 1

The last word I would use is affable. He’s the coach for my kid’s third-grade baseball team, so the kids feel very comfortable talking to Coach Thomas, and the parents, you know, will go up to him and talk about anything. They’re not hesitant. He’s just so easy to talk to. I can come home from work and just kinda tell him about my day or about girlfriend issues. Something like that.

omg.name: How Can This Phrase Exist In So Many Languages?
omg.description: There are a few choice words and phrases out there that have a tendency to transcend the language they’re uttered in due to the expansiveness of the idea behind them. So how do you say this common US phrase in other languages?
omg.transcript:
There are a few choice words and phrases out there that have a tendency to transcend the language they’re uttered in due to the expansiveness of the idea behind them.

Take the phrase Oh my God!

And, we’re not talking about today’s whole OMG thing.

The Oh my God we’re discussing has to do with the exclamation of surprise—either in a delightedly satisfied way or a scandalously shocked way.

Countries everywhere have their own version of Oh my God that they call upon any time they’re at a loss for words.

The French, for example, have sacrébleu!

Unlike the rather PG Oh my God though, sacrébleu is considered more of a profanity. It translates into “God damnit,” although literally it means “sacred blue.”

The Germans, on the other hand, like to say Gott in Himmel, literally translated to “God in Heaven.”

A bit more poetic than just a plain old Oh my God, and, in fact, it does serve for more dramatic use.

Our brothers and sisters across the pond favor the phrase, By, Jove!, when crying out to the Almighty.

Jove was another name for the king of the Roman gods, Jupiter.

To swear by Jove was originally a serious oath to take, and now it’s simply a matter of frustration or shock.

Jove also stems from the Latin word for love, so unbeknownst to them, thousands of English natives are swearing in the name of love … how sweet.

problems.name: You'll Never Guess When These Words Were Born
problems.description: Sometimes the phrases most of us see as modern inventions actually go way back—yes, even before the internet!
problems.transcript:
Sometimes the phrases most of us see as modern inventions actually go way back—yes, even before the internet!

For instance, did you think your generation just made up the phrase I can’t even to imply that something is too amazing, too frustrating, too surprising, or too exciting to handle, thus leaving the speaker unable to even form the words to finish their sentence?

Nope, none other than world-famous musician Bob Dylan was actually among the first to utter the words I can’t even in emotional discombobulation that appeared in an outtake while recording “She’s Your Lover Now” in 1966.

Here’s another one …

Spill the tea is thought to have originated with celebrated drag performer The Lady Chablis, who is quoted in the 1994 bestseller Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil say saying, “Yeah, my T. My thing, my business, what’s goin’ on in my life.” The T in this instance means “truth.” [image of her?]

Another theory is that spilling the tea is Black gay slang referencing Southern culture, in which groups of well-to-do women often got together for some afternoon tea … and trash-talking. The phrase spread via RuPaul’s Drag Race and online culture. [show clip of RuPaul’s drag race]

Has your mind exploded yet? Good, because we have more …

First World Problems may seem so 2008, since that’s the year #firstworldproblems [show hashtag on screen] became a hashthag on Twitter, but it’s actually been a thing since 1979.

Geoffrey K. Payne used the phrase in an article for the journal Built Environment about environmental problems associated with developed countries. The more ironic use of the phrase began in the 1990s, when it became a way of denoting trivial problems faced by people with social and economic privilege.

OK, OK, last one.

It wasn’t your older brother who came up with the acronym OMG, or Oh my God!

It was Admiral John Arbuthnot Fisher who first used this shorthand for the phrase oh my God in a 1917, yes 1917, letter to Winston Churchill. [show picture of Churchill]

He wrote, “I hear that a new order of the Knighthood is on the tapis—O.M.G. (Oh! My God!)—Shower it on the Admiralty!” [show quote on screen]

Now go out there and use these phrases proudly—because your ancestors certainly did.

tea.name: Did You Know These Phrases Are Actually Repetitive?
tea.description: Stop wasting your breath ... these phrases are repetitive! These words actually mean the same thing!
tea.transcript:
Stop wasting your breath …

these phrases are repetitive!

ATM machine is overdone.

The M already stands for machine.

Love that chai tea?

Well, you’re actually drinking tea tea.

That’s right. Chai already means “tea.”

Was that an unexpected surprise?

Of course it was! The whole point of a surprise is that it’s unexpected.

No surprise here: Naan bread is delicious.

But if you order it this way, you’re really asking for bread bread.

As a bonus, we’ll leave you with this.

You really don’t have to say “added bonus.”

A bonus is something that’s already extra!

game-show.name: Can You Compete In This New Episode Of Our Grammar Gameshow?
game-show.description: We're back ... and it's Round 3 of our Gigantic Grammar Gameshow. We know you missed us. Today, we'll quiz these contestants about grammar. Because grammar questions are endless, folks.
game-show.transcript:
We’re back … and it’s Round 3 of our Gigantic Grammar Gameshow. We know you missed us.

Today, we’ll quiz these contestants about grammar. Because grammar questions are endless, folks.

Question #1: i.e. vs. e.g. (show on screen)

In the following sentence, should you use i.e. or e.g.?

My friends like to tell me I’m high-maintenance ( _____ they’re jealous of me 😉).

[contestants respond] [host reveals answer] My friends like to tell me I’m high-maintenance (i.e., they’re jealous of me 😉).

A quick tip: i.e. is used when you mean to say “in other words.” [bold the I’s in these as their on screen to show the connection]. E.g. is used when you mean to say “for example.” [bold the e’s in these to show the connection]

Question #2: Alright, things are going to start getting tricky now. What are five, yes five, types of nouns?

[contestants guess] [host can give some hints if needed since it’s an open-ended question] [host reveals answer and comments on if contestants got some, none, or all right]

Here are all of the types of nouns: singular, plural, common, proper, concrete, abstract, collective, compound, countable, uncountable, material, possessive … and if we want to be inclusive … pronouns. [show on screen as host says them]

Add-on question: What type of noun is the word love.

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer]: Love is an abstract noun. Abstract nouns are intangible ideas. They’re not things people can see, smell, hear, or touch. Common examples include emotions, social concepts, political theories, and character traits.

OK, on to our last question for all the grammar bragging rights.

Question #3: Should you use a comma, semicolon, or colon in this sentence? Chocolate ice cream is delicious ____ vanilla pudding tastes good, too.

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer] In the sentence, Chocolate ice cream is delicious ____ vanilla pudding tastes good, too., there should be a semicolon. Semicolons link two or more independent clauses that are closely related. You can also use a semicolon with connecting words (such as nevertheless, thus, or besides) to combine two sentences.

Goodbye you groovy grammar gurus. Until next time!

grammar.name: Can You Correct These Grammatically Incorrect Song Lyrics?
grammar.description: These lyrics may be catchy, but there’s one, big grammatical error within them. Can you spot it?
grammar.transcript:
These lyrics may not make a lot of sense, but there’s one, big grammatical error within them. Can you spot it? 

(singing) Every little thing she does is magic. (singing) Everything she do just turns me on. (singing) Even though my life before was tragic …

“Everything she do …”

How does it go from “everything she does” to “everything she do”?

Yeah … Yes, “everything she do.” 

Yeah, that doesn’t sound right.

”Every Little Thing She Does is Magic” has one of those great, explosive choruses that makes it impossible not to sing along. But, it’s hard not to cringe, as you arrive at the lyric, “Everything she do just turns me on.” In that sentence, the verb do should be does. 

(singing) I want your love and I want your revenge. (singing) You and me could write a bad romance. 

Could it be, “You … you and I”? 

“You and I” maybe? Yeah … “you and I.”

But I’ve never understood why though. 

I … you have to … I think you have to take out the, the first if it’s, like, a combination with and, you have to take out the first one and if the second part makes sense, like, “me could write a bad romance,” it would have to be I. “I could …” you know, it should stand alone.

– That sounds good.

– Oooooh …

In the case of Lady Gaga’s “Bad Romance,” Lady Gaga sings, “You and me could write a bad romance,” when it should be “you and I.”

(singing) If there’s something strange in your neighborhood, (singing) who you gonna call? (singing) Ghostbusters!

“Who are you gonna call”? “Who are you gonna call,” maybe?

Going … ?

[Makes “buzzer” sound] (Wrong!)

In the timeless “Ghostbusters Theme Song,” Ray Parker Jr. asks over and over again, “Who you gonna call?” The answer, of course, is the Ghostbusters which are a group of people. Since the Ghostbusters are a group, they’d be described using the pronoun them. And that means their theme song should technically ask, “Whom are you going to call?” 

(singing) T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you tasty. (singing) T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you tasty.

I don’t know … I like that song. (laughing)

– I just sing it. I don’t think about it.

– I did too, like, fifteen years ago … uh …

And on that note, in the early 2000s, Fergie’s hit song, “Fergalicious,” taught the world how to spell delicious and tasty. There’s only one small problem with the impromptu spelling lesson, the song spelled tasty incorrectly. The lyrics include rapper will.i.am chanting, “T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you’re tasty.” In reality, tasty is spelled sans E.

typo.name: We All Make Typos: What's Your Worst One?
typo.description: We asked this woman about her worst typo. Her response: OK, so this might be now one of my most favorite stories to tell. Then it was utterly devastating.
typo.transcript:
OK, so this might be now one of my most favorite stories to tell. Then was utterly devastating.
I was going on a first date with a guy. I was probably, like, 16 or 17 and we were going to see a
movie. And I had arrived before he had and I texted him and I was gonna ask him if he wanted
any popcorn. But, good ol’ autocorrect asked him if he wanted any “poopcorn”! Well, I was so
embarrassed! I’m immediately texting him, like, “OMG!”, like, “Sorry! Autocorrect!” And I was,
like, really embarrassed, ‘cause I was 16! I would say that, uh, asking a boy on a first date if he
wanted “poopcorn” is probably one of the best autocorrect stories that, um, I’ve been a part of.
And I wish that I could say that that was, like, the only time that “poopcorn” was autocorrected
from “popcorn”…Definitely happened to me more than once, so be careful when you’re asking
your friends about popcorn on your phone.

superhero.name: What Do The Names Of Our Favorite Superheroes Mean?
superhero.description: We love superheroes. Without them, there would be no one to fight crime in ... leotards and capes! And we have to admit, they have pretty cool names, too. Who wouldn't want the nickname Spidey? But have you ever wondered what their names really mean?
superhero.transcript:
We love superheroes. Without them, there would be no one to fight crime in … leotards and capes!

And we have to admit, they have pretty cool names, too. Who wouldn’t want the nickname Spidey?

But have you ever wondered what their names really mean?

We all know Bruce Wayne goes into his bat-filled lair to slip on his all-black bat costume when he wants to save lives. But, did you know that, in one telling of his tale, his name Batman stems from a childhood fear?

In the 2005 movie Batman Begins, a young Bruce Wayne falls into a well on his parents’ property, which is swarmed with bats. He grows up terrified of bats but he decides to challenge that fear by turning into one.

He conquers his phobia by using it to fight villains in Gotham City. That’s courage. So, Batman is really about overcoming … chiroptophobia then[pronunciation tip for host: [kahy-rop-tuh-foh-bee-uh], “the fear of bats.”

Wonder Woman’s mission is to help encourage good in others. Her real name is Princess Diana, and she comes from the female-only island of Themyscira [thuh-miss-er-uh], which the Greek gods gave to the Amazons who weren’t fans of … the male species. She is also the daughter of Zeus and Hippolyta, the Amazon queen [pronunciation tip for host: [hi-pol-i-tuh].

The Amazon princess received the name Wonder Woman after winning a battle with Captain Steve Trevor. She sets off to the “Man’s World” to promote what she (and her name) stands for: peace, honesty, and strength. As her original comic goes: “As lovely as Aphrodite—as wise as Athena—with the speed of Mercury and the strength of Hercules—she is known only as Wonder Woman!”

Sure, we know Superman goes by another name when not sporting his red cape, ahem, Clark Kent. But, he has a third name, his real one—and it has Hebrew roots.

In Superman’s hometown of Krypton, his real name is Kal-El.

The El in his name is thought to refer to a Hebrew word meaning “of God,” and Kal, “voice.” This means Superman’s official name, Kal-El could be translated to “voice of God.” Talk about childhood pressure …

We can’t forget Robin, right? That’s because Robin and Batman are considered the Dynamic Duo. But Robin is also a master fighter and acrobat on his own.

Origin stories of the name Robin, the Boy Wonder, are many. It’s often cited that his original creator loved The Adventures of Robin Hood, hence Robin’s medieval-looking outfit. In one of the comics, Robin takes his name from a golden bracelet featuring a robin, given to him by his mother before she died.

Wolverine might not have been born with his superhero name—he also goes by the name James Howlett or Logan. He was born, however, with his special powers.

Due to a “genetic mutation,” Wolverine possesses animal-like senses and claws in both hands, which are actually bone.

Because of his strong sense of animal characteristics (and the way he looks), he is called Wolverine.

A wolverine is part of the weasel family (despite its name, unlike a wolf, which is in the canine category) and resembles more of a bear. It is so viciously strong it can kill creatures much bigger in size.

career.name: Did You Know The Names Of These Unique Careers?
career.description: Remember when you were little and everyone kept asking, “What do you wanna be when you grow up?” Well, we found some of the most unique career names to help you decide.
career.transcript:
Remember when you were little and everyone kept asking, “What do you wanna be when you grow up?”   

Maybe you said something generic like “lawyer or doctor.”  Or, maybe you said something more original like “a beekeeper or entrepreneur.”

Well, I can guarantee you probably didn’t say “lexicographer,” right? Because what-the-french-toast is that?

It’s the name for a writer, editor, or compiler of a dictionary. Not like we’re biased or anything.

Lexicographer comes from Greek roots meaning “recorder of words.” Fun fact: what’s considered the oldest English dictionary dates back to 1604.

Now, picture this. At the end of a long, happy life, you see a white light, and there guiding you is a beautiful singing voice, along with the gentle strums of the harp.

No, it’s not any angel of death, it’s a music thanatologist.  

A music thanatologist unites medicine and music to assist in end-of-life care, often by literally singing and playing the harp to provide comfort.

Thanatology means “the study of death,” a sub-discipline in medicine and psychiatry. It comes form the Greek thanatos, a personification of death.

Now, to the lighter side of things (laughs): gumology.

A gumologist is someone who spends all day, every day, tasting and reviewing, yes you guessed it, gum.

Gumologists work at the candy company, Cadbury, and professionally taste gum. 

Don’t quit your day job just yet: gumologists have to be able to tell apart 70 different ingredients from a single pack of gum.

Alright, let’s take a … closer look … at one more. Ocularist.

Sounds innocent enough, right? Well, it may not be for the faint-hearted. An ocularist is “a person who makes artificial eyes.”

It’s rooted in the Latin oculus, “eye.” Did you know that archeologists discovered an artificial eye in Iran that was almost 5,000 years old? That’s, um, a pretty good piece of work (say with knowing corniness).

aries.name: How Well Do You Know The Signs Of The Zodiac?
aries.description: Today we're going to find out what these two so-called astrology buffs actually know about the zodiac signs and names. Do you know more than they do?
aries.transcript:
Hey, what’s your sign?

OK, guess that did sound a little sleazy … but the zodiac isn’t something to roll your eyes at. In fact, the concept of the zodiac is ancient.

It means is “an imaginary belt of the heavens, extending about 8° on each side of the ecliptic, within which are the apparent paths of the sun, moon, and principal planets. It contains 12 constellations and hence 12 divisions called signs of the zodiac.”

Each sign has its own symbol (taken from what the ancients likened the constellation to). And if you’re at all into astrology and the zodiac you probably know what symbol aligns with your birth date too. Right? Well, today we’re going to find out what these two so-called astrology buffs actually know about the zodiac signs and names.

Question #1: What is the first sign of the zodiac?

OK, here’s a hint.

[host reveals right answer: Aries]

Bonus round: What does Aries mean?

Aries is Latin word for “ram.” The image of the ram is also why the zodiac symbol for Aries represents two curled ram’s horns. (show symbol again)

Question #2: Which zodiac sign does this symbol represent?

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer — show symbol on screen again as host says “Leo”]

Bonus round: What does Leo mean?

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer]: The name for the sign comes from the Latin word for “lion.” The symbol for Leo in astronomy is thought to show the lion and its tail or mane.

Question #3: Which zodiac sign does this symbol represent?

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer — show symbol on screen again as host says “Sagittarius”]

Bonus round: What does Sagittarius mean?

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer]: Sagittarius is Latin for “archer.” According to Greek mythology, Sagittarius shows the centaur Chiron, considered the wisest and most just of the half-horse, half-men creatures. He is known for having educated the hero Achilles in archery. The symbol for Sagittarius, ♐, shows the bow and arrow Chiron was known for.

So, what’s your sign?

[host reveals right answer: Aries]

Aries is Latin word for “ram.” The image of the ram is also why the zodiac symbol for Aries represents two curled ram’s horns. (show symbol again)

Question #2: Which zodiac sign does this symbol represent?

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer — show symbol on screen again as host says “Leo”]

Bonus round: What does Leo mean?

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer]: The name for the sign comes from the Latin word for “lion.” The symbol for Leo in astronomy is thought to show the lion and its tail or mane.

Question #3: Which zodiac sign does this symbol represent?

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer — show symbol on screen again as host says “Sagittarius”]

Bonus round: What does Sagittarius mean?

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer]: Sagittarius is Latin for “archer.” According to Greek mythology, Sagittarius shows the centaur Chiron, considered the wisest and most just of the half-horse, half-men creatures. He is known for having educated the hero Achilles in archery. The symbol for Sagittarius, ♐, shows the bow and arrow Chiron was known for.

So, what’s your sign?

sagittarius.name: How Well Do You Know The Signs Of The Zodiac?
sagittarius.description: Today we're going to find out what these two so-called astrology buffs actually know about the zodiac signs and names. Do you know more than they do?
sagittarius.transcript:
Hey, what’s your sign?

OK, guess that did sound a little sleazy … but the zodiac isn’t something to roll your eyes at. In fact, the concept of the zodiac is ancient.

It means is “an imaginary belt of the heavens, extending about 8° on each side of the ecliptic, within which are the apparent paths of the sun, moon, and principal planets. It contains 12 constellations and hence 12 divisions called signs of the zodiac.”

Each sign has its own symbol (taken from what the ancients likened the constellation to). And if you’re at all into astrology and the zodiac you probably know what symbol aligns with your birth date too. Right? Well, today we’re going to find out what these two so-called astrology buffs actually know about the zodiac signs and names.

OK, here’s a hint.

en-dash.name: Who vs. Whom: Can You Answer That Plus More Grammar Questions?
en-dash.description: Wow, we can't believe we're here ... here being Round 4 of these never-ending but very gratifying Grammar Gameshow. Are you ready?
en-dash.transcript:
Wow, I can’t believe we’re here … here being Round 4 of these never-ending but very gratifying Grammar Gameshow. We know you love ’em, which is why we’re back … quizzing these contestants … because what’s more fun than hearing other people mess up grammar rules? Nothing!

Let’s jump right in, shall we?

Question #1: When listing a date range, what kind of dash should you use? For example: January 4 ____ February 4.

In a date range like January 4–February 4, you would use an en dash. An en dash is slightly longer than a regular dash (or hyphen), but shorter than an em dash. An en dash is used for a range or to connect the endpoints of a route. It can also show a contrast or connection between two words. Or, you can use it to replace the words to, and, or versus.

Question #2: who vs. whom bwahahah. In this sentence, which should you use? You talked to _____?

[contestants guess] [host reveals answer]: In the sentence, You talked to __?, whom is the correct choice. Quick tip: if you can substitute him or her, then whom is the right choice. If he or she makes more sense, go with who.

OK last question … and it’s a tough one.

Question #3: What is the correct term for this type of phrase? “to quickly read”

[host reveals answer] The term for the phrase “to quickly read” is a split infinitive. A split infinitive occurs when there’s an adverb between two parts of an infinitive. An infinitive consists of the word to and the simple form of a verb (e.g., to go and to read).

It’s over, y’all … it’s over. You did great.

who.name: How To Use "Who" vs. "Whom"
who.description: In short, whom is the object form of the pronoun who. But, let’s have some examples to spell it out.
who.transcript:
I once applied for a job as an English tutor. Before submitting them, I carefully read over my résumé and cover letter to make sure they were flawless.

A few days later, I got a phone call. Thinking I was being very proper, I answered: “Whom, may I ask, is calling?”

It was the employer. We chatted for a bit, but they never did invite me in for an interview. I can’t help but wonder if it’s because I didn’t know my who from whom.

[Title slide]

I’ve brushed up on my English grammar since then. In short, whom is the object form of the pronoun who. But, let’s have some examples to spell it out.

I was the applicant who didn’t get an interview. Who, here, is referring back to me, the person doing the action—the subject, getting the interview.

I was the applicant whom they didn’t interview. Whom, here, shows I am receiving the action—the object, being interviewed.

Whom will also follow prepositions like to, for, by, and from. Such as when starting a letter To whom it concerns or asking “The book was written by whom?”

Why the M? The M in whom is a leftover from way back when English used case endings on words to show what part it was playing in a sentence, such as subject or object.

Anyhoo, using whom often sounds stiff to the point of ridiculousness because its use is on the decline. Asking someone Whom do you love? may impress your junior-high English teacher, but this just isn’t how most of us actually talk.

But, in formal settings, especially in writing, distinctions between who and whom are often more important. So important, in fact, that many people who want to be seen as smart and careful about language end up using who and whom incorrectly.

That’s when things get awkward. Just ask me. “Whom, may I ask, is calling?” as I asked my would-be employer. Whom, here, should have been who, because it is referring back to the person doing the calling, the subject—not the object of ask.

Well, go ahead and ask me who cares about ‘em anyways. Not me.

literary.name: Can You Guess Which Books These Literary Quotes Are From?
literary.description: Who loves writing? Who loves reading? Yup, us too! Let's test your knowledge of some of literature's most famous lines. Ready?
literary.transcript:
Who loves writing? [contestants raise hands] Who loves reading? [contestants raise hands] Wonderful. Let’s test your knowledge of some of literature’s most famous lines. Ready?

Question #1: [show on screen] “In spite of everything I still believe that people are really good at heart.”

Is this from the book: The Catcher in the Rye | The Diary of Anne Frank | The Hate U Give

[host reveals right answer: The Diary of Anne Frank by Anne Frank]

Question #2: [show on screen] “It’s strange because sometimes, I read a book, and I think I am the people in the book.”

Is this from the book: The Perks of Being a Wallflower | To Kill a Mockingbird | The Hunger Games

[host reveals right answer: The Perks of Being a Wallflower by Stephen Chbosky]

Question #3: [show on screen] “There is nothing like puking with somebody to make you into old friends.”

Is this from the book:  Looking for Alaska | The Bell Jar | The Great Gatsby

[host reveals right answer: The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath]

Question #4: [show on screen] “To really be a nerd, she’d decided, you had to prefer fictional worlds to the real one.”

Is this from the book: Fangirl | Eleanor & Park | Carry On

[host reveals right answer: Fangirl]

BONUS: Who is the author of all of those books?

[jeopardy like music timer for contestants to guess] [host reveals right answer: Rainbow Rowell]

city.name: What Are Some US City Names That We Are All Pronouncing Wrong?
city.description: Even if you have lived in the US your whole life there are still cities that you probably pronounce wrong. So, what is the right way to say them? Watch on!
city.transcript:
I am from Kansas City, on the Kansas side. And, uh, even though I’ve grown up here my whole life I don’t know that much about some of the smaller towns that are located in the great state of Kansas. Um, but my husband is from a small town south of Wichita. One time I was down there visiting and I got in a discussion with my father-in-law about a neighboring city called Ark City and, um, I said, “Now, Ark City. Is that short for Ar…Arkansas City ‘cause it’s by the Arkansas River?” And he looked at me very seriously and he said, “No, it is short for Ar-Kansas City and it is located near the Ar-Kansas River.” And I just had to chuckle at that ‘cause I said, “Was that just to set yourself apart from Arkansas?” And he said, “Yeah. Absolutely.” So it turns out that Kansas, the name Kansas, comes from the Kansa tribe where Arkansas is the French pronunciation of a tribe from that area. Um, when Arkansas became a state, uh, they chose to keep the French pronunciation whereas, of course, when Kansas became a state they took the English form of the Kansa tribe name. Uh, so when Arkansas City established itself they decided to keep the, uh, Ar-Kansas, Arkansas spelling because they were near the Arkansas River, which they call the Ar-Kansas River. Anytime you find yourself in, uh, great Ark City, uh, do not call it Arkansas City. They will correct you. It is Ar-Kansas City.

Contributor 2

Hello, my name’s AJ and I’m from Peoria, Illinois. Now maybe it’s because I’m from here but, uh, Peoria, Illinois’s never been too much trouble for me to say. I remember in high school, I went to Peoria High and we chant P-E-O-R-I-A! Easy to spell, easy to say, right? Well, apparently, not so much. I get junk call or something and you can tell that they’re not from the area because, uh, even if they pronounce Peoria right they, they, like, pronounce it really timidly. Instead of Peoria, it’s like, “Pee-orrr-ee-uh?” Of course, you get…pe or-uh, peeorrhea, pariah, pure-uh, portia…that’s even adding a letter, I’m not even sure how that happens, but Peoria. Apparently, it’s super hard to pronounce, but Peoria. Just spell it out. ‘Course that’s not unique, a lot of central Illinois cities and towns and even around Illinois there’s a lot of different, uh, cities that get mispronounced. There’s San Jose, Illinois…not San José, Illinois, it’s pronounced San Joes, Illinois. Down south, uh, southern Illinois you got Cairo, Illinois. It’s not pronounced Ky-row, Illinois. It’s Kay-row, Illinois. And yes, it’s spelled exactly like Cairo, Egypt but it’s pronounced Kay-row…because Illinois.

united-states.name: Have You Been Pronouncing These US Places Correctly?
united-states.description: This woman took a road trip across the US and found out she was pronouncing a lot of state and city names ... wrong. Have you been pronouncing them incorrectly too?
united-states.transcript:
For about three years, I lived in Seattle, Washington.
I was able to do this epic cross-country trip and take two weeks and go through a bunch of
different states.
Of course, the first state I entered when I left Washington was what I thought was “awr-i-gon.”
(laughs)
But the locals very, very quickly corrected me and said that they pronounce it “awr-guhn”. Like
an organ in your body, a kidney or a liver or something. They do not separate the three syllables
and say “awr-i-gon” which is how I learned it.
They just say “awr-guhn.”
After that, I got to Las Vegas. I always said “nuh-vad-uh”. But everyone who lives there says
“nuh-vah-duh.” (laughs)
I thought that was maybe, like, dealers choice? Pun intended. But, actually, I was corrected a lot
by everyone who lived there and said, “Nope, it’s nuh-vah-duh, not nuh-vad-uh!”
I also drove through Kentucky and stayed with a friend in what I thought was “loo-ee-vil”, or
“loo-is-vil”, but they take out a lot of those letters and just say “loo-uh-vuh l”. (laughs)
Very smooth. “loo-uh-vuh l”
And similarly, uh, New Orleans, in Louisiana, they all pronounce “naw-luh nz” Louisiana.
Sounds much cooler.
Back on the East Coast. I grew up in Massachusetts. Every time we went to the town
Worcester, I would see these signs that said: “wor-kester” or “wor-sester?” Or maybe,
“wor-chester?” Uh no! It’s pronounced, “woo s-ter”
If you’re a local Massachusetts-ian, and you have any kind of Bostonian accent, you’re probably
actually going to say it, “Wuhstah.”
A lot of letters in there, just kinda suggestions. (laughs)
And then similar to Worcester is Gloucester and Leicester. They both have that c-e-s
combination that Worcester does that you kinda just smoosh all together. So, Gloucester looks
like “glow-ses-ter” or “glow-kester?” But it’s “glos-ter.” Like glossy.
And then my favorite is Reading, which is spelled exactly the same way as reading. And of
course, there’s also a North Reading in Massachusetts. When you’re on the highway, the sign
for North Reading is abbreviated as “No. Reading.” And so it looks like “no reading.” It looks like,
“If you take this exit, you are entering a town where reading is banned.” (laughs)
So I remember always being really concerned about that when I was little.

kentucky.name: Has Your Family Ever Said This Kentucky Word?
kentucky.description: If you're from Kentucky, maybe you've heard this word before. If you're not from Kentucky, do you know what it means?
kentucky.transcript:
Tars 

My grandfather was from Kentucky. He still had a very thick Kentucky accent.  Now for the most part we all grew up with it so we’ve of course always understood our grandfather.  But every once in a while a word or two would come out that were like, “What is he saying?” One day and I remember in his, uh, in his kitchen, we were all having a discussion and he talked about tars.  You know, if we got some tars and we’re thinking like, “What? What what do we need tars for?” I mean, what do you use tar for? I don’t even know what you use tar for. Use it for fixing a roof or a driveway?  I don’t know, tars. And he got frustrated with us, and he’s like, “No! Tars, you know, four tars on a car!” He wasn’t saying “tars,” he was saying “tires.” After that, I think a lot of us just started saying tars, at least when we got together as a family if we ever referred to tires for any reason. Tars:  the “Kentucky word” for tires.

ailurophile.name: Words For "Cheese Lover" And Other Passions
ailurophile.description: There are many -phile (or "lover") words out there. And if you don't love cheese maybe one of these other ones applies to you.
ailurophile.transcript:
Have you ever wondered if anyone out there loves cheese as much as you do? Well, guess what, you aren’t alone. There are others like you! And y’all even have a name: turophiles. Yup, there’s a word for “a lover of cheese.”

There are many more -phile (or “lover”) words out there, too. And if you don’t love cheese maybe one of these applies to you.

We all have that friend, or maybe we are that friend, whose catchphrase is it’s 5 o’clock somewhere. They’re the one to crack open a bottle of rosé right after work or take a weekend getaway to Napa Valley. Well, this friend is also an oenophile.

An oenophile is defined as “a person who enjoys wines, usually as a connoisseur.”

The term emerged in France, appropriately enough, in the mid-1800s, based on the Greek word for “wine,” oinos.

Friend 1: Ah yes, I’m getting a hint of melon.

Friend 2: *eye roll*

If you think there’s nothing more beautiful than a full moon, you may just be a werewolf. But more likely, you’re a selenophile.

When not said of certain plants in botany, a selenophile can refer to “a person who loves the moon.” I use “can” because this word has some technical, scientific meanings, too. The origins of obscure -phile words are hard to track down. But, here’s a fun tidbit: In Greek mythology, Selene is the goddess of the moon, ergo selenophile.

This one’s for all the Sheldon Coopers out there.

A vexillophile is a “person who collects or studies the flags.”

The formal study of flags, called vexillology, dates back to the late 1950s, early 1960s. The word is based on the Latin vexillum, meaning “military banner.” Whenever Sheldon loses interest in theoretical physics, we see a bright future for him as a vexillophile.

OK, one more for now. If being called a cat lady sounds like a compliment rather than an insult, then you’re definitely an ailurophile.

An ailurophile means “lover of cats,” of course.

And you’re in good company too, John Lennon, Abraham Lincoln, and Pablo Picasso are all considered famous ailurophiles. The ancient Egyptians even worshipped feline goddess, Bastet, and the punishment for injuring cats was severe.

Ailurophile is based on the ancient Greek word for “cat,” ailouros.

The origins of obscure -phile words are hard to track down. But, here’s a fun tidbit: In Greek mythology, Selene is the goddess of the moon, ergo selenophile.

This one’s for all the Sheldon Coopers out there.

A vexillophile is a “person who collects or studies the flags.”

The formal study of flags, called vexillology, dates back to the late 1950s, early 1960s. The word is based on the Latin vexillum, meaning “military banner.” Whenever Sheldon loses interest in theoretical physics, we see a bright future for him as a vexillophile.

OK, one more for now. If being called a cat lady sounds like a compliment rather than an insult, then you’re definitely an ailurophile.

An ailurophile means “lover of cats,” of course.

And you’re in good company too, John Lennon, Abraham Lincoln, and Pablo Picasso are all considered famous ailurophiles. The ancient Egyptians even worshipped feline goddess, Bastet, and the punishment for injuring cats was severe.

Ailurophile is based on the ancient Greek word for “cat,” ailouros.

crystalline.name: We Asked: What's Your Favorite Winter Word?
crystalline.description: It's cold. It's dark. It's the middle of winter. But some people like winter, right? To find out, we asked these people what their favorite winter words are. Do you agree?
crystalline.transcript:
My favorite winter word is toboggan. I mean, just say it! Toboggan. It is such an exciting word,I don’t know what it is about the word that feels so good on my mouth, but toboggan, toboggan, toboggan, toboggan! It’s my favorite winter word. So, the word toboggan means, “a long, narrow, flat-bottomed sled made of a thin board curved upward and backward at the front, often with low handrails on the side, used especially in the sport of coasting over snow or ice.” So, tobogganing is, uh, sledding! [laughs] Essentially. Um, except it’s way more fun and way more advanced than sledding on a piece of cardboard, which I used to do back in the day.

Well, the only word that comes to mind when I think of winter is my birthday month, the month of February! As we all know, you know, February is the second month of the year, and it’s the only month that has less than 30 days. Now, when it comes to the pronunciation of February, February has two Rs, but a lot of times, a lot of people like to drop that first R and replace it with a Y. And this is a natural process called dissimilation. And what this means is, if the same sound reoccurs, together in a word, then people will start to differentiate the two instances, which means the R now sounds like Y. They’re saying “Feb-yoo-er-ee” instead of “Feb-roo-er-ee.”

Crystalline.  It means, of course, “having the structure of a crystal.” But more than that, I think it means incredibly clear, and to me, pure. It gives me the feeling of the sound of wind chimes, but wind chimes made from ice. It just feels so wintery for me. Uh, not necessarily in terms of the meaning, but how it sounds, and how that sound feels.

My favorite winter word is a Danish word, pronounced “hoog-uh.” And it means a sense of contentment, or well-being that’s created by a warm and cozy environment. For example, if you wanted to have a hygge experience, you would light candles, read a book, bring friends over, um,  hot chocolate, cocoa, a fire, all things that would make you feel well and content.

coleslaw.name: Hot dogs, Coleslaw, And Other Debates About Food
coleslaw.description: We all love food, but that doesn't mean we all agree on what certain foods should be called. There are some serious food debates that spark intense reactions. Watch to see if you agree or disagree with these food classifications.
coleslaw.transcript:
Speaker 1: We all love food, but that doesn’t mean we all agree on what certain foods should be called. There are some serious food debates that spark intense reactions.

Like the hot dog.

Is a hot dog a sandwich?

Speaker 2: I think I speak for everyone when I say a hot dog is a hot dog. Definitely not a sandwich.

Speaker 3: Wait a minute. A sandwich is defined as two or more slices of bread with a layer of toppings between each pair. We can all agree on that, right? So, a hot dog is between bread…

Speaker 2: But it’s open-faced! And the bread is connected. It isn’t technically between two slices of bread.

Speaker 3: Ah, but a sandwich can also be an open-faced sandwich, which is served on only one slice of bread.

Speaker 1: The verdict is: sandwich. A hot dog is a sandwich. [show on screen]

Whew, that escalated quickly!

What about tomatoes? [show tomato on screen]

Fruit or vegetable?

Speaker 2: Fruit, for sure.

Speaker 3: I agree, fruit. Fruits have seeds.

Speaker 1: Correct! It is a fruit. And just as a fun fact, an avocado is also a fruit, but it’s technically considered to be a berry.

Speaker 2: What?

Speaker 3: Seriously?

Speaker 1: Yes! A berry is a fruit with a pulpy pericarp [on screen: pericarp: the walls of a ripened fruit] in which the seeds are embedded. That definition matches the avocado. It’s fleshy on the inside with a big seed.

Speaker 2: That’s … my mind is blown.

Speaker 1: So, here’s another one that has the potential to spark lasting feuds. Coleslaw: Is it a salad? [coleslaw on screen]

Speaker 3: Yes! Absolutely.

Speaker 2: No! It’s coleslaw, not cole-salad.

Speaker 3: Tell me: what is coleslaw?

Speaker 2: It’s sliced up cabbage and vegetables…

Speaker 3: … like a salad. It’s a salad!

Speaker 2: Can we get a ruling here?

Speaker 1: I’m tempted to see how far this can go, but OK. Coleslaw is a salad of finely sliced or chopped raw cabbage.

Speaker 3: Next thing I know, you’re gonna tell me bananas are technically berries! (Speaker 1 looks at Speaker 3 and nods yes). OMG, they are?!

Speaker 1: Let’s do a dessert round. White chocolate. Is it actually chocolate?

Speaker 2: Oh, is it not chocolate? I always thought it was chocolate.

Speaker 3: Me too.

Speaker 1: White chocolate is milk and sugar, mixed with cocoa butter, but surprise! It contains no chocolate solids.

Speaker 2: This is all too much for me.

Speaker 1: I don’t make the rules. I just bring the definitions.

Speaker 3: Hey, really quickly, I just need to know: is it pronounced like pi-kahn or pi-kan?

Speaker 2: Pee-kan.

Speaker 1: All pronunciations are accepted.

Speaker 2: Fine, but caramel is said like kar-muhl, not kair-uh-mel.

Speaker 1: Actually, both of those are also OK to say.

Speaker 2: I can’t even. Everything I know is a lie. I think need a hot dog … sandwich.

Speaker 3: Next thing I know, you’re gonna tell me bananas are technically berries! (Speaker 1 looks at Speaker 3 and nods yes). OMG, they are?!

Speaker 1: Let’s do a dessert round. White chocolate. Is it actually chocolate?

Speaker 2: Oh, is it not chocolate? I always thought it was chocolate.

Speaker 3: Me too.

Speaker 1: White chocolate is milk and sugar, mixed with cocoa butter, but surprise! It contains no chocolate solids.

Speaker 2: This is all too much for me.

Speaker 1: I don’t make the rules. I just bring the definitions.

Speaker 3: Hey, really quickly, I just need to know: is it pronounced like pi-kahn or pi-kan?

Speaker 2: Pee-kan.

Speaker 1: All pronunciations are accepted.

Speaker 2: Fine, but caramel is said like kar-muhl, not kair-uh-mel.

Speaker 1: Actually, both of those are also OK to say.

Speaker 2: I can’t even. Everything I know is a lie. I think need a hot dog … sandwich.

love.name: Quotes On Love And Heartbreak
love.description: If you've ever experienced heartbreak, you'll understand these quotes.
love.transcript:
Want to read the books some of these quotes came from? Check them out below:

  • Milk and Honey
  • The Perks of Being a Wallflower
  • My Sister’s Keeper
  • Invisible Monsters
  • The Alchemist
  • Wuthering Heights
  • Airman’s Odyssey
  • Kafka on the Shore

bubbler.name: How Do You Say This Word In Your Part Of The Country?
bubbler.description: Have you ever heard a phrase said in a different part of the country, and it's said in just a slightly different way than how you say it back home? Those different phrases are called regionalisms. Do you use any in your state?
bubbler.transcript:
[should be friends sitting have a conversation]

host 1: Have you ever heard a phrase said in a different part of the country, and it’s said in just a slightly different way than how you say it back home? But, that one difference isn’t so subtle, it’s actually huge! Because, why in the world would you say “going down the shore” for “going to the beach,” right? Looking at you New Jersey!

Welp, New Jerseyans say “gown down the shore” because most people from the state are literally driving down the shoreline to get to the beach. [clip of someone saying this?]

host 2: Oh, what about this one! I’m _____ line at the cash register to check out. What’s the word you use?

host 1 (or 3): I’m “in line.”

Host 2: (smirks) Except in New York, they say “on line.” [show clip?]

host 1 (or 3): “On line”? For real?

Host 2: Yeah, I mean why do we say we get “on the phone”? Do we sit on top of it? No, but we all say “on the phone” (laughs)

Host 1 (or 3): All right, all right, that’s enough East Coast.

Host 2: What do you call that thing you can take a sip of water from while you’re at school or the airport? [show clip of water fountain with voice over]

Host 1: water fountain

Host 3: drinking fountain

Host 2: How about a … bubbler. Ah, that refreshing bubbler. At least that’s what I’d say if I was from Wisconsin, Massachusetts, or Rhode Island [show states on map]?

Host 1: That one makes me feel kind of all nice and bubbly. (smiles, happily shakes shoulders)

Host 3: OK, OK, I got one. I’m from the South, and when I moved to California, people made so much fun of me for using the phrase chill bumps.

Host 1: Uh, what’s that?

Host 2: Goosebumps?!? OMG, you call them chill bumps? That’s classic.

Host 1: Suddenly it’s feeling very cold in here … [gives side eye]

Host 2: Have you ever heard the phrase I swanee?

Host 3: I used to hear it all the time.

Host 2: Right, because you’re from the South, and in the South I swanee means, basically, “Well, I’ll be damned.”

Hoat 3: I swanee is an old-fahshioned expression for “I swear.” And, Lord-a-mercy, honey, Southerners don’t swear, they swanee.

Host 1: And while we’re on the South, I have to tell you all about this conversation I overheard in the grocery store when I was visiting Atlanta.

Host 2: I love Southern regionalisms, yay! [looks excited]

Host 1: This mom was basically telling her daughter that if she doesn’t try out for drill team, she’ll never know if she can do it or not. But, she legit said can’t never could in place of that whole If you don’t try, you’ll never succeed proverb.

Host 3: My grandma loved this one. This string of double negatives is actually meant as encouragement. It’s cute, right?

Host 2: love, love, love, dawlin’.

funemployment.name: Why Is "Funemployment" In The Dictionary?
funemployment.description: Is "funemployment" actually fun? And why is this word in the dictionary?
funemployment.transcript:
Contributor 1

So, funemployment. Unemployment, as you know, is when you don’t have a job or, more specifically, when you are laid off from a job and therefore you receive compensation on a weekly basis from the EDD. So, during this time you are supposed to be looking for a job. Sometimes you know your job is coming back and you’re only going to be laid off for a certain amount of time so during that time, rather than looking for another full-time job, you can take that time and kind of do some stuff that you wanna do. For example, I used to work for a very big reality TV show and we only ran for a certain amount of time and then we would have several months that we had off. Well, during that time that we had off, where I was not only using my savings but had my unemployment, I was able to focus on some of the things that I really wanted to do in the rest of my life and it was really really fun. And then I would go back to work as soon as it was time to get back on.

Contributor 2 

I have definitely experienced funemployment. And, it’s really fun in the beginning because you get all to, you know, go to the beach, or hang out with friends who also work weird hours, maybe they work at a restaurant or something. And you just get to derp around all day. Until you realize, you don’t have any money! Because your source of money, was your job. And, you didn’t actually file for unemployment. So, you have to get back on the grind of applying and the fun goes away.

comma.name: What Are Some Of The Biggest Grammar Pet Peeves?
comma.description: Let’s talk about some grammar pet peeves. We all have them. What are yours?
comma.transcript:
CONTRIBUTOR 1

Let’s talk about some grammar pet peeves. We all have them. You’ll pick up that document or read that email and just cringe a little because someone maybe a co-worker or a peer has written something that is inappropriately worded. And I’m– listen, there are the standards we’ll say. The Usual Suspects. The YOUR vs. the YOU ARE or THERE as in a place, or THEY ARE, contraction. That usage– if you haven’t figured that out and you’re a certain age… I’m worried about you, okay? So… But my big two were kind of a surprise to me. The first being, sort of an oddity if you will. It’s the contraction of “you all”. Which my Southerers out there will understand it’s y’all and that is Y apostrophe A L L. There are some monsters of the universe who choose to make the contraction with the apostrophe between the A and the first L. NOPE. That ain’t how it goes, bros.  Because, again, we are contracting “you all” and the Y is what’s retained, and we lose you know for whatever reason those two vowels and then it’s that contraction. So, that’s a big one for me. I see it and i’m like, “you don’t know any better do you?”

CONTRIBUTOR 2

My grammar pet peeve is the incorrect use of there, they’re, their. So … there, T-H-E-R-E, referring to a physical place. They’re, T-H-E-Y-apostrophe-R-E, a contraction for “they are.” And their, T-H-E-I-R, which shows possession.

So, for example, if you’re using it in a sentence, “We’re going over there for dinner.”  It’s T-H-E-R-E. Um, “They’re inviting us over for dinner.” so, they are, T-H-E-Y-apostrophe-R-E. Or, “Have you seen their new dog?”, T-H-E-I-R.

I think it really bothers me because it completely changes the context of a sentence when you’re writing out the incorrect there//they’re/their so people should just use a different word in the sentence to see if it still makes sense, um, especially they are. You can just break it apart to see if it fits in the sentence.

CONTRIBUTOR 3 – PART 1

Commas.

One of my biggest grammatical pet peeves is people that don’t use commas at all, ever.  This is especially noticeable in social media posts.   People just don’t use commas at all. Now I’m not going to go through all the rules because there’s there’s quite a few rules for using a comma, it’s a pretty prevalent punctuation so, I’ll just name a couple that should be pretty easy for people to use.   Especially on the internet people don’t use commas when attributing a quote before you say quote you got to put a comma in there you know. You know this celebrity said comma then the quote, it’s easy I don’t understand why people can’t remember to do that, it’s just one little comma.   The second one and this is one the boggles my mind the most is when you make a list of items or events or things you know just you’re listing off, like several, you know, four or five things, put a comma between them.

CONTRIBUTOR 3 – PART 2

Further and farther are very similar words, but did they get misused a lot. Now both can be adverbs and adjectives however their generally used as adverbs and that’s when people misuse them.   The problem is people misuse them by interchanging them when they’re just ever so slightly different.   They’re not the same word the general grammatical rule is further is a relation to metaphorical distance where farther is of actual physical distance.  Now the definitions of the words are further: going or extending beyond; farther: at or to a greater distance or more advanced point.   The way I can remember it is I can throw something far but I can’t throw it fur.

You know this celebrity said comma then the quote, it’s easy I don’t understand why people can’t remember to do that, it’s just one little comma.   The second one and this is one the boggles my mind the most is when you make a list of items or events or things you know just you’re listing off, like several, you know, four or five things, put a comma between them.

CONTRIBUTOR 3 – PART 2

Further and farther are very similar words, but did they get misused a lot. Now both can be adverbs and adjectives however their generally used as adverbs and that’s when people misuse them.   The problem is people misuse them by interchanging them when they’re just ever so slightly different.   They’re not the same word the general grammatical rule is further is a relation to metaphorical distance where farther is of actual physical distance.  Now the definitions of the words are further: going or extending beyond; farther: at or to a greater distance or more advanced point.   The way I can remember it is I can throw something far but I can’t throw it fur.

pet-peeve.name: What Are Some Of The Biggest Grammar Pet Peeves?
pet-peeve.description: Let’s talk about some grammar pet peeves. We all have them. What are yours?
pet-peeve.transcript:
CONTRIBUTOR 1

Let’s talk about some grammar pet peeves. We all have them. You’ll pick up that document or read that email and just cringe a little because someone maybe a co-worker or a peer has written something that is inappropriately worded. And I’m– listen, there are the standards we’ll say. The Usual Suspects. The YOUR vs. the YOU ARE or THERE as in a place, or THEY ARE, contraction. That usage– if you haven’t figured that out and you’re a certain age… I’m worried about you, okay? So… But my big two were kind of a surprise to me. The first being, sort of an oddity if you will. It’s the contraction of “you all”. Which my Southerers out there will understand it’s y’all and that is Y apostrophe A L L. There are some monsters of the universe who choose to make the contraction with the apostrophe between the A and the first L. NOPE. That ain’t how it goes, bros.  Because, again, we are contracting “you all” and the Y is what’s retained, and we lose you know for whatever reason those two vowels and then it’s that contraction. So, that’s a big one for me. I see it and i’m like, “you don’t know any better do you?”

CONTRIBUTOR 2

My grammar pet peeve is the incorrect use of there, they’re, their. So … there, T-H-E-R-E, referring to a physical place. They’re, T-H-E-Y-apostrophe-R-E, a contraction for “they are.” And their, T-H-E-I-R, which shows possession.

So, for example, if you’re using it in a sentence, “We’re going over there for dinner.”  It’s T-H-E-R-E. Um, “They’re inviting us over for dinner.” so, they are, T-H-E-Y-apostrophe-R-E. Or, “Have you seen their new dog?”, T-H-E-I-R.

I think it really bothers me because it completely changes the context of a sentence when you’re writing out the incorrect there//they’re/their so people should just use a different word in the sentence to see if it still makes sense, um, especially they are. You can just break it apart to see if it fits in the sentence.

CONTRIBUTOR 3 – PART 1

Commas.

One of my biggest grammatical pet peeves is people that don’t use commas at all, ever.  This is especially noticeable in social media posts.   People just don’t use commas at all. Now I’m not going to go through all the rules because there’s there’s quite a few rules for using a comma, it’s a pretty prevalent punctuation so, I’ll just name a couple that should be pretty easy for people to use.   Especially on the internet people don’t use commas when attributing a quote before you say quote you got to put a comma in there you know. You know this celebrity said comma then the quote, it’s easy I don’t understand why people can’t remember to do that, it’s just one little comma.   The second one and this is one the boggles my mind the most is when you make a list of items or events or things you know just you’re listing off, like several, you know, four or five things, put a comma between them.

CONTRIBUTOR 3 – PART 2

Further and farther are very similar words, but did they get misused a lot. Now both can be adverbs and adjectives however their generally used as adverbs and that’s when people misuse them.   The problem is people misuse them by interchanging them when they’re just ever so slightly different.   They’re not the same word the general grammatical rule is further is a relation to metaphorical distance where farther is of actual physical distance.  Now the definitions of the words are further: going or extending beyond; farther: at or to a greater distance or more advanced point.   The way I can remember it is I can throw something far but I can’t throw it fur.
