delicious.name: Can You Correct These Grammatically Incorrect Song Lyrics?
delicious.description: These lyrics may be catchy, but there’s one, big grammatical error within them. Can you spot it?
delicious.transcript:
These lyrics may not make a lot of sense, but there’s one, big grammatical error within them. Can you spot it? 

(singing) Every little thing she does is magic. (singing) Everything she do just turns me on. (singing) Even though my life before was tragic …

“Everything she do …”

How does it go from “everything she does” to “everything she do”?

Yeah … Yes, “everything she do.” 

Yeah, that doesn’t sound right.

”Every Little Thing She Does is Magic” has one of those great, explosive choruses that makes it impossible not to sing along. But, it’s hard not to cringe, as you arrive at the lyric, “Everything she do just turns me on.” In that sentence, the verb do should be does. 

(singing) I want your love and I want your revenge. (singing) You and me could write a bad romance. 

Could it be, “You … you and I”? 

“You and I” maybe? Yeah … “you and I.”

But I’ve never understood why though. 

I … you have to … I think you have to take out the, the first if it’s, like, a combination with and, you have to take out the first one and if the second part makes sense, like, “me could write a bad romance,” it would have to be I. “I could …” you know, it should stand alone.

– That sounds good.

– Oooooh …

In the case of Lady Gaga’s “Bad Romance,” Lady Gaga sings, “You and me could write a bad romance,” when it should be “you and I.”

(singing) If there’s something strange in your neighborhood, (singing) who you gonna call? (singing) Ghostbusters!

“Who are you gonna call”? “Who are you gonna call,” maybe?

Going … ?

[Makes “buzzer” sound] (Wrong!)

In the timeless “Ghostbusters Theme Song,” Ray Parker Jr. asks over and over again, “Who you gonna call?” The answer, of course, is the Ghostbusters which are a group of people. Since the Ghostbusters are a group, they’d be described using the pronoun them. And that means their theme song should technically ask, “Whom are you going to call?” 

(singing) T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you tasty. (singing) T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you tasty.

I don’t know … I like that song. (laughing)

– I just sing it. I don’t think about it.

– I did too, like, fifteen years ago … uh …

And on that note, in the early 2000s, Fergie’s hit song, “Fergalicious,” taught the world how to spell delicious and tasty. There’s only one small problem with the impromptu spelling lesson, the song spelled tasty incorrectly. The lyrics include rapper will.i.am chanting, “T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you’re tasty.” In reality, tasty is spelled sans E.

luscious.name: This Or That: "Delicious" vs. "Luscious"
luscious.description: Delicious and luscious are very similar words, which is why they are often confused with each other. So which one should we use to describe food?
luscious.transcript:
[Host with a bowl of strawberries]: Mmm … these strawberries look so luscious. I bet they taste delicious.

Wait, why did I use both of those words to describe the same thing. Is there a difference? [host points as if to cue the intro screen]

Of course there’s a difference. That’s why we’re here making this video. Ready? Here we go.

Delicious and luscious are very similar words, which is why they are often confused with each other.

Delicious comes from the Latin deliciae [dey-lee-kee-ay], meaning “delight.” Something delicious is delightful, for sure. [host smiles and looks up as  image of strawberries comes up over his head]

Usually, though, delicious refers to something that delights the senses, like taste or smell. Tasty food, like these strawberries, is often described as delicious. But, really, anything that you find pleasing can be delicious. It may sound funny, but you could say: “My dad has a delicious sense of humor.”

[host says this as an aside] To me, anyway. His terrible dad jokes aren’t for everyone … I get it.

However, when it comes to using delicious over luscious, it’s not a clear answer. The biggest advice we can give you is that, when describing something as luscious, it’s best if you’re trying to say that it is extremely delightful to the senses.

Luscious implies a particular richness or ripeness—a luxury. You wouldn’t call a richly decorated mansion delicious,  but it is probably luscious.

Luscious is also associated with, ahem, arousing sexual desire. You might describe a beautiful person’s shiny long hair as luscious.

Luscious can be used to describe something that looks, tastes, or smells especially wonderful, too, like a fragrant, creamy chocolate cake. Mmm … chocolate cake with strawberries. I’m hungry, in case y’all can’t tell.

Rhat brings me back to this wonderful bowl of strawberries. They are so ripe and juicy, they look and smell absolutely delicious. [takes a bite] And luscious, too.

gmo.name: Are GMOs Good Or Bad?
gmo.description: GMO foods have been around since the 1980s ... so why don't we know if they are good or bad yet?
gmo.transcript:
1 (holding and looking at a nondescript, packaged food, snarkily exasperated): I can’t eat this.

2: Why not?

1: It’s GMO.

2. Do you know even know what that means?

1: It’s, uh, uh—bad.

2. It’s a genetically modified organism. (display GMO and definition on screen)

1 (says initials a little more slowly): GMO.

2: And that means its genes, its DNA, have been modified, or altered, in some way.

1: Like making a pig glow in the dark.

2: That’s an extreme example. Most of the times we hear about GMOs—

1: It’s about food.

2: Scientists, for example, have genetically modified corn so it is resistant to certain herbicides, meaning it won’t be harmed if farmers spray for weeds.

1: And they inject cows with hormones so they produce more milk. That’s like, that’s like playing God!

2: It does sound like something out of science fiction, but consider this. How did we get cows and corn in the first place?

1 (tentatively): Domestication … ? >> could we put the definition on the screen, as below:

Domestication:
1. taming an animal by generations of breeding to live in close association with humans as a pet or work animal
2. adapting a plant to be cultivated by and beneficial to humans

2: Yep, from wild animals and plants, whose genes we modified by breeding and farming—

1: Over the course of thousands of years, though. It’s an entirely different thing when we splice some genes in a lab, release them into the wild, and then put ‘em on our plates!

2: Opponents, yes, are concerned that the foods aren’t safe and present unknown risks to our environment and health down the line.

1 (snarkily): I’m sensing a big “but” here.

2: But (laughs then serious), GMO foods have been around since the 1980s and have posed no more known risks to our health than non-GMO food. Plus, they hold a lot of promise for our future, like resisting drought or even fighting cancer.

1: The debate continues.

2: One thing, though, is not up for debate. G-M-O doesn’t automatically spell—

1: B-A-D. (pause, looks to 1 and says in a deadpan tone) You think—you think they’ll make pigs fly? [ show clip of pigs flying]

doorknob.name: What's The Funniest Word Your Kid Has Mixed Up?
doorknob.description: It's always funny (and endearing) when kids misspeak. Have your kids mixed up these words too?
doorknob.transcript:
Contributor 1: It’s always funny when kids mispronounce things. It’s usually more cute than funny and uh, uh, so endearing. One of the earliest “misspoken” moments I ever experienced with one of my kids is, my daughter called doorknobs “doorknocks.” And, it’s just so cute because a “doorknock” is kind of still a thing. It’s not the same thing as a doorknob but, it’s something you do with your that relates to a door. And, it’s just, I think a little into the tiny person’s when they say, “Uh … I can’t turn the doorknock.

Contributor 2: I am the proud aunt of a very smart, funny, articulate, um … four year old boy. And, uh, as it is with most young children or toddlers, there are going to be instances of miscommunication. And, one such um, miscommunication mishap um, occurred when, um, I took my nephew to the pool. When we got in the car, he said um, “Uncle Joe, Aunt Lou, um, do you guys have nickels?” Mmm … my husband and I looked at each other and we said uh, “Ya know, no we don’t, I don’t think we brought any change with us.” And he said, “No! Do you have nickels?” And he said, “You know my parents told me that everybody has nickels.” So, we get out of the car and, we, we make our way into the pool. And um, at that point, um, Uncle Joe took off his shirt and started uh, putting sunscreen on his chest. And, that’s when [laughs] my nephew looked and said, “Oh, Uncle Joe, see! You do have two nickels.” “Why did you tell me you didn’t?”

Contributor 3: In downtown Colonial Williamsburg, there are a series of little shops and whatnot. When my younger daughter was say, four to eight years old, she would often say, “I want to go to the ‘magicon’ store.” If we went to Disney, she wanted to go to the “magicon” store. So, after a fair amount of relentless questions, I finally deduced that the “magicon” store is the magician’s store.

Contributor 2: “Yesterday-ago” is a phrase that my three year old daughter uses quite often. She may say, “Yesterday-ago we went to the beach.” And, she’s talking about a family vacation that we took three months ago. She might also say, “Yesterday-ago we got ice cream.” To talk about how we just got ice cream like, ten minutes ago and we just got home. So, it’s something that just happened. And, she can also sometimes use it as in, “Yesterday-ago we’re going to go to Nana and Papa’s house, ” to talk about something that we’re doing in the future. You know, she’s just three she doesn’t really understand the passing of time. Saturday morning we start packing the car to make the drive to Nana and Papa’s house. And um, as we’re getting up my daughter looks at me and says, “What, what are we doing today?” And I was like, “Honey, we’re going to Nana and Papa’s house.” She goes, “Oh yeah um, it’s tomorrow.” And I’m like, “Yeah, yeah. So, so, now it’s today” And she said, “Oh um, but you said that we were going tomorrow so, we’re not going today.” And I said, “Well, but today is now tomorrow. So, so, yesterday was Friday, and now today is Saturday and today, since it’s Saturday, we’re going to Nana and Papa’s.” And she said, “No, but you said that we were going to go tomorrow to Nana and Papa’s and if Saturday is today then we’ll go tomorrow.” And I started to have this crazy uh, mind uh, blowing experience where I thought to myself, well what, wait a minute no but, today is now tomorrow … and now, now ta–yesterday uh, was what today was yesterday. But now we’re going tomorrow. And as I’m trying to explain how the passage of time continues and how today turns into tomorrow but now it’s today because it’s happening now and what happened yesterday is now in the past. And my daughter just stared at me blankly and she said, “OK.” And I said, “So, we’re going to leave for Nana and Papa’s now.” And she said, “Yeah, yesterday-ago.” And I just said, “Yesterday-ago.”

Contributor 1: All three of my kids read the Harry Potter series uh, pretty close together, and it afforded us some pretty funny misspoken, uh, names and words, which is pretty understandable. The Harry Potter title that I think is intentionally being misspelled or was being misspelled by my children was “The Prisoner of Azka-bananas.” I think it’s just fun to say, “The Prisoner of Azka-bananas.” Ah, if only as adults we could still just be as endearing when we misspeak.

nipple.transcript:
Contributor 1: It’s always funny when kids mispronounce things. It’s usually more cute than funny and uh, uh, so endearing. One of the earliest “misspoken” moments I ever experienced with one of my kids is, my daughter called doorknobs “doorknocks.” And, it’s just so cute because a “doorknock” is kind of still a thing. It’s not the same thing as a doorknob but, it’s something you do with your that relates to a door. And, it’s just, I think a little into the tiny person’s when they say, “Uh … I can’t turn the doorknock.

Contributor 2: I am the proud aunt of a very smart, funny, articulate, um … four year old boy. And, uh, as it is with most young children or toddlers, there are going to be instances of miscommunication. And, one such um, miscommunication mishap um, occurred when, um, I took my nephew to the pool. When we got in the car, he said um, “Uncle Joe, Aunt Lou, um, do you guys have nickels?” Mmm … my husband and I looked at each other and we said uh, “Ya know, no we don’t, I don’t think we brought any change with us.” And he said, “No! Do you have nickels?” And he said, “You know my parents told me that everybody has nickels.” So, we get out of the car and, we, we make our way into the pool. And um, at that point, um, Uncle Joe took off his shirt and started uh, putting sunscreen on his chest. And, that’s when [laughs] my nephew looked and said, “Oh, Uncle Joe, see! You do have two nickels.” “Why did you tell me you didn’t?”

Contributor 3: In downtown Colonial Williamsburg, there are a series of little shops and whatnot. When my younger daughter was say, four to eight years old, she would often say, “I want to go to the ‘magicon’ store.” If we went to Disney, she wanted to go to the “magicon” store. So, after a fair amount of relentless questions, I finally deduced that the “magicon” store is the magician’s store.

Contributor 2: “Yesterday-ago” is a phrase that my three year old daughter uses quite often. She may say, “Yesterday-ago we went to the beach.” And, she’s talking about a family vacation that we took three months ago. She might also say, “Yesterday-ago we got ice cream.” To talk about how we just got ice cream like, ten minutes ago and we just got home. So, it’s something that just happened. And, she can also sometimes use it as in, “Yesterday-ago we’re going to go to Nana and Papa’s house, ” to talk about something that we’re doing in the future. You know, she’s just three she doesn’t really understand the passing of time. Saturday morning we start packing the car to make the drive to Nana and Papa’s house. And um, as we’re getting up my daughter looks at me and says, “What, what are we doing today?” And I was like, “Honey, we’re going to Nana and Papa’s house.” She goes, “Oh yeah um, it’s tomorrow.” And I’m like, “Yeah, yeah. So, so, now it’s today” And she said, “Oh um, but you said that we were going tomorrow so, we’re not going today.” And I said, “Well, but today is now tomorrow. So, so, yesterday was Friday, and now today is Saturday and today, since it’s Saturday, we’re going to Nana and Papa’s.” And she said, “No, but you said that we were going to go tomorrow to Nana and Papa’s and if Saturday is today then we’ll go tomorrow.” And I started to have this crazy uh, mind uh, blowing experience where I thought to myself, well what, wait a minute no but, today is now tomorrow … and now, now ta–yesterday uh, was what today was yesterday. But now we’re going tomorrow. And as I’m trying to explain how the passage of time continues and how today turns into tomorrow but now it’s today because it’s happening now and what happened yesterday is now in the past. And my daughter just stared at me blankly and she said, “OK.” And I said, “So, we’re going to leave for Nana and Papa’s now.” And she said, “Yeah, yesterday-ago.” And I just said, “Yesterday-ago.”

Contributor 1: All three of my kids read the Harry Potter series uh, pretty close together, and it afforded us some pretty funny misspoken, uh, names and words, which is pretty understandable. The Harry Potter title that I think is intentionally being misspelled or was being misspelled by my children was “The Prisoner of Azka-bananas.” I think it’s just fun to say, “The Prisoner of Azka-bananas.” Ah, if only as adults we could still just be as endearing when we misspeak.

lick.name: How This Teacher Remembers Her Most Memorable Student Question
lick.description: A couple years ago, one of this teacher's students asked her a question that really threw her for a loop. Do you know the answer?
lick.transcript:
I have taught The Adventures of Tom Sawyer several times and every year I teach it, I know that my kids are gonna struggle with, um , the dialect – it’s super hard. Um, some of the chapters are really long and boring. I know it’s one of the harder novels that we read during the year. So every year before we read Tom Sawyer I try and take care of any problems that I see ahead of time. I try and make sure that they understand what’s happening, they have the right vocabulary skills so that when we start reading the story I can kind of stay ahead of those problems that might arise.

So, um, here I am, so confident, taught the book several times, feel like I know any question that might pop up. Um, until a couple years ago when a kid, um, asked me a question that really threw me for a loop. So a couple days in, um, we’ve read a couple chapters, I say to my students, “OK, um, how’s everyone feelin’ about the book?” You know, I kind of get some mixed reactions and I’m like, “OK, so, so tell me, like, what’s confusing? What’s something that you need clarification on?” And, you know, there’s a lot of blank stares, which I’m used to, so I waited a little bit and finally this kid gets up the nerve to raise his hand and I’m like, “Ok, what, what’s the deal? What can I help you with with The Adventures of Tom Sawyer?” And he says, “Um, I…don’t understand why Tom keeps telling people he’s gonna lick them? Like, isn’t that disgusting?!” And I look around the room and I see all the other students’ heads nodding and they’re like, “Yeah, that’s really weird.” And I’m like, “Wait! You think he’s actually gonna…lick people?!” And he’s like, “Yeah, well, in chapter one he says, “I can lick you” to the kid walkin’ down the street. Later on he says to Huck Finn, you know, “I’m gonna lick you if you don’t do this”. And he said, “It’s just such a weird, it, it’s such a weird threat!” And all the students are like, “Yeah, it’s just really kinda disgusting.” And I said, “Oh my gosh, you guys. You guys don’t understand that lick, in this case, does not mean that he’s gonna lick them. In this case, lick means that he’s gonna start a fight, he, that he can best them, that he can beat them at something, he can beat them up. And all of a sudden, I see the lightbulbs go off in their head and they’re like, “Ohhhh, yeah, that makes sense now!”

expressway.name: What Phrases Do You Only Hear In The Midwest?
expressway.description: There are a few words and phrases that these Midwesterners say that maybe the rest of the country doesn't. Here are just a few examples ...
expressway.transcript:
Contributor 1

Being from the Midwest and having the opportunity to travel this fine country over the years, I’ve noticed there’s a few words and phrases that we Midwesterners say that maybe the rest of the country doesn’t. Here are just a few examples: Expressway. When you want to get somewhere fast, take the expressway. What’s the expressway? It’s usually a highway, or interstate … usually in a big city. The expressway. Puppy chow. Now, no, we’re not eating dog food. Puppy chow is a, a sweet staple of many Midwestern family gatherings and classroom parties. Puppy chow it’s a, it’s a dessert usually made of uh, a certain cereal, powdered sugar, chocolate, peanut butter, some other stuff. Uh, a lot of times it’s also called muddy buddies, or, monkey munch, even reindeer chow. Puppy chow! We’re not eating dog food, we’re eating puppy chow.

Contributor 2

Cigarette in St. Louis is called a square. [laugh] So like, I’ve had an encounter where people ask me you know, “Do you smoke squares?” Or you know, “You know where I can get some squares?” But, one phrase that I’ve noticed in St. Louis that they say that is very, very popular, and that phrase is: On my mama. [laugh] And what on my mama means, something that you know is to be true. It has the same dynamics as, I swear to God. You know, you say, you know, “On my mama that ain’t true.” Or, “On my mama he said it.” You know, or, “On my mama I ain’t do that.” [laugh]

Contributor 3

So, a word that only some Midwesterners use, I think is, ope. O-P-E. Ope. So, you know, you’re at the grocery store and you accidentally get in someone’s way: “Ope! I’m sorry.” Or you’re, you know, turning around and you bump into someone “Ope! I’m sorry.” Or any sort of way to kind of apologize. Um, I don’t know, I don’t know [laugh] where this came from or how this started.

Contributor 1

Let me scooch by ya here real quick. Usually paired with the ever popular, Midwestern ope! Let me scooch by ya here real quick is just a way of saying, “Let me get around you.” Now, you can use it with people you know very well, you can use it with complete strangers. If you need to get around somebody whether in a crowded theater, or just in the grocery store: “Let me scooch by ya here real quick.” Easy. Now, these ones are a little confusing so, I’m going to go through them quickly and then we’ll break them down. Yeah-no. No-yeah. Yeah-no, for sure. That of course means: yeah-no = no. No-yeah = yes. Yeah-no, for sure = absolutely! See? Easy.

chicano.name: Have You Ever Found One Word That Helped You Define Yourself?
chicano.description: We asked some Dictionary users what words they've found that have helped them define themselves. Do you have that one word?
chicano.transcript:
The word Chicano used to be used as a derogatory term, um, to push down people of Mexican descent. But it was reclaimed during the first Chicano movement in the sixties and seventies. And it made a resurgence, uh, within the last ten years that was focused on staying in touch with indigenous roots of Mexican people. Growing up I always felt that I was kind of in between two cultures. I wasn’t quite Mexican, but I wasn’t quite American, either. Even though I was born in the US, I have Mexican family and I speak Spanish and it was always hard for me to figure out who I was. In college, when I was at orientation and I was trying to find something to get involved with. And I was talking to a group called Chicano Student Programs, and I asked them, “What does Chicano mean?” I had never heard it before. And they described something that really impacted me and it’s made me understand my identity so much more. It described who I am in a way that I had never thought of before where I wanted to be in touch with who I was, uh, and who my family is. But I also have another identity as being an American, and this really describes that intersection.

What is a Hufflepuff, you might ask? It’s not so much a “what” as a “who.” It is the last name of one of the founders of the four Hogwarts houses. The Hufflepuff house values loyalty, kindness, fair play, honesty, um, being humble. I don’t know why I’m crying? [laughs] Uh, a lot of kids probably when they were growing up wanted to be Gryffindors because that’s what Harry and his friends in the Harry Potter series are. The Gryffindors are cool and popular and strong and brave, but for a lot of us, um, I think as we grew up, we started to realize that the other houses had really important values, too. I can walk into a room full of people and say, “Hey, what’s your Hogwarts house?” and suddenly we could all find a point of reference to better understand one another. When I walk into a room and say, “I’m a Hufflepuff!” what I’m saying is I value loyalty and honesty. I’m saying that I may not be the bravest or the strongest or the most cunning or the most intelligent, but I care about my friends and I’m going to do what’s right because it’s the right thing to do and not because I expect to be rewarded for it.

So the first time I heard the word chink, I was in 5th grade. I went with my best friend to her cousin’s house in California. And when we arrived, he looked at me and was like: “Oh, you’re a chink.” And I was like: “ha, ha, ha. Yeah I’m a chink.” Not knowing what that meant. Later my best friend apologized for her cousin using the word chink as the Chinese ethnic slur. And that was a defining moment. I was like “wow,” you know, I’d never experienced that before. But I was like, “You know what? I’m proud of my Korean ethnicity and I’m not going to let him, you know, define who I am by calling me bad names like that.” So, I just make a conscious effort to be gracious and nice to others. Words have many different meanings and I think we need to make a conscious effort to stop. Use words for good—uplifting people—rather than, you know, bringing each other down.

I’m saying that I may not be the bravest or the strongest or the most cunning or the most intelligent, but I care about my friends and I’m going to do what’s right because it’s the right thing to do and not because I expect to be rewarded for it.

So the first time I heard the word chink, I was in 5th grade. I went with my best friend to her cousin’s house in California. And when we arrived, he looked at me and was like: “Oh, you’re a chink.” And I was like: “ha, ha, ha. Yeah I’m a chink.” Not knowing what that meant. Later my best friend apologized for her cousin using the word chink as the Chinese ethnic slur. And that was a defining moment. I was like “wow,” you know, I’d never experienced that before. But I was like, “You know what? I’m proud of my Korean ethnicity and I’m not going to let him, you know, define who I am by calling me bad names like that.” So, I just make a conscious effort to be gracious and nice to others. Words have many different meanings and I think we need to make a conscious effort to stop. Use words for good—uplifting people—rather than, you know, bringing each other down.

psychopath.name: What Is The Difference Between "Psychopath" vs. "Sociopath"?
psychopath.description: Despite all the confusion around the terms psychopath and sociopath, is there actually a difference? Let us explain!
psychopath.transcript:
Think of your classic con artist: they lie, they’re manipulative, they don’t care about anyone else, and they lack remorse. Are these criminals psychopaths? Sociopaths? Both?

People tend to think that a sociopath is a psychopath who doesn’t go around doing criminal things. Likewise, psycho remains shorthand for all kinds of deviant antisocial behavior, from stalking to murder.

We’ve got some news for you. Despite all the confusion around the terms psychopath and sociopath, clinically speaking, there is no difference. The DSM 5, the Bible of psychiatric disorders, doesn’t define sociopathy or psychopathy as official diagnoses. The technical term for it these days is antisocial personality disorder or ASPD, in case you were interested.

So, where does our popular understanding of these terms come from … the history of psychology folks.

I went to school for Psychology so hear me out …

In 1847, the term psychopathy was coined. Originally, it referred to any disease related to a mental illness. It comes from Greek roots meaning “suffering soul.” In 1885, the term psychopath became more widely known in relation to a horrible story: a girl named Sarah Becker was killed in Russia. A woman confessed to the murder, but her confession was thrown out after a psychiatrist, Ivan M. Balinsky, described her as a “psychopath.” While Dr. Balinksy likely meant this in the general sense, the English-speaking world took it as a mark of her violent, self-interested nature.

In 1930, an American psychologist, G. E. Partridge, studied the general category of psychopath closely. He came to the conclusion that psychopathy was too broad a definition to be useful. He proposed changing the expression to sociopathy to define antisocial behavior. Sorry, Dr. Partridge, but sociopathy didn’t really stick, either.

While psychopathy and sociopathy aren’t terms commonly found in a clinical setting, that doesn’t stop armchair psychologists from using them … like me. I’m getting my PHD …  one day … OK?!

et-tu-brute.name: The Meaning Behind "Et Tu Brute?"
et-tu-brute.description: There is more to this phrase than a simple translation. Watch and learn about the true meaning behind "Et tu, Brute?" in this video.
et-tu-brute.transcript:
Et tu, Brute?!

So “Et tu, Brute?” is a phrase from William Shakespeare’s “Julius Caesar”. It is Latin for, “And you, Brutus?” 

Julius Caesar was a Roman General and he went off and won all of these wars and came back to Rome and everyone in Rome loved him. They just thought he was the most amazing person ever and they wanted to make him the emperor. Some of his other generals and some of the Senators in Rome did not love Julius Caesar. As a matter of fact, they really disliked him and they were terrified that he was going to use this opportunity to become the emperor, so they conspired to kill him. One of Julius Caesar’s best friends, Marcus Brutus, was part of the conspiracy. He decided he needed to kill Caesar with love…so that he wouldn’t turn into a tyrant. When Julius Caesar came back from the wars there was a soothsayer or a truthsayer or a future seer who told him to beware the Ides of March. The Ides of March is the 15th of March. Caesar didn’t understand what he meant. Well, it turns out on the Ides of March Caesar went to the Capitol and that is where he was killed. They all literally stabbed him in the back and the very last persona to do so was Marcus Brutus. And when Brutus gave that last stab in the back, Julius Caesar turned and looked at him and said, “Et tu, Brute?” before dying. 

“You too? You’ve betrayed me too?” It’s often used in a comedic or ironic way. Say, for example, I go out to, uh, have lunch with a friend of mine and I’m complaining about the fact that I don’t have a job, but I need more money and I can’t pay my bills and this is the time that my friend decides to remind me that I owe him $25…”Et tu, Brute?” 

So kids, when it’s almost winter break and every teacher has given you homework but the last teacher of the day, who never gives you homework, you know is going to let you out early, and she tells you to have a book read by the end of break…now you know what to say.

down.name: What Were Your Favorite Words To Use In The '00s?
down.description: The aughts (the early 2000s) was a special time of boy bands, Raven Simone, and fun slang. What was your favorite word to use during this time?
down.transcript:
I definitely loved the language of the day. I remember, growing up here in southern California, we had like, a mix of, like, the emo scene, mixed with, like, growing up next to the beach. So, it was kind of a combination of that, so we would say things like chillax or rawr. Rawr was a big one. I don’t really know what we would ever say it to, except … everything. All the time. We also grew up with AIM, so LOL, LMAO, LMFBO, which I’ll let you guys figure that one out. But I think the one that stuck around the most was down. “You wanna do this?” “Down.” “Do you want to go to the beach?” “Down.” “Do you wanna paint my house?” “No, not really.” 

Um, most of what I know from my childhood is from the 2000s. Uh, a lot of it is from what I watched and what I listened to. I loved the show That’s So Raven on Disney Channel, so my favorite, of course, was “Oh, snap!” … “Ohhh, snap!” and “Ya nasty!” I heard that, ya nasty! Those were, of course, the most iconic phrases and of course I had to work them into my everyday language. I mean, “Oh, snap!” was so iconic it could be said for anything! It could be, it could be a joyous “Oh, snap!” or a [skeptically] “Oh, snap!” It was, it was so versatile I didn’t have to worry about it. I loved the phrase dawg. Like, calling everything dawg, but like D-A-W-G because, you know, that’s how the cool kids do it. But even, even my parents caught on, when my little brother, named Kaleb … uh, they called him K-Dawg. And still to this day, he is still K-Dawg. So, it stuck.  So, I look back and I think, “Maybe these were not the best phrases and the best words to be using.” And I don’t really use them today. Um, but maybe hey, uh, maybe we’ll look back in 10 years, in 20 years, and look back at the way we speak now and think, um [laughs], that it’s not cool anymore, and that we’re pretty lame for it. But … who knows?

germany.name: These Are Some Of The Most Mispronounced International Cities And Places
germany.description: If pronouncing cities and places in your own country is hard, try pronouncing international city names! Can you get these pronunciations, right?
germany.transcript: I grew up an army brat and we lived in Germany for awhile … Um … one of them is Weißenburg on paper it looks like, ‘vi-sen-berg’ and we didn’t know that in German you have to pronounce the ‘w’ as a ‘v’  and there’s also a special character that looks like a capital B and its known as an eszett in German. It’s actually the only language that has this character is German and its pronounced with a double ss. So Weißenburg looks like ‘vi-sen-berg’, but it…it’s not. That was interesting to learn. We never actually got a chance to go to Weißenburg, but one place we did go is Munich, and it’s a pretty popular German city. Everyone knows Munich, but for the longest time I couldn’t figure out where München was. and I spent a lot of time looking for it on a map. Turns out that’s how Germans pronounce Munich they say, “München.” While I was in Germany I played soccer for my high school team and we played against a lot of teams across Germany and from one city in particular it was Stuttgart, but on paper it looks like, ‘stuht-gahrt’. Also when we got to Germany for the first time and we landed at the airport we were being driven to the place where we were going to end up and all of us kids we kept seeing signs for a city for like an hour. Over and over again we kept driving past signs for this city and the cities name was Ausfahrt, so we finally asked the driver like is this the capitol … like “what is this city that there’s so many signs for”, and he let us know that that actually just means exit.

british.name: Think You Know British Slang?
british.description: Obviously. game shows about words are our favorite ... and now we've gone international. How many of these British slang words will you get right?
british.transcript:
Those Brits … why does their accent make them sound so attractive, distinguished, and smart?

It’s funny because half of what they’re saying is as crude as American English … it just sounds so much better.

Do you know what this British slang actually means?

Question #1: [I got a bit pissed last night]. That’s adorable, right? But, what does pissed mean?

[contestants guess] [host] In the US we may assume this meant a person was angry, but actually “pissed” means drunk, like pretty drunk.

Question #2: Sometimes you get so pissed you start throwing up and [it’s honking] … OK … what does honking mean?

[contestants guess] [host] Honking means it smells baaaad.

Question #3: After that real hard night of drinking and puking, your friends and you might reminisce about it [that night was a bloody cock-up]. So, what does cock-up mean?

[contestants guess] [host] Cock-up means that night was a bit of a bungle or mishap.

[host] Cheerio, mates

acai.name: Common Food Names We’re Mispronouncing
acai.description: These foods are fairly commonplace now ... but are you still pronouncing them wrong?
acai.transcript:
Oh, the food I really like to eat that a lot of people will mispronounce is quinoa. I first found out about this when I was working at a restaurant that, like, added it to our menu and people would come in asking, “What’s ‘kwin-oh-uh’?” Super confident and not even realizing that it’s wrong. And I had this struggle of, like, “Do I…tell them that…it’s ‘keen-wah’? Do I just ignore it?” “Oh, you mean the, the ‘keen-wah’?” and they sometimes would look at me kinda weird and wonder what I’m saying because it doesn’t necessarily look the same as what quinoa would be. Um, but, I usually would just try to correct them. If you’re wondering how to say it, it’s just two syllables. It’s “keen,” like you’re keen to do something, and then “wah,” so like the beginning of water.

I really like açaí bowls but I, before I knew it was pronounced “ah-sah-ee” I would say, uh, I think I used to say, “uh-chai.” There’s not even an H in it but I was just wondering what it could be. So I went in one day to order one from this smoothie shop that just started having these and I said, “Could I get an ‘uh-chai’ bowl?” And they looked at me like, “… What are you saying?” And then I pointed to it and they said, “Oh!  You mean an ‘ah-sah-ee’ bowl?” And I said this in front of a few of my friends so they’re all laughing at me as this, uh, employee is looking at me funny and so, that was kinda how I learned what açaí was. Uh, but I still eat those today … I just say it right!

hero.name: What Did The Word "Hero" Used To Mean?
hero.description: We've long been captivated by heroes, but who and what we call heroes has definitely changed over time.
hero.transcript:
Achilles, Joan of Arc, Martin Luther King, Mother Teresa, Spiderman … your friend who brought over the spare key when you got locked out of your apartment!

We’ve long been captivated by heroes, but who and what we call heroes has definitely changed over time.

The word hero goes back to the Ancient Greek heros. This was a man—yes, usually a man—of superhuman strength, courage, or skill. They were venerated as demigods, or “part divine and part mortal,” like the legendary Hercules or Maui.

English has the word by the 1500s for these mythic figures, but by the 1600s, hero was already naming people, regular ol’ people, of great bravery (usually soldiers) or achievement, like the astronomer Galileo.

And again, these were also usually men. That’s not because women were never considered heroic. From Amazon queens to Joan of Arc, history remembers many—though not nearly enough—examples. It’s just that they were called heroines, a female form of hero.

Fortunately, this gender divide has largely fallen away today. George Washington, Abraham Lincoln: American heroes. Harriet Tubman, Rosa Parks: Also American heroes.

Now, characters who don’t have the traditional qualities of a hero, but who we still often root for anyways, are antiheroes, like Huckleberry Finn … or Homer Simpson.

And then we have superheroes, a term actually found in the 1890s but, since the 1960s, now mostly used of comic-book characters like Wonder Woman or Batman. These are mythical characters of superhuman strength, courage, or skill, almost god-like in their abilities.

The word hero has come a long way, but the Avengers of the Marvel universe really aren’t all that different from Achilles of ancient Greece, right?

idiom.name: Can You Correct These Idioms?
idiom.description: Have you ever heard the idiom it’s a doggie-dog world? Well that’s not the correct phrase. It’s actually dog-eat-dog world. Can you correct these other common idioms?
idiom.transcript:
Have you ever heard the idiom it’s a doggie-dog world? Yeah, of course you have. You live in the 21st Century. But, guess what? That’s not the correct phrase. It’s actually dog-eat-dog world. Sinister, right? If you love seeing people get things wrong and learning something in the process, stay tuned for this episode of, Guess That Idiom.

I think it’s A. first come, first serve. I think it’s B though. First come, first served. 2. Why? Or, first come first serve like it’s presently happening. Alright, we’ll go with A.

[whispering] In the butt. I don’t … [laughs] In the bud! I’m thinking, like, you’re nipping weeds like … That’s funny. I don’t know. I’m thinking nipped it in the bud. Wait. But you’re reaction the first time …

I think it’s definitely intent. Yes I … I concur. 2. and purposes, like, the intent… I think the intent to do something, like, the act of …you know … I think that’s the correct answer. Heeey! 2. OK!

Mooot point. Moo… Moo… 2. Moot? Moot point? I’ve never heard this one. Moo… 2. Have you heard this one before? Just, like, keep saying moo. It’s fun. Mute point. Final answer. Ugh! See, cows! What did I tell you? They always win. Got it.

This is so funny because I always say, “You’ve got another thing coming,” but, listening to that it sounds like think is the correct answer. Yeah, I’m going to go with that. Oh, if you think you’re going to play me then, you have another think coming. That makes more sense, like, you’ve got another I just like all of that. 2. guess at life coming. That just works for me. 2. guess at life coming. Wow! See, I have to start saying it right now. I just … you should do that for every … all of them.

nostalgic.name: Kids Redefine Nostalgic Words From Your Past
nostalgic.description: This kid definitely showed us a new, hilarious perspective on nostalgic words we used to say all the time!
nostalgic.transcript:
When we asked this kid to define a Walkman, galoshes, a service station, and a typewriter … her answers definitely showed us a new, hilarious perspective on these nostalgic words we used to say all the time!

We guess a Walkman is a weird name for an old-school iPod, no?

not.name: What Is Your Favorite Word To Use From The '90s?
not.description: The 90s were a time of interesting fashion, music, and slang. What is your favorite word to use from the 90s ... and do you still use it today?
not.transcript:
Contributor 1

Yo! Check it! When it comes to all things ’90s, I’d say I’m a resident expert on all things music, fashion, “Pika!” and pop culture! “Hey hetero life mate, here’s a pop culture power up!” But also the lingo! I mean come on, I was totally hip to the know about what we were saying back in the day …  not!

Contributor 2

Growing up in the ’90s, I used to use quite a few slang words. Um, two that really stood out are: not. Uh, so you would say something like, “I’m so excited for work tomorrow … not!”  or “I really want to clean the bathroom … not!” So it was kinda jokingly saying, um, you wanted to do something but you really didn’t. 

Contributor 1

I think pop culture infused a lot of the lingo of the day. We had stuff like, show me the money! which we can thank a certain uh Gooding Jr. for [laughs]. Show me the money. And also, schwing!, uh, à la SNL’s “Wayne’s World.” Living on your own definitely has its perks. Schwing!

Contributor 2

The other one that I used quite a bit, and I think I still use it a lot today, is whatever.  So kind of when someone tells you something and you don’t care what they say. And I remember, in the ’90s, um, you would do the hand gestures and it was, uh, “Whatever!”

Contributor 1

I’d be really lucky if I could land,  like a solid yo mama joke. But the reality was I couldn’t. But if I did, I’d be like, “Score!” Well, this has been ’90s lingo.  By, your one and only resident expert of all things ’90s. Mm. That’s da bomb!

unlucky.name: Four Reasons Why Friday The 13th Is Unlucky
unlucky.description: There are many theories as to why Friday the 13th is considered an unlucky day. Fortunately, there aren't 13 of them. Aside from that whole horror movie thing, there are some old reasons why this day has inspired so many superstitions.
unlucky.transcript:
There are many theories as to why Friday the 13th is considered an unlucky day. Fortunately, there aren’t 13 of them. Aside from that whole horror movie thing, which is, to be sure, scary AF, there are some old, like Bible old, reasons why this day has inspired so many superstitions.

Reason 1: Jesus. Anthropology professor Phillips Stevens Jr. has argued that fear of the date may have been inspired in the Middle Ages surrounding Christian beliefs about the death of Jesus Christ.

According to Stevens, Jesus’ Last Supper is said to have had 13 participants, including Jesus, and occurred on the evening before his crucifixion on a Friday, leading to dark associations between Friday and the number 13.

Reason 2: Vikings and numerology. Sorry, Friday, but the fears around Friday the 13th may have to do with the unlucky number 13 itself. Here are a couple:

Viking lore: where the trickster Loki is believed to be the 13th god in the Norse pantheon; numerology: where 13 is in low regard because it follows 12, considered a very “complete” number.

Reason 3: self-fulfilling prophecy. The general rule of a self-fulfilling prophecy is that if you think it’s going to happen, it probably will.

If you’re expecting unlucky things to happen, you might even change your habits on days like this. That means that, maybe Friday the 13th is unlucky … just because we say it is.

Multiple studies estimate that businesses lose millions of dollars in revenue each Friday the 13th because some people avoid regular behaviors like traveling or making investments.

Reason 4: paraskevidekatriaphobia. Yup, that’s a frighteningly long word there. It means … “fear of Friday the 13th.” Maybe the day is unlucky because you have to figure out how to pronounce this word each time it occurs on the calendar?

Or maybe it’s Jason … OK, it’s definitely Jason, because I sure won’t be able to get him out of my head tonight.

a-m-.name: What Are "a.m." And "p.m." Short For?
a-m-.description: A.m. and p.m. ... we use them all the time, we know what they mean, but what in the world are they short for?
a-m-.transcript:
A.m. and p.m. … we use them all the time, we know what they mean, but what in the world are they short for?

It’s Latin, right? It has to be Latin …

Yup, the abbreviation a.m. is short for the Latin ante meridiem, meaning “before noon,” which refers to the period from midnight until noon.

And, p.m. then? It’s short for the Latin phrase post merīdiem meaning “after noon.” Got it.

One minute after noon is 12:01 p.m.

So, what’s the correct way to write these words: uppercase, lowercase, periods, no periods?

Well, according to the Chicago Manual of Style and the AP Style (some of the most prominent style guides out there y’all) the most common way to write these terms are the lowercase “a.m.” and “p.m.” (with periods).

And remember, 6 a.m. in the morning  or 9 p.m. at night is kinda redundant so save your breath and omit those extra words.

emigration.name: What Is The Difference Between "Immigration" And "Emigration"?
emigration.description: The words immigration and emigration both refer to leaving one country or region to live in another. So, what’s the difference between these terms?
emigration.transcript:
The words immigration and emigration both refer to leaving one country or region to live in another.

Pretty straightforward, right? Well, it’s also pretty easy to get turned around by these words too. So, what’s the difference between these terms?

Immigration and emigration share the same Latin root, migrare [mee-grahr-ay], which means “to move, transport.” It gives us migration, or “changing one’s place of residence.” The word dates back to the 1500s.

Great, but back to the whole differences thing … the real difference between the words immigration and emigration comes down to how they’re spelled. It’s hard to hear the difference when spoken, but a closer at their prefixes reveals the issues.

The e– in emigration ultimately comes from a Latin prefix meaning “out of.” Emigration is “migrating out of” a country or place. It’s leaving it, often due to lack of opportunity or various hardships.

The im– in immigration ultimately goes back to another Latin prefix, in-, meaning, well, “in” or “into.” So, immigration is “migrating into” a new place, typically on a permanent basis.

Whether someone is an emigrant or immigrant depends on their direction—on whether they are coming or going. If you leave the US to live in France, you emigrated to France. Bon voyage! If you leave France to live in the US, you’ve immigrated to the US. Bievenue!

Let’s look at another example. If you’re Portuguese and you’re worried that a lot of people are leaving for New Jersey, you might say, “Emigration is a real challenge for our nation.” If you’re an American living in New Jersey, you might say “Portuguese immigration is really good for our state.”

It’s all about your frame of reference.

binge.name: How Can The Word "Bingeing" Be Offensive?
binge.description: What's the issue with casually using binge ... like in binge-watch?
binge.transcript:
We binge-watch. We binge-eat. We binge-read. We even binge-listen to hit podcasts like Serial or Dirty John.

First recorded in the mid-1800s, binge was a word for “soaking a wooden vessel,” so that the wood would expand to prevent leaks.

By 1854, binge became a noun and verb describing heavy drinking bouts, you know, like “soaking” the body with alcohol.

In the 20th century, binge started being applied to other forms of “excessive indulgence,” such as binge-eating.

And by 1998, we found the term binge-watching enter our vocabulary.

So, what’s the issue with casually using binge … like in binge-watch? Well, even though it’s a part of English, using binge to refer to Netflix actually makes light of eating disorders because it draws attention away from the seriousness of the word. But binge-watch wasn’t the first to play on eating disorder language in this way.

Remember the 1990s? Remember the phrase gag me with a spoon, a reference to the act of making yourself throw up? Thankfully, that’s not a popular thing to say anymore.

Which is why we can probably move away from the phrase binge-watch (and binge-read, listen, etc.) pretty easily too. Like with one of these words … and these are only a few:

  • indulge
  • treat myself
  • splurge
  • gorge
  • devour
  • marathon

A Netflix marathon (way better than a running marathon just saying) can be just as good as a Netflix binge—plus it doesn’t shame those with eating disorders. Win-win.

adulation.name: Common Words That Originated From The Animal Kingdom
adulation.description: Did you know that the word "muscle" is derived from the Latin word for “mouse?” And this isn't the only word in the English language that is unexpectedly inspired by animals.
adulation.transcript:
A lot of everyday words have origins that might surprise you. Did you know, for example, that the word muscle is derived from the Latin word for “mouse?” Or that henchmen comes from the Old English term for “horse?”

And those aren’t the only words in the English language that are unexpectedly inspired by animals. Whether we realize it or not, many of our most common words share a rich etymological connection to the animal kingdom.

Take the word adulation. Meaning “excessive devotion to someone,” dog-owners experience adulation every time they return home and get smothered with dog kisses. The term traces back to the Proto-Indo European term for “tail.” So the original notion would have been “to wag the tail.” Aww.

The word berserk falls into a similar category. These days, we associate berserk with wild, deranged, or violent behavior. Like what we see every year on Black Friday. As Viking enthusiasts might already know, a berserk, in Old Norse, was a “raging warrior of superhuman strength.” But when you break the word down, berserk loosely means “bear shirt,” to the ancient Norse, and therefore a berserk was “a warrior clothed in bearskin.” Talk about fearsomely fashionable.

One last example can be found at your nearest grocery store: cantaloupe. Yet, a cantaloupe is a delicious peach-colored melon, but, surprisingly, the word relates to wolves. Cantalupo was the name of the region just outside of Rome where these melons were originally grown in the Middle Ages, and, in Latin, cantare means “to sing” and lupus means “wolf.” So the region–and therefore the melon–was named for the many wolves that could be heard “singing” in the night.

So the next time you offer someone a slice of cantaloupe or show your pet your undying adulation, remember the adorable origins of some of your favorite words.

Take the word adulation. Meaning “excessive devotion to someone,” dog-owners experience adulation every time they return home and get smothered with dog kisses. The term traces back to the Proto-Indo European term for “tail.” So the original notion would have been “to wag the tail.” Aww.

The word berserk falls into a similar category. These days, we associate berserk with wild, deranged, or violent behavior. Like what we see every year on Black Friday. As Viking enthusiasts might already know, a berserk, in Old Norse, was a “raging warrior of superhuman strength.” But when you break the word down, berserk loosely means “bear shirt,” to the ancient Norse, and therefore a berserk was “a warrior clothed in bearskin.” Talk about fearsomely fashionable.

One last example can be found at your nearest grocery store: cantaloupe. Yet, a cantaloupe is a delicious peach-colored melon, but, surprisingly, the word relates to wolves. Cantalupo was the name of the region just outside of Rome where these melons were originally grown in the Middle Ages, and, in Latin, cantare means “to sing” and lupus means “wolf.” So the region–and therefore the melon–was named for the many wolves that could be heard “singing” in the night.

So the next time you offer someone a slice of cantaloupe or show your pet your undying adulation, remember the adorable origins of some of your favorite words.

culture.name: What Does "Culture Shock" Mean?
culture.description: What does the phrase "culture shock" mean ... and how can a culture be shocking?
culture.transcript:
A lot of times, when people come to New York they talk about feeling culture shock. They see these huge buildings, they watch everyone moving real fast, and, with any luck, they run into a bonafide native New Yorker who takes that culture shock and elevates it to a catatonic state.  

So, what’s so shocking about big or foreign cities that makes people feel uncomfortable?

Well the concept of a culture shock has a lot to do with people leaving their comfort zone. In fact, it’s literal definition is “a state of bewilderment and distress by an individual who is suddenly exposed to a new, strange, or foreign social and cultural environment.”    

Sometimes, that bewilderment is simple and endearing, like craning your neck to see the top of a skyscraper. Other times, it’s a bit more serious, like expats who experience severe irritability and anger because they straight up cannot handle their new surroundings.

In texts as early as 1802, culture shock was even described as something “to be conquered.” It’s an interesting idea, conquering something like a culture … kind of medieval even.

But we think all of this is evidence that it’s time to change the meaning of culture shock. A culture can be shocking, very true, but in the same way a skyscraper can be. It’s big and magnificent and makes you look up instead of down. And, it can lead to a wonder and a desire to understand what makes other people and cultures tick … no conquering wanted or needed.

disillusion.name: What Makes You Feel Disillusioned?
disillusion.description: "Disillusion," or "disillusionment," is that feeling you get when you realize that everything isn’t rainbows and butterflies—that things aren’t as great as you imagined they were or hoped them to be.
disillusion.transcript:
We hear a lot these days about how great the economy is doing, but I’m not feeling it so much.

Sure, the stock market is at an all-time high, but I’m working two jobs to cover rent and driving Uber on the weekends to pay off my student loans. Meanwhile, just eight billionaires—eight people—have as much wealth as half the world. That’s almost four billion people. Four billion!

Yeah, I guess you could say I’m feeling pretty disillusioned.

Disillusion, or disillusionment, is that feeling you get when you realize that everything isn’t rainbows and butterflies—that things aren’t as great as you imagined they were or hoped them to be.

Think about the word as a word, one which goes back to the early 1800s. The dis-, here, means “a lack of” or “opposite,” such as dislike or distrust. So disillusion is “an absence of illusion.” It’s being freed of having any illusions that things are otherwise.

That sounds like a good thing, doesn’t it? Being free of illusions? To see things as they really are? Yes, that can definitely be positive, but disillusion carries with it a sense of disappointment—of being let down by the world, like politics or the economy or, you know, being a grownup.

See, I was always told you go to college, you get a good job, and then you retire. But college is expensive. Jobs aren’t as stable as they used to be. Plus, the numbers are showing that people in my generation are gonna have work into our 70s.

Poof. That’s sound of my illusions about life disappearing.

Yeah, I’m pretty disillusioned with things. I don’t have as idealistic or rosy a view of the world, but I’m also trying not to become another vocabulary word: cynical. I may not have the same illusions about the world I used to, but that doesn’t mean I can do some … re-imagining.

republican.name: What Is The Origin Of The Republican Party?
republican.description: And although today’s Republican Party–also known as the Grand Old Party, or the GOP—is the party of conservatism and small government, their beginnings might surprise you.
republican.transcript:
Our two main political parties, the Republicans and Democrats, are diametrically opposed on nearly every issue, from government spending to favorite NFL quarterbacks.

And although today’s Republican Party–also known as the Grand Old Party, or the GOP—is the party of conservatism and small government, their beginnings might surprise you.

The party was founded in 1854, in fervent opposition to the Kansas-Nebraska Act, a Democrat-supported act which would have allowed slavery to expand into new territories.

The first Republicans were a coalition of former Whigs and Democrats, pro-business economic modernizers, and northern abolitionists.

Their second presidential candidate they ever ran, in 1860, turned out to be a home-run: Abraham Lincoln. You may have heard of him.

Lincoln and his early Republicans expanded federal power in ways that are pretty, well, un-Republican today: new federal taxes to fund the creation of a nationalized bank system, a nationalized railroad, high import tariffs, and establishing the state university system.

Well, except those high tariffs. That has modern Republican written all over it.

So when did the Republican Party become the way we know it today?

Well, it was a slow process, but as early as Reconstruction, and into the 1920s, Republican administrations do things we’re familiar with today like passing tax cuts, immigration restriction acts, and business friendly legislation.

In the 1930s, Republican politicians lined up in opposition to president Franklin Roosevelt’s progressive New Deal reforms.

And after Democratic administrations through much of the tumultuous 1960s, 1969 saw Republicans at the top again with the election of Mr. Silent Majority himself, Richard Nixon, whose campaign platform is now an old Republican favorite: “Law and Order.”

Once Reagan rolled around in 1981 with his tax cuts, his supply-side economics, and his calls for smaller government, well, all you need to do is throw in a couple Bushes, some Fox News, and former reality television host Donald Trump, and that pretty much brings us up to speed to today’s Republican Party.

wear-out-one-s-welcome.name: What Does "Wear Out Your Welcome" Mean?
wear-out-one-s-welcome.description: What does it actually mean to "wear out your welcome"? This woman explains using a story from her college days.
wear-out-one-s-welcome.transcript:
I think I’m a great person to hang out with. But, sometimes, I worry that I wear out my welcome.

It’s uh … kind of weird, transitioning from living by yourself in college, being like a crazy kid that can stay up until like 1:00 AM and come home and eat nachos in your bed and no one really tells you otherwise, if that’s bad. Transitioning to that, to being back home with your parents is a little rough. I remember I would come home super late, and it would drive them crazy because I would always wake them up and eat nachos in my bed.

Welcome means “to greet the arrival of a person with pleasure or kindly courtesy.” When you’re wearing that out, you’re taking advantage of one’s welcome. So I was very, very much wearing out the welcome of my dear old mom and dad.

Needless to say, I’m no longer in college. I’ve got my own home to eat nachos in bed in, but, uh, that’s just a small example a time that I’ve felt that I’ve worn out the welcome of my loved ones as a guest.

set--up.name: Is It "Setup" Or "Set Up"?
set--up.description: Is the term setup one word or two? Does anyone know? Help!
set--up.transcript:
Is the term setup one word or two? Does anyone know? Help!

Why does English have to be so complicated?

Here’s the dilemma: When my sister walked in on her surprise birthday party … she yelled “This is a setup.” (She hates surprises.) And, she wasn’t wrong … but when I wanted to caption the picture I took of her saying that phrase … I had no idea which form of the word setup to use.

Upon doing a little digging (and by using some common-sense analysis) I think I may have found the difference!

Set up (two words) is a verb; setup (one word) is a noun.

So, when my sister said “this is a setup,” she was using the noun form—I should write it as one word.

But, when I set up her party before she walked in (I’m such a good sibling), I was performing an action—It’s a verb, and therefore it’s two words.

And, just to throw some more confusion your way (plus I’m a serious word nerd): the hyphenated set-up is more commonly used in British English whereas setup (without a hyphen) is more American English.

So, even though English is still pretty freaking complicated … the Dictionary is here to set you up (two words!) for success, don’t worry!

hello.name: Why Are There So Many Ways To Say "Hi"?
hello.description: Why on Earth are there so many ways to say "hi"? Is it because greeting people is something we all do ... all the time? Probably.
hello.transcript:
Have you ever noticed how many different ways there are to say hi to someone?

Hey! Hiya! Hello! Hola! Yo.

Where did all of these different words come from, and why on Earth do we have so many?

Originally a call to attract attention, the word hi, likely originated from the 15th century Middle English word hy or hey.

But, hi is an Americanism … the Americans created it, and actually it was the Native Americans as it was first recorded in the speech of a Kansas Indian.

It was our own special little greeting made in the USA.

So that’s interesting … but still, why so many different ways to say hi?

Well, it’s likely that we came up with all these ways to greet each other as an extension of trying to express a level of familiarity. And, hi is one that can work in most situations; that’s what makes it so versatile.

For example, when you walk into a job interview with a stranger, you would probably greet them with the more formal “Hi, how do you do” and not a “What’s crack a lackin’?!”

At least, we as a dictionary definitely wouldn’t advise that.

gift.name: Do You Give Presents or Gifts?
gift.description:
It's that time of year again!  Which will you be giving, gifts or presents? Speak without worry, because the giving of both presents and gifts are incredibly welcome this holiday season.

****Add yoast images.
gift.transcript:
Well, it’s that time of year again.

You know, giving gifts, receiving presents. But I guess the question is: Which is the right term?

They’re synonyms. That’s right. Basically, they mean the same thing. Now both of them have traveled quite a way, to get to the current definition that we use today. But, they both landed right around the same year. I think it was 1300.

Let’s start with the term gift. It essentially means now “to give something to someone without any expectation of payment, to honor an occasion, or to honor a person, or just to offer assistance.”

Present also had an interesting journey, from the old Norman term, or old French term, that essentially means the same as the adjective present now, which is “be there.” And, then eventually over time, it became synonymous with “the giving of something, to someone else.”

Speak without worry, because the giving of both presents and gifts are incredibly welcome this holiday season.

narcissism.name: Where Did The Word "Narcissist" Come From?
narcissism.description: In conversation, we tend to use this word casually to mean "a person who is overly self-involved, and often vain, and selfish," but "narcissist" actually has a pretty sordid history.
narcissism.transcript:
My neighbor is the classic definition of a narcissist.

It started off as mailbox conversations that seemed to revolve around only her.

She would never let me disagree with her opinion.

She had this superiority complex. She needed to always be the best … her, her, her.

In college, we read about Narcissus in Greek mythology.

One day, he came across a reflection of himself in a pool of water and fell deeply in love.

When he realized it was just a reflection, and his love could never be returned, he killed himself.

Now I know I went a little too dark. However, that’s where the definition of narcissist comes from.

In conversation, we tend to use the word a little bit more casually to mean “a person who is overly self-involved, and often vain, and selfish.”

Like when I talk about my neighbor, I wish I could have had a neighborly relationship with her.

But thanks to her narcissism, I’m hiding behind my drapes when I see her out on the sidewalk.

ignorant.name: What Is The Difference Between "Stupid" And "Ignorant"?
ignorant.description: Do you know the difference between the words "stupid" and "ignorant"? This man didn't either until, one day, he realized he should probably look the meanings up. Now, he can explain!
ignorant.transcript:
I remember years ago I was the director of a summer camp program that was put on by a major university in the Southeast, where I lived.

This one time, one of the counselors walked over to me during a free period and asked pretty casually, ”Are you from India or Asia?”

And, I thought to myself, unless they’ve moved one or the other, I’m from both. I remember walking away thinking, “how stupid.”

That term stupid, I used to use it all the time when I was a kid. I’d use it to describe lunch, or homework, or the girl I was sitting next to on the bus. I was misusing it all the time.

It wasn’t until I got older that I realized it was such a derogatory term. I found out that it came from the Latin word stupere to mean “amazed or stunned.” And, that’s exactly how I felt when that girl asked me that question.

It wasn’t until maybe the 1540s where it got the more derogatory ”mentally slow” label attached to it.

And, I realized this girl wasn’t mentally slow. She just didn’t have all the information about the subject.

In fact, she was ignorant, which is probably a better term, because ignorance means ”not having all of the information about a given subject or fact.”

I realized then, to not be ignorant, I should stop calling people stupid.

nauseated.name: How Do You Use The Words "Nauseous" And "Nauseated"?
nauseated.description: Does anyone know how to use the words "nauseated" and "nauseous" correctly? Let us try to explain.
nauseated.transcript:
Quick, think of something that makes you nauseous. Then think of something that makes you feel nauseated. First off, what is it?? Tell us! No wait, don’t! And secondly, what exactly is the difference between these two words?

Well, lucky for us the difference isn’t too extreme.

Nauseous and nauseated both come from the word nausea, which has roots in the Greek word naûs meaning “ship.” This means that both of these words can be used to describe a feeling of sickness, (often times from a ship). So, saying “I am nauseated by this rotten apple” or “This rotten apple has made me nauseous” are both correct.

However, nauseous has something a little extra to it: it can also be used to describe something that causes sickness, as in “This rotten apple is nauseous.” Aha!

Even with the slight distinction, when it comes down to expressing that horrible feeling of nausea, both words work! And anyone who has objections to the interchangeable usages will just have to come to terms with the rolling sea of meaning.   Ugh, just saying “rolling sea” makes me feel nauseous.

Nauseous and nauseated both come from the word nausea, which has roots in the Greek word naûs meaning “ship.” This means that both of these words can be used to describe a feeling of sickness, (often times from a ship). So, saying “I am nauseated by this rotten apple” or “This rotten apple has made me nauseous” are both correct.

However, nauseous has something a little extra to it: it can also be used to describe something that causes sickness, as in “This rotten apple is nauseous.” Aha!

Even with the slight distinction, when it comes down to expressing that horrible feeling of nausea, both words work! And anyone who has objections to the interchangeable usages will just have to come to terms with the rolling sea of meaning.   Ugh, just saying “rolling sea” makes me feel nauseous.

active-voice.name: How Do You Fix Passive Voice In A Sentence?
active-voice.description: What is "passive voice" and why exactly should we never use it?
active-voice.transcript:
English teachers love telling us not to use passive voice, right? I think I heard that about 10 times in 1oth-grade English-class alone! But, what is passive voice and why exactly should I never use it?

In passive voice, the subject of the sentence is acted on by the verb. For example, this dad here is being fed by his daughter.

But, in an active sentence, the subject is doing the action. The girl is feeding her dad (kind of, I don’t think she really got it in his mouth, but you get the idea).

Ok, let’s take another example.

These kids are having fun, cute right? The merry-go-round is being pushed by them … and it’s making me dizzy.

Except that sentence was in passive voice. An easier, quicker, and more active way to say it is: the kids pushed the merry-go-round. Simple.

Let’s get extreme.

The tightrope is making him unbalanced … ahh.

But, in active voice, he’s unbalanced on the tightrope, he’s the subject of the action. Either way, we’re scared for him!

Even when we’re low-key … passive voice finds us.

This woman was sent a message by me … we’re friends.

However, if I was a better friend I’d teach her more about active voice and say: I sent a message to this woman. Just saying.

So maybe passive voice is still confusing, but when it’s messing with your mind on that next English essay, remember that active voice is easier, it’s quicker, it’s usually less words, and it makes more sense. If a sentence is tripping you up, it’s probably because it’s in passive voice, and all you need to do is word it a bit more actively.

That essay wasn’t written by you, you wrote (and dominated) that essay! You’ve got this.

allies.name: We Asked: What Does The Word "Allies" Mean To You?
allies.description: This man answered ... "To be allies is people or entities coming together for a common purpose or for a common goal, you know?"
allies.transcript:
I think allies is seen as a scarier word than it needs to be sometimes.
When people think of it, they think of like World War II or countries being allied together, something on a big, epic, global scale, or with war, something big and terrible.
To be allies is people or entities coming together for a common purpose or for a common goal, you know?
A good metaphor is, like, is the binding of sticks together. You know, one stick, you know, it’s easy to break, but you bind a bunch of sticks together, that’s a lot harder to break, you know? They’re kind of stronger together.  
Coming together for a common purpose is kind of the whole point of being allies.
So, um, thanks for allying with me in this video.

catalyst.name: Can A Person Be A Catalyst?
catalyst.description: A catalyst means "something that causes activity, an event, or change." And usually, these events and changes are big. But, can a catalyst be a person?
catalyst.transcript:
A catalyst means “something that causes activity, an event, or change.” And usually, these events and changes are big … like in chemistry it’s how a match gets lit, or historically it could be something revolutionary like the Boston Tea Party, or more personally the dating app that led to you meeting your husband … crazy, life-shattering things like that.

So, the other day when my daughter’s teacher called her a catalyst, I was confused.

Can a catalyst be a person? Here’s what happened.

My daughter had a new girl join her class mid-year, and that is never easy. She was often eating lunch alone, or walking to school by herself, and my daughter mentioned that she wanted to help.

She recruited some friends, and together they invited the new girl to walk to school with them, ensuring that she felt welcome, which led to this girl becoming more energetic, happier, and more comfortable.

To me, that was just a nice act … something to make someone’s day a little better.

But, what her teacher pointed out, and why they called her a catalyst, was because her behavior actually caused the new student to open up while also causing the other students to be friendlier too.

So, yes, events, actions, and words are catalysts.

But, people can be catalysts too … and we don’t always have to be catalysts for extreme, life-changing movements and revolutions.

We can just be catalysts for positive, fun, good moods. Who knew?

orthopedic.name: Does The Word "Orthopedics" Just Describe Shoes?
orthopedic.description: Guess what, the word "orthopedics" doesn't just apply to shoes ... for old people.
orthopedic.transcript:
We all know that life is full of transitions, and I’m not just talking about this fun new haircut. Right? You guys can’t respond back to me. It’s a video.

I recently went under another fun little transition, um, which was shopping for orthopedic shoes. Yep. That’s right folks, and I am 24.

Yep. Turns out my feet are not so great. I have really, really high arches, actually. Thanks, Mom. Weirdly though, the word orthopedics was developed from the Greek word orthos meaning “straight and correct,” and paideia meaning “rearing of children.” So back in the day, orthopedics was actually a term that focused more on children than old people. So, that makes me feel a little better.

And, that leads us to the actual definition. It’s not actually about footwear, believe it or not. In fact, it’s a noun used to describe “the medical speciality that deals with the correction of the skeletal system, especially the arms, legs, and spine, and associated structures…like feet.”

The next time that anyone out there wants to make fun of me for wearing my orthopedic shoes, it’s not because I’m just looking after my high arches. No. I’m looking after my whole body. Yeah, that’s right, taking care of myself at 24.

e-g-.name: How Do You Use i.e. And e.g.?
e-g-.description: Have you ever been able to keep these two abbreviations straight? We've got a small little life hack to help you out!
e-g-.transcript:
I don’t know about you, but at this point in my life, I feel like I should more confidently know the difference between i.e. and e.g. I think it’s mostly because the abbreviations don’t actually help me remember which is which, and for too long I haven’t been able to keep them straight. But you know what, that’s changing TODAY.

I.e. and e.g. are both Latin abbreviations. E.g. stands for exempli gratia and means “for example,” so it would be a literal example of the thing being explained. I.e. is the abbreviation for id est and means “in other words.”

So by remembering the first letter for each abbreviation, I could start keeping them straight. The i in i.e. represents “in other words” and the e in e.g. represents “example.”

I’m so tired (i.e., go home)

The relationship didn’t work out (i.e., they dumped me)

The food was OK (i.e., I ate it because I was hungry, but the entire time wished it was better)

That wasn’t funny (i.e., that was crazy offensive … but I don’t want to start an argument right now).

I’m totally getting the hang of this.

I’m so tired (e.g., I fell asleep at my desk this morning)

She’s really sweet (e.g., she brought me a cupcake for my birthday)

He was nice (e.g., he takes care of his nephew after work)

I love being corny (e.g., Happy Hump Day coworkers!)

I’m so good at this (i.e., why did I wait this long to master something this easy).

cue.name: What Is The Difference Between "Cue" And "Queue"?
cue.description: Homophones are words that sound the same but mean different things (and are often times spelled differently too). "Queue" and "cue" are examples of homophones. Do you know what they both mean?
cue.transcript:
The other night I was out with my girlfriends and we all decided to take up a game of pool.

We lined up behind a few other people at the bar, got the cues and such after a nod from the bartender, and started playing.

Then, my one buddy, total dork that he is, pointed out that we experienced two similar words in one setting: queue and cue. He’s a high school English teacher so please just give her a break.

Although phonetically they sound the same, the words we experienced: cue and queue, are not only spelled pretty differently, but they mean entirely different things: queue means “a line or sequence of something and cue is to signal and also the names of those pool sticks we were using.

We’re all actually, totally word nerds.
