dad-joke.name: Dad Jokes Explained By Our Kids
dad-joke.description: A dad joke is a joke so corny or lame that only a tragically unhip dad would think it's funny ... or is it?
dad-joke.transcript:
What do you call a fake noodle?

An impasta.

Five fourths of people admit they are bad with fractions.

A dad joke is a joke so corny or lame that only a tragically unhip dad would think it’s funny.

You know the ones, the kind of joke your dad embarrasses you with when he’s dropping you off at the mall with your friends … but 20 years later makes you break down crying because you realize it was his way of saying “I love you.”

The shovel was a groundbreaking invention.

whose.name: Whose Vs. Who's
whose.description: Apostrophe or no apostrophe? That may be the real question.

distrust.name: What's The Difference Between "Mistrust" And "Distrust"?
distrust.description: Did you know there was a difference between the words mistrust and distrust? Yea, we didn't either. Watch Emmy explain ...
distrust.transcript:
Did you know there was a difference between the words mistrust and distrust? Yea … we didn’t either. Watch Emmy explain:

Hey there! My name is Emmy, and I’m here to talk about the fact that distrust and mistrust are two different words with two different meanings.

I can definitely confirm that most of my life I thought they pretty much meant the same thing.
Au contraire.

Distrust is the complete lack of trust that tends to be based on an experience. In my case, um… one time I ate chocolate cake, and it gave me the worst stomachache of my life, and because of that I distrust the chocolate cake that is sitting the break room for Karen’s birthday.

Sorry, Karen.

Mistrust is a complete lack of trust that tends to not be based on experience but more of instinct or gut feeling. I was looking at houses around the area, and I checked out this one house, and I got that gut feeling. Every part of my body was screaming at me that I mistrusted that house, and I needed to get out. So, instead of becoming a main character in a scary movie, I left because I mistrusted that house.

irregular-verb.name: How Did These Regular Verbs Turn Irregular?
irregular-verb.description: What's the difference between regular and irregular verbs? And why do regular verbs sometimes become "irregular" over time?
irregular-verb.transcript:
1 (as if in the middle of a story): … and so I sneaked out of the house and went to party anyways!

2: (looks blankly)

1: What?

2: It’s snuck. Sneaked just sounds … wrong.

1 (exasperated): I’m telling a story here!

2: And I’m telling you the past tense of sneak is snuck. (display sneak, sneaked, and snuck on screen)

1: It’s not leak and luck. It’s leaked.

2: Yeah, but speak turns to spoke.

1 (scrolls on phone): OK … says here we have been saying snuck since the late 1800s. Wow.

2: Yeah, so, I remember in English class, these were called irregular verbs—like sing, sang, sung. But because they’re irregular, we kind of stop using them after a while because it just doesn’t feel natural to say them. So they become regular over time. The past tense of help used to be holp, not helped.

1: So that means we also make regular verbs, like sneak …

2: Irregular. Yup. And not just sneak. Dive. (display and keep up on screen for next word)

1: Dove. (display on screen)

2: It was originally dived, but some people say dove on the model of drive/drove.

1 (half to self): Drive, drove, driven. Dive, dove … diven? (Shakes head “no.”)

2: Plead. (display and keep up on screen for next word)

1: Pled. (display on screen)

2: The original past tense of plead is pleaded. But, many people say pled on the model of irregular verbs like …

1: Lead/led.

2: Drag. (display and keep up on screen for next word)

1 (tentatively): Dr–, dr–

2: Drug. (display on screen) Some people say, “I drug the bag across the floor.” Not dragged.

But, the real morale of the story here is that it’s important to remember you can say either sneaked or snuck, dived or dove, pleaded or pled, and even dragged or drug, but the regular form, the one’s ending in –ed, are considered more appropriate for formal writing.

1: What about hanged and hung? (display both on screen)

2: Good one. We say “Criminals are hanged” but “paintings are hung.” The reason for this difference has to do with verbs in Old English and Old Norse. It’s actually a pretty neat story—

1 (humorously peeved): Uh, what happened to the story I was telling that you so rudely interrupted?? Huh, huh!?

2: OK, sorry. Don’t get so … hung up about it.

belch.name: What Do You Call These Bodily Functions?
belch.description: What do you call that red bump on your skin? How about that dried snot in your nose? Get ready for some bodily function talk ...
belch.transcript:
C1: A pimple.

C2: A zit.

C1: A second head.

C2: I never get those, what? I have perfect skin, what are you talking about? (laughter)

C1: A fart.

C2: Sometimes I like to call it a toot.

C1: A toxic tuba concert.

C1: (burp) That was lame.

C2: A burp! (laughter)

C1: A belch.

C2: A hangnail.

C1: The worst feeling ever.

C2: I usually call it poop.

C1: Poo poo. Doo doo. Toilet turds.

C1: Boogers. Nose crusties.

C2: I usually call it just … crusties. But I guess technically it’s mucus.

C1: Eye boogers. 

C2: Also crusties! I literally will wake up and say that I’m really crusty. That’s one of the first things that I say to my husband who … (breathing) What a lucky guy to have such a crusty wife. I mean like good for him.

C2: Also crusties! I literally will wake up and say that I’m really crusty. That’s one of the first things that I say to my husband who … (breathing) What a lucky guy to have such a crusty wife. I mean like good for him.

envious.name: This Or That: Jealous vs. Envious
envious.description: Are "jealous" and "envious" synonyms? What is the difference between these two words?
envious.transcript:
Would you say your girlfriend ever gets jealous?

Well, sometimes she comments on how I’m always laughing at my coworker Nora’s jokes. I mean, Nora is pretty hilarious—

OK, so would you say you have an envious girlfriend?

Who ever really says they have an envious girlfriend?

Yeah, that’s what I’m wondering about. Jealous and envious can be synonyms, right?

Totally.

I was jealous of the college my sister got into. There. I said it. I am envious of my friend’s new car. Nope. Not gonna hold back today.

In both situations, you’re bitter about something they have but you don’t.

Hey, now!

You said it!

Jealous can mean more than just envious, though.

Like a jealous girlfriend.

Right.

Your girlfriend’s jealous because she feels a little threatened or suspicious? That maybe you like Nora more than her? That maybe you’d be … unfaithful?

So, here’re some general guidelines.

Don’t cheat on people?

About jealous vs. envious.

Jealous and envious both can refer to negative feelings that result from another person’s success, advantages, and so on.

They both are also frequently followed by of. Jealous of, envious of.

But, jealous and envious often get at slightly different negative feelings. When we describe a person as envious, we are often driving at a kind of greedy desire they have. And when we describe a person, often in the context of relationships, as jealous, we are driving at those more suspicious, untrusting, overprotective, controlling behaviors.

Their jealousy is that they are going to lose something they have.

Oh, maybe I should go talk to my girlfriend

and maybe I should go talk to Nora … hm.

new-year.name: How Do Other Parts Of The World Celebrate The New Year?
new-year.description: How do other people in other parts of the world celebrate their New Year? Here are a couple of celebrations we love!
new-year.transcript:
… 3 … 2 … 1 … Happy New Year!

Host 1: This year, I’m going to start my New Year’s resolution right away.

Host 2: No time like the present! What is it?

Host 1: I’m going to learn more about other languages and cultures. Like, how do you say “Happy New Year!” in Spanish?

Host 2: ¡Feliz año nuevo!

Host 1: French?

Host 2: Bonne année!

Host 1: Wow. You’re good at this.

Host 2: Try me.

Host 1: Chinese.

Host 2: Mandarin, Cantonese, or … ?

Host 1: Mandarin.

Host 2: Gong xi fa cai!

Host 1: Gong xi fa cai …

Host 2: But, Chinese New Year doesn’t fall on January 1st. It’s known as the Spring Festival and falls between January 21st and February 20th.

Host 1: Oh, interesting … why is their new year in the spring?

Host 2: It’s based on a traditional lunar—or a moon-based—calendar. One tradition includes setting off firecrackers and giving money in red envelopes.

Host 1: Do other cultures celebrate a Lunar New Year?

Host 2: Yea! Korean New year is called Seollal. Vietnamese New Year is Tết

Host 1: Now you’re just showing off …

Host 2: Jewish New Year is called Rosh Hashanah. That means “head of the year,” and it falls around September and October each year, based on the Hebrew calendar.

Host 1: OK, OK, we get it, you have knowledge. But guess what, I know about Rosh Hashanah too! It’s marked by sounding a shofar, a ram’s horn, and bringing a sweet new year by eating apples dipped in honey.

Host 2: Shanah Tovah! Have a “good year”!

Host 2: Here’s one you may not know: Enkutanesh.

Host 1: [repeats] Enkutanesh.

Host 2: It’s the first day of the New Year in Ethiopia. It falls on September 11th, and features food, family, and flowers.

Host 2: The Islamic New Year falls on the first month of its lunar calendar, called Moharram. Because the Islamic calendar is 10–11 days shorter than the solar calendar, the date of Islamic New Year varies throughout the year. The day is more of a low-key, prayer-filled day.

Host 1:  What about New Year’s in India?

Host 2: It depends on where you are. India is a large and diverse country. In the state of Gujarat in Western India, Hindus traditionally observe the new year on the day after Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, which falls between October and November each year.

Host 1: However you say it, whenever you observe it …

Host 1 and 2: Happy New Year!

berry.name: Are These Foods Fruits, Vegetables, Or Berries?
berry.description: How can we know what is a fruit? A vegetable? A berry? A nut? Doesn't it seem like it's always changing? Why is it so confusing?
berry.transcript:
How can we know what a is a fruit? A vegetable? A berry? A nut? Doesn’t it seem like it’s always changing? Why is it so confusing?

After endless debates with my friends, my family, the internet … I’m here to help answer these categorization questions about some of our most confusing foods.

Zucchini: It’s a summer squash, and squash is a vegetable, right? Wrong.

Zucchini is a fruit. Why?!

In botany, or “the science of plants,” a fruit can be defined as a “ripened, seed-bearing ovary of a flowering plant.” Zucchinis have seeds, and the green tube is itself the ripened ovary of the zucchini flower.

The confusion is that botanists don’t really talk about vegetables and what they mean (in a botanical sense). In everyday life, we conventionally think of fruits as sweet and vegetables as all the leafy, root-y, bulb-y, tuber-y stuff.

So, what you and me call a fruit and vegetable are all just different parts of flowering plants we can eat.

Nope! Why would it be that easy … of course they aren’t true berries.

Botanically speaking, a berry is “a fleshy fruit that has one or more seeds and no stone,” like in a peach. That means the following things are berries:

  • bananas
  • grapes
  • oranges (a modified type of berry)
  • pumpkins
  • tomatoes; and
  • watermelons

The “seeds” you see on the outside of strawberries are actually little fruits themselves (called achenes), each with a tiny seed inside it. Whoa. Maybe we should consider changing the name?

OK, I’m ready for the next one … I think.

No, a cashew is not a nut because it is a seed?! What? Did I read that right?

Yes, the part of a cashew you eat is the seed—or, “an encased plant embryo” that can grow into a whole new plant—of the cashew apple, harvested from the cashew tree. Yes, cashews grow on trees. And, that means coffee beans are also seeds, which is weird.

To botanists, a nut is basically a hard, dry fruit.

Speaking of hard and dry, these classifications aren’t either … they are all just technicalities.

Don’t worry about these distinctions in everyday speech. You can call a zucchini a vegetable and a strawberry a berry.

Think of it this way: The zucchini is a culinary vegetable, but a botanical fruit. The strawberry is a type of fruit, yes, but botanically it’s not a berry.

And, whatever their real classification … I call (most of) them delicious.

Think of it this way: The zucchini is a culinary vegetable, but a botanical fruit. The strawberry is a type of fruit, yes, but botanically it’s not a berry.

And, whatever their real classification … I call (most of) them delicious.

zucchini.name: Are These Foods Fruits, Vegetables, Or Berries?
zucchini.description: How can we know what is a fruit? A vegetable? A berry? A nut? Doesn't it seem like it's always changing? Why is it so confusing?
zucchini.transcript:
How can we know what a is a fruit? A vegetable? A berry? A nut? Doesn’t it seem like it’s always changing? Why is it so confusing?

After endless debates with my friends, my family, the internet … I’m here to help answer these categorization questions about some of our most confusing foods.

Zucchini: It’s a summer squash, and squash is a vegetable, right? Wrong.

Zucchini is a fruit. Why?!

In botany, or “the science of plants,” a fruit can be defined as a “ripened, seed-bearing ovary of a flowering plant.” Zucchinis have seeds, and the green tube is itself the ripened ovary of the zucchini flower.

The confusion is that botanists don’t really talk about vegetables and what they mean (in a botanical sense). In everyday life, we conventionally think of fruits as sweet and vegetables as all the leafy, root-y, bulb-y, tuber-y stuff.

So, what you and me call a fruit and vegetable are all just different parts of flowering plants we can eat.

Nope! Why would it be that easy … of course they aren’t true berries.

Botanically speaking, a berry is “a fleshy fruit that has one or more seeds and no stone,” like in a peach. That means the following things are berries:

  • bananas
  • grapes
  • oranges (a modified type of berry)
  • pumpkins
  • tomatoes; and
  • watermelons

The “seeds” you see on the outside of strawberries are actually little fruits themselves (called achenes), each with a tiny seed inside it. Whoa. Maybe we should consider changing the name?

OK, I’m ready for the next one … I think.

No, a cashew is not a nut because it is a seed?! What? Did I read that right?

Yes, the part of a cashew you eat is the seed—or, “an encased plant embryo” that can grow into a whole new plant—of the cashew apple, harvested from the cashew tree. Yes, cashews grow on trees. And, that means coffee beans are also seeds, which is weird.

To botanists, a nut is basically a hard, dry fruit.

Speaking of hard and dry, these classifications aren’t either … they are all just technicalities.

Don’t worry about these distinctions in everyday speech. You can call a zucchini a vegetable and a strawberry a berry.

Think of it this way: The zucchini is a culinary vegetable, but a botanical fruit. The strawberry is a type of fruit, yes, but botanically it’s not a berry.

And, whatever their real classification … I call (most of) them delicious.

boojie.name: When Did "Boujee" Become A Good Thing?
boojie.description: Boujie used to be a bad thing. But, today, it means something different.
boojie.transcript:
Look, there’s nothing a bougie person hates more than being called bougie.

The word bougie comes from the 16th-century French word bourgeoisie [borj-wa-zee] which originally described city-dwellers but took on the connotation of the middle class by the 18th century. One of the reasons the bourgeoisie are so unpopular? Well, in the 19th century, communist Karl Marx put forward the theory that the bourgeoisie exploits the proletariat also known as the workers, under capitalism—not a great look.

In the 1960s, a time when the counter-culture was on the upswing in the United States, bourgeois was shortened to bougie. Anyone who took on the attitude or look of the middle class was deemed bougie—and it wasn’t a good thing. The term was adopted particularly in Black American community to describe middle class or wealthy Black folks, or those with upwardly mobile aspirations.

Today, bougie, sometimes spelled b-o-u-g-i-e, sometimes j-i-e, sometimes with two e’s at the end, is found particularly in hip-hop music, like the 2017 hit “Bad and Boujee” by Migos. Some folks, particularly in the Black community, have reclaimed the bougie moniker for themselves as a statement of their fabulousness. Some things Bougie Black People love, according to writer Damon Young at The Root? Pretending to enjoy La Croix, Questlove, and natural hair. More power to them.

But seriously, I am not bougie. I just love pumpkin spice lattes.

masochist.name: What's The Difference Between "Sadist" And "Masochist"?
masochist.description: These commonly confused words are a little sordid ... be prepared to learn the difference between the two.
masochist.transcript:
Yesterday we were all stuck at work till around 9:30 last night because our client decided to request some last-minute changes. 9:30!

When our boss told us, one of my co-workers called the She-Who-Shall-Not-Be-Named client a “masochist” when my other team member corrected him and said, “Actually, she’s a sadist.” The two co-workers, neither wanting to be wrong, had a bit of a back and forth. Then, of all people, our quiet secretary, Barb, chimed in.

She was  like, “alright everyone, listen up, I know the answer to this!” Masochists really like to humiliate themselves. Like, they get sexually aroused by either receiving pain or degradation. [Aside to the camera] I mean,not my thing, but you know, to each their own!

That was already a fair amount of info, but Barb kept going with more details! Apparently, it first popped up in the late 1800s as a term coined by a neurologist named Richard von Krafft-Ebing. Krafft-Ebing formed this denomination based on the writings of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch, an Austrian author whose writings involved a lot of scenes involving one guy, one girl, and, well…torture. The idea was that the more dominant the woman, the more smitten the man. That’s…uh… sweet, I guess?

A sadist, on the other hand, is a person that gets turned on by other people’s pain and humiliation (i.e., our client). Also coined by Krafft-Ebing, This personality type can be accredited to a lovely Frenchman called the Marquis de Sade, a writer who liked to pen stories about sex and–you guessed it–violence.

After that sexy history lesson, I came away with two things. 1) The interesting word histories of these two words, but more importantly, 2) the fact that quiet Barb seems like she may have a pretttttty interesting social life. Alright Barb. [sly approving tone with a wink]

charismatic.name: When To Use "Charismatic" Vs. "Charming"
charismatic.description: We often describe a charismatic person as "charming." But, we would never describe a charming house, outfit, or book, no matter how attractive they are, as "charismatic." Let’s break the spell of these two similarly compelling words.
charismatic.transcript:
We often describe a charismatic person as charming. They are confident and magnetic. They tell great stories but know how to listen. We want to be around them and follow them.

But, we would never describe a charming house, outfit, or book, no matter how attractive they are, as charismatic. Let’s break the spell of these two similarly compelling words.

Being charismatic is “having charisma.” Found in English in the 17th century, charisma comes from an ancient Greek root, charis [kah-ris], meaning “gift” or “favor.” It was historically used in the Christian Bible for “divine grace,” that is, a spiritual power or talent given from God.

In the late 19th century, the German sociologist Max Weber [vey-bur] likened this Christian charisma to leaders who have some extraordinary quality that gives them influence or authority over others. Martin Luther King Jr., for instance, had such charisma.

By the mid-20th century, charismatic was being used of people, like teachers, politicians, or speakers, who motivate or move us. They have a kind of charm that draws us in.

Which brings us to charming, which, of course, “has charm.” In the 1300s, when charm enters English from French, it referred to a “magic spell.” The word ultimately is from the Latin carmen [kahr-muhn], a “song” or “incantation,” which the ancients would chant hoping it would bring various successes in life.

A charming smile or story, then, puts us under its metaphorical spell. This is how charming comes to mean “alluring” more generally, a sense that came about in the 1600s.

So, a charming person isn’t necessarily charismatic. Though we do casually describe someone who is dynamic and likable as charismatic, we tend to reserve charismatic for people who truly inspiring or influential.

And, while a charismatic person is often charming in some way, charming is a nice way of calling not just people but also places and things as “pleasing” or “delightful.”

Unless it’s that charming little house your realtor wants to show you. That means it’s old—and needs a lot of work. Don’t let your charismatic Realestate Agent fool you!

Most of us know Dumbledore from “Harry Potter.” But, he’s not the only “dumbledore” in town …

[music playing] [artist illustrating]

overmorrow.name: Why Did We Stop Saying "Overmorrow"?
overmorrow.description: "Overmorrow" is the perfect word ... so why did we stop using it?
overmorrow.transcript:
No, no, no. The event is Saturday.

Two days from today. The day after tomorrow.

Am I not making sense here?

Don’t you wish there was a word for this?

Well, luckily, there used to be: overmorrow.

Overmorrow means “the day after tomorrow.”

There’s today, there’s tomorrow, then there’s overmorrow.

So, if today was Thursday, overmorrow would be,

yes, that’s right, Saturday.

Overmorrow had some currency in the 1500s

as both a noun and an adverb.

For instance, “Saturday is overmorrow”

or “The event will be held overmorrow.”

Now, I can’t guarantee that this word

will solve all of your communication problems,

but maybe it’ll at least help with your scheduling.

[on the phone] Hey!

OK, OK.

I think I can put some clarity to this.

So, the meeting is overmorrow.

What do you mean you don’t

know what overmorrow means?

dog.name: Do You Know How To Speak DoggoLingo?
dog.description: In DoggoLingo, a puppy is called a pupper. A teeny doggo is called smol. A big one is a woofer. Did you follow all that?
dog.transcript:
Back in 2005–2006, cats were the kings (and queens) of internet memes. Through adorable images and deliberately bad English like “I can haz cheezburger?”, these cute kitties sparked their own lingo on the internet, known as LOLcats. LOL means, of course, laughing out loud, and these furry felines were certainly hilarious.

But the LOLcats reign came to an end a few years later when cat’s mortal enemies came for them…

Doggos.

Doggo lingo is, like LOLcat slang, an internet language that revolves around the new meme royalty—dogs. In DoggoLingo, a puppy is called a pupper. A teeny doggo is called smol. A big one is a woofer. And, that adorable thing when a doggo has only a small portion of their tongue sticking out? There’s a word for that, too: blop. Oh, in the doggo lingo universe, dogs don’t bark—they bork. [dog woofing]

Doggos are so sweet and wholesome that when things are doing them a concern (DoggoLingo for “being worried”), their go-to expression is heck. Isn’t that heckin’ adorable? Yeah, heckin’ means “extremely” in DoggoLingo.

So, you might be wondering where all this DoggoLingo, also known as dog-speak, comes from. Like so many internet things, it seems to come from the hive mind—and the tendency for internet slang to play on misspellings of words and deliberately wrong grammar. But according to a 2017 NPR story, it’s possible that the seeds for DoggoLingo come from the Land Down Under: Australia.

See, in Australian slang, they often add O‘s to the end of words, often after shortening them. Instead of afternoon, they might say arvo. Definitely? Deffo. Business? Bizzo. You get the picture. So, in 2014, the Facebook group Dogspotting took off in Australia, where doggo had long been used as an affectionate term for doggies. This might have helped the term doggo to go viral, furthered along by the heckin’ popular Twitter account, We Rate Dogs.

DoggoLingo is active as a pupperino. But who knows, maybe one day it will go the way of LOLcats, clearing the way for the next adorable animal to take its place. We’re rooting for hippos.

jomo.name: JOMO: The Word You Didn't Know You Needed
jomo.description: We all know what FOMO is ... but what is JOMO?
jomo.transcript:
[sigh] I wish I was at Coachella.

You’re probably familiar with this sensation, right?

It’s called FOMO. Or, “the fear of missing out.”

Well, sorry, Coachella.

Today’s word is the complete opposite of that.

JOMO is the “joy of missing out.”

It describes that “feeling of contentment with one’s own pursuits and activities, without worrying over the possibility of missing out on what others may be doing.”

Not gonna lie, I was feeling pretty salty about not being at Coachella when I was scrolling through Instagram, but when I learned how hot and expensive everything was, I got a serious rush of JOMO.

Like, I’ll be honest … long lines to dance parties and Uber surcharges?

No thanks.

Oh, look.

It’s time for my meditation.

father.name: A Mom's Handy Word List For Questions That Won't Quit
father.description: To save your sanity while expanding your kids' vocabulary, here's a handy word list for questions that just won't quit.
father.transcript:
As a mother, I get real tired of saying the same words over and over and over and over. So, to save my sanity while expanding my kids’ vocabulary, I came up with this handy word list for questions that just won’t quit.

“Mom, can I have a snack?” How many times can you say OK before you break down and play dead? Let us help:

fine, affirmative, absolutely, all right, aye, by all means, certainly, definitely, gladly, indubitably, most assuredly, naturally, of course, positively, precisely, roger, sure thing, surely, undoubtedly, unquestionably, very well, yep

“Why?”

We all know because won’t cut it as an answer … so I tend to whip out one of these instead.

as things go, it came to pass, it took place, it transpired, it ensued, it materialized, it manifested, it eventualized

And how about this all time favorite: “Are we there yet?”

No is so boring, so you can always throw in a nay or nix.

Or …

about, approximately, around, essentially, practically, relatively, roughly, virtually, nigh, well-nigh, all but, bordering on, close to, for all practical purposes, in effect, in the neighborhood of, in the vicinity of, just about, near to, not far from, not quite, on the brink of, on the edge of, on the point of, on the verge of, pretty near, within sight of

These little word hacks are just small ways to make motherhood (or fatherhood, Dads you’re welcome to use these words too) a little bit more tolerable. Kids are cute and all, but wowza are they incessant and …

ceaseless, constant, continual, continuous, endless, interminable, nonstop, perpetual, relentless, round-the-clock, unceasing, unending, unrelenting, unremitting, day-and-night

despite.name: What's The Difference Between "Spite" And "Despite"?
despite.description: If you cut off your nose despite your face, that’s like lopping off your schnoz without any regard to your face. But if you cut off your nose to spite your face, you’re doing because you’re so mad at it. So which is it?
despite.transcript:
I was having this argument with my sister. She was saying that I’m on my phone so much it’s rude. Things got pretty heated, and I wanted to show her. So, I threw my phone…and the screen completely shattered.

“You really cut off your nose despite your face,” she said. Oh, I was fuming, but I knew I could get the last word. “It’s ‘to spite,’” I said. “The expression is ‘to cut off one’s nose to spite one’s face.’ Not ‘despite.’”

[title slide]

Mad as I was, my sister wasn’t exactly wrong, etymologically speaking. See, the word spite, which means “bitter ill will” or “to show malice,” was actually shortened from despite.

Despite is found in English by 1300. It originally meant “contemptuous treatment” or “hatred,” borrowed from French and ultimately from the Latin despicere [duh–spik-ur-ey], which means and gives us the word “to despise.”

We didn’t altogether lose despite, though. It became a preposition—you know, one of those words like from or under. “Despite our big fight, my sister and I still get along.” We can also use in spite of in the same way.

So, if you cut off your nose despite your face, that’s like lopping off your schnoz without any regard to your face. But if you cut off your nose to spite your face, you’re doing because you’re so mad at it. The point is, you’re creating a disadvantage for yourself because of your own spiteful actions.

Like destroying a perfectly good cell phone just to prove a point.

So, if you cut off your nose despite your face, that’s like lopping off your schnoz without any regard to your face. But if you cut off your nose to spite your face, you’re doing because you’re so mad at it. The point is, you’re creating a disadvantage for yourself because of your own spiteful actions.

Like destroying a perfectly good cell phone just to prove a point.

paradigm.name: This Teacher Helps Explain What "Paradigm Shift" Actually Means
paradigm.description: This teacher stopped telling students to put away their phones during class. Why? He underwent what is known as a paradigm shift. A paradigm shift is a dramatic change in a way of thinking or behaving.
paradigm.transcript:
I’m a high-school teacher, which means I’m constantly telling students to put away their phones.

Or, at least I was. Because I recently stopped. That’s right. I’m not demanding students have them off and in their lockers. I’m letting it slide when Steve snaps a selfie in science.

See, I underwent what is known as a paradigm shift. A paradigm shift is a dramatic change in a way of thinking or behaving.

We can thank the scientist Thomas Kuhn for paradigm shifts. He came up with paradigm shifts in his hugely influential 1962 book The Structure of Scientific Revolutions. In it, he looked at shifts, or “changes,” in scientific paradigms, or “fundamental ways of understanding the world.

Here’s a biggie: That the Earth revolves around the Sun and not the other way around. This paradigm shift didn’t just transform astronomy. It completely changed our sense of our place in the whole universe.

Kuhn used paradigm to mean a “world view” or “framework.” The word—that tricky G is silent except for in forms like paradigmatic—came into English in the late 1400 and originally was a “pattern” or “model.” It goes back to a Greek word, paradeigma [pair-uh–deyg-muh], literally “showing side by side.”

Over time, paradigm shift became a more general way of talking about a “significant change.” Like cell phones. They have brought about all sorts of paradigm shifts, completely changing everything from how we work to how we date to … how we learn.

I had always assumed that cell phones are just disruptions and distractions in class. Then, I realized that Megan listens to music because it helps her concentrate while Noah is on Wikipedia researching whales. But, here is what really spurred my paradigm shift: When I stopped bugging students about their phones every other minute and treated them more like adults? They ended up just putting them away on their own.

[To camera – takes on a bit of a teachers tone at first] Like you there. I’m sure you were just playing Candy Crush because it helps you commit all this information to your long-term memory, right? [wink]

homogeneous.name: Is It "Homogenous" Or "Homogeneous"?
homogeneous.description: When something is homogeneous, it’s “composed of things that are the same kind.” When something is homogenous, it’s—wait for it—homogeneous. In everyday settings, they mean the same thing.
homogeneous.transcript:
I recently moved to New York City and got to talking with a guy at my local coffeeshop. He asked me why I moved.

“Where I’m from,” I said, “everyone listened to the same music, wore the same clothes, drove the same cars. It was just too homogenous [huh-moj-uh-nuhs].”

“Don’t you mean homogeneous [hoh-muh-jeen-yuhs]?” he asked.

When something is homogeneous, it’s “composed of things that are the same kind.” When something is homogenous, it’s—wait for it—homogeneous. In everyday settings, they mean the same thing.

Why two different words, then?

Homogeneous, which some people also pronounce [hoh-muh-jee-nee-uhs] is older, recorded in the 17th century. It comes from the Latin homogeneus [hoh-moh-gen-ee-uhs], in turn from the Greek homogenes [oh-moh-gen-eys], literally “of the same kind.” Homos [oh-mos] means “same,” like homosexual, and genos [gen-os], “kind,” like genetic. It’s opposite is heterogeneous, where hetero- means “different.”

Around 1870, it looks like biologists started using this technical term homogenous for “structures that have a common origin,” such as how wings, fins, and arms all trace back to an evolutionary ancestor.

Homogenous doesn’t have that second E, but it does come from the same Greek roots as homogeneous.

Over time, it seems people started saying and writing homogenous for homogeneous. Maybe homogenous is easier to say and spell. Maybe the verb homogenize had some influence.

Today, homogenous has become more common homogeneous—except in chemistry class, where homogeneous mixtures are uniform ones, like a cup of black coffee.

But we still frequently use both words to describe two things in particular: groups and societies, whose people and culture aren’t diverse. Everyone is the same race, speaks the same language, practices the same religion—or, in the case of my hometown, just lived out the same lifestyles.

Which brings me back to the coffeeshop.

“No, I don’t mean homogeneous,” I said to the guy. “They mean the same thing…I just like to be a little different.”

lay.name: Two Nerdy Steps To Learn "Lay" vs. "Lie"
lay.description: When we asked this woman the difference between lay and lie ... she couldn't answer right away. Maybe her nerdy steps to learn how to use these words will help you learn the difference between lay and lie too?
lay.transcript:
When we asked this woman the difference between lay and lie … she couldn’t answer right away. Maybe her nerdy steps to learn how to use these words will help you learn the difference between lay and lie too?

I never really understood the difference between lay and lie. This is super embarrassing. Like is it lay in bed? Lie in bed? Is it lay your phone down? Lie your phone down? But … now that I’m a mom I figured I probably should know the difference between the two.

Step 1: research

So you say lie, when it’s something you do yourself. You say lay, when it involves an object.

Step 2: use in a sentence

Can you lay your water down please? 

You wanna lie down on the ground? 

Hazel, mommy is just gonna lie down on the couch just for a little bit to close her eyes. No. Wait. Gotta “mom.” Sorry. I’ll sleep … never.

hump-day.name: Boost Your Mid-Week Mood With This Phrase
hump-day.transcript: Wednesday first came to be known as hump day in the 1950s. The expression figures Wednesday, the middle of the workweek, as the hump people get over to coast into the weekend. And so, since the 1980s coworkers have wished one another “Happy Hump Day!” in acknowledgment that day-to-day work can be a drag. Fast forward to September 2013 when GEICO introduced a talking camel named Caleb … and soon camels + hump day became the perfect pair. Sometimes, hump day makes some people happier than others … happy hump day is frequently used on Wednesday in pornographic social-media posts, with accompanying images. Beware! So, in general, does saying “happy hump day” make hump day happier? It can’t hurt … or can it? We’ll do more research …

vomitorium.name: This Is Why You Should Not Judge A Word By How It Sounds
vomitorium.transcript: In the 1700s, Cassia of Rome warned that maybe we should judge a word by how it sounds. Sit back, it's story time. One night, Cassia was walking home when a charming man approached with an invite to a mysterious drama called "The Vomitorium." Cassia followed him to an ancient amphitheater. As he led her through the passageway next to the seats, she was confused when he opened a door that led underground. Inside were three men: Gaius, Ivan the Terrible, Vlad the III ... plus two empty chairs. As she realized who they were and where she might be, hell, Gaius started vomiting all over Ivan. Ivan couldn't handle it. He threw up on Vlad. Vlad seemingly enjoyed it—weird, Dracula—but wasn't immune and began puking. The vicious circle continued. Cassia bolted back into the passageway vomiting in the opening that led to the seats: The Tenth Circle of Hell, the Vomitorium. This story is fictional. Do not judge a word by how it sounds. A vomitorium, coined in the 1700s, is a passageway in ancient theaters that led to the seats, allegedly where ancient Romans deliberately vomited during feasts.

advice.description: When to use advice and advise

bribery.name: What Is The Difference Between "Bribery" vs. "Extortion"?
bribery.description: These are some of the oldest crimes we have in the history books, dating all the way back to English Common Law from the Middle Ages. But, even back then, there was a distinction between the two.
bribery.transcript:
So, a couple of weeks ago, a friend of mine goes to a really popular, crowded restaurant without making a reservation. He gets up to the maître d’ and she says, “I’m sorry but we have no available tables at this time.” So, my friend really wanted to impress his date, takes a 50 out from his wallet, flips it across the table. Boom, he’s in. 

My friend comes back to the same restaurant, but this time he learned his lesson, so he made a reservation. He gets up to the maître d’, but this time she says, “I’m so sorry, but we’re not able to honor the reservation at this time … unless you could maybe help me out?” So, my friend again, takes out a 50, (whooot) slides it across the table. 

Now, to be sure, bribery and extortion are closely linked. But, which one of my friend’s dinners was bribery, and which one was extortion?

These are some of the oldest crimes we have in the history books, dating all the way back to English Common Law from the Middle Ages. But, even back then, there was a distinction between the two.

Extortion is a word that dates back to the late 1200s. In extortion situation, you are trying to get something out of someone else, usually by force. You’re being forced to pay for average service that should actually be provided for free. It comes from the Latin word meaning “to twist out of.”

In a bribery situation, you’re giving something in order to get something else. You’re trying to get better-than-average service by paying an authority figure. This word is slightly older, dating back to the 1300s. It comes from the French word bribe, which meant to give scraps of food as alms, as in charity. That definition took a turn for the worse, didn’t it?

So, speaking of food, going back to the restaurant situation, what happened with my friend is he bribed the maître d’ and then she extorted him. My advice: go to a different restaurant. And, leave a Yelp review. [laughs]

oh-my-god.name: How Can This Phrase Exist In So Many Languages?
oh-my-god.description: There are a few choice words and phrases out there that have a tendency to transcend the language they’re uttered in due to the expansiveness of the idea behind them. So how do you say this common US phrase in other languages?
oh-my-god.transcript:
There are a few choice words and phrases out there that have a tendency to transcend the language they’re uttered in due to the expansiveness of the idea behind them.

Take the phrase Oh my God!

And, we’re not talking about today’s whole OMG thing.

The Oh my God we’re discussing has to do with the exclamation of surprise—either in a delightedly satisfied way or a scandalously shocked way.

Countries everywhere have their own version of Oh my God that they call upon any time they’re at a loss for words.

The French, for example, have sacrébleu!

Unlike the rather PG Oh my God though, sacrébleu is considered more of a profanity. It translates into “God damnit,” although literally it means “sacred blue.”

The Germans, on the other hand, like to say Gott in Himmel, literally translated to “God in Heaven.”

A bit more poetic than just a plain old Oh my God, and, in fact, it does serve for more dramatic use.

Our brothers and sisters across the pond favor the phrase, By, Jove!, when crying out to the Almighty.

Jove was another name for the king of the Roman gods, Jupiter.

To swear by Jove was originally a serious oath to take, and now it’s simply a matter of frustration or shock.

Jove also stems from the Latin word for love, so unbeknownst to them, thousands of English natives are swearing in the name of love … how sweet.

class.name: What's The Funniest (Or Most Embarrassing) Thing You've Said During Class?
class.description: School may not physically be in session right now, but you can still say funny (and really embarrassing) things in a Zoom class too! Watch these people's most embarrassing classroom moments. Can you relate?
class.transcript:
Contributor 1:

Everyone’s always called their teacher, “mom,” or said, “I love you,” before they left class, but to me, I was in Spanish class and I was trying to explain to my teacher that I was embarrassed, so I said, “Muy embarazada.” And he looked at me like I was crazy, and I was confused like, “Wh-what’s wrong? What’s wrong?” And he was like, “That means pregnant.” And I was just … shocked.

Contributor 2:

For a while, I used to work as a peer educator, going to schools and sharing information about safe sex and how to prevent STDs, HIV, that kind of thing, with middle school and high school students. So, while I was training for this position, I was up in front of all of the rest of my, uh, student educators. We were all practicing together on what we would say in front of the students. What I was supposed to say is, “Casual contact is safe.” Casual contact meaning high-fiving, hugging, that kind of thing. Nobody’s gonna get an STD from high-fiving their friend.  What I said when I went up and I saw all of my peers out there and I got really nervous, I said, “Casual touching is safe.” And I know it’s just, like, a little different in wording but it sounded really wrong. The moment it came out I thought, “Noooooo. That’s not what I meant to say.” And everyone just burst out laughing and I was so embarrassed because I, if I had said that in front of actual students, oh my gosh, that would’ve been a problem.

Contributor 3:

At one time in the fifth grade, my teacher, Miss Coleman, seemed to know a lot, including what we’re thinking. So one day I decided to ask her if she was psychic. Instead of asking if she was psychic, I ended up asking, “Miss Coleman, are you psycho?”

empathy.name: What Is The Real Difference Between "Empathy" And "Sympathy"?
empathy.description: Empathy and sympathy both describe feelings, especially toward another person. But what is the real difference between them?
empathy.transcript:
Screen 1: What is the difference between empathy and sympathy?

Screen 2: Both sympathy and empathy have roots in the Greek term páthos, meaning “suffering, feeling.”

Screen 3: But sympathy is the older of the two terms. It entered English in the mid-1500s.

Screen 4. Sympathy means:

1. harmony of or agreement in feeling, as between persons or on the part of one person with respect to another.
2. the fact or power of sharing the feelings of another, especially in sorrow or trouble; fellow feeling, compassion, or commiseration.
Screen 5: In other words, sympathy is when you feel bad for another person … but you don’t know what it is like to be in their shoes.
Screen 6: Empathy entered English a few centuries after sympathy—in the late 1800s.
Screen 7: Psychologists began using empathy as a translation for the German term Einfühlung and the concept that a person could project their own feelings onto an object.
Screen 8: Empathy means (definition screen layout):
the psychological identification with or vicarious experiencing of the feelings, thoughts, or attitudes of another.
Screen 9: In other words, empathy is the ability to imagine oneself in the situation of another, experiencing the emotions, ideas, or opinions of that person.

flammable.name: This Or That: Play Along With This Quiz Show On Commonly Confused Words
flammable.description: Today, we're quizzing people on camera in front of you all to see if they know the difference between these commonly confused words. Do you know the answers?
flammable.transcript:
Have you ever been in the middle of a conversation only to be tripped up by two very similar words. You pause, you contemplate, and you choose one hoping it was the right choice. We’ve all been there … but today, we’re going to make the stakes even higher. We’re quizzing people on camera in front of you all to see if they know the difference between these commonly confused words.

Question 1: What is the difference between infamous and notorious?

Answer: Infamous describes a person, place, or thing known for “having an extremely bad reputation.” Think: Fyre Festival. Notorious can also mean “widely and unfavorably known,” but it can also describe someone “publicly or generally known, as for a particular trait.” So, it’s not all bad w/ notoriety.

Question 2: What is the difference between empathy and sympathy?

Answer:

  • sympathy is feeling compassion, sorrow, or pity for the hardships that another person encounters
  • empathy is putting yourself in the shoes of another, which is why actors often talk about it

Bonus Question: What is the difference between flammable and inflammable?

Answer: There isn’t one, they mean the same thing: “able to be set on fire.”

Host: Interestingly enough, the “in” in inflammable doesn’t mean “not flammable.” But inflammable comes from the Latin inflammāre, “to inflame.” Think about this as “setting on fire,” of “putting flame into or onto (something).”

Contestants: How can we refer to something that isn’t flammable, then?

Host: In a word? Nonflammable. Now that’s makes sense.

Contestants: How can we refer to something that isn’t flammable, then?

Host: In a word? Nonflammable. Now that’s makes sense.

notorious.name: This Or That: Play Along With This Quiz Show On Commonly Confused Words
notorious.description: Today, we're quizzing people on camera in front of you all to see if they know the difference between these commonly confused words. Do you know the answers?
notorious.transcript:
Have you ever been in the middle of a conversation only to be tripped up by two very similar words. You pause, you contemplate, and you choose one hoping it was the right choice. We’ve all been there … but today, we’re going to make the stakes even higher. We’re quizzing people on camera in front of you all to see if they know the difference between these commonly confused words.

Question 1: What is the difference between infamous and notorious?

Answer: Infamous describes a person, place, or thing known for “having an extremely bad reputation.” Think: Fyre Festival. Notorious can also mean “widely and unfavorably known,” but it can also describe someone “publicly or generally known, as for a particular trait.” So, it’s not all bad w/ notoriety.

Question 2: What is the difference between empathy and sympathy?

Answer:

  • sympathy is feeling compassion, sorrow, or pity for the hardships that another person encounters
  • empathy is putting yourself in the shoes of another, which is why actors often talk about it

Bonus Question: What is the difference between flammable and inflammable?

Answer: There isn’t one, they mean the same thing: “able to be set on fire.”

Host: Interestingly enough, the “in” in inflammable doesn’t mean “not flammable.” But inflammable comes from the Latin inflammāre, “to inflame.” Think about this as “setting on fire,” of “putting flame into or onto (something).”

Contestants: How can we refer to something that isn’t flammable, then?

Host: In a word? Nonflammable. Now that’s makes sense.

sympathy.name: What Is The Real Difference Between "Empathy" And "Sympathy"?
sympathy.description: Empathy and sympathy both describe feelings, especially toward another person. But what is the real difference between them?
sympathy.transcript:
Screen 1: What is the difference between empathy and sympathy?

Screen 2: Both sympathy and empathy have roots in the Greek term páthos, meaning “suffering, feeling.”

Screen 3: But sympathy is the older of the two terms. It entered English in the mid-1500s.

Screen 4. Sympathy means:

1. harmony of or agreement in feeling, as between persons or on the part of one person with respect to another.
2. the fact or power of sharing the feelings of another, especially in sorrow or trouble; fellow feeling, compassion, or commiseration.
Screen 5: In other words, sympathy is when you feel bad for another person … but you don’t know what it is like to be in their shoes.
Screen 6: Empathy entered English a few centuries after sympathy—in the late 1800s.
Screen 7: Psychologists began using empathy as a translation for the German term Einfühlung and the concept that a person could project their own feelings onto an object.
Screen 8: Empathy means (definition screen layout):
the psychological identification with or vicarious experiencing of the feelings, thoughts, or attitudes of another.
Screen 9: In other words, empathy is the ability to imagine oneself in the situation of another, experiencing the emotions, ideas, or opinions of that person.

stan.name: Where Did The Slang Word "Stan" Come From?
stan.description: Stan. Is it a male's given name or slang for a "diehard fan" of, you know, BTS or Arya Stark? Both! So how did this word evolve?
stan.transcript:
Stan. That’s my dad’s name. Come to think of it, my mailman’s a Stan, too. Hi, Stan. Thank you!

So, how on Earth does stan become slang for a “diehard fan” of, you know, BTS or Arya Stark?

Eminem. Slim Shady. Yep, the rapper. We can thank him for stan. And I’m, like, kind of obsessed with this fact.

[Title slide]

In 2000, Eminem came out with the track, “Stan.” It was about a fan, named Stan, who becomes dangerously obsessed with him.

[Open to cutting: The song and video also featured the singer Dido. Remember Dido? [Hums part of chorus of “Thank you.”] Oh yeah, we still stan Dido.]

“Stan,” apparently, made an impact on another hip-hop artist, Nas, who used stan as an insult for “an obsessed fan” in a 2001 diss track.

How stan spreads from there is one of the fascinating mysteries of language, but by 2008, stan is on Urban Dictionary and Twitter.

Into the 2010s, stan was taken up in online fandom culture as a noun and verb. If you’re really into Mariah Carey, you’re a Mariah stan or you stan Mariah. [Can cut out, too: And, as any true stan of Mariah will know, her fans even have a nickname: lambs.]

Early on, stan could have a negative connotation. It could imply “excessive” or “crazy,” like Eminem’s Stan.

People definitely described themselves as stans, but they could be seen as too into the celebrities or fictional characters they loved—to the point of going at other people if they criticized their faves.

Now, stan has evolved somewhat. As a verb, to stan is more generally “to love or admire” someone. It’s often used in the phrase we stan when a famous person is being authentic or relatable or … just being decent and doing what’s right. Not always for the big, obvious stuff.

Like when Chris Evans helped Regina King onto the stage at the Oscars …

Or, when my mailman gives treats to all the doggos on my street. We stan.

converse.name: What Is Accent Prestige Theory?
converse.description: No accent is more correct than another. And, here’s the irony. None of us talk the same way all the time. So why do we think some accents sound better than others?
converse.transcript:
[Speaking in exaggerated Southern accent] This cookie tastes real good.

[Speaking in exaggerated British accent] This biscuit is absolutely lovely.

Which sounds more intelligent? Which sounds more trustworthy? More successful? Even more attractive?

The person who sounds like they are from the South … or the person who sounds like they’re from across the pond?

How you answer this question may depend on something called Accent Prestige Theory. According to this theory, we make judgments about other people—including their character and social status—based on how they talk.

Do you say? [words on screen with each item]:

vase [in General American accent] or vahz [exaggerating British accent, open A with Z sound at end]

aunt [in General American accent – like the bug] or aunt [exaggerating British accent, ah sound]

totally [in General American accent] or totally [exaggerated valley girl accent]

Many people think certain accents sound smarter and sexier.

See, certain dialects of a language—which we broadly refer to as accents—are considered more “correct” or “better” than others [air quote to indicate these terms are subjective]. These accents tend to be the standard form of the language, so, these are usually the pronunciations you hear from mass media, government, business, education … from the dominant social group. 

At least in more formal settings, we’re told the General American accent sounds smarter, more honest, safer—and that’s because it carries the prestige of social standing. And that means accents have consequences.

If we give the General American accent prestige, that means we judge Southern accents, Black accents, Latin accents, Boston accents, the speech of teenaged girls. And that ain’t right.

No accent is more correct than another. And, here’s the irony. None of us talk the same way all the time.

We talk one way with our peers and another with our elders. We talk one way around the kitchen table and another in the conference room. This is a good thing. We can speak in different ways to get different things done. Bing, bam, boom.

But, let’s try not to fall under the false belief that sounding British means you’re smarter and sounding Southern, Latin, Bostonian, and so on, means you can’t be trusted. There’s no right or wrong way to speak.

Variety, as they say, is the spice of life–and of language. [Looks at cookie. Takes bite. Mmm.]

firstly.name: Words In The Dictionary That People Hate
firstly.description: Listen up, word nerds, this video is for you. Firstly, don't hate ... watch with an open mind. Because words like firstly may be nonstandard, sure, but that doesn't mean they're wrong.
firstly.transcript:
Listen up, word nerds, this video is for you.

Firstly, don’t hate … watch with an open mind.

Because words like firstly may be nonstandard, sure, but that doesn’t mean they’re wrong, OK.

Formal usage is for the birds … at least in this video … because we’re all about the fluidity of modern English, which takes into account all the different types of English spoken in our diverse culture.

Everyone is legitimate and valid in our dictionary (go ahead, go look up firstly, it’s in there).

And, what we really need to conversate about is accepting all the dialects and regionalisms that exist within this here US of A.

Yup, we said conversate.

It’s not just us … a lot of other people have been using conversate since the 2000s, too.

Yes, it has the same function as converse but isn’t that why we have a Thesaurus … because words have synonyms (or other words that have similar meanings).

We bet you think this video is funner then an English class, because it sure is!

And, funner is most definitely a very informal substitute for more fun yet acceptable all the same.

So, now that you’re fuming because we’ve used these nonstandard words in very standard ways … let’s all remember to respect one another, irregardless of grammar rules.

(Come on, we had to throw irregardless in).

caramel.name: Why Do These Words Have Different Pronunciations?
caramel.description: How is it possible that a word, spelled the same way, can have so many different pronunciations? Caramel, data, either ... how do you pronounce these words, and which way is correct?
caramel.transcript:
1st Host: How is possible that a word, spelled the same way, can have so many different pronunciations?

2nd host: Oh yea, like the word data? I really hate that word … because if it’s not my boss criticizing me about how I say it, it’s the internet.

And they’re all telling me the way to pronounce data is always dey-tuh.

But this doesn’t stop people (me) from saying dat-uh instead. I know, it’s why analysts hate me and Star Trek fans roll their eyes. [nod to Data from Next Generation].

1st host: I feel you. Because my word that I always trip up on is caramel [kar–uh-muhl].

2nd Host: OMG, it’s caramel [kahr-muhl]!

1st Host looks annoyed … see? So, because I’ve tried to so hard to figure out how this word is pronounced, I’ve learned a few things about it:

1. It comes from the Latin calamellus, “little reed,” but its meaning influenced by a different Latin expression, canna mellis, meaning “sugar cane.” Calamellus This word was adopted by the Spanish and later the French, becoming “care-e-melle” [bougie French accent].

2. Once the word was adopted into English, the variation of pronunciations began.

3. Which means, more importantly, that I can pronounce it however I like. [wags finger]

2nd host: You’re so strange, haha. I have one for you …. either [ee-ther] or [ahy–ther], which one is it?!

1st host: Ha, I’ve actually heard this word pronounced differently, sometimes in the same sentence by the same person.

2nd host: What I’ve learned is that the correct pronunciation of this word has been a problem child for centuries. Grammarians back in the 1600s were prescribing pronunciations, which, back then, included [ey–ther].

1st Host: So, what you’re saying is you can pronounce this word … either way [cheeky grin]? I’m here all week, folks.

temper-tantrum.name: What Are The Best Words To Stop A Temper Tantrum?
temper-tantrum.description: Temper tantrums. If you're a parent, you know there is no easy way to avoid them. But these parents have some words that have worked to them during these stressful moments. Maybe they'll work for you too!
temper-tantrum.transcript:
TRANSCRIPT

Contributor 1

Kids have temper tantrums. My 18 month old had one just this week when I made the mistake of buttering her bread. We were at a dinner at my husband’s grandma’s house. And she did not want that bread buttered, and so she screamed and threw a fit and was just beside herself. So I read that if your child is throwing a temper tantrum to kind of get on their level, get at eye level, so they know you’re looking right at them and not towering above them. And just kind of say, “I know you’re upset, I’m sorry Mommy buttered your bread, um, but how can we make this better?” And just kind of talk them down. Because toddlers, and really, kids of any age will go through every emotion in a matter of seconds, just to kind of test the waters. So, if they know that you’re, you know, on their level and talking to them, then they’re more likely to be more reasonable. So, we were able to exchange the buttered bread for regular bread and everything was OK.

Contributor 2

One day we, uh, were, uh, at the supermarket and she want something. And she start crying and she start screaming. And she, you know, the whole package. So she start rolling on the ground or something. And she was, I believe she was 2 or 3. Well, I was not having it. So, I just um put my knees down and get myself to her level and so I try to talk to her and she was not responding. And I just said, I don’t know out of no where I just said breathe. Darling breathe. And I don’t know why she, she really did it she started breathing (Breathing in). (Laughs) In the middle of the crying and everything. And she start breathing and we did it for like 3 or 4 times. Deep breathing.  Just breathe. Yes. Do it again.(breathes in) And she’s five now and that’s my go to. 

Contributor 1

I have also learned that another great tool is: distraction. You know. Anything else. Oh, look at that over there. What’s the doggie doing? Oh, look at grandma, what’s she having for dinner? You know, anything else that can distract them from the current situation that is making them upset is another great idea.

bogus.name: Do You Remember This Radical 80s Slang?
bogus.description: When you re-hear to this 80's slang you'll feel like you've been transported back in time. Do you remember these totally 80's words?
bogus.transcript:
Contributor 1

My name’s AJ and I’m a child of the ‘80s! Much of my vernacular has been influenced by a certain quartet of reptilian practitioners of ninjutsu – the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Totally radical, dude! Righteous! Cowabunga! Totally tubular! For someone who’s never surfed I have a lot of surfer lingo in there thanks to Michelangelo. Let’s see…it’s pretty gnarly…except for when it was bogus!

Contributor 2

One word that I find myself using all the time is dude. I use it, usually, when I’m very serious: “Like, dude.” And, it comes from, back in the 1800s, it was actually an insult. Yankee Doodle Dandy. It was Americans that were trying to get gussied up and emulate the style of Europe at the time. So, it’s pretty funny that it was an insult, and now people use it as a sign of affection. Like, “Hey, dude!” Or, like me, “Like, dude.” Very serious. Another word that I find myself using is radical. I use it a lot in business meetings actually, like when someone has a great idea. It’s just totally rad. I can’t help it. I have to say it. That comes from the [Latin word for] root, actually, so it’s easy to remember. Radish is a root vegetable, and radical is the word that comes from that.

Contributor 1

That’s all I got…PSYCH! See you weren’t ready for that. I…PSYCH!…got ya! PSYCH! I don’t say that too much anymore. That was really annoying back then and, eh, it continues to be so today. 

Contributor 2

Another word I find myself using is awesome, because, you know it’s a great word. Awesome.

Contributor 1

If I got a problem with somebody, “What’s your damage?” Even today I still say that.  Actually, if I, I’ve got a problem with somebody, I’ll ask, “What’s your damage?” But in closing for real this time…Be excellent to each other. And party on, dudes!

If I got a problem with somebody, “What’s your damage?” Even today I still say that.  Actually, if I, I’ve got a problem with somebody, I’ll ask, “What’s your damage?” But in closing for real this time…Be excellent to each other. And party on, dudes!

psych.name: Do You Remember This Radical 80s Slang?
psych.description: When you re-hear to this 80's slang you'll feel like you've been transported back in time. Do you remember these totally 80's words?
psych.transcript:
Contributor 1

My name’s AJ and I’m a child of the ‘80s! Much of my vernacular has been influenced by a certain quartet of reptilian practitioners of ninjutsu – the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Totally radical, dude! Righteous! Cowabunga! Totally tubular! For someone who’s never surfed I have a lot of surfer lingo in there thanks to Michelangelo. Let’s see…it’s pretty gnarly…except for when it was bogus!

Contributor 2

One word that I find myself using all the time is dude. I use it, usually, when I’m very serious: “Like, dude.” And, it comes from, back in the 1800s, it was actually an insult. Yankee Doodle Dandy. It was Americans that were trying to get gussied up and emulate the style of Europe at the time. So, it’s pretty funny that it was an insult, and now people use it as a sign of affection. Like, “Hey, dude!” Or, like me, “Like, dude.” Very serious. Another word that I find myself using is radical. I use it a lot in business meetings actually, like when someone has a great idea. It’s just totally rad. I can’t help it. I have to say it. That comes from the [Latin word for] root, actually, so it’s easy to remember. Radish is a root vegetable, and radical is the word that comes from that.

That’s all I got…PSYCH! See you weren’t ready for that. I…PSYCH!…got ya! PSYCH! I don’t say that too much anymore. That was really annoying back then and, eh, it continues to be so today. 

Contributor 2

thanks.name: Do You Remember Your Favorite Teacher?
thanks.description: Watch Chuck Wendig, Stephanie Land, Chris Grabenstein, and Veronica Roth thank their favorite teachers and talk about how they helped inspire their writing careers.
thanks.transcript:
I knew that I was a writer when I was in the fourth grade. I had a teacher named Mr. Birdsall. This is my very first journal when I was in his class, and it stretched to … there are two shelves of journals here!

Writing is pretty much my favorite activity in the whole world. My favorite thing about being a writer is that I get to do it all the time, and make a living off of it, which is really the dream! One of the reasons that I’m here and I’m able to do this for work is that I had a really significant teacher in my life. That teacher’s name is Ryan Gobel. He was my sophomore year English teacher. He had a really inventive and engaging and unique teaching style. Um, and he interacted with us like, um, in a more, I don’t know, collegial kind of way, which was great and the first time that had ever happened to me. What he mostly did is he encouraged me to take my writing seriously, as something that was worthy of my time and worthy of attention.

My seventh grade English teacher, Mrs. June P. Garrett, at Signal Mountain Junior High School in Signal Mountain, Tennessee. Mrs. Garrett loved to laugh, and I liked to write funny essays whenever I had a homework assignment. And she liked what I wrote so much, she wrote in the margins of one of my papers, “You will make your living as a writer someday!”

I was a daily writer for a very long time, and it grew into a book that’s called Maid and it has been translated into, I think, maybe twelve languages. Most of my English teachers have, in some way, given me something. Uh, you know, Mrs. Book from fifth and sixth grade, Mrs. Strasnefski in high school. Uh, but the really, the one teacher I think who uh imprinted me most significantly is probably uh Doctor Kobre, Mike Kobre, a professor of mine in college. To him I just want to say, “Thank you!”

If you’re watching, Mr. Gobel, thank you.

bell.name: Have You Used The Phrase "Get Your Goat" In This Way?
bell.description: This family recounts how the phrase "get your goat" inspired them to create a new saying. Have you used this phrase before? Has your family ever created your own word?
bell.transcript:
Have you heard the term “get your goat”? Well, I have a little sister and, um, growing up she
always would be getting my goat and was always annoying me or saying something to rub me
the wrong way and my mom would always joke that my sister had taken the jingly bell off of my
goat’s collar. So…we started to use the phrase “get your jingly bell” when we were talking about
people being really really annoyed by someone. We’d say, “Oh, they got their jingly bell!”

oregon.name: Have You Been Pronouncing These US Places Correctly?
oregon.description: This woman took a road trip across the US and found out she was pronouncing a lot of state and city names ... wrong. Have you been pronouncing them incorrectly too?
oregon.transcript:
For about three years, I lived in Seattle, Washington.
I was able to do this epic cross-country trip and take two weeks and go through a bunch of
different states.
Of course, the first state I entered when I left Washington was what I thought was “awr-i-gon.”
(laughs)
But the locals very, very quickly corrected me and said that they pronounce it “awr-guhn”. Like
an organ in your body, a kidney or a liver or something. They do not separate the three syllables
and say “awr-i-gon” which is how I learned it.
They just say “awr-guhn.”
After that, I got to Las Vegas. I always said “nuh-vad-uh”. But everyone who lives there says
“nuh-vah-duh.” (laughs)
I thought that was maybe, like, dealers choice? Pun intended. But, actually, I was corrected a lot
by everyone who lived there and said, “Nope, it’s nuh-vah-duh, not nuh-vad-uh!”
I also drove through Kentucky and stayed with a friend in what I thought was “loo-ee-vil”, or
“loo-is-vil”, but they take out a lot of those letters and just say “loo-uh-vuh l”. (laughs)
Very smooth. “loo-uh-vuh l”
And similarly, uh, New Orleans, in Louisiana, they all pronounce “naw-luh nz” Louisiana.
Sounds much cooler.
Back on the East Coast. I grew up in Massachusetts. Every time we went to the town
Worcester, I would see these signs that said: “wor-kester” or “wor-sester?” Or maybe,
“wor-chester?” Uh no! It’s pronounced, “woo s-ter”
If you’re a local Massachusetts-ian, and you have any kind of Bostonian accent, you’re probably
actually going to say it, “Wuhstah.”
A lot of letters in there, just kinda suggestions. (laughs)
And then similar to Worcester is Gloucester and Leicester. They both have that c-e-s
combination that Worcester does that you kinda just smoosh all together. So, Gloucester looks
like “glow-ses-ter” or “glow-kester?” But it’s “glos-ter.” Like glossy.
And then my favorite is Reading, which is spelled exactly the same way as reading. And of
course, there’s also a North Reading in Massachusetts. When you’re on the highway, the sign
for North Reading is abbreviated as “No. Reading.” And so it looks like “no reading.” It looks like,
“If you take this exit, you are entering a town where reading is banned.” (laughs)
So I remember always being really concerned about that when I was little.

nightmare.name: The Scary History Behind The Word "Nightmare"
nightmare.description:
It's dark. You're alone. Was that a footstep? Did something just brush up against you? You fight to get up, but you're stuck ... right on top of you is a horrifying nightmare.

Sorry, did you say a nightmare was on top of me?
nightmare.transcript:
It’s dark.

You’re alone.

Was that a footstep?

Did something just brush up against you?

You fight to get up and get the hell out of there, but you’re paralyzed and stuck right in the middle

of a horrifying nightmare!

And then you wake up because you don’t want to die.

When I was a kid I had lots of nightmares.

And, I’d always wake my parents up to make me feel safe.

But, one time my dad decided he’d educate me in order to make me feel less afraid.

Here’s what he told me.

The word nightmare was coined in the late 13th century and meant an evil female spirit afflicting sleepers with the feeling of suffocation.

From the Old English word mare meaning “night-goblin” or “incubus,” people in the 1200s (and before) legitimately thought that bad dreams were caused by ghosts and monsters who inflicted terrors upon them while they slept.

Nowadays, children may still think something similar about the origins of those bad dreams that wake them up at night.

But, in reality, medical professionals and sleep scientists classify nightmares as “dreams or anxieties experienced in daily life where your subconscious mind can explore your stressors and fears.

When my dad finished his comforting little history lesson I was no longer just scared of falling asleep and returning to my nightmare, I was absolutely terrified of a nightmare spirit entering my room and choking me!

A nightmare by the way that you don’t wake up from.

You instead wake up to it.

Mmm…thanks, Dad.

lethologica.name: "Lethologica" vs. "Lethonomia": What's The Difference?
lethologica.description: Ugh, "tip of the tongue" syndrome is a pretty common experience, right? We've all been there ... but, did you know there's a technical name for this?
lethologica.transcript:
It’s right on the tip of my tongue … What is the word for the thing that you use in that game? You know, that one thing you always use?

Ugh, “tip of the tongue” syndrome is a pretty common experience, right? We’ve all been there …

But, did you know there’s a technical name for this?

Lethologica is “the inability to remember the right word.”

Aha, that’s a word I wasn’t looking for.

You know what else always happens to me? When I’ve just met some at a party, they definitely introduced themselves to me, and I, of course, cannot remember their name. Did it start with an A? A T? Who knows.

Welp, there’s a technical word for this one, too.

Lethonomia is “the inability to recall the right name.” And you can totally throw out this word now to distract from the fact that you forgot this person’s name that you just met. You’re welcome.

Fun fact: Both lethonomia and lethologica are derived from the river Lethe in the underworld of Hades in Greek mythology. The river was thought to cause oblivion or forgetfulness of the past.

Ah! I got it! The name of that thing you use in that one game is …

force.name: Star Wars Meets the Dictionary
force.description: Star Wars has certainly added some new words to our vocabulary. Watch to see which ones have received dictionary entries!
force.transcript:
Star Wars has certainly added some new words to our vocabulary.

Lightsaber is even in the dictionary!

But some of Star Wars‘s iconic words have very different meanings in English.

In Star Wars, the Sith are an ancient order devoted to the dark side of the Force.

In English, sith is just another way of saying “since.”

The Force acts as a universally binding energy in the Star Wars franchise.

The closest definition for literal force?

Probably this one: “power to influence, affect, or control.”

What about Star Wars itself?

Dictionary.com defines it as “a U.S. weapons research program begun in 1984 to explore technologies, including ground- and space-based lasers, for destroying attacking missiles and warheads.”

May the force be with you!
