school.name: Help Students Prepare For Back-To-School With These Questions
school.description: This teacher gets real tired of saying the same words over and over. So, she came up with these helpful lists of synonyms to encourage just a little amount of participation during that time of year she calls the back-to-school blues.
school.transcript:
As a teacher, I get real tired of saying the same words over and over. So, to save my sanity—and expand my students’ vocabulary—I came up with these helpful lists of synonyms to encourage just a little, itty-bitty, eensy-weensy amount of participation during that time of year I call the back-to-school blues. “Anyone have a favorite book from the summer reading list?” [crickets] Really, nothing? Not even a “Whaa?” or “Huh?” I’m not asking for a novel response!

OK. Why don’t we try this, instead: “Anyone have a beloved, cherished, favored, prized, treasured, adored, best-loved … book you read?” Someone’s gotta say <em>Beowulf</em> after that inspiring synonym list I just rattled off, I know it.

“What do you all remember about Algebra from last year?” [crickets again] Dang, who let a cricket in the room? Nope, that’s just my students basically telling me they remember <em>zilch</em>, <em>nada</em>, <em>zip</em> about Algebra. OK, then, let’s experiment: “What do you all recall, recognize, recollect, retain, call to mind, call up, conjure up, know by heart … from Algebra?”

All right, Science teachers, this one’s for you. Don’t you love asking the question: “Who can tell me an element from the Periodic Table?” So, this year, try posing it like this: “Who can declare, disclose, explain, express, inform, instruct, mention, notify, report, reveal, say, speak, state, summon, let slip …

You got this teachers! Don’t worry, they’ll respond tomorrow. We’re sure, confident, positive, certain [bell rings].

schatzi.name: How Do You Use The Term "Schatzi"?
schatzi.description: Schatzi is a German term of endearment but how do you use it and what does it actually mean?
schatzi.transcript:
Schatzi is a German term of endearment.

Uh, it was first recorded in the 1950’s and it translates to “sweetheart” or “darling,” and it comes from the German word “Schatz,” which literally translates to “treasure.”

Um, I first learned about the word schatzi when I was in high school. I had a friend who was hosting a German foreign-exchange student and this foreign-exchange student loved my friend’s dog.

Um, he would always call the dog “Schatzi” and I didn’t really understand that because it wasn’t the dog’s name. So I finally asked about it and he explained to me that it was a term of endearment that you might use for, you know, a romantic partner or a family member, um, even a co-worker or a pet and I just thought that was so neat.

Um, I later actually learned that it is also the name of a dog from “That 70’s Show,” um…which apparently it’s a very common dog name, but I can see why ‘cause there’s something so special about calling someone or something your “little treasure.”

Um, I really enjoy that. So, schatzi. Try calling somebody you know schatzi today and, uh, see how they respond. (Laughing)

abbreviation.name: What Is The Difference Between Abbreviations And Acronyms?
abbreviation.description: There really could be a whole separate dictionary for the abundance of acronyms and abbreviations people use today. But what is the actual difference between abbreviations and acronyms?
abbreviation.transcript:
“IDK, I’m rly not sure atm.”

Is that English? I know I’m older, but to me that doesn’t look like the language I grew up speaking …

However, it is the language my daughter uses … so I’m trying to learn.

It’s a language full of abbreviations, initialisms, and acronyms.

[show these on screen]

IDK -I don’t know

rly – really

atm – at the moment

There really could be a whole separate dictionary for the abundance of acronyms and abbreviations people use today, especially in text and on social media.

But, let’s take a step back for a minute … because what the heck is the difference between an acronym and an abbreviation, anyways?

Most people think they’re pretty similar … and they’re definitely used in similar ways.

But, there are slight differences … I’m an expert now with all the research I’ve done to just try and decipher one of my daughter’s text messages …

Abbreviation is an umbrella term—so basically all these little shortened text-speak words we’re using now are abbreviations because they are essentially just shortened versions of a word or phrase. Rly is a great example … they just took out the vowels—who needs ‘em.

But, IDK and ATM are abbreviations and acronyms because acronyms are types of abbreviations. Say that 10 times fast.

Acronyms are usually in the form of initialisms—which is when a phrase is represented by the first letter of each word that makes it up.

So, when do you call a word an acronym and when do you call it an initialism?

Acronyms can usually be read as one word, like NATO or ASAP.  Initialisms are usually pronounced by saying each letter of the acronym, like IDK and ATM (not ah-tem).

And although my daughter would like to think she’s starting the abbreviation and acronym trend, using abbreviations has been something people have been doing since the 1400s.

Even then, it was a way to save time in communication, writing larger ideas down in smaller ways.

Some things never change.

excelsior.name: How Do You Use "Excelsior" In A Sentence?
excelsior.description: Excelsior is Latin for "higher, loftier, more elevated." So how do you use this great word in a sentence?
excelsior.transcript:
[host trying to be intellectual, maybe wearing glasses] “Who has gone farthest? for I would go farther.”

[host throws glasses and goes back to being casual] That is apparently the opening line of the poem “Excelsior” by Walt Whitman, and it sums up the meaning of this motto really well. Stay with me.

Excelsior is Latin for “higher, loftier, more elevated.” It was even adopted as the New York State motto in 1778—which is why it’s sometimes referred to as the Excelsior State.

For some reason though, the motto is often mistranslated as “ever upward” or “still higher”—but close enough.

And, it isn’t just the state of New York that has adopted excelsior as a motto.

Legendary comic book writer Stan Lee often signed off his weekly “Stan’s Soapbox” column in Marvel Comics with excelsior beginning in the 1960s.

It was also adopted as a motivational expression by Pat Solitano, played by Bradley Cooper, in the 2012 film Silver Linings Playbook … it’s everywhere!

Outside of motivational mantras and uplifting sign-offs, excelsior does have specific meanings in carpentry and typography, in case you’re interested. In the carpentry field, excelsior refers to wood shavings that are used for stuffing and packing, as in “Rub a handful of excelsior across the wood as the stain begins to dry.”

In the United States, 3-point fonts are traditionally referred to as excelsior, although, confusingly, it’s also the name of a specific typeface developed in 1931.

OK, that was too deep, I want to know more about Stan Lee … which is why I’m signing off just like the great legend once did. Excelsior!

capitalization.name: Capitalization Is Complicated: Can You Answer These Questions Correctly?
capitalization.description: With so many rules, capitalization is perfect for a game show. Will you learn something new or take the prize?
capitalization.transcript:
Capitalization is so complex it requires it’s own gameshow to make sure we cover all of its nuances and rules. And because nuances and rules are typically not fun we’re asking these people tough capitalization questions so you can laugh at them … and learn, of course. We’ve got 3 sets of questions coming up about some of the weirdest capitalization rules … are you ready? Question #1: It’s all in the family … in the following sentences, do you capitalize ___randpa? ___randpa Ed danced all night long. My ___randpa is much cooler than me.

[contestants guess]

Grandpa Ed danced all night long. My grandpa is much cooler than me. Words that indicate family relationships should also be capitalized when used as titles in front of a person’s name. However, if you’re just talking about relationships with no names involved, the titles shouldn’t be capitalized. Question #2: In good company … Do you always have to capitalize company names?

[contestants guess]

The names of companies and organizations should also be capitalized, such as Nike and Stanford University. There are some exceptions: Sometimes a company may choose not to use a capital letter at the beginning of its name or product as a stylistic choice. Examples include eBay and the iPhone. It’s all about style, folks. Alright, you may be asking what other capitalization questions can be left?! But, don’t worry, we’ve got one more up our sleeves with this last question … Question #3: Ahoy, landmarks ahead (host rolls their eyes at this one). Would you capitalize any or all of the words in this landmark’s name? If you don’t drive over the ___olden ___ate ___ridge in San Francisco, are you even a real tourist?

[contestants guess]

Yes, you should capitalize every word in Golden Gate Bridge. Landmarks and monuments also start their proper names with capital letters, such as the Empire State Building and the Golden Gate Bridge. Street names are always capitalized, too (e.g. Main Street). Go forth and capitalize correctly folks!

family.name: What Are 5 Words To Describe The Silent Generation?
family.description: The Silent Generation is the generation born between 1925–1945. Here are the words they think describe their generation.
family.transcript:
Home. My parents came from the Caribbean … Port of Spain, Trinidad. When they referred to home, they didn’t mean “I’m going back to the house.” They meant home, where their heart was, where they were born. And, home is where your folks were. Home is where you were born. Home is, is where you wanted to go back to.

Nothing is more valuable than having a family. It feels safe and sound.

Progressive. They’re willing to do, try new things, succeed at some, fail in others, and learn from their failures.

Lucky. We missed the Great Depression, and we missed two world wars.

Spoiled. Because we have had a relatively easy life.

When I was in, uh, late elementary school and junior high school I had a really good friend, and her name was Janice. And, Janice used to speak something to me called pig Latin. People thought I knew pig Latin too, but I didn’t.

The tone of what I’m told is the Silent Generation really changed in the 60s. One day, in Mississippi, Stokely Carmichael raised his hand, and he said black power. And James Brown, the singer, said, “Say it loud: I’m Black and I’m proud.” And, that was an era of Black people coming into consciousness. And, that was an era where we were not silent.

cuff.name: Can You Define These Modern Relationship Words?
cuff.description: Are you currently in the dating scene? Well, if you aren't (or haven't been in the last 5 years) you may be completely unfamiliar with a whole subset of dating and relationship terms out there. Time to find out!
cuff.transcript:
Are you currently in the dating scene? Well, if you aren’t (or haven’t been in the last 5 years) you may be completely unfamiliar with a whole subset of dating and relationship terms out there.

Time to find out!

Question 1: What does cuffing season mean?

[contestants guessing]

Answer: This is when someone “shacks up” with someone else during the fall and winter months. [show answer on screen]

The metaphor is of handcuffing oneself to a partner (i.e., being exclusive) during these times as opposed to being single in spring and summer, when people want to be outside playing.

The term was popularized by rapper Fabolous’s 2013 song “Cuffin Season.”

Question 2: What does Instagram husband mean?

[contestants guessing]

Answer: A person who helps a partner manage their Instagram social media channel, especially by taking photos. [show answer on screen]

Ever wonder how your favorite insta influencers look flawless in every photo? Well, it may be thanks, at least in part, to the person behind the camera: their Instagram husband.

Celebrities and public figures such as John Legend, Jay Z, and President Barack Obama have all been dubbed Instagram husbands thanks to their famous, glamorous, and accomplished wives (and their popular Instagram accounts).

Question 3: What does DTR mean?

[contestants guessing]

Answer: It stands for define the relationship. [show answer on screen]

If you’ve been going out with someone for a while, it might be time to have the DTR talk with that person, where you clarify where you stand with respect to each other and what your expectations of the relationship are.

Of course, DTR‘ing can be a make-or-break moment.

No matter what new technology we have, no matter what new terms we use, one fact will never change: relationships are hard.

definition.name: Can You Guess These Words From Their Definitions?
definition.description: In this game, one person is going to share the definition of a word they chose. Then, another person has to guess what word it is. You should guess along at home! Don’t worry: we’ll have clues!
definition.transcript:
You know, so much of learning vocabulary is just word-definition, word-definition, word-definition. Let’s shake things up.

In this game, one person is going to share the definition of a word they chose. Then, another person has to guess what word it is. You should guess along at home! Don’t worry: we’ll have clues!

OK, let’s give this a go.

This word’s a noun, and it means [display]:

noun mental and emotional strength in facing difficulty, adversity, danger, or temptation courageously

Need a hint? It’s kind of like bravery.

Need another clue? Think “strong like a fort.”

Answer: fortitude

Host 2: Alrighty, my turn! This one sums me up perfectly. [display]

noun a person who likes cats; cat fancier.

Hint time: Well, –phile is “a lover of something” …

Stumped: Added to this the ancient Greek word for “cat.”

Answer: ailurophile

Guesser: Like I was going to guess the ancient Greek word for “cat”!

Host 3:

My word is something I think we call use a little bit of these days. It’s an adjective. [display]

adjective pleasantly calm or peaceful; unruffled; tranquil; serenely quiet or undisturbed

Hint: there’s a lake and village named after it in upstate New York.

Need another: think placate or placebo.

Answer: placid

Host 4:

My word is a verb, and it’s a great word that comes from Yiddish. [display]

verb to be extraordinarily pleased; especially, to be bursting with pride, as over one’s family

Wanna hint? It starts with two consonants that you don’t see together too often.

Firing off another hint for ya: you could say it’s opposite is kvetch.

Answer: kvell

Host 5:

For my word, know that I didn’t just … come up with it on the spot. My choice is an adjective. [display]

adjective done, spoken, performed, etc., without special advance preparation; impromptu

Hint: It’s a long word. Six syllables!

One more? Rhymes with spontaneous.

One more?! The word tempo is inside it.

Answer: extemporaneous

Host 6:

File mine

to throw (a person or thing) out of a window.

Answer: defenestrate

Host 7 [back to Host 1 for guessing]:

Final word, everyone! I think this verb is very beautiful and useful right about now! [display]

verb to make or become better, more bearable, or more satisfactory; improve

Hint: This one’s tough for hints unless you know your Latin. But, the name Amelia comes to mind …

Answer: ameliorate

Guesser: [after guessed or revealed] As in, this game really ameliorated my vocabulary? See what I did there?

Wanna hint? It starts with two consonants that you don’t see together too often.

Firing off another hint for ya: you could say it’s opposite is kvetch.

Answer: kvell

Host 5:

For my word, know that I didn’t just … come up with it on the spot. My choice is an adjective. [display]

adjective done, spoken, performed, etc., without special advance preparation; impromptu

Hint: It’s a long word. Six syllables!

One more? Rhymes with spontaneous.

One more?! The word tempo is inside it.

Answer: extemporaneous

Host 6:

File mine

to throw (a person or thing) out of a window.

Answer: defenestrate

Host 7 [back to Host 1 for guessing]:

Final word, everyone! I think this verb is very beautiful and useful right about now! [display]

verb to make or become better, more bearable, or more satisfactory; improve

Hint: This one’s tough for hints unless you know your Latin. But, the name Amelia comes to mind …

Answer: ameliorate

Guesser: [after guessed or revealed] As in, this game really ameliorated my vocabulary? See what I did there?

thot.name: Is The Word "Thot" Offensive?
thot.description: Pronounced either like “thought” or “thawt,” THOT is an acronym that stands for “that ho over there” or “thirsty hoes over there.” But is it offensive?
thot.transcript:
There’s not a lot of love for THOT (spelled T. H. O. T) …

Pronounced either like “thought” or “thawt,” THOT is an acronym that stands for “that ho over there” or “thirsty hoes over there.”

It’s a relatively recent term, popping up in rap lyrics and on the Twittersphere starting in 2011.

Heard (loudly) in clubs and (judgmentally) in corners, some people use it jokingly, even about themselves.

Others use it in a less fun way: to describe women who are trying to be sexually alluring but are basically coming off as, well, cheap.

This creates a sort of desperation to their “ho-ness,” giving THOT a derogatory flavor with a tiny aftertaste of sexism.

Ladies, where my ladies at? Well, we’re working together to put the “hot” back in THOT.

So what if we’re thirsty or hoes … over there? [have a puzzled look on face and have them point, trying to add in “over there”] … you get it.

We can be sexually active just like guys, can’t we?

That THOT isn’t hurting anyone. (wink)

search.name: Did You Mean To Look Up "Search" On Dictionary.com?
search.description: It’s OK, we’ve all been here. Search is actually one of our most searched words! Stick around to find out why it's one of our favorite words!
search.transcript:
Did you actually mean to look up search on Dictionary.com?

It’s OK, we’ve all been here. Search is actually one of our most searched words!

That’s probably because if you leave that little search box blank on the Dictionary.com homepage and press “enter” … it brings you here.

Or, if you hit the magnifying glass icon by accident without typing in a word … it takes you here too.

We just love the page for search though … and now that you’re here, we’ll make you love it too.

To start, do online searches ever feel like you’re in an endless circle? There’s a reason for that!

The word search is a derivative of the Latin circus, which means “circle” (not the tent with the animals or acrobats).

This eventually turned into the late Latin circare (“to go around”) and transformed into the Middle English serchen by the 1300s.

Even search was searching for its true self for thousands of years … kind of like how you’re looking for direction on this site, but now you’re just trapped in the Dictionary.com equivalent of a YouTube loop …

Second, did you know that there are actually 14 definitions of the word? That’s a lot of meaning for a seemingly unhelpful word (or web page).

So … even if this page wasn’t what you were searching for, hopefully we’ve taught you a little something about one of our favorite words.

And, pro tip: type something into the search bar next time you come to the site.

It will help you find what you’re looking for a little faster (fun fact: found has four definitions for you to peruse over on that page, just saying).

I- I’m gonna speed read it. Char-gah-guh-gah-man-choo-ah-guh-gahw-go-choo-nah-guh-wah-guh-mawg.

Speaker 7:

[singing] Lake Chargoggagoggmanchauggagoggchaubunagungamaugg.

y-all.name: What Are All Of The Different Ways To Pluralize "You"?
y-all.description: What's up you guys?! Or wait, should it be what's up y'all? Let's break down all of the ways you can address the plural you.
y-all.transcript:
What’s up you guys?! Or wait, should it be what’s up y’all? Well, I guess it all really depends on your personal preference and also, more importantly, what region you hail from. Let’s break down all of the ways you can address the plural you.

Up first, we have old faithful- “you guys”. Like… hey, do you guys remember that scene in the Goonies where Sloth yells “HEY YOU GUYS?!?!” Man, I still love that movie (lost in thought). But anyway, I digress. People have been saying the phrase “you guys” to address a mixed-gendered group of people for a long time, but lately, this usage has been called into question as some believe it is not gender-inclusive. Ok, fair enough. Let’s take a look at some of our other options.

Up next, we have the southern plural of you which is “y’all” or even all y’all”… which is a contraction of the words you and all.

If you are from the New York area, you might be a big fan of yous, youse, and youse guys… or gals, of course.

If you think all of that is interesting, get a lot of this – in the Appalachian and Western Pennsylvania region of the United States, they came up with the word “yinz” in order to address the plural you. How on earth did they come up with that?! Well, it most likely was derived from “you ones”, which came from Irish-American speakers in the 19th century, switching to using English and being confused by the lack of singular second-person pronouns, which Gaelic has in the form of tú, as well as a plural form, sibh. 

Because who needs all those pesky extra letters and apostrophes when trying to quickly address a room full of people?!

doctor.name: When Did The Word "Doctor" Become Medical?
doctor.description: The roots of the word "doctor" don’t have anything to do with medical practice. So when did this word start describing those in the medical field?
doctor.transcript:
Every time someone sees the “Dr.” in my signature, they automatically ask me what kind of medicine I practice. And then they’re automatically confused when I tell them no, I’m a philosophy professor.

You know, being a doctor isn’t just about getting into the medical field. Most people don’t realize that. The word-for-word definition of doctor is both “a person licensed to practice medicine, as a physician, surgeon, dentist, or veterinarian” or (get this) “a person who has been awarded a doctor’s degree.”

The roots of the word doctor don’t even have anything to do with medical practice! Its original Latin root is “docere” which translates to “to show, teach, or cause to know” (in other words, a teacher). One of the meanings it adopted in the 1300s as doctor was “holder of the highest degree in a university,” given to people who were the best in their field, hence, the best ones to teach it.

So, how exactly did doctor come to be directly associated with medicine? Well, it started in the 1300s as well, but didn’t become popularly used in this sense until at least the late 1600s – likely due to a character in Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales called the Doctor of Phesike, who was a well-dress Physician.

discriminate.name: What Are Other Words Related To "Prejudice"?
discriminate.description: Most people experience "prejudice" during their lifetime. But what are some other words that are related to "prejudice" that you may also experienced?
discriminate.transcript:
I was the first female host for an all-male sports talk show, and I was so excited.

My boss asked me to do an introductory contract, so I would work for 60 days for a lower wage, um, just to prove myself, and then I’ll get an official contract.  So once the 60 days passed, I know I killed it [laughs] and … the boss said, “You were great. We want you to stay.”

But still offered me a lower wage.

And I felt … I felt very disappointed.  And I talked to him, and I said, “Is it because I’m female?  I feel like I’ve proven myself, and I deserve the same wage as my male co-hosts.”  And from there, we were able to have a discussion, and he gave me that bump up.

galentine.name: What Is The Origin Of Valentine's Day?
galentine.description: Red roses, heart-shaped candy boxes, fancy dinner reservations—how did all of these come to signify romance on February 14th?
galentine.transcript:
Red roses, heart-shaped candy boxes, fancy dinner reservations — how did all of these come to signify romance on February 14th? Like all holidays, it starts with an animal sacrifice. Just kidding! But Valentine’s Day really does trace its roots back to ancient Rome. The feast of Lupercalia fell on Feb 13th – 15th, and for the sake of their fertility, women would line up on order to be whipped with the hides of recently slain goats and dogs. This holiday also consisted of a “couples lottery” where men would draw women’s names from a jar and, well… couple. Romantic, right?

St. Valentine came into the picture when two men, both names Valentine, were executed by Emperor Claudius II on February 14th in different years. Weird coincidence. The Catholic church honored the dual Valentines with the celebration of St. Valentine’s Day.

Around the same time this holiday started to be known for love as it was easily confused with the similar sounding Galatin’s Day. This Norman holiday celebrated Galatin as the “lover of women.” Leslie Knope would certainly approve of this as a Gal-entine’s Day celebration honoring your best girlfriends.

Romance continued to be the order of Valentine’s Day as Chaucer and Shakespeare romanticized it in their words and handmade cards began to be exchanged across Britain and the rest of Europe in the Middle Ages.

And so the celebration of Valentine’s Day goes on, in varied ways. Many will break the bank buying jewelry and flowers for their beloveds. Others will celebrate in a SAD (that’s Single Awareness Day) way, dining alone and binging on self-gifted chocolates. A few may even be spending this day in the same coupling up way that the early Romans did. But let’s not go there.

homework.name: What's A Unique Homework Routine That Works?
homework.description: Even with the best homework routine, homework is getting harder and harder and weirder and weirder. So we asked some tutors and parents what has worked for them before.
homework.transcript:
The kids that I babysit are 12. They are twins and they are in middle school, their first year of middle school, so sixth grade. And the homework routine, things that I’ve used for them, we don’t have like a set thing that we do like, English first or anything like that, but we do have a set order in the afternoon that we do things in. So first thing’s first. I do not let them get distracted by outside things before doing homework. So no screens, no TV, no toys. None of that before homework. Like, fun stuff is for after homework, and doing homework is how you unlock doing the fun stuff. 

Just have a couple minutes between school and homework to chill and acknowledge that we’re home now. But then after about that amount of time, I’m very lucky. She usually wants to hop into homework and usually so does he, because at that point, both of them are kind of unwound enough that they do want their screen time at that time.

It’s kind of a push and pull between this is a routine but y’all also kinda get to choose what you’re doing when because I get the least resistance by doing that, and they get everything done.

Homework routines. I’m a parent of three, and I’ve always worked from home, so I’ve always had homework duty. And what would always seem to work best for me is do homework while I’m making dinner. In order to do that, you have to also be someone who makes dinner at home almost every day, which I did. And I speak in the past tense because my kids are older now. Through elementary school and junior high school, we would always sit down, everybody at the dinner table, and do homework while I was cooking. And so it’s very easy to answer questions while you’re cooking from a distance, which makes them have good questions to answer and makes them solve it on their own without you taking the pen or pencil out of their hand. But also, you’re in the room with them, which is always more fun. And it’s easy to just spin around and take a look at something and answer it as well. It gets everybody in the room together. It has sort of that dinner vibe, and it doesn’t really have a school homework-y begrudging vibe. It’s kind of like, “Hey, I’m making food. Here, taste this food. What do you think? Let me answer your question. Hopefully I can answer it.”

“60% of the time,

it works every time” – Anchorman

The ongoing problem is though, even with the best homework routine, homework is getting harder and harder and weirder and weirder. So I’m not sure if even the best routine is gonna help you get that homework done all the time.

adverb.name: What Exactly Is An Adverb?
adverb.description: Adverbs tell us how, when, where, and to what degree something happens. In this way, they modify verbs, adjectives, and other adverbs. But how do you find one in a sentence?
adverb.transcript:
I recently bought a new phone. I patiently saved up for it because, you know, phones can be ridiculously expensive.

It was so nice. It downloaded apps instantly. It streamed videos smoothly. It also had far more space than I ever had before.

After I paid for it, I held my phone as lovingly and carefully as a newborn baby. But, when I stepped outside, a runner appeared out of nowhere. He was going too fast and I couldn’t get out of the way.

Crash! The collision sent my phone into the sky. I saw it flipping over and over again, like in slow-motion, then plummet to the ground. Nervously, I picked it up. It was completely shattered. My brand-new baby had cracks here, there, everywhere.

Fortunately, I also saved up for phone insurance.

Adverbs tell us how, when, where, and to what degree something happens. In this way, they modify verbs, adjectives, and other adverbs.

First, adverbs can tell how something happens or is done. Patiently, instantly, lovingly, nervously. These adverbs typically modify verbs and can appear throughout a sentence. Often they add -ly to existing adjectives, but not always, as in going fast, which makes them easy to confuse for some adjectives.

Second, adverbs can tell when something happens. When, then, again. Ever had before. These are often special words all their own in the language and sometimes shift around in a sentence.

Third, adverbs can tell where something happens. We don’t mean, like, Paris or the moon. We mean here, there, everywhere. I stepped outside. These kinds of words.

Finally, adverbs can tell the extent or degree of something. So nice. Too fast. Ridiculously expensive. These adverbs often modify adjectives and other adverbs.

Adverbs are extremely useful and common, but they also can be incredibly frustrating. Like smashing a new phone.

Which brings to mind another part of speech: interjections. Ahhhhhhhhhh!

internet.name: Words That The Internet Has Changed
internet.description: Have you ever found yourself scrolling through social media, confused by all of the new slang out there. Well we asked all of you to tell us about the words you've seen change in meaning on social media.
internet.transcript:
Have you ever found yourself scrolling through social media, confused by all of the new slang out there. And then, you find yourself really relating to Steve Buscemi on 30 Rock?

Yeah … us too. But don’t worry! Dictionary.com is here to help!  We recently asked our awesome Twitter audience about the words that they have seen change and morph in meaning since the inception of social media, and Twitter did not let us down.

[When host is reading tweets please have an image of the tweet below the host as they read for viewer reference]

James Butler @’d us with a fairly logical first response for the Twitterverse:

Fair point, James. The hashtag used to be something that was most commonly related to phone calls, then the concept of tagging came about and we became #blessed with the current form of hashtag.

User Bunny Queen Rushda also had some feelings she wanted to dish out.

Notice how I said “dish out”… well, that is because tea isn’t just something you have with crumpets any longer! Black drag culture started using tea while referring to gossip and then the rest of the world latched on! Including Azealia Banks, who has definitely been known to “spill some tea” in her time …

The internet is a weird place ya’ll.

social-media.name: How Did April Reign Create The Hashtag #OscarsSoWhite?
social-media.description: Hashtags are great for getting a conversation going. But how do you create one, and how does it go viral? April Reign answered some of these questions.
social-media.transcript:
Hi. I’m April Reign, the creator of OscarsSoWhite.

In January of 2015, I was still a practicing attorney, um, and I had no connection whatsoever to the entertainment field, other than the fact that I was a rabid consumer of film. Uh, so the Oscars particularly were like my Super Bowl. There were special snacks involved. I’d rope off the TV so everybody knew this was mommy’s night. I’d watch the pre-show, the show, the after show, the show the next day. Everything about the Oscars I loved.

Uh, so I was… That morning, January 2015, I was watching the nominations on one of the morning television shows, and it just struck me for no particular reason that year because, unfortunately, it happened both before then and since, um, there were no people of color nominated in any of the acting categories. 20 different spots. So I picked up my phone, um, which is typically embedded in my forearm, and got on social media and tweeted, “OscarsSoWhite they asked to touch my hair.” And that was it. I then went on to work, uh, and then when I checked in on Twitter around lunchtime, the hashtag based on that one tweet was then trending internationally.

Um, as I said, this was a very organic campaign, I guess. I wasn’t even planning for it to be a campaign or a movement initially. Uh, I was just thinking out loud. (laughs) Very often, I think out loud on Twitter to share my thoughts, um, with my followers and whoever is interested.

I know generally, having had hashtags go internationally viral both before OscarsSoWhite and since, that hashtags have to be short, um, first and foremost. You know, in January of 2015, we were still relegated to 140 characters, not the 280 that we have now, uh, so every single letter, every single word or phrase matters. Um, and so I knew that OscarsSoWhite was short. I was hoping that it was to the point, (laughs) even though, um, years later, people still pretend at least to misunderstand what my meaning was with that phrase. Um, and I was hoping that it would be memorable. And, in fact, it was. Uh, and so now, um, here we are now in year six of OscarsSoWhite, and people are still using the hashtag. And, in fact, um, the phrase has broadened. You know, now there is a JournalismSoWhite and an EducationSoWhite and even a BrooklynSoWhite, none of which I started, um, I think that goes to show that, um, when you are doing something that makes sense that can be universal, and that’s what you want a hashtag to be, people may take it and riff off of it, um, to make it their own, and then I think that’s great.

Um, so hashtags sh- should be short, they should be to the point, um, they should ensure that your message is getting across in just that one phrase, um, and hopefully they are memorable.

To people who are interested in creating their own viral movements or campaigns, um, you know, I would say you can absolutely start on social media, but don’t stay there. Um, remember that there are people who don’t use social media (laughs), surprisingly enough, uh, so you need to meet people where they are. Hashtags are great for getting a conversation going, and hopefully that conversation will continue, even if you’re not leading it. Um, but you also need to write. You need to speak. Um, i- but if you have an issue that touches your heart, um, something that you feel passionate about, um, something that you want to see changed, absolutely get on social media, regardless of the size of your platform, and start talking about it using that hashtag, and then get your friends, family, and followers involved, um, to help you with your campaign. Good luck.

he.name: How To Use Personal Pronouns
he.description: It's totally cool if someone doesn't identify as a he or a she and wants to be a they. If you really want to be an ally, consider asking what pronoun someone prefers.
he.transcript:
You CAN use “they” to refer to a single person. Think this goes against everything you learned in English class? Don’t worry about it! Using “they” as a singular pronoun is perfectly acceptable when you don’t know the gender of the person, or when they have expressed a preference for a nonbinary gender. Get that? It’s totally cool if someone doesn’t identify as a he or a she and wants to be a they. If you really want to be an ally, consider asking what pronoun someone prefers.

[Personal Story]

boarder.name: What Is The Difference Between "Boarder" vs. "Border"?
boarder.description: Boarder and border are homophones of each other. But how do you use each word correctly?
boarder.transcript:
Recently we at Dictionary.com had a request for some grammar assistance from one of our esteemed Twitter followers.

Well, @ComplyAnalyst, you came to the right place! Here comes the break down:

First, boarder and border are homophones of each other. What’s a homophone, you ask? Good question!

A homophone is “two or more words having the same pronunciation but different meanings, origins, or spelling,” e.g., new and knew, hear and here, or even … boarder and border. 

Next comes usage …

The word boarder *B-O-A-R-D-E-R* dates back to the 1520s and refers to “someone seeking food or lodging at the house of another.” If you have someone crashing on your couch, or you host one of your rooms as an Airbnb, then you’ve experienced the meaning of the word boarder.

The word border, *B-O-R-D-E-R*, dates back to the mid to late 14th century. At first, it meant, “broad, colored band surrounding the shield,” it later also took on the meaning of “a boundary of a city or country.”

In this specific tweet, President Donald Trump is talking about the border between Mexico and the United States. So, this would be the perfect time to use the word border.

Chin up, Donald, a lot of people get tripped up when using homophones. You might even say that they are grammar’s version of BIG DANGER! (wink)

silly.name: Is "Silly" A Positive Or Negative Word?
silly.description: Silly means "weak-minded or lacking good sense; stupid or foolish: a silly writer," or "absurd; ridiculous; irrational: a silly idea," or "stunned; dazed." But, did it always mean these things? Why does everyone think it's such an endearing word?
silly.transcript:
I need some advice … because I can’t stop getting offended when my girlfriend, my grandma, my mom calls me … silly.  Is it just me? Why is this word so triggering?

Well, if you know me, I decided to sit at my computer for an hour rather than actually get someone’s opinion about the offensive nature of this word. Here’s what I found …

The definition (on the one and only Dictionary.com) confirms my thoughts, get this … silly means “weak-minded or lacking good sense; stupid or foolish: a silly writer,” or “absurd; ridiculous; irrational: a silly idea,” or “stunned; dazed.” So, yea, those aren’t great definitions. 

But, did silly always mean these things? Why does everyone think it’s such an endearing word?

Well, back in the early 1200s, the original sense of silly was “blessed” or, more accurately, “spiritually blessed.” Huh?

Silly actually is from an Old English word: gesǣlig, meaning “happy, blessed.” In Middle English, this gesǣlig started to mean “holy, innocent, helpless,” then “pitiable” and “insignificant,” then “simple” and “ignorant.” By the end of the 1500s, silly was used for “lacking good sense, foolish, irrational, ridiculous.”

So, with that in mind, I’ll give my family and friends the benefit of the doubt when they call me silly … because they’re “blessed” to have me in their lives, regardless of what they call me 😉

a.name: Thesaurus.com Presents The Gigantic, Gratifying, Grammar Gameshow
a.description: YES, grammar can be fun ... keep watching ... because we've asked these 2 people to join our first ever Gigantic, Gratifying, Grammar Gameshow.
a.transcript:
Here at Dictionary.com, we like grammar. Surprise, surprise, right? But we also know, grammar is hard. Like really hard.

So, we also like to teach people grammar … in fun ways. YES, grammar can be fun … keep watching … because we’ve asked these 2 people to join our first ever Gigantic, Gratifying, Grammar Gameshow.

(show contestants waving)

You won’t want to miss it, we’re confident … or is it confidante (show spellings on screen to illustrate the difference). See grammar is confusing.

First up, a pretty common grammar faux pax: affect vs. effect.

(show sentence on screen) That polar vortex really had an ____ on the winter weather this year.

(show 2 people thinking)

(first person guesses affect or effect, then 2nd person guesses).

The answer is: (show :”effect” on screen)

Here’s a basic guideline for affect vs. effect: Generally, we use affect as a verb (an action word) and effect as a noun (an object word).

Next up, do you know when to use a or an?

Here’s the sentence …

(show sentence on screen) I’ll be there in ___ hour, sorry for the delay!

(show 2 people thinking)

(first person guesses affect or effect, then 2nd person guesses).

The answer is: (show “an” on screen).

Here’s the thing about a and an. We all pretty much know the rule a before consonants and an before vowels. But, that’s not actually the whole rule. It’s more about consonant and vowel sounds, then about the letters themselves.

So, with the word hour. You have a vowel sound … an is used. Easy.

OK, so we’ve arrived at our bonus question … for all the grammar gusto … How many commas belong in this sentence?

(show sentence on screen): Yesterday my friend Tina as well as my friend Lee told me 1000 jokes seriously 1000 jokes in one hour and they were not funny.

(first person guesses affect or effect, then 2nd person guesses).

The answer is: 8 commas.

(show sentence on screen) Yesterday, my friend Tina, as well as my friend Lee, told me 1,000 jokes, seriously 1,000 jokes, in one hour, and they were not funny.

Commas come after introductory clauses, before and after nonrestrictive clauses (like as well as), in numbers of 4 digits and more, before and after interrupters (like seriously), and before independent clauses.

Phew.

affect.name: How To Use "Affect" vs. "Effect"
affect.description: Effect and affect: can you keep these two words straight? We can't either which is why we are giving you some examples to learn the difference between the two!
affect.transcript:
So, I signed up for this Word of the Day thing on Dictionary.com. Every day, I get an email about a different word. And, you wouldn’t believe some of them. Onomastic. Milieu. Marvy. Marvy?!

Well, all these words have had a big effect on my vocabulary … or … is it … affect on my vocabulary? Forget marvy. Effect and affect: I can never keep these two words straight.

Effect and affect. They sound the same. They have similar ideas of “influence.” And they both came from the same root: the Latin facere [fah-kur-ey], meaning “to do” or “make.” It’s just that one begins with an E and the other, an A, those pesky, little … facere’s [playing on another form of the F word].

Let’s break them down. Most often, effect beginning with E is an noun and it means a “result” or “consequence.” Think cause and effect. For instance, I was hangry. I ate some pizza. OK, I ate a lot of pizza and looked at pictures of online for like 20 minutes. But the effect—the outcome—was that I felt better.

Affect beginning with an A is most commonly a verb that means “to act on,” “to influence,” or “to produce a change in” something. I was hangry. I ate some pizza. It affected my mood—it had an impact on my mood—because I felt a whole lot better afterwards. And yeah, the puppy pictures helped. Affect “brings about an effect.” 

Here’s another example. True story. Concerned about distractions and disruptions, my school decided to take away free WiFi. It had the effect, the end result, of students paying more attention in class, but it also affected our ability,  it altered our ability, it to get our work done because we couldn’t look up information online.

In everyday speech, effect and affect sound the same, though sometimes people emphasize the initial vowel a little more for clarity. It’s when we’re writing them that we tend to get tripped up, and it’s in writing them that we need to be careful. We might remember their differences this way: “Affect alters, effect is the end result.” See the two A’s, affect and alter, and two E’s, effect and end result?

Now, there are other meanings to effect and affect. Effect with E can also be a verb meaning “to bring about” or “to cause to happen,” as in The WiFi policy effected a change in student behavior: It made them more focused but less productive. You see how this is similar to but slightly different from affect with an A? Yeah, no? Well, it’s confusing—and the effect is that effect is not used as a verb all that much.

Affect with an A can also be a noun with its stress on the first syllable: [a-fect]. It means “emotion” or “feeling,” as in negative affect, which is when someone is experiencing anger or fear or disgust all the time—maybe like how you feel about this effect and affect business.

Negative affects can definitely has a negative effect, or impact, on others. But, this affect is mostly just used in psychology … or do I mean … psychiatry? Ah, f-f-f-f … forget it [again, as if about to swear]. We’ll save that vocab lesson for another day.

do.name: Can You Correct These Grammatically Incorrect Song Lyrics?
do.description: These lyrics may be catchy, but there’s one, big grammatical error within them. Can you spot it?
do.transcript:
These lyrics may not make a lot of sense, but there’s one, big grammatical error within them. Can you spot it? 

(singing) Every little thing she does is magic. (singing) Everything she do just turns me on. (singing) Even though my life before was tragic …

“Everything she do …”

How does it go from “everything she does” to “everything she do”?

Yeah … Yes, “everything she do.” 

Yeah, that doesn’t sound right.

”Every Little Thing She Does is Magic” has one of those great, explosive choruses that makes it impossible not to sing along. But, it’s hard not to cringe, as you arrive at the lyric, “Everything she do just turns me on.” In that sentence, the verb do should be does. 

(singing) I want your love and I want your revenge. (singing) You and me could write a bad romance. 

Could it be, “You … you and I”? 

“You and I” maybe? Yeah … “you and I.”

But I’ve never understood why though. 

I … you have to … I think you have to take out the, the first if it’s, like, a combination with and, you have to take out the first one and if the second part makes sense, like, “me could write a bad romance,” it would have to be I. “I could …” you know, it should stand alone.

– That sounds good.

– Oooooh …

In the case of Lady Gaga’s “Bad Romance,” Lady Gaga sings, “You and me could write a bad romance,” when it should be “you and I.”

(singing) If there’s something strange in your neighborhood, (singing) who you gonna call? (singing) Ghostbusters!

“Who are you gonna call”? “Who are you gonna call,” maybe?

Going … ?

[Makes “buzzer” sound] (Wrong!)

In the timeless “Ghostbusters Theme Song,” Ray Parker Jr. asks over and over again, “Who you gonna call?” The answer, of course, is the Ghostbusters which are a group of people. Since the Ghostbusters are a group, they’d be described using the pronoun them. And that means their theme song should technically ask, “Whom are you going to call?” 

(singing) T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you tasty. (singing) T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you tasty.

I don’t know … I like that song. (laughing)

– I just sing it. I don’t think about it.

– I did too, like, fifteen years ago … uh …

And on that note, in the early 2000s, Fergie’s hit song, “Fergalicious,” taught the world how to spell delicious and tasty. There’s only one small problem with the impromptu spelling lesson, the song spelled tasty incorrectly. The lyrics include rapper will.i.am chanting, “T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you’re tasty.” In reality, tasty is spelled sans E.

”Every Little Thing She Does is Magic” has one of those great, explosive choruses that makes it impossible not to sing along. But, it’s hard not to cringe, as you arrive at the lyric, “Everything she do just turns me on.” In that sentence, the verb do should be does. 

(singing) I want your love and I want your revenge. (singing) You and me could write a bad romance. 

Could it be, “You … you and I”? 

“You and I” maybe? Yeah … “you and I.”

But I’ve never understood why though. 

I … you have to … I think you have to take out the, the first if it’s, like, a combination with and, you have to take out the first one and if the second part makes sense, like, “me could write a bad romance,” it would have to be I. “I could …” you know, it should stand alone.

– That sounds good.

– Oooooh …

In the case of Lady Gaga’s “Bad Romance,” Lady Gaga sings, “You and me could write a bad romance,” when it should be “you and I.”

(singing) If there’s something strange in your neighborhood, (singing) who you gonna call? (singing) Ghostbusters!

“Who are you gonna call”? “Who are you gonna call,” maybe?

Going … ?

[Makes “buzzer” sound] (Wrong!)

In the timeless “Ghostbusters Theme Song,” Ray Parker Jr. asks over and over again, “Who you gonna call?” The answer, of course, is the Ghostbusters which are a group of people. Since the Ghostbusters are a group, they’d be described using the pronoun them. And that means their theme song should technically ask, “Whom are you going to call?” 

(singing) T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you tasty. (singing) T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you tasty.

I don’t know … I like that song. (laughing)

– I just sing it. I don’t think about it.

– I did too, like, fifteen years ago … uh …

And on that note, in the early 2000s, Fergie’s hit song, “Fergalicious,” taught the world how to spell delicious and tasty. There’s only one small problem with the impromptu spelling lesson, the song spelled tasty incorrectly. The lyrics include rapper will.i.am chanting, “T to the A to the S-T-E-Y, girl, you’re tasty.” In reality, tasty is spelled sans E.

alcohol.name: These Words Are Guaranteed To Ruin An Apology
alcohol.description: For all those apology-givers out there, listen up! These words will cancel out any apology you're trying to give.
alcohol.transcript:
The other day a friend of mine said how she and her boyfriend got into a fight. Finally, after a half hour, he said. “Sorry.

Only the way he said it was, “Sorry, but…”

And the fight continues…

For all those apology-givers out there, listen up: never start out with a, “Sorry, but” thrown in there. What business does a but have in an apology? None, is the answer.

Actually, now that I’m thinking about it, you can also skip using No offense in an apology, because that usually means a big offense is on its way.

Also maybe try not to sneak a you in there either, kind of like, “I’m sorry you might feel that way…” Oh yeah? I’m sorry you stink at saying sorry. There’s probably even a but somewhere in that sentence. Or an if…if is almost as bad as a but.

Ugh, then, there’s the blame game. Like, when someone acts like a jerk for saying something after too many shots (looking at you, Jeff) and says they blame it on the alcohol. If you’re not Jamie Foxx, don’t say it, basically.

That goes for not, too…”Sorry not sorry.” Is that even an apology at all? No!

Don’t believe me? Call my friend’s boyfriend, Jeff, at 1-800-DOGHOUSE.

curious.name: How Would You Describe Millennials In One Word?
curious.description: Millennials were born between the early 1980s and the mid-1990s to early 2000s. We asked 4 people from that generation to describe millennials in one word.
curious.transcript:
I think the one word that, that describes my generation would be tech-savvy. Because we’re always on our phones. We’re always on a device, whether it’s an iPad, a computer, a video game, even our cars are a device now. We’re always at our fingertips, something … technical. (laughs) 

One word to describe my generation would definitely be … entrepreneurship. I say that because I think this generation has a record number of entrepreneurs and it’s exciting. We’re blazing our own path, and creating opportunities that weren’t there before.

Well, one word I would describe my generation is sensitive. Because, let’s be honest, everybody’s feelings be getting hurt on social media. And, it’s cool to see that other people are feeling your vibe, but, also, it’s like you don’t have to be angry about everything. Don’t take it personal. Just live your life. Chill out, OK? And just do you, boo boo.

One word I would use to describe my generation is curious. I think my generation is really curious about technology, about the different ways we can make money, about what a career means, what an identity means, what sexuality means. Curiosity is key to innovation. I think things don’t change, until we’re curious about how different they could be. And, our generation is constantly trying to do things differently than before. We’ve never seen more change than is happening right now. I’m glad we’re curious. I’m excited to see what’s going to happen.

We’ve never seen more change than is happening right now. I’m glad we’re curious. I’m excited to see what’s going to happen.

black-power.name: What Are 5 Words To Describe The Silent Generation?
black-power.description: The Silent Generation is the generation born between 1925–1945. Here are the words they think describe their generation.
black-power.transcript:
Home. My parents came from the Caribbean … Port of Spain, Trinidad. When they referred to home, they didn’t mean “I’m going back to the house.” They meant home, where their heart was, where they were born. And, home is where your folks were. Home is where you were born. Home is, is where you wanted to go back to.

Nothing is more valuable than having a family. It feels safe and sound.

Progressive. They’re willing to do, try new things, succeed at some, fail in others, and learn from their failures.

Lucky. We missed the Great Depression, and we missed two world wars.

Spoiled. Because we have had a relatively easy life.

When I was in, uh, late elementary school and junior high school I had a really good friend, and her name was Janice. And, Janice used to speak something to me called pig Latin. People thought I knew pig Latin too, but I didn’t.

The tone of what I’m told is the Silent Generation really changed in the 60s. One day, in Mississippi, Stokely Carmichael raised his hand, and he said black power. And James Brown, the singer, said, “Say it loud: I’m Black and I’m proud.” And, that was an era of Black people coming into consciousness. And, that was an era where we were not silent.

first-come--first-served.name: Can You Correct These Idioms?
first-come--first-served.description: Have you ever heard the idiom it’s a doggie-dog world? Well that’s not the correct phrase. It’s actually dog-eat-dog world. Can you correct these other common idioms?
first-come--first-served.transcript:
Have you ever heard the idiom it’s a doggie-dog world? Yeah, of course you have. You live in the 21st Century. But, guess what? That’s not the correct phrase. It’s actually dog-eat-dog world. Sinister, right? If you love seeing people get things wrong and learning something in the process, stay tuned for this episode of, Guess That Idiom.

I think it’s A. first come, first serve. I think it’s B though. First come, first served. 2. Why? Or, first come first serve like it’s presently happening. Alright, we’ll go with A.

[whispering] In the butt. I don’t … [laughs] In the bud! I’m thinking, like, you’re nipping weeds like … That’s funny. I don’t know. I’m thinking nipped it in the bud. Wait. But you’re reaction the first time …

I think it’s definitely intent. Yes I … I concur. 2. and purposes, like, the intent… I think the intent to do something, like, the act of …you know … I think that’s the correct answer. Heeey! 2. OK!

Mooot point. Moo… Moo… 2. Moot? Moot point? I’ve never heard this one. Moo… 2. Have you heard this one before? Just, like, keep saying moo. It’s fun. Mute point. Final answer. Ugh! See, cows! What did I tell you? They always win. Got it.

This is so funny because I always say, “You’ve got another thing coming,” but, listening to that it sounds like think is the correct answer. Yeah, I’m going to go with that. Oh, if you think you’re going to play me then, you have another think coming. That makes more sense, like, you’ve got another I just like all of that. 2. guess at life coming. That just works for me. 2. guess at life coming. Wow! See, I have to start saying it right now. I just … you should do that for every … all of them.

hermaphrodite.name: What Is The Origin Of The Term "Nymphomaniac"
hermaphrodite.description: The term nymphomaniac may sound dirty or risque today. But back in Ancient Greece -- well, it also was dirty and risque. Take a look at the origin story of this word!
hermaphrodite.transcript:
Nymphomanic comes from the Ancient Greek creatures, nymphs.

Nymphs were natural spirits that liked to hang around in the water or woods … and they were super, super horny.

They even had a habit of chasing after guys who visited the woods in order to get their sexual fill.

One of the juicier nymph-based stories has to do with the water nymph, Salmacis, who wanted the handsome hero Hermaphoditus so bad she physically merged her body with his.

Yup, that’s right—Hermaphoditus became half man, half woman because a water nymphomaniac just needed to get laid.

She even created the term hermaphrodite in the process.

But, you’re on the definition page for nymphomaniac …

So, nymphomaniac is a sex-obsessed woman, got it. However, fellas, there is a term out there for you too: satyriasis.

See, satyrs were also particularly lustful creatures of Greek mythology who were men with the physical characteristics of a goat or of a horse.

These guys had a sex drive so high they had a penchant for getting  caught in situations involving attempted rape A LOT, and the gods weren’t too happy about it.

Uh, neither are we … not acceptable now, not acceptable then.

Well, if we learned nothing else today … we’re now certain the Ancient Greeks were a pretty kinky bunch.

accent.name: What Is Accent Prestige Theory?
accent.description: No accent is more correct than another. And, here’s the irony. None of us talk the same way all the time. So why do we think some accents sound better than others?
accent.transcript:
[Speaking in exaggerated Southern accent] This cookie tastes real good.

[Speaking in exaggerated British accent] This biscuit is absolutely lovely.

Which sounds more intelligent? Which sounds more trustworthy? More successful? Even more attractive?

The person who sounds like they are from the South … or the person who sounds like they’re from across the pond?

How you answer this question may depend on something called Accent Prestige Theory. According to this theory, we make judgments about other people—including their character and social status—based on how they talk.

Do you say? [words on screen with each item]:

vase [in General American accent] or vahz [exaggerating British accent, open A with Z sound at end]

aunt [in General American accent – like the bug] or aunt [exaggerating British accent, ah sound]

totally [in General American accent] or totally [exaggerated valley girl accent]

Many people think certain accents sound smarter and sexier.

See, certain dialects of a language—which we broadly refer to as accents—are considered more “correct” or “better” than others [air quote to indicate these terms are subjective]. These accents tend to be the standard form of the language, so, these are usually the pronunciations you hear from mass media, government, business, education … from the dominant social group. 

At least in more formal settings, we’re told the General American accent sounds smarter, more honest, safer—and that’s because it carries the prestige of social standing. And that means accents have consequences.

If we give the General American accent prestige, that means we judge Southern accents, Black accents, Latin accents, Boston accents, the speech of teenaged girls. And that ain’t right.

No accent is more correct than another. And, here’s the irony. None of us talk the same way all the time.

We talk one way with our peers and another with our elders. We talk one way around the kitchen table and another in the conference room. This is a good thing. We can speak in different ways to get different things done. Bing, bam, boom.

But, let’s try not to fall under the false belief that sounding British means you’re smarter and sounding Southern, Latin, Bostonian, and so on, means you can’t be trusted. There’s no right or wrong way to speak.

Variety, as they say, is the spice of life–and of language. [Looks at cookie. Takes bite. Mmm.]

How you answer this question may depend on something called Accent Prestige Theory. According to this theory, we make judgments about other people—including their character and social status—based on how they talk.

Do you say? [words on screen with each item]:

vase [in General American accent] or vahz [exaggerating British accent, open A with Z sound at end]

aunt [in General American accent – like the bug] or aunt [exaggerating British accent, ah sound]

totally [in General American accent] or totally [exaggerated valley girl accent]

Many people think certain accents sound smarter and sexier.

See, certain dialects of a language—which we broadly refer to as accents—are considered more “correct” or “better” than others [air quote to indicate these terms are subjective]. These accents tend to be the standard form of the language, so, these are usually the pronunciations you hear from mass media, government, business, education … from the dominant social group. 

At least in more formal settings, we’re told the General American accent sounds smarter, more honest, safer—and that’s because it carries the prestige of social standing. And that means accents have consequences.

If we give the General American accent prestige, that means we judge Southern accents, Black accents, Latin accents, Boston accents, the speech of teenaged girls. And that ain’t right.

No accent is more correct than another. And, here’s the irony. None of us talk the same way all the time.

We talk one way with our peers and another with our elders. We talk one way around the kitchen table and another in the conference room. This is a good thing. We can speak in different ways to get different things done. Bing, bam, boom.

But, let’s try not to fall under the false belief that sounding British means you’re smarter and sounding Southern, Latin, Bostonian, and so on, means you can’t be trusted. There’s no right or wrong way to speak.

Variety, as they say, is the spice of life–and of language. [Looks at cookie. Takes bite. Mmm.]

common.name: How Do You Use Synonyms To Replace Common Words?
common.description: Synonyms can make our conversation and sentences sound better and more eloquent. But how do you actually use synonyms in place of common words?
common.transcript:
[Story with basic vocabulary told by Host #1:]

Yesterday, I told my friend that I could meet her after work for a drink.

[Story with synonyms told by Host #2.:]

Uh, boring! Lang syne, I besought my old chum to rendezvous after work for a libation.

[Story with basic vocabulary told by Host #1:]

It’s something we do all the time. Because we live close to each other, we are able to meet up after work often to catch up.

[Story with synonyms told by Host #2.:] [snoring] Actually … It’s a recurring plan for us. Since we have neighboring residences, we rally after our nine-to-fives ofttimes to catch up.

[Story with basic vocabulary told by Host #1:]

She’s so funny and helps me feel better after a long day. She’s the best. Do you want to come too?

[Story with synonyms told by Host #2.:]

She’s hilarious and recharges me after a strenuous day. She’s nonpareil.

[HOST 1]

Wow… that really changes things. I’m not even sure if I know what you just said.

[HOST 2]

Yeah, you are right, that was a bit… over-the-top, or maybe it was elaborate, excessive overdone, overblown… super extra.

[HOST 1]

Alright, alright! I get the picture! You are trying to tell me that I should look at Thesaurus.com more often and learn a few synonyms for some of my favorite words so I can expand my vocabulary. You are such a nerd sometimes!

[HOST 2]

A nerd, yes! But maybe also a fool, jerk, weirdo, dolt …

[HOST 1]

Dork, dweeb, goober, goofball …

[HOST 2]

See! Now you are getting it! Now that that’s settled, you were saying something about a drink … ? (throws thesaurus looking book over shoulder)

communism.name: How To Use The Terms "Socialism" vs. "Communism"
communism.description: Socialism and Communism are two words that fall under the category of: learned it a while ago, probably should know it, but actually don't because these are confusing are hard. So what do these terms mean?
communism.transcript:
Socialism and Communism are two words that fall under the category of: learned it a while ago, probably should know it, but actually don’t because these are confusing are hard.

Well, I’m for sure guilty of this which is why I dug a little deeper to figure out the real differences between socialism and communism … just for you all watching this video. You can thank me later.

Socialism is a social theory .. makes sense.

It theorizes that a collective cooperation of citizens will make all governmental institutions public.

That’s why socialism is brought up when universal health care is discussed because the institution of healthcare would be public and run by the government.

Essentially, no one will receive a healthcare bill when going to the doctor because they, and everyone else, have paid a hefty amount in government taxes. That’s where the collective cooperation comes in.

Many Scandinavian countries, such as Sweden, are socialist countries in that they practice publicized government programs, such as decentralized healthcare.

Communism, on the other hand, is a branch of socialism.

It’s similar in that it’s still founded on the idea of collective cooperation, but differs in that communists believe that cooperation should be run by a totalitarian government made up of one and only one government.

Russia gave communism a bad name when it reigned as the USSR.

It was here that thousands who were seen as threats to the state—artists, authors, intellectuals, even those who practiced religion—were sent to be slaughtered or exiled … uh, yikes.

Although the USSR fell way back when, Russia is still very communist culturally, though financially they’re a capitalistic system.

Countries like the People’s Republic of China are certainly more communist than Russia, where all things are publicized up to the point that citizens can’t even use the internet fully due to the government’s fear of free thought.

So does that mean communism and socialism are bad? Not really. Sometimes, they just fall into the hands of bad people.

fuck.name: What Are Synonyms For The F Word?
fuck.description: Sadly, there are situations where f*ck is not appropriate. That's where this ample list of synonyms comes in handy.
fuck.transcript:
The “F” word, or F*ck, is a remarkable word.

It’s old, for one: F-ck is believed to have first showed up in written form some time in the 1400s.

Sure, it’s vulgar, but it’s also impressive how many different things it can express.

F*ck can literally mean “to have sex.”

But, it can also be used as a modifier for emphasis, as in “you’re f*cking kidding me.”

F*ck can describe being treated badly or roughly.

And … I’m pretty sure we’re all aware there’s many more uses for this f*cking word.

OK, enough with the bleeping out … we’ll take it back to PG because, sadly, there are situations where f*ck is not appropriate.

That’s where this ample list of synonyms comes in handy.

Ready … ?

First up, acronyms.

FU: f*ck you

GTFO: get the f*ck out

STFU: shut the f*ck up

CTFU: crack(ing) the f*ck up

GMFU: got me f*cked up

While these acronyms span from humorous to serious, these vulgar letters don’t carry much offense.

And, then there’s foreign languages … you can get away with a lot when people don’t understand you.

There’s verga (in Spanish) and shtup in Yiddish …

And now you’re going to look up those words, aren’t you? We know you’re motivated to find the many, many other words you can use as a substitute for f*ck.

Go on … go find ’em. We know you can f*cking do it.

apostrophe.name: What Are The Rules For Adding An Apostrophe Plus An S To Words?
apostrophe.description: The rules for showing possession—that is, owning, having, or belonging to something—in English grammar can be extremely frustrating. Here are three general rules.
apostrophe.transcript:
The rules for showing possession—that is, owning, having, or belonging to something—in English grammar can be extremely frustrating.

Here are three general rules.

One: Add an apostrophe plus an S after a singular noun to show possession. Tweet about “Ariana Grande’s (e apostrophe s) new song,” not “Ariana Grandes (e s) new song.” Tweet about “the dog’s (g apostrophe s) fluffy hair,” not “the dogs (g s) fluffy hair.”

If the singular noun already ends in an S, like LeBron James, you have several options. We like to add an apostrophe and an S. So, tweet about “LeBron James’s stats.”

Two: Add an apostrophe after plural nouns to show possession. So, “the dogs’ fluffy hair” means you’re tweeting about the hair of two or more dogs. So, that means if you tweet about “Ariana Grandes’ (s apostrophe) new song” not only is that bad grammar… but maybe also some wishful thinking. Which is fair, the more Arianas the better.

If the plural noun is irregular, like men and women, add an apostrophe and S. “The women’s rights movement” is right. “The mens’ rights movement” is wrong in so, so many ways.

Three: Don’t add an apostrophe to possessive pronouns. Write his and hers, not his’s or her’s. Write ours and theirs, not our’s or theirs’s. The trickiest one is the possessive form of it. It’s is a contraction of it is, has, or was: “It’s got the best tacos.” Its, on the other hand, means belonging to some it: “Its tacos are the best.”

English is confusing!

hyperbole.name: What Are Examples Of Hyperbole?
hyperbole.description: Hyperbole is a super-exaggerated way of describing something for the sake of emphasis that often borders on the fantastical or ridiculous. But what are some examples of hyperbole?
hyperbole.transcript:
[Host lets out a big, exaggerated sigh and drops shoulders] God, I have, like, a million things to define about this word with absolutely zero time to do it.

OK, maybe that was a bit dramatic … but that was hyperbole, a super-exaggerated way of describing something for the sake of emphasis that often borders on the fantastical or ridiculous … and can usually be heard sprouting from the mouths of teenagers everywhere!

Just kidding … adults do it all the time too.

Ever talked about something going faster than the speed of light …. Hyperbole.

How about when your shopping bags weigh a ton? Hyperbole.

What about yesterday when you were so hungry you could eat a horse … or that person who cut you off on the way to work who was a total pea-brain. Hyperbole.

You can thank the ancient Greeks for this one … although the first recorded use of hyberbole was way back in the 15th century which is, like, a billion years ago. There was even this Greek politician, Hyperbolus, who used to make all these outlandish promises to his people and ended up getting ostracized for the rest of his life … because they were never accurate or true.

Weirdly enough though, there’s not a direct connection between him and the creation of the actual word hyperbole … but fun story, right?

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’m dying to get out of here! Bye.

life.name: What Makes Something A Lifestyle?
life.description: Our lifestyle is what helps us define ourselves to others and it conveys our morals and values. But what makes something a lifestyle per se?
life.transcript:
When you hear the word lifestyle, what do you think of?

Lifestyles of the rich and famous? Champagne wishes and caviar dreams!

What about Beyonce and her vegan and green lifestyle? If he takes out the recycling will she take his ass to Red Lobster? Seems only fair.

It seems like lifestyle is a pretty flexible word. And, that’s partly because at its core lifestyle is trying to encompass a lot; it contains “the habits, attitudes, tastes, moral standards, economic level, etc., that together constitute the mode of living of an individual or group.”

When you try to define all of those things about one specific group, it gets complicated. Even more complicated when we think about all of the groups we have in our country … in the world.

Lifestyle is important to each and every one of these groups though. Makes sense; our lifestyle is what helps us define ourselves to others and it conveys our morals and values too.

Plus, identifying lifestyles that bigger groups identify with (or wish they identified with) is an easy way to make $$. You know you were thinking it!

All those lifestyle magazines and blogs … a lot of them are dedicated to a fitness lifestyle: you know, the kind of decisions you make on a regular basis that contribute to your health. Some follow an extreme healthy lifestyle, like dieting and constant exercise (kudos to you). Others are a bit more casual about it … like taking the stairs instead of the elevator (it’s a big step, you guys)!

Lifestyle is also a cultural matter. Eating Sunday dinners and making gravy is an Italian lifestyle, for example. It’s about the tradition of coming together and participating in an activity that promotes family and heritage.

That’s the thing about lifestyles—you can choose which one you want to live, or you can embrace the one you’ve been given through family values and traditions. Plus, there’s always room to make up your own: a lifestyle can pertain to an individual (not just a group) too—remember that definition from before?

As for me, I wouldn’t mind adopting a daily afternoon nap lifestyle … new lifestyle members welcome.

See ya!
