As for me, I wouldn’t mind adopting a daily afternoon nap lifestyle … new lifestyle members welcome.

See ya!

style.name: What Makes Something A Lifestyle?
style.description: Our lifestyle is what helps us define ourselves to others and it conveys our morals and values. But what makes something a lifestyle per se?
style.transcript:
When you hear the word lifestyle, what do you think of?

Lifestyles of the rich and famous? Champagne wishes and caviar dreams!

What about Beyonce and her vegan and green lifestyle? If he takes out the recycling will she take his ass to Red Lobster? Seems only fair.

It seems like lifestyle is a pretty flexible word. And, that’s partly because at its core lifestyle is trying to encompass a lot; it contains “the habits, attitudes, tastes, moral standards, economic level, etc., that together constitute the mode of living of an individual or group.”

When you try to define all of those things about one specific group, it gets complicated. Even more complicated when we think about all of the groups we have in our country … in the world.

Lifestyle is important to each and every one of these groups though. Makes sense; our lifestyle is what helps us define ourselves to others and it conveys our morals and values too.

Plus, identifying lifestyles that bigger groups identify with (or wish they identified with) is an easy way to make $$. You know you were thinking it!

All those lifestyle magazines and blogs … a lot of them are dedicated to a fitness lifestyle: you know, the kind of decisions you make on a regular basis that contribute to your health. Some follow an extreme healthy lifestyle, like dieting and constant exercise (kudos to you). Others are a bit more casual about it … like taking the stairs instead of the elevator (it’s a big step, you guys)!

Lifestyle is also a cultural matter. Eating Sunday dinners and making gravy is an Italian lifestyle, for example. It’s about the tradition of coming together and participating in an activity that promotes family and heritage.

That’s the thing about lifestyles—you can choose which one you want to live, or you can embrace the one you’ve been given through family values and traditions. Plus, there’s always room to make up your own: a lifestyle can pertain to an individual (not just a group) too—remember that definition from before?

As for me, I wouldn’t mind adopting a daily afternoon nap lifestyle … new lifestyle members welcome.

See ya!

credible.name: How Do Certain Words Make Things Seem Less Trustworthy?
credible.description: There are some words that just make things seem less reliable and trustworthy. So why do we use them?
credible.transcript:
Life is full of possibilities; anything is possible. But sometimes, deeming something as just possible doesn’t make it seem very credible or probable.

Like when the media reports a possible hate crime or even when the weatherperson says there’s a possible chance of rain.

Do you feel confident that those things have happened or will in the future? Yea, we don’t either …

And, what do you think about these phrases: fast food, fast fashion, pull a fast one … The Fast and the Furious. OK, the word fast didn’t really affect how bad the Fast and the Furious chain is … but you get the drift.

Fast has a positive association in a world run by high-speed internet and is particularly beneficial if you happen to be an Olympic sprinter.

But what about when an item was made fast, chances are it’s sloppily done and not sustainable. Fast tends to cheapen the word it’s next too. As The Tortoise and the Hare has taught us: slow and steady wins the race.

Oh, here’s one that definitely adds credibility … extreme. You know if something is labeled as extreme it has to be amazing, right? Uh …

To be quite frank, anything that has extreme in front of it really isn’t that extreme at all. Take, for example, the least extreme of the extremes: extreme frisbee. That’s an oxymoron if I ever heard one.

This may have to do with extreme’s core definition. For something to be extreme, it has to have “a character or kind farthest removed from the ordinary or average.” Juxtaposing extreme next to something plain or ordinary—such as frisbee—cancels out the extraordinary aspect behind the word. 

It’s like those ads for extreme weight loss or extreme enjoyment. Chances are your weight loss and enjoyment will be pretty average … and we all know it.

But, the thing about these words is that they do add intrigue, and they provide purpose (possible actually helps journalists not get sued for libel … so that’s good).

Sorry freeloaders … these words are here to stay.

arcade.name: What Are 5 Words To Describe Generation X?
arcade.description: Generation X is made up of people who were born in the early 1960s to the late 1970s. So, we asked them what words they think describe their generation.
arcade.transcript:
Five words to describe my generation … 

I would start with classic. We were raised by our parents or babysitters not a smartphone or a computer. 

I would say resilient. We know the value of hard work, old school work ethics, and overcoming obstacles in a real world manner.

Awesome. Because we try to be the best role models we can for millennials.

Hardworking. Because my first job paid me $4.25 an hour, and I know the value of a dollar.

Arcades. We all grew up in an arcade or on a Nintendo, Sega, Playstation, and it’s deeply rooted in who we are.

busted.name: Is There A Difference Between East Coast And West Coast Slang?
busted.description: Is there a difference between east coast slang and west coast slang? The short answer: yes. Take a look.
busted.transcript:
Once upon a time on the east coast of the good ol’ USA, a young man began his day. Some people may call this bro a guido because he was Italian, and he had big, spiky hair, and he loved the gym. But, he didn’t think of himself that way. He was just a New Jersey homie representing the Garden State: represent, represent!

He wasn’t like one of those mad beat dudes who lived out in bumble f&*k Pennsylvania and called everything jawn. And, he wasn’t like one of those Boston guys who were wicked annoying and busted. He was from New Jersey, the armpit of America, some may say … he was a down-home kinda dude, no doubt about it.

However, that same day a gangsta from the west coast woke up too. He was hella tired but he rolled out of bed anyways because the freeway was going to be a mess in 20 minutes … and if he wanted to stop for In & Out to get that animal style he had to hecka move. Back east, where he grew up, the highways weren’t this bad, but that’s what you pay to live on the best coast, as his grom friends always say. Alright, finally out the door, on the road, and on the way toward making that gouda, cha ching.

bamboozle.name: What Is The Origin Of The Word "Bamboozled"?
bamboozle.description: Bamboozle is one of those words that has been confounding etymologists for centuries. No one knows for sure what its origins are.
bamboozle.transcript:
Is that a walking banana? Oh, no! It’s a corgi in a banana suit! Oh heck! Bamboozled again!
Bamboozle is one of those words that has been confounding etymologists for centuries. No one knows for sure what its origins are.
One thing we do know is that it was originally considered “low language,” at least among defenders of language like British satirist Jonathan Swift, who hoped (and correctly predicted that it would quickly fast from the English lexicon). Unfortunately for Mr. Swift, the internet got a hold of it.
OK, so I’m sure you’ve realized I’m really into dogs and dog speech. But what does it actually mean to bamboozle someone?
Well, as far as we can tell, the earliest meaning of bamboozle was “to deceive by trickery, hoodwink,” which is why some believe that it arose among the criminals of the underworld. So for example, “I thought he was helping me walk across the street but he was picking my pocket! I have been bamboozled!”
By 1712, it acquired the sense “to perplex; mystify.” It is not known for certain, but this sense might have emerged under the influence of the Scottish word bumbaze (or bombaze), meaning “to confuse.” Given that alcohol is pretty good at making people act in confusing or mystifying ways, it shouldn’t be much of a surprise that in the 1800’s bamboozle began to be used as slang for “drunk.”
So, there you have it folks. While we may still feel pretty bamboozled by the origins of the word bamboozle, it’s no real cause for heckin’ concern. But, if you do start to get concerned, just do a quick search for bamboozled doggo and you will feel better … trust me.

clairvoyant.name: What Does It Mean To Be Clairvoyant?
clairvoyant.description: In the 19th century, the term clairvoyant was widely used in a medical context. So when did it change?
clairvoyant.transcript:
[Actor 1]: (Passes money across the table.) Ok, so, I want to know if my boyfriend really likes me, or if he is more into my roommate Jessica. (Note: question doesn’t really matter – just make it something kind of vapid and funny).

[Actor 2]:  I see, I see. Let me think on that a minute… (futzes with props). Oh! I think I am receiving an answer… wait for it… Ah! [Snaps up in a eureka movement and begins to rattle off the meaning of clairvoyant with confidence as if that was the question that was asked.]

Clairvoyant literally means “clear-sighted” in French, and for nearly 200 years that is what it meant in English as well.

But then the (mid-) 19th century came around and people started getting funky.  Case in point: clairvoyant took on the meaning of “having psychic gifts” or “seeing beyond,” which it still carries today.

[Actor 1]: Uhhhh. I am not sure what this has to with my question but….

[Actor 2 cutting the other person off]: In the 19th century, the term clairvoyant was widely used in a medical context.

An especially astute doctor might be able to see a patient’s symptoms and try to make a clairvoyant diagnosis. While some of these doctors were legitimate and extremely skilled, the term clairvoyant physician was generally used to describe your typical 19th-century quack.

[Actor 1]: A quack, you mean kind of like you?

[Actor 2 ignoring the question]: But, back to today, where clairvoyant carries more spiritual connotations. The modern clairvoyant prefers only to “see” things that cannot be easily refuted by disbelieving skeptics. Some choose to believe that these clairvoyants have other worldly insights that most people do not. Others chose to think of them as quacks. [Seems to snap out of clairvoyant reverie]. Either way, we will take your money. Thanks!

psychic.name: What Does It Mean To Be Clairvoyant?
psychic.description: In the 19th century, the term clairvoyant was widely used in a medical context. So when did it change?
psychic.transcript:
[Actor 1]: (Passes money across the table.) Ok, so, I want to know if my boyfriend really likes me, or if he is more into my roommate Jessica. (Note: question doesn’t really matter – just make it something kind of vapid and funny).

[Actor 2]:  I see, I see. Let me think on that a minute… (futzes with props). Oh! I think I am receiving an answer… wait for it… Ah! [Snaps up in a eureka movement and begins to rattle off the meaning of clairvoyant with confidence as if that was the question that was asked.]

Clairvoyant literally means “clear-sighted” in French, and for nearly 200 years that is what it meant in English as well.

But then the (mid-) 19th century came around and people started getting funky.  Case in point: clairvoyant took on the meaning of “having psychic gifts” or “seeing beyond,” which it still carries today.

[Actor 1]: Uhhhh. I am not sure what this has to with my question but….

[Actor 2 cutting the other person off]: In the 19th century, the term clairvoyant was widely used in a medical context.

An especially astute doctor might be able to see a patient’s symptoms and try to make a clairvoyant diagnosis. While some of these doctors were legitimate and extremely skilled, the term clairvoyant physician was generally used to describe your typical 19th-century quack.

[Actor 1]: A quack, you mean kind of like you?

[Actor 2 ignoring the question]: But, back to today, where clairvoyant carries more spiritual connotations. The modern clairvoyant prefers only to “see” things that cannot be easily refuted by disbelieving skeptics. Some choose to believe that these clairvoyants have other worldly insights that most people do not. Others chose to think of them as quacks. [Seems to snap out of clairvoyant reverie]. Either way, we will take your money. Thanks!

climate.name: What Is The Difference Between "Weather" vs. "Climate"?
climate.description: Although there is a wealth of scientific evidence, the difference between weather and climate can be difficult to understand. But all hope is not lost—we're here to help you learn the difference.
climate.transcript:
All you seem to hear about these days are droughts, polar vortexes and global warming! Whatever happened to 75 and blue skies?

Some of these problems can be solved with an ice cold beverage or a warm coat… but others are a warning sign of something more sinister. How do we know when we need need a soda, or when the remedy is a little more complicated? The debate seems to rage on, when really there should be no debate at all.

Although there is a wealth of scientific evidence, the difference between weather and climate can be difficult to understand.

But all hope is not lost! Between the brilliant minds at Dictionary.com, and the rocket scientists at NASA, we are able to set the record straight. Let’s see how the dictionary defines these two words…

You see, the key here is time.

Weather is your day to day rain or shine, whereas climate is the overall pattern of temperature, humidity and rainfall you can expect to see in a certain area.

This is corroborated by NASA, the guys who spend more time looking at the Earth than pretty much anyone else.

So, in other words, a sunny day in Alaska is a nice weather surprise, but that doesn’t mean it’s about to start challenging Florida for climate-based title of “The Sunshine State”.

Changes in weather are part of life on Earth; giving us the opportunity to build snowmen on some days and sand castles on others.

Climate change, however, is far more serious. Just consider the rate at which the sea level is rising. Disney World will be a lot less fun if it’s under water.

shenanigan.name: Where Does The Word "Shenanigans" Come From?
shenanigan.description: We love the word "shenanigans." Just saying the word is almost as much fun as planning some shenanigans to pull on someone.
shenanigan.transcript:
I love the word shenanigans. Just saying the word is almost as much fun as planning some shenanigans to pull on someone.

And, the word shenanigans is playing tricks on us too … because literally nobody can figure out where the word came from. All we know is that it’s from around the 1850s and it was first seen in the San Francisco area. That’s it. That’s shenanigans. Oh, you tricky, little, deceitful term, you.

Makes me think of high school, primarily. My friend Josh … (laughs) and I went out on a school night and purloined (stole) one of those real estate catalog dispensers and they were made of plastic, and the top looked like a house, you know, it had like gables or whatever.

And it must’ve been, I mean, definitely after midnight … small town, USA. And we grabbed it, threw it in the back, and we were driving away with it, and … I remember being like, “What do we do with this thing?”

And, he’s like, “I want my mom to see it in the morning.” And, I was like, “Okaay …” (laughing)

We drove up to the freeway and left it on the shoulder on his mom’s way to work. The next afternoon or evening, I’m sure he was probably, you know, prying with her, like, “Did you see anything funny on the way to work today, Mom?” (laughing)

Ooooh, man. I wonder how long it stayed out there.

Shenanigans is literally the most nostalgic word. Because of that, I don’t care that we don’t know much about it.

In fact, I’m going to use it proudly and literally LOL every time I say it. (laughing) Whew …

compound.name: How To Know If A Term Is One Word Or Two Words
compound.description: English loves to take existing words and smash them together so they act as one unit. This is called compounding. But how do you know if a word is one word or two?
compound.transcript:
Tweeter and toxicologist Kevin Shanks is asking the big questions.

It’s one word (pause) – motherfucker. You see, motherfucker is a compound noun made up of two other nouns, mother and fucker. It’s become common enough since it was first recorded in the 1910s that we write it out as a single—one word, not two, without a hyphen.

But, you make a good point, Mr. Shanks. English can be a real pain in the a [as if about to say ass]—neck.

[Title slide]

English loves to take existing words and smash them together so they act as one unit. This is called compounding. Hashtag combines the nouns hash and tag. This is known as a closed compound. Live-tweeting joins the adjective live and the verb tweet. This is a hyphenated compound. Log out mixes the verb log and the adverb out. This is an open compound.

Compounding gets a lot more complex than this, but here are three general guidelines to help you decide whether it’s one motherf—uggin’ word or two.

First, compound nouns often like to be closed or hyphenated. On Thanksgiving, tweet about how much you love the cornbread, one word, made by your mother-in-law, hyphenated.

Compound nouns, when they become very common, tend to go from being written separately to being hyphenated to being written as one word. We can see this happening with the words email and website, for instance, which most people aren’t writing as e-mail (hyphenated) or web site (two words) anymore.

Second, compound adjectives often like to be hyphenated. Tweet about how your good-looking, dog-loving boyfriend encouraged you to have a Netflix-bingeing Sunday. Some adjectives do become common enough, though, to earn one-word status: freethinking is a good example.

Finally, compound verbs often like to be open. Tweet about how you set up your new computer and logged in to all of your accounts. When the words get joined into one, their part of speech generally changes. Your computer login or your video-game setup—login and setup here are nouns made from those open, two-word verb phrases.

When in doubt, look up the word on Dictionary.com. If it’s not in there, pick which form—closed, hyphenated, or open—you think most clearly communicates what you are trying to say. And, if anyone calls you out, Mr. Shanks knows one good word you can use. (wink)

metaphor.name: This Or That: Simile vs. Metaphor
metaphor.description: Simile vs. metaphor ... it’s the age-old question that none of us can keep straight. So, let’s try looking at it a different way ...
metaphor.transcript:
Simile vs. metaphor … it’s the age-old question that none of us can keep straight. So, let’s try looking at it a different way …

Similes and metaphors are both ways to compare things, right?

But … a metaphor is a bit more dramatic, like the theater-school student; he’s direct and he exaggerates … just a bit.

When complimenting you, the metaphor tells you “your smile is sunshine,” and “baby, you’re a firework.” No ifs, ands, or buts about it. (And yes, most metaphors are into Katy Perry too.)

Then, there’s simile. She’s that person who’s more reserved, analytical, and thoughtful.

When she compares things, she usually uses the words like or as. She’s not as direct or dramatic as metaphor … but she’s getting the same job done: comparing one thing to another.

When simile compliments you … she uses her words to gently suggest “your smile is like sunshine,” or “your personality is as energetic as a firework.”

Who you chose is up to you and it can depend on the situation … they’re both great at comparisons, really.

(show somebody swiping right?)

alone.name: We Asked These People To Explain The Saddest English Phrases
alone.description: There are some words that are inherently sad and some others that, depending on context, may be even more depressing. Do you agree with the words these people believe are the saddest?
alone.transcript:
Alright, so the saddest phrase I’ve ever heard is:  “I needed more time.” It’s the past tense of the word needed that really gets me, because it implies that the opportunity for more time is gone.  And, as we all know, time is something that we can’t get back. Now this shouldn’t be confused with the very similar phrase, “I need more time.” Which is more of a request than an expression of regret.

One of the saddest words in the dictionary to me is inequality. Simply put, there is unfairness in a system, a society, a country. Now, I believe that all men are created equal because we are of one race: the human race. So wherever, or whenever, there is unfairness or inequality, it is up to us, the human race, to address and rebuke such matter, because we are all created equal and we should all be treated with equal rights, consequence, and respect.

The word alone can be a very sad word, and I think it’s one of the saddest words in our vocabulary. While being alone technically means being separate or isolated, I don’t think that in itself is always a bad thing. I think some of us enjoy being physically alone. And that can be good sometimes, we enjoy our, um, our solitude. But sometimes when we use the word alone, we use it more as in an emotional sense such as, “I’m feeling alone in my thoughts.” Or, “I’m feeling alone in my opinions.” And that type of loneliness, I think, is much harder to understand. When my first child was born, and I was home on maternity leave, even though I was physically with my newborn child, and there were a lot of friends and family members who were supporting me through that time, I still felt very lonely. As in, nobody understands what it feels like to have to raise a brand new human being and have no idea what you’re doing. 

So we can feel alone in the decisions that we’re making, in the opinions that we have, um, in our emotions, we can feel alone, and that’s when I think the word alone can take on a very profound sense of sadness, and it’s something that is much more complicated to figure out than just being physically by yourself.

oscars.name: How Did April Reign Create The Hashtag #OscarsSoWhite?
oscars.description: Hashtags are great for getting a conversation going. But how do you create one, and how does it go viral? April Reign answered some of these questions.
oscars.transcript:
Hi. I’m April Reign, the creator of OscarsSoWhite.

In January of 2015, I was still a practicing attorney, um, and I had no connection whatsoever to the entertainment field, other than the fact that I was a rabid consumer of film. Uh, so the Oscars particularly were like my Super Bowl. There were special snacks involved. I’d rope off the TV so everybody knew this was mommy’s night. I’d watch the pre-show, the show, the after show, the show the next day. Everything about the Oscars I loved.

Uh, so I was… That morning, January 2015, I was watching the nominations on one of the morning television shows, and it just struck me for no particular reason that year because, unfortunately, it happened both before then and since, um, there were no people of color nominated in any of the acting categories. 20 different spots. So I picked up my phone, um, which is typically embedded in my forearm, and got on social media and tweeted, “OscarsSoWhite they asked to touch my hair.” And that was it. I then went on to work, uh, and then when I checked in on Twitter around lunchtime, the hashtag based on that one tweet was then trending internationally.

Um, as I said, this was a very organic campaign, I guess. I wasn’t even planning for it to be a campaign or a movement initially. Uh, I was just thinking out loud. (laughs) Very often, I think out loud on Twitter to share my thoughts, um, with my followers and whoever is interested.

I know generally, having had hashtags go internationally viral both before OscarsSoWhite and since, that hashtags have to be short, um, first and foremost. You know, in January of 2015, we were still relegated to 140 characters, not the 280 that we have now, uh, so every single letter, every single word or phrase matters. Um, and so I knew that OscarsSoWhite was short. I was hoping that it was to the point, (laughs) even though, um, years later, people still pretend at least to misunderstand what my meaning was with that phrase. Um, and I was hoping that it would be memorable. And, in fact, it was. Uh, and so now, um, here we are now in year six of OscarsSoWhite, and people are still using the hashtag. And, in fact, um, the phrase has broadened. You know, now there is a JournalismSoWhite and an EducationSoWhite and even a BrooklynSoWhite, none of which I started, um, I think that goes to show that, um, when you are doing something that makes sense that can be universal, and that’s what you want a hashtag to be, people may take it and riff off of it, um, to make it their own, and then I think that’s great.

Um, so hashtags sh- should be short, they should be to the point, um, they should ensure that your message is getting across in just that one phrase, um, and hopefully they are memorable.

To people who are interested in creating their own viral movements or campaigns, um, you know, I would say you can absolutely start on social media, but don’t stay there. Um, remember that there are people who don’t use social media (laughs), surprisingly enough, uh, so you need to meet people where they are. Hashtags are great for getting a conversation going, and hopefully that conversation will continue, even if you’re not leading it. Um, but you also need to write. You need to speak. Um, i- but if you have an issue that touches your heart, um, something that you feel passionate about, um, something that you want to see changed, absolutely get on social media, regardless of the size of your platform, and start talking about it using that hashtag, and then get your friends, family, and followers involved, um, to help you with your campaign. Good luck.

arete.name: Arete: Visual Word of the Day
arete.description: Who in your life embodies the idea of arete?

bunglesome.name: Bunglesome: Visual Word Of The Day
bunglesome.description: Why is it so satisfying to watch other people screw up?

treat.name: Why Do We Say "Trick Or Treat" On Halloween?
treat.description: "Trick or Treat" is the quintessential Halloween greeting but why do we say it?
treat.transcript:
Trick or Treat is the quintessential Halloween greeting …

… but why do we say it?

The custom is believed to have been borrowed from England, Scotland, and Ireland.

They practiced guising or mumming …

… which means performing a song, card trick, or story for a treat.

The routine took hold in the US in the ‘30s,

but not everyone was on board.

Some adults were angered by the entitlement of asking for treats.

Rumor has it that in a 1947 Halloween parade,

the Madison Square Boys Club held a banner that read: “American Boys Don’t Beg.”

Eventually, people got over it,

and we’ve been trick or treating excitedly since the 1950s!

prayer.name: Where Does The Phrase "Thoughts And Prayers" Come From?
prayer.description: When tragedies happen, social media fills up with thoughts and prayers. So, how did this phrase get so popular?
prayer.transcript:
When tragedies happen, social media fills up with thoughts and prayers.

So, how did this phrase get so popular?

Theories on the history of thoughts and prayers vary,

but it is often traced back to the Columbine High School massacre in 1999.

People felt unable to do anything tangible to take away the pain of the victims’ families and the survivors.

And politicians felt restricted in what they could say because

the tragedy was directly related to the contentious gun debates.

On their own, the words aren’t inherently bad.

Thoughts typically refer to thinking positively for a victim and hoping they recover quickly.

Prayers generally implies that a person will pray for a quick recovery.

Criticism lies in the lack of action that goes along with these words.

If thoughts and prayers truly feels heartfelt to you, then by all means, say that.

But, if there are other ways you can support someone during a trying time, stick to that.

atm.name: Did You Know These Phrases Are Actually Repetitive?
atm.description: Stop wasting your breath ... these phrases are repetitive! These words actually mean the same thing!
atm.transcript:
Stop wasting your breath …

these phrases are repetitive!

ATM machine is overdone.

The M already stands for machine.

Love that chai tea?

Well, you’re actually drinking tea tea.

That’s right. Chai already means “tea.”

Was that an unexpected surprise?

Of course it was! The whole point of a surprise is that it’s unexpected.

No surprise here: Naan bread is delicious.

But if you order it this way, you’re really asking for bread bread.

As a bonus, we’ll leave you with this.

You really don’t have to say “added bonus.”

A bonus is something that’s already extra!

deadly-sins.name: Who Invented The 7 Deadly Sins?
deadly-sins.description: Do you know where the seven deadly sins came from ... and what they mean?
deadly-sins.transcript:
Screen 1: Where did the seven deadly sins come from … and what do they mean?

Screen 2: Long ago, like really long ago, in the late 6th century, Pope Gregory I first listed the seven deadly sins.

Screen 3: For his list, Pope Gregory drew from the ideas of Evagrius Ponticus, a 4th century Christian monk who identified eight evils humans should resist.

Screen 4: In the 13th century, Christian theologian Thomas Aquinas further wrote about the seven deadly sins, which he called “capital vices.”

Screen 5: Capital comes from the Latin caput, “head.”

  • Aquinas believed the head leads the body in the capital vices, chief among them pride and greed, and that leads to further immorality.

Screen 6: As you can tell, he believed the seven deadly sins were the cause of all other offenses.

Screen 7: About a century after Aquinas, capital began to mean “deadly” in English … and that’s how the capital vices became the deadly sins for good.

Screen 8: So what are the seven deadly sins?

Screen 9: pride and definition

Screen 10: envy and definition

Screen 11: gluttony and definition

Screen 12: greed and definition

Screen 13: lust and definition

Screen 14: sloth and definition

Screen 15: wrath and definition

Screen 4: In the 13th century, Christian theologian Thomas Aquinas further wrote about the seven deadly sins, which he called “capital vices.”

Screen 5: Capital comes from the Latin caput, “head.”

  • Aquinas believed the head leads the body in the capital vices, chief among them pride and greed, and that leads to further immorality.

Screen 6: As you can tell, he believed the seven deadly sins were the cause of all other offenses.

Screen 7: About a century after Aquinas, capital began to mean “deadly” in English … and that’s how the capital vices became the deadly sins for good.

Screen 8: So what are the seven deadly sins?

Screen 9: pride and definition

Screen 10: envy and definition

Screen 11: gluttony and definition

Screen 12: greed and definition

Screen 13: lust and definition

Screen 14: sloth and definition

Screen 15: wrath and definition

promiscuous.name: Why Is The Word "Promiscuous" Mostly Used For Women?
promiscuous.description: The word promiscuous seems only ever to describe two things. First, sex, and second, women. Is promiscuous just a dressed-up attempt to avoid words like slutty or whore?
promiscuous.transcript:
The word promiscuous seems only ever to describe two things. First, sex, and second, women. Is promiscuous just a dressed-up attempt to avoid words like slutty or whore?

Today, the word promiscuous is most commonly used for “having sexual relations with a number of partners on a casual basis.”

When first recorded in the 1570s, however, promiscuous meant “random” or “mixed in a disorderly way.” Mixed is key, because promiscuous comes from a Latin word, prōmiscuus [proh-mis-koo-uhs], literally meaning “mixed about.”

This Latin root had the sense of “in common” or “indiscriminate.” A promiscuous crowd was made up of both commoners and aristocrats. Or, a promiscuous event was open to all. Promiscuous, then, was not concerned with sex, but with social class.

By the mid-1600s, promiscuous was describing something or someone as “undiscriminating” in their choices. One example from around this time called birds promiscuous, because they ate everything from seeds to insects.

But, when we humans aren’t thinking about sex, it seems we’re making judgments about other people’s lifestyle choices. By the end of the 1800s, promiscuous was squarely in the bedroom, characterizing people who had a lot of casual sex—people who aren’t being discriminate about who they are having sex with.

And, given our double standards about sex in society, it’s no surprise, sadly, that women have been larger targets of the word promiscuous than men have.

Not everything is sex and sexism with the word promiscuous today, though. It’s sometimes used more metaphorically for something “done too freely or frequently”—like He’s promiscuous with his credit card number, giving it out to just anyone who asks for it or The company’s promiscuous use of the word “organic” made us question just exactly where the food came from.

It’s hard to get away from sex—and sexism—with promiscuous, but perhaps this is one word that should really… get around more. [wink]

pandemic.name: Why Dictionary.com Chose This Word To Describe 2020
pandemic.description: Choosing one word to describe 2020 has not been easy, it's been a tumultuous year with many newsworthy events ... and words. That's why we recorded some of the reasons behind our choice word to sum up 2020. Do you agree with our Word of the Year?
pandemic.transcript:
absentee vote, acquit, asymptomatic, Black Lives Matter, conspiracy theory, contact tracing, defund, doomscrolling, flatten the curve, frontliner, furlough, infodemic, Karen, lockdown, PPE, quarantine, social distancing, superspreader, rona, Zoom fatigue, pandemic

The pandemic defined 2020 …

The pandemic changed the dictionary …

The pandemic changed everything …

Dictionary.com saw many trends in 2020 …

and the pandemic shaped them all in some way.

Remember these?

acquit

conspiracy theory

quarantine

social distance

isolation

super spreader

Black Lives Matter

defund

Karen

doomscrolling

absentee vote

These words were all top searches by you on Dictionary.com this year,

yet the one thing that ties them together is the …

pandemic

Pandemic is Dictionary.com’s Word of the Year for 2020.

How could it not be?

The word pandemic ultimately comes from the Greek pân, “all,” and dêmos, “people”—all people

Without a doubt, the pandemic affected all people, all over the world.

And the many ways the pandemic runs through the events and terms of 2020 …

only reinforced our decision to name pandemic our 2020 Word of the Year.

How has the pandemic changed us?

The pandemic has wreaked social and economic disruption on a historic scale and scope.

All other events for most of 2020, from the protests for racial justice to a heated presidential election, were shaped by the pandemic.

Despite its hardships, the pandemic inspired the best of our humanity: resilience and resourcefulness in the face of struggle.

The pandemic has made us acquire and invent new words to understand the world.

And the team at Dictionary.com will be here alongside you for it all …

continuing to document, explain, and share the words that are helping us make sense of our new reality.

Dictionary.com is passionate about our role in giving you the information you need about changing words—in a changing world.

has.name: 3 Tips For Using "Have" vs. "Has" Correctly
has.description: Do you know how to use "have" and "has" correctly? Check out these 3 tips from the dictionary to make sure you never mix them up again.
has.transcript:
Screen 1: Do you know how to use have and has correctly?

Screen 2: Have and has are both forms of the verb to have. To have primarily means “to possess, own, hold for use, or contain.” (definition screen layout)

Screen 3: Tip #1: If you’re speaking in the first person, use have.

Screen 4: Have is the conjugation of to have that’s used when:

  • speaking in the first person (I): I have a dog. We have a dog.
  • speaking in the second person (you): You have a cat.
  • speaking in the third person plural (they): They have a snake, eek!

Screen 5: Tip #2: Has is the conjugation of to have that’s used when:

  • speaking in the third person singular (he, she, and it): He has a parrot; it has green feathers.

Screen 6: Tip #3: Have or has can be used with the past participle form of another verb to create the present perfect tense.

Screen 7: So what is the present perfect tense?

Screen 8: The present perfect tense is used to show that the action of the verb was completed previously (not in the present).

Screen 9: The same rules apply as before.

  • She has received her gift.
  • I have received mine also.

Screen 10: [aha moment signoff from other scripts]

niche.name: How To Pronounce The Word "Niche"
niche.description: The word "niche" is borrowed directly from the French. But what is the correct way to say it in English?
niche.transcript:
Screen #1: Have you ever had someone tell you to “find your niche”? [say nich]
Screen #2: A niche is (definition screen format):
[noun] a place or position suitable or appropriate for a person or thing.
[adjective] pertaining to or intended for a market niche; having specific appeal.
Screen #3: But should it actually be pronounced as [nich]? If so, why do so many people say [neesh]?
Screen #4: Niche is borrowed directly from the French. It actually comes from the word nicher meaning “to make a nest.”
Screen #5: Both pronunciations: [nich] and [neesh] are common in American and British English.
Screen #6: The pronunciation of [neesh] preserves the pronunciation of the word in French. While the pronunciation of [ nich ] is more Anglicized—that is, more in line with native English sounds.
Screen #7: Dictionaries generally give [nich] as the typical pronunciation, but the alternative [neesh] may be gaining ground.
Screen #8: Some people may even use both, depending on context.
Screen #9: So what is the correct way to pronounce niche?
Screen #10: There isn’t one! Pick your favorite or play around with pronunciation.
Screen #11: Sometimes we can have fun with the English language!

egypt.name: The Gory Meaning Behind The Word "Sarcophagus"
egypt.description: "Sarcophagus" may be one of those words you learned in a museum or history class and never thought about again. But the origin of the word "sarcophagus" is so fittingly odd and gross, we had to share it.
egypt.transcript:
Screen #1: Sarcophagus may be one of those words you learned in a museum or history class and never thought about again.

Screen #2: But the origin of the word sarcophagus is so fittingly odd and gross, we had to share it.

Screen #3: First, a sarcophagus is (definition screen format):

a stone coffin, especially one bearing sculpture, inscriptions, etc., often displayed as a monument.

Screen #4: Remember King Tut? Yup, he was buried in a sarcophagus.

Screen #5: Sarcophagus is pronounced like this: (voice-over saying word).

Screen #6: OK, enough of the basics—let’s explore where this historical word came from.

Screen #7: The word sarcophagus comes from a Greek word meaning “flesh-consuming.”

Screen #8: The Greeks believed there was a kind of stone thought to consume the flesh of corpses, and so it was used for coffins.

Screen #9: So sarcophagus not only describes the coffin but also the stone used for the coffins.

Screen #10: So, for the ancients, not only did the coffins provide a resting place for the dead, they also were thought to eat up the corpses with their flesh-consuming stone.

Screen #11: Talk about efficiency.

2023-07-01.description: ✅ Stifle means to end something by force, crush something, or quell it (to stifle debate on an issue). ✅ Squelch means crush, suppress, or silence something (squelch the publication of a controversial book). ✅ Stifle and squelch both mean to end something, and both can suggest ending something with force, aggression, or violence (stifle someone’s dreams). ✅ Squelch suggests greater force and violence as well as a more complete suppression (squelch a revolt).
